2015-01-03 09:40:20+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3745934/read-random-line-from-a-file-c-sharp> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=1&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:40:20+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3745934/read-random-line-from-a-file-c-sharp>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u"<pre><code>string[] lines = File.ReadAllLines(...); //i hope that the file is not too big\nRandom rand = new Random();\nreturn lines[rand.Next(lines.Length)];\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Another (and maybe better) option is to have the first line of the file contain the number of records in it and then you don't have to read all the file.</p>",
	              'comments': [u'+1: I hate it when people answer the questions I can actually answer before I can, especially when they use exactly the same code I would :)',
	                           u'Thanks, i just figured it out. But your way seems better.',
	                           u"That works as long as the file is relatively small.  I've provided an alternative that allow you to not have to keep the entire file in memory.",
	                           u'@tvanfosson: The second version will work also if file is very large (by adding # of records in first line) and the advantage of it over you solution (which i really like from math perspective) is that on average only half of the file will be read (and only one line in memory each time).',
	                           u'+1 for the "first line of the file contain the number of records" part.'],
	              'extid': 3745951,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3745934/read-random-line-from-a-file-c-sharp/3745951#3745951',
	              'user_id': 349990,
	              'vote': 13},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Read each line keeping a count, N, of the lines you have seen so far.  Select each line with probability 1/N, i.e., the first line will always be chosen, the second line will be chosen 1/2 times to replace the first, the third 1/3 times, ...  This way each line has a 1/N probability of being the selected line, you only have to read the file once, and you don\'t need to store all of the file in memory at any given time.</p>\n\n<p>Here\'s an implementation that can be adapted for your needs.</p>\n\n<pre><code>public string RandomLine( StreamReader reader )\n{\n    string chosen = null;\n    int numberSeen = 0;\n    var rng = new Random();\n    while ((string line = reader.ReadLine()) != null)\n    {\n        if (rng.NextInt(++numberSeen) == 0)\n        {\n            chosen = line;\n        }\n    }\n    return chosen;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Based on a <a href="http://www.daniweb.com/code/snippet216918.html">C implementation</a> for selecting a node from an arbitrarily long linked list.</p>',
	              'comments': [u"the math looks wrong to me. Isn't the probability of selecting the 1st line 1/n! by the time you get to the end?",
	                           u'The math here is fine and nice :)',
	                           u"@Itay: only if you believe the comments: I don't. But, I've been fooled by probability before.",
	                           u'@Itay: Ahh, I think I am getting a clue now. In step n you ',
	                           u' the previous selection with probability (n-1)/n. And by induction, the probability of the previous selection was 1/(n-1), so multiplying through gives 1/n. Clever.',
	                           u'@GregS - use inductive reasoning.  Assume that at the Nth step, each element has 1/n probability of being chosen.  For N = 1, this is clear.  For N = 2, the first was chosen at step 1 and has a 1/2 probability of being replaced at step 2 so our assumption holds. Now at step, n+1 each of the preceding elements, by our hypothesis, had 1/n chance of being selected randomly.  With probability 1/n+1 we choose to replace it.  Clearly the current element has a 1/n+1 probability of being selected, but that element was selected randomly so all preceding elements have a 1/n probability of being selected'],
	              'extid': 3745973,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3745934/read-random-line-from-a-file-c-sharp/3745973#3745973',

2015-01-03 09:40:21+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752993/mysql-select-statement-with-multiple-where-conditions>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>You can union the two sets of data together, viz all games where Fabiano is User 1, with all games that he is in the role of User 2:</p>\n\n<pre><code>SELECT x.Opponent\nFROM\n(\n    SELECT u.Name AS Opponent\n    FROM games g\n    INNER JOIN users u\n    ON g.userId2 = u.UserId\n    WHERE g.UserId1 = 2 -- Fabiano\n\n    UNION\n\n    SELECT u.Name\n    FROM games g\n    INNER JOIN users u\n    ON g.userId1 = u.UserId\n    WHERE g.UserId2 = 2 -- Fabiano\n) AS x;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>At this point as assume that Fabiano can\'t simultaneously both be <code>User1</code> and <code>User2</code>, as we would need to consider <a href="http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/union.html" rel="nofollow">UNION ALL vs UNION DISTINCT</a> :)</p>\n\n<p>This could also be tidied up a bit into:</p>\n\n<pre><code>SELECT x.Opponent\nFROM\n(\n    SELECT u.Name AS Opponent, g.UserId1 AS PlayerId\n    FROM games g\n    INNER JOIN users u\n    ON g.userId2 = u.UserId\n\n    UNION\n\n    SELECT u.Name, g.UserId2 AS PlayerId\n    FROM games g\n    INNER JOIN users u\n    ON g.userId1 = u.UserId\n) AS x\nWHERE x.PlayerId = 2; -- Fabiano\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [u"Thanks. Based on your answer, I wrote a simple, single query which is relatively easy for a beginner like me to read - I'm adding it to my question.",
	                           u'Glad to be of help. Apologies, I see I left off '],

	              'comments': [],

	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>You can do this without a UNION clause</p>\n\n<pre><code>SELECT g.gameid,\nCASE WHEN u1.userid = 2 -- fabino* \n            THEN u2.username\n            else u1.username END AS Opponent\nFROM games g\nLEFT JOIN users u1\nON g.userId1 = u1.UserId\nLEFT JOIN users u2\non g.userid2 = u2.userid\nWHERE (g.UserId1 = 2 OR g.userid2 = 2) -- fabino\n</code></pre>',

	 'body': u"<p>I have the following two tables in mysql:</p>\n\n<p>users:</p>\n\n<pre><code>+--------+-----------+\n| userId | userName  |\n+--------+-----------+\n| 1      | magnus    |\n| 2      | fabiano   |\n| 3      | alexander |\n| 4      | veselin   |\n+--------+-----------+\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>games:</p>\n\n<pre><code>+--------+---------+---------+\n| gameId | userId1 | userId2 |\n+--------+---------+---------+\n| 1      | 1       | 2       |\n| 2      | 1       | 3       |\n| 3      | 2       | 3       |\n| 4      | 2       | 4       |\n+--------+---------+---------+\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>How can I construct a single query such that I get this below output of say, fabiano's opponents:</p>\n\n<p>output:</p>\n\n<pre><code>+--------+-----------+\n| gameId | userName  |\n+--------+-----------+\n| 1      | magnus    |\n| 3      | alexander |\n| 4      | veselin   |\n+--------+-----------+\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Edit1: </p>\n\n<p>This was what I was trying and I wasn't able to get them into a single query:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>select fabiano's opponents [select * from games where 2 in (userId1, userId2);]</li>\n<li>read each of the rows, and check which of them is fabiano(2), and select the other userId</li>\n<li>from the userIds of these opponents, get their name from users table</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Edit2:\nInspired by the answers below, I wrote this (they work too):</p>\n\n<pre><code>// NO JOIN\nselect x.gameId, users.userName from\n(\nselect gameId, userId2 as id from games where userId1=2\nUNION\nselect gameId, userId1 as id from games where userId2=2 \n) as x, users \nwhere users.userId = id;\n\n// NO JOIN, NO UNION        \nselect x.gameId, users.userName from (\nSELECT g.gameId,\n    CASE WHEN userId1 = 2\n            THEN userId2     \n         WHEN userId2 =2\n            THEN userId1\n         END AS id\nFROM games g) as x, users\nwhere users.userId = id;\n</code></pre>",

2015-01-03 09:40:22+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753354/how-to-select-varchar-column-based-on-int-min-function-in-sql> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=1&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:40:22+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Filtered duplicate request: <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/sql/info> - no more duplicates will be shown (see DUPEFILTER_DEBUG to show all duplicates)
2015-01-03 09:40:22+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753354/how-to-select-varchar-column-based-on-int-min-function-in-sql>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>you can get your desired result by joining your existing subquery and the original table itself. This solution works in all rdbms.</p>\n\n<pre><code>SELECT  a.*\nFROM    Reorganised a\n        INNER JOIN\n        (\n            select TID,min(twu)as TWU \n            from REORGANISED \n            group by tid\n        ) b ON  a.TID = b.TID\n                AND a.TWU = b.TWU\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753383,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753354/how-to-select-varchar-column-based-on-int-min-function-in-sql/27753383#27753383',
	              'user_id': 491243,
	              'vote': 0},

2015-01-03 09:40:25+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27729930/is-declaration-of-variables-expensive> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=1&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:40:25+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27729930/is-declaration-of-variables-expensive>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u"<p>In C99 and later (or with the common conforming extension to C89), you are free to mix statements and declarations.</p>\n\n<p>Just as in earlier versions (only more so as compilers got smarter and more aggressive), the compiler decides how to allocate registers and stack, or do any number of other optimizations conforming to the as-if-rule.<br>\nThat means performance-wise, there's no expectation of any difference.</p>\n\n<p><em>Anyway,</em> that was not the reason such was allowed:</p>\n\n<p>It was for restricting scope, and thus <strong>reducing the context a human must keep in mind</strong> when interpreting and verifying your code.</p>",
	              'comments': [u'thanks for your reply, and to all. If i understand correctly your statement, it does not cost any performance issue, but brings out the clarity. Is that right ?',
	                           u'Simply put, yes.',
	                           u'If you want to see the optimizer in action, write a function with declarations which initialize like ',
	                           u', compile your code with optimizer and debugging flags (',
	                           u' for example) and step through the function in the debugger.  The step point will bounce around and delay initializing the variable until it needs it.'],
	              'extid': 27729967,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27729930/is-declaration-of-variables-expensive/27729967#27729967',
	              'user_id': 3204551,
	              'vote': 53},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>In C, I believe all variable declarations are applied as if they were at the top of the function declaration; if you declare them in a block, I think it\'s just a scoping thing (I don\'t think it\'s the same in C++).  The compiler will perform all optimizations on the variables, and some may even effectively disappear in the machine code in higher optimizations.  The compiler will then decide how much space is needed by the variables, and then later, during execution, create a space known as the stack where the variables live.</p>\n\n<p>When a function is called, all of the variables that are used by your function are put on the stack, along with information about the function that is called (i.e. the return address, parameters, etc.).  It doesn\'t matter <em>where</em> the variable was declared, just that it was declared - and it will be allocated onto the stack, regardless.</p>\n\n<p>Declaring variables isn\'t "expensive," per se; if it\'s easy enough to be not used as a variable, the compiler will probably remove it as a variable.</p>\n\n<p>Check this out:</p>\n\n<p><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/uzTZc.png" alt="Da stack"></p>\n\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_stack#Functions_of_the_call_stack">Wikipedia on call stacks</a>, <a href="http://gribblelab.org/CBootcamp/7_Memory_Stack_vs_Heap.html#sec-2">Some other place on the stack</a></p>\n\n<p>Of course, all of this is implementation-dependent and system-dependent.</p>',
	              'comments': [u"How would that work with VLAs? Or completely eliminating the variable / it's stack space? Or aliasing slots?",
	                           u'@Deduplicator Apparently, it increases the ',
	                           u' (according to ',
	                           u' presentation).  It says ',
	                           u', but the two ',
	                           u'.  ',
	                           u' allocates space from the stack.  Reminder: those are implementation defined.',
	                           u'Just thought to prod you with some constructs your explanation would preclude just now, so you can refine it.',
	                           u"@Deduplicator I'm sorry?  I don't think I understand what you're trying to say.",
	                           u'@Paul It\'s not unusual to draw the stack "reversed" if you so wish (the top of the stack being at the top of the paper has obvious advantages if you draw by hand). And in any case you might want to tell HP that they\'ve been doing it wrong all those years (PA-RISC traditionally has the stack growing upwards ;) Heck if you don\'t have ',
	                           u' and ',
	                           u" operations (do any RISC ISAs actually?) it's just a convention - MULTICS had upward growing stacks."],
	              'extid': 27730109,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27729930/is-declaration-of-variables-expensive/27730109#27730109',
	              'user_id': 3488231,
	              'vote': 15},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p><strong>Do whatever makes sense, but current coding style recommends putting variable declarations as close to their usage as possible</strong></p>\n\n<p>In reality, variable declarations are free on virtually every compiler after the first one.  This is because virtually all processors manage their stack with a stack pointer (and possibly a frame pointer).  For example, consider two functions:</p>\n\n<pre><code>int foo() {\n    int x;\n    return 5; // aren\'t we a silly little function now\n}\n\nint bar() {\n    int x;\n    int y;\n    return 5; // still wasting our time...\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>If I were to compile these on a modern compiler (and tell it not to be smart and optimize out my unused local variables), I\'d see this (x64 assembly example.. others are similar):</p>\n\n<pre><code>foo:\npush ebp\nmov  ebp, esp\nsub  esp, 8    ; 1. this is the first line which is different between the two\nmov  eax, 5    ; this is how we return the value\nadd  esp, 8    ; 2. this is the second line which is different between the two\nret\n\nbar:\npush ebp\nmov  ebp, esp\nsub  esp, 16    ; 1. this is the first line which is different between the two\nmov  eax, 5     ; this is how we return the value\nadd  esp, 16    ; 2. this is the second line which is different between the two\nret\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><strong>Note: both functions have the same number of opcodes!</strong></p>\n\n<p>This is because virtually all compilers will allocate all of the space they need up front (barring fancy things like <code>alloca</code> which are handled separately).  In fact, on x64, it is <em>mandatory</em> that they do so in this efficient manner.</p>\n\n<p>(Edit: As Forss pointed out, the compiler may optimize some of the local variables into registers.  More technically, I should be arguing that the first varaible to "spill over" into the stack costs 2 opcodes, and the rest are free)</p>\n\n<p>For the same reasons, compilers will collect all of the local variable declarations, and allocate space for them right up front.  <strong>C89 requires all declarations to be up-front because it was designed to be a 1 pass compiler.</strong> For the C89 compiler to know how much space to allocate, it needed to know all of the variables before emitting the rest of the code.  In modern languages, like C99 and C++, compilers are expected to be much smarter than they were back in 1972, so this restriction is relaxed for developer convenience.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Modern coding practices suggest putting the variables close to their usage</strong></p>\n\n<p>This has nothing to do with compilers (which obviously could not care one way or another).  It has been found that most human programmers read code better if the variables are put close to where they are used.  This is just a style guide, so feel free to disagree with it, but there is a remarkable consensus amongst developers that this is the "right way."</p>\n\n<p><strong>Now for a few corner cases:</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>If you are using C++ with constructors, the compiler will <em>allocate</em> the space up front (since it\'s faster to do it that way, and doesn\'t hurt).  However, the variable will not be <em>constructed</em> in that space until the correct location in the flow of the code.  In some cases, this means putting the variables close to their use can even be <em>faster</em> than putting them up front... flow control might direct us around the variable declaration, in which case the constructor doesn\'t even need to be called.</li>\n<li><code>alloca</code> is handled on a layer above this.  For those who are curious, <code>alloca</code> implementations tend to have the effect of moving the stack pointer down some arbitrary amount.  Functions using <code>alloca</code> are required to keep track of this space in one way or another, and make sure the stack pointer gets re-adjusted upwards before leaving.</li>\n<li>There may be a case where you usually need 16-bytes of stack space, but on one condition you need to allocate a local array of 50kB.  No matter where you put your variables in the code, virtually all compilers will allocate 50kB+16B of stack space every time the function gets called.  This rarely matters, but in obsessively recursive code this could overflow the stack.  You either have to move the code working with the 50kB array into its own function, or use <code>alloca</code>.</li>\n<li>Some platforms (ex: Windows) need a special function call in the prologue if you allocate more than a page worth of stack space.  This should not change analysis very much at all (in implementation, it is a very fast leaf function that just pokes 1 word per page).</li>\n</ul>',
	              'comments': [u'Please be explicit and say C89, ISO C90, K&R C, etc. " requires all declarations to be up-front because it was designed to be a 1 pass compiler."  You obviously know the difference because you call out C99 as an exception, but C!=C89.  Arguably, right now, C=C11.',
	                           u'Note also that one can use {} to mix declarations and code in C89, provided the scoping works.',
	                           u"@Jeff: Ahh, I did not know that you could use braces in such a way.  Guess that's what I get for being a C++ person trying to answer using C terminology!",
	                           u"C++ is a superset of C89, so you should be okay most of the time.  C99 will get you though, because it's not a strict subset of C++03.",
	                           u'"In reality, variable declarations are free on virtually every compiler after the first one." Is this true if you consider using more variables than the compiler can optimize into registers?'],
	              'extid': 27734685,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27729930/is-declaration-of-variables-expensive/27734685#27734685',
	              'user_id': 2728148,
	              'vote': 13},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>It ultimately depends on the compiler but usually all locals are allocated at the beginning of the function.</p>\n\n<p>However, the cost of allocating local variables is very small as they are put on the stack (or are put in a register after optimization).</p>',
	              'comments': [u'"all locals are allocated at the beginning of the function". do you mean if i use lazy approach also, does it get allocated ?',
	                           u"Probably yes. It's up to the compiler how to do it but the easiest way is to allocate all at the beginning and deallocate all att the end.",
	                           u'However the allocation is just a single add instruction so it is incredably cheep. Not at all like using malloc.',
	                           u'But, looking at all other engineers reply, it seems to be no performance or any other expenses in any manner except readability? :)',
	                           u"That's right, it's for improved readability."],
	              'extid': 27729988,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27729930/is-declaration-of-variables-expensive/27729988#27729988',
	              'user_id': 2379112,
	              'vote': 8},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Yes, it can cost clarity.  If there is a case where the function must do nothing at all on some condition, (as when finding the global false, in your case), then placing the check at the top, where you show it above, is surely easier to understand - something that is essential while debugging and/or documenting.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27729984,

	              'vote': 7},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>The best practice is to adapt a <strong>lazy</strong> approach, i.e., declare them only when you really need them ;) (and not before). It results in the following benefits:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>Code is more readable if those variables are declared as near to the place of usage as possible.</li>\n</ol>',
	              'comments': [u"This is incorrect (at least for me). And as others have pointed out, compilers are smart enough to optimize allocations.",

	              'body': u"<p>Keep the declaration as close to where it's used as possible. Ideally inside nested blocks. So in this case it would make no sense to declare the variables above the <code>if</code> statement.</p>",
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27729960,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27729930/is-declaration-of-variables-expensive/27729960#27729960',
	              'user_id': 430766,
	              'vote': 4},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>I prefer keeping the "early out" condition at the top of the function, in addition to documenting why we are doing it. If we put it after a bunch of variable declarations, someone not familiar with the code could easily miss it, unless they know they have to look for it. </p>\n\n<p>Documenting the "early out" condition alone is not always sufficient, it is better to make it clear in the code as well. Putting the early out condition at the top also makes it easier to keep the document in sync with the code, for instance, if we later decide to remove the early out condition, or to add more such conditions. </p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27729997,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27729930/is-declaration-of-variables-expensive/27729997#27729997',
	              'user_id': 252576,
	              'vote': 4},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u"<p>If it actually mattered the only way to avoid allocating the variables is likely to be:</p>\n\n<pre><code>int function_unchecked();\n\nint function ()\n{\n  if (!someGlobalValue) return false;\n  return function_unchecked();\n}\n\nint function_unchecked() {\n  internalStructure  *str1;\n  internalStructure *str2;\n  char *dataPointer;\n  float xyz;\n\n  /* do something here with the above local variables */    \n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>But in practice I think you'll find no performance benefit. If anything a minuscule overhead.</p>\n\n<p>Of course if you were coding C++ and some of those local variables had non-trivial constructors you would probably need to place them after the check. But even then I don't think it would help to split the function.</p>",
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27730089,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27729930/is-declaration-of-variables-expensive/27730089#27730089',
	              'user_id': 4213662,
	              'vote': 3},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>If you have this</p>\n\n<pre><code>int function ()\n{\n   {\n       sometype foo;\n       bool somecondition;\n       /* do something with foo and compute somecondition */\n       if (!somecondition) return false;\n   }\n   internalStructure  *str1;\n   internalStructure *str2;\n   char *dataPointer;\n   float xyz;\n\n   /* do something here with the above local variables */    \n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>then the stack space reserved for <code>foo</code> and <code>somecondition</code> can be obviously reused for <code>str1</code>etc., so by declaring after the <code>if</code>, you may save stack space. Depending on the optimization capabilities of the compiler, the saving of stack space <em>may</em> also take place if you flatten the fucntion by removing the inner pair of braces or if you  do declare <code>str1</code> etc. before the <code>if</code>; however, this requires the compiler/optimizer to <em>notice</em> that the scopes do not "really" overlap. By positining the declarations after the <code>if</code> you facilitate this behaviour even without optimization - not to mention the improved code readability.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27731908,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27729930/is-declaration-of-variables-expensive/27731908#27731908',
	              'user_id': 1640715,
	              'vote': 2}],
	 'body': u'<p>While coding in C, I came across the below situation.</p>\n\n<pre><code>int function ()\n{\n  if (!somecondition) return false;\n\n  internalStructure  *str1;\n  internalStructure *str2;\n  char *dataPointer;\n  float xyz;\n\n  /* do something here with the above local variables */    \n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Considering the <code>if</code> statement in the above code can return from the function, I can declare the variables in two places. </p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>Before the <code>if</code> statement.</li>\n<li>After the <code>if</code> statement. </li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>As a programmer, I would think to keep the variable declaration after <code>if</code> Statement. </p>\n\n<p><strong>Does the declaration place cost something? Or is there some other reason to prefer one way over the other?</strong></p>',

2015-01-03 09:40:25+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/file/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>A block of arbitrary information, or resource for storing information, accessible by the string-based name or path. Files are available to computer programs and are usually based on some kind of persistent storage.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>A <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_file" rel="nofollow">computer file</a> is a block of arbitrary information, or resource for storing information, which is available to a computer program and is usually based on some kind of durable storage. A file is durable in the sense that it remains available for programs to use after the current program has finished. Computer files can be considered as the modern counterpart of paper documents which traditionally are kept in offices\' and libraries\' files, and this is the source of the term.</p>\n\n<p>On <a href="/questions/tagged/unix" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'unix\'" rel="tag">unix</a> based systems, many types of system information are also represented as files, in filesystems such as sysfs and devfs, even though they don\'t represent information on a durable storage medium.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>References</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_file#File_systems_and_file_managers" rel="nofollow">File definition on wikipedia</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>Related</h2>\n\n<p><a href="/questions/tagged/directory" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'directory\'" rel="tag">directory</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/folder" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'folder\'" rel="tag">folder</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/stream" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'stream\'" rel="tag">stream</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/filesystem" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'filesystem\'" rel="tag">filesystem</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/block" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'block\'" rel="tag">block</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/file-io" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'file-io\'" rel="tag">file-io</a></p>',
	 'name': 'file',
	 'qcount': 34860,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/file/info'}

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>The .NET framework is a software framework designed mainly for the Microsoft Windows operating system. It includes an implementation of the Base Class Library, Common Language Runtime (commonly referred to as CLR) and Dynamic Language Runtime. It supports many programming languages, including C#, VB.NET, F# and C++/CLI.\r\n</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>The <a href="http://www.microsoft.com/net/" rel="nofollow">.NET Framework</a> is not specific to any one programming language. The <a href="/questions/tagged/c%23" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c#\'" rel="tag">c#</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/vb.net" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'vb.net\'" rel="tag">vb.net</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/c%2b%2b-cli" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c++-cli\'" rel="tag">c++-cli</a>, and <a href="/questions/tagged/f%23" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'f#\'" rel="tag">f#</a> programming languages from Microsoft, as well as many other languages from other vendors, all use the <em>same</em> <a href="/questions/tagged/.net" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'.net\'" rel="tag">.net</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/framework" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'framework\'" rel="tag">framework</a>.</p>\n\n<p>The .NET Framework includes a large <a href="/questions/tagged/library" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'library\'" rel="tag">library</a> of <a href="/questions/tagged/functions" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'functions\'" rel="tag">functions</a> as part of the Base Class Library (BCL), including those related to user interface design, data access, database connectivity, <a href="/questions/tagged/cryptography" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cryptography\'" rel="tag">cryptography</a>, development of web applications, mathematical algorithms, and network communications. This extensive library simplifies development and makes it easy to rapidly develop new applications.</p>\n\n<p>As such, <a href="/questions/tagged/questions" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'questions\'" rel="tag">questions</a> like "How do I do file I/O in C#?" should really be "How do I do file I/O with .NET?". Because such a question concerns the file I/O libraries provided by the .NET Framework, it should be tagged with both the <a href="/questions/tagged/.net" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'.net\'" rel="tag">.net</a> tag, <em>and</em> with the <a href="/questions/tagged/c%23" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c#\'" rel="tag">c#</a> tag, to indicate that you\'d like the answer to be written in the C# <a href="/questions/tagged/programming-language" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'programming-language\'" rel="tag">programming-language</a>.</p>\n\n<p>See also: <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/mono/info">Mono</a> or <a href="/questions/tagged/mono" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged 2015-01-03 09:40:26+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/select/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Select is a common keyword used to query data. \'select()\' is also a programming function for triggering code based on file handle or other system activity. Not to be confused with the HTML `select` tag.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<h2>In query languages (SQL, \u2026)</h2>\n\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Select_%28SQL%29" rel="nofollow">SELECT</a> is a statement in query languages, like SQL or SPARQL. It returns a result set of records from one or more tables. </p>\n\n<p><code>SELECT</code> queries require two essential parts. The <em>first part</em> is the <strong>WHAT</strong>, which determines what we want SQL to go and fetch. The <em>second part</em> of any SELECT command is the <strong>FROM WHERE</strong>. It identifies where to fetch the data from, which may be from a SQL table, a SQL view, or some other SQL data object.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Reference</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms189499.aspx" rel="nofollow">SQL Server</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://docs.oracle.com/cd/B19306_01/server.102/b14200/statements_10002.htm" rel="nofollow">Oracle</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/select.html" rel="nofollow">MySQL</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.sqlite.org/lang_select.html" rel="nofollow">SQLite</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.3/static/sql-select.html" rel="nofollow">PostgreSQL</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>In HTML</h2>\n\n<p><code>&lt;select&gt;</code> is also an HTML user interface element for choosing one or more option(s) from a finite collection of elements. <strong>Do not use this tag for this purpose, use <a href="/questions/tagged/html-select" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'html-select\'" rel="tag">html-select</a> instead.</strong></p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>In C and C++</h2>\n\n<p><code>select()</code> is an important system call used by C and C++ programs and libraries that avoids busy waiting for network activity and other I/O to complete.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>In Perl</h2>\n\n<p><a href="http://perldoc.perl.org/functions/select.html" rel="nofollow">In Perl 5</a>, <code>select()</code> has two different uses. When called with four parameters, it calls the same syscall as C and C++. In this form it has limited portability. Otherwise it is called with one or no parameters and sets or gets current default filehandle for output. The filehandle is used e.g. by <code>print</code> if no other specified. Special variables like <code>$|</code> relate to it, too. This second form is perfectly portable.</p>\n\n<p><a href="http://perlcabal.org/syn/S32/IO.html#select%28both%29" rel="nofollow">In Perl 6</a> it has been completely dropped.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>In Go</h2>\n\n<p>The <a href="http://golang.org/ref/spec#Select_statements" rel="nofollow">select statement</a> lets a goroutine wait on multiple channel operations. A select blocks until one of its cases can run, then it executes that case.</p>',
	 'name': 'select',
	 'qcount': 18725,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/select/info'}

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>MySQL is an open-source, relational database management system. If your issue relates to MySQLi, use the MySQLi tag instead.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://www.mysql.com" rel="nofollow">MySQL</a> is a <em>relational database management system</em> (<a href="/questions/tagged/rdbms" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'rdbms\'" rel="tag">rdbms</a>) that runs as a server providing multi-user access to a number of databases. Its source code is available under the GNU (General Public License).</p>\n\n<p>MySQL offers standard database driver connectivity for using MySQL with applications and tools that are compatible with industry standards <a href="/questions/tagged/odbc" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'odbc\'" rel="tag">odbc</a> and <a href="/questions/tagged/jdbc" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jdbc\'" rel="tag">jdbc</a>.</p>\n\n<h2>Deprecation of <code>mysql_</code> functions</h2>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>PHP functions that start with <code>mysql_</code> have been deprecated as of PHP 5.5.0. If you are in a position to do so, please consider updating your code to use the <a href="http://www.php.net/manual/en/book.mysqli.php" rel="nofollow"><code>mysqli_</code></a> or <a href="http://www.php.net/manual/en/ref.pdo-mysql.php" rel="nofollow">PDO</a> extensions instead.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>For a more detailed explanation, see <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12859942/why-shouldnt-i-use-mysql-functions-in-php">Why shouldn\'t I use mysql_* functions in PHP?</a> or <a href="/questions/tagged/mysqli" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'mysqli\'" rel="tag">mysqli</a>.</p>\n\n<h2>Pronunciation</h2>\n\n<p>Officially it is /ma\u026a\u02cc\u025bskju\u02d0\u02c8\u025bl/ ("My S-Q-L"), but is often pronounced /ma\u026a\u02c8si\u02d0kw\u0259l/ ("My Sequel").</p>\n\n<h2>Example</h2>\n\n<pre class="lang-sql prettyprint-override"><code>SELECT * FROM users ORDER BY 	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>FASTA is a software package for sequence alignment of proteins and nucleic acids. FASTA is also the name of the file format used by these programs to represent sequences of peptides or nucleotides. The format is a de facto standard in bioinformatics.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>The FASTA format (read as "fast A format") is a text-based format used by the FASTA software for representing nucleic acids and proteins. It represents each nucleotide and amino-acid as a letter. The FASTA format also supports naming of sequences.</p>\n\n<p>The format achieved great popularity, becoming the de facto standard for representing biological sequences.</p>\n\n<p>A bioinformatical record in FASTA format consists of the header (comment) string followed by one or more strings describing the sequence (one letter per nucleotide or amino acid). Header strings begin with <code>&gt;</code>. The sequence that follows is wrapped at a fixed width (often 60, but generally no more than 80).</p>\n\n<pre><code>&gt; Sample nucleotide sequence\nAGCACTGAGTAACGTATAAGCAGTCCCCGGACGCGTA\n&gt; Nucleotide sequence #2\nGCCACGGGAGTTGAAGAACATCGAGAATGCCACTAGTTTTCACCCTTCATAGATATCCTA\nGCGCCGTACATGTATACGAGATCTTTGTCACGCAGTATGGAGGATTGTGGCCAGCAATAC\nGTCGTGTCCCGCAATGCTTCATTAGATCCCCGTATATCCATCCTGAGTCATTGTCTGTTG\nTCCGTTTTGAAGGAGTCTAGCAGCTTGATA\n</code></pre>',
	 'name': 'fasta',
	 'qcount': 212,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/fasta/info'}
2015-01-03 09:40:27+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/sql/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752993/mysql-select-statement-with-multiple-where-conditions)
2015-01-03 09:40:27+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/sql/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Structured Query Language (SQL) is a language for querying databases. Questions should include code examples and table structure, and include a tag for the DBMS implementation (e.g. MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, MS SQL Server) being used. If your question relates to a specific DBMS (uses specific extensions/features), use that DBMS\'s tag instead. Answers to questions tagged with SQL should use ANSI SQL as much as possible.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>SQL is an acronym that stands for <em>Structured Query Language</em>.</p>\n\n<p>One subset of the SQL standard consists of the <strong>DDL</strong> (data definition language), which is used to create tables and constraints. These include:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><code>CREATE</code></li>\n<li><code>DROP</code></li>\n<li><code>ALTER</code></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Another subset is the <strong>DML</strong> (data manipulation language):</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><code>SELECT</code></li>\n<li><code>INSERT</code></li>\n<li><code>UPDATE</code></li>\n<li><code>DELETE</code></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>The final "standard" subset of commands is the <strong>DCL</strong> (data control language):</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><code>GRANT</code></li>\n<li><code>REVOKE</code></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Many database implementations require the use of SQL, and over the years, vendors have implemented dialects of SQL to provide more functionality as well as simplify it. Because of these deviations from the standard, SQL is fractured - syntax that works on one vendor does not necessarily work on another. </p>\n\n<p><strong>ISO/IEC</strong> (formerly ANSI) standards have been beneficial in resolving such situations, but adoption is selective. Queries conforming to these standards should be portable to other databases, but it does not mean that performance will be the same nor that performance will be on par with native functionality.</p>\n\n<p>Most DBMS have additional languages for writing stored procedures. In Oracle this is PL/SQL, in PostgreSQL it\'s PL/pgSQL. Outside of stored procedures or functions, these DBMS use SQL. Thus the tags <a href="/questions/tagged/plsql" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'plsql\'" rel="tag">plsql</a> and <a href="/questions/tagged/plpgsql" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'plpgsql\'" rel="tag">plpgsql</a> should only be used for problems directly related to writing stored procedures. Microsoft SQL Server uses the term T-SQL (<a href="/questions/tagged/tsql" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'tsql\'" rel="tag">tsql</a>) for both, "plain" SQL (queries, DML, ..) and the language used for stored procedures.</p>\n\n<h3>Tagging Recommendation</h3>\n\n<p>This tag should be used for general SQL programming language questions, in addition to tags for specific products (for example, questions about Microsoft SQL Server should use the <a href="/questions/tagged/sql-server" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'sql-server\'" rel="tag">sql-server</a> tag, or question regarding MySQL should use the <a href="/questions/tagged/mysql" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'mysql\'" rel="tag">mysql</a> tag) that implement some flavor of this language. SQL is the umbrella under which these products exist; tagging them by product (including version, e.g <a href="/questions/tagged/oracle11g" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'oracle11g\'" rel="tag">oracle11g</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/sql-server-2008" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'sql-server-2008\'" rel="tag">sql-server-2008</a>) is the easiest way to know what functionality is available for the task at hand.</p>\n\n<p>Please read this <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQL-92" rel="nofollow">summary</a> about the SQL standard (1992 one in this case, broadly implemented) and if you can, refer to the <a href="http://www.contrib.andrew.cmu.edu/~shadow/sql/sql1992.txt" rel="nofollow">book itself</a>.</p>\n\n<h3>Free SQL Programming Books</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.cs.arizona.edu/people/rts/publications.html" rel="nofollow">Developing Time-Oriented Database Applications in SQL</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://use-the-index-luke.com/" rel="nofollow">Use The Index, Luke!: A Guide To SQL Database Performance</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://sql.learncodethehardway.org/" rel="nofollow">Learn SQL The Hard Way</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3schools.com/sql/default.asp" rel="nofollow">SQL Tutorial For Starters</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.computer-books.us/sql.php" rel="nofollow">SQL - Free books</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0735663866" rel="nofollow">Microsoft SQL Server 2012 Step by Step</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Free SQL/Database Online Courses</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://class.coursera.org/db/auth/auth_redirector?type=login&amp;subtype=normal" rel="nofollow">Coursera-Introduction to Databases</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://www.google.com.pk/search?q=stanford+database+course&amp;oq=stanford+database+course&amp;aqs=chrome..69i57j0l5.8288j0j7&amp;sourceid=chrome&amp;espv=2&amp;es_sm=122&amp;ie=UTF-8" rel="nofollow">Stanford Online-DB: Introduction to Databases</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Useful Resource</h3>\n\n<p>You should always provide complete code examples (e.g. schema, data sample and expected result) in your question or answer, but you can also isolate problematic code and reproduce it in an online environment such as <a href="http://sqlfiddle.com/" rel="nofollow">SQL Fiddle</a>.</p>',
	 'name': 'sql',
	 'qcount': 255922,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/sql/info'}

2015-01-03 09:40:28+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/sql-server/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Microsoft SQL Server is a relational database management system. Use this tag for all SQL Server editions including Compact, Express, Azure, Fast-track and PDW. Do not use this tag for other types of DBMS (MySQL, PostgreSQL, etc.).</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://www.microsoft.com/sqlserver" rel="nofollow">Microsoft\'s SQL Server</a> is a suite of <strong><em>relational database management system</em></strong> (RDBMS) products providing multi-user database access functionality. It originated from the Sybase SQL Server 4.x codebase and <em>Transact-SQL dialect</em> (T-SQL), but it has forked significantly since then.</p>\n\n<p>SQL Server is available in multiple versions, typically identified by release year, and versions are subdivided into <em>editions</em> to distinguish between product functionality. The latest released version is <a href="http://www.microsoft.com/sqlserver/en/us/editions.aspx" rel="nofollow">SQL Server 2014</a>.</p>\n\n<p>The SQL Server product range is split broadly into five categories:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p><strong>SQL Server</strong> is the main suite of enterprise and developer server products. Primary differences are licensing costs, capacities, and components included in the product, with some minor differences supported language features.  Standard components include database language and storage server, developer tools, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extract,_transform,_load" rel="nofollow">ETL</a> tools, schedulers, and replication. Other components include OLAP, reporting, and parallel computation. Components runs as NT Services.</p></li>\n<li><p><strong>SQL Server Express</strong> is free for use and distribution but has reduced engine performance, functionality and capacity than found in its other server siblings. It is focused on small deployments and runs as an NT Service.</p></li>\n<li><p><strong>SQL Server Compact</strong> is an embeddable subset of SQL Server. Like the Express edition it has a reduced language, functionality and capacity, but it is free to distribute. It\'s focused on small installations and desktop applications where its small footprint and no-management-required features are a great advantage.</p></li>\n<li><p><strong>SQL Azure</strong> is a completely managed, hosted, high-availability instance of SQL Server 2005 with some language syntax support for federated queries, operated in <a href="http://www.microsoft.com/windowsazure/" rel="nofollow">Microsoft Azure</a> datacenters.</p></li>\n<li><p><strong>SQL Server Parallel Data Warehouse</strong> is a pre-built DataWarehouse appliance that offers massively parallel processing for SQL Server, allowing support for many hundreds of terabytes.</p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<p><strong>SQL Server Release History</strong></p>\n\n<pre class="lang-none prettyprint-override"><code>Version     Year  Release Name             Codename\n1.0 (OS/2)  1989  SQL Server 1.0 (16 bit)    - \n1.1 (OS/2)  1991  SQL Server 1.1 (16 bit)    -\n4.21(WinNT) 1993  SQL Server 4.21           SQLNT\n6.0         1995  SQL Server 6.0            SQL95\n6.5         1996  SQL Server 6.5            Hydra\n7.0         1998  SQL Server 7.0            Sphinx\n -          1999  SQL Server 7.0 OLAP Tools Palato mania\n8.0         2000  SQL Server 2000           Shiloh\n8.0         2003  SQL Server 2000 x64       Liberty\n9.0         2005  SQL Server 2005           Yukon\n10.0        2008  SQL Server 2008           Katmai\n10.25       2010  SQL Azure DB              CloudDatabase\n10.5        2010  SQL Server 2008 R2        Kilimanjaro (aka KJ)\n11.0        2012  SQL Server 2012           Denali\n12.0        2014  SQL Server 2014           Hekaton\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><strong>References</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms189826.aspx" rel="nofollow">MSDN SQL Server 2005 Transact-SQL Reference</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb510741(v=sql.105)" rel="nofollow">MSDN SQL Server 2008 R2 Transact-SQL Reference</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb510741(v=sql.110)" rel="nofollow">MSDN SQL Server 2012 Transact-SQL Reference</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb510741" rel="nofollow">MSDN SQL Server 2014 Transact-SQL Reference</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_SQL_Server" rel="nofollow">SQL Server Wikipedia Article</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/sql-azure/info">SQL Azure Stack-Overflow Tag</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-in/sqlserver/aa336270.aspx" rel="nofollow">MSDN SQL Server DevCenter</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/sqlserver/bb671430" rel="nofollow">SQL Server Best Practices</a> </li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>Tagging recommendation:</strong></p>\n\n<p>There are several version specific tags. It is recommended to use the <a href="/questions/tagged/sql-server" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'sql-server\'" rel="tag">sql-server</a> tag together with the version specific tag, e.g. <a href="/questions/tagged/sql-server-2005-express" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'sql-server-2005-express\'" rel="tag">sql-server-2005-express</a>.Do not use this tag for other types of DBMS (<a href="/questions/tagged/mysql" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'mysql\'" rel="tag">mysql</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/postgresql" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'postgresql\'" rel="tag">postgresql</a>, etc.).</p>',

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Composer is a tool for dependency management in PHP. It allows you to declare your project dependencies and will install them in for you. See http://getcomposer.org</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<h1>Presentation</h1>\n\n<p><a href="http://getcomposer.org" rel="nofollow">Composer</a> is a tool for dependency management in PHP. It allows you to declare the dependent libraries your project needs and it will install them in your project for you.</p>\n\n<p>Composer is not a package manager. Yes, it deals with "packages" or libraries, but it manages them on a per-project basis, installing them in a directory inside your project. By default it will never install anything globally. Thus, it is a dependency manager.</p>\n\n<h1>Useful links</h1>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><a href="http://getcomposer.org/doc/" rel="nofollow">Current documentation</a>: The main source of documentation for the project.</p></li>\n<li><p><a href="http://packagist.org/" rel="nofollow">Packagist</a>: It is the main Composer repository. It aggregates all sorts of PHP packages that are installable with Composer.</p></li>\n<li><p>The <a href="https://github.com/composer/composer" rel="nofollow">source code is available on GitHub</a> and distributed under MIT license.</p></li>\n<li><p><a href="http://composer.borreli.com/" rel="nofollow"><em>Composer as a service</em></a>: copy/paste your <code>composer.json</code> and get the vendor.zip file of your dependencies. Also, you can check the log of your build. Could be useful for debug.</p></li>\n</ul>',

	 'qcount': 2203,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/composer-php/info'}
