2015-01-03 09:40:36+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11996857/how-to-use-parameters-within-the-filter-in-angularjs> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:40:36+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11996857/how-to-use-parameters-within-the-filter-in-angularjs>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p><strong>UPDATE:</strong> I guess I didn\'t really look at the documentation well enough but you can definitely use the <a href="http://docs.angularjs.org/api/ng.filter%3afilter">filter</a> filter with this syntax (see <a href="http://jsfiddle.net/4PYZa/2/">this fiddle</a>) to filter by a property on the objects:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;tr ng-repeat="user in users | filter:{status:4}"&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p>Here\'s my original answer in case it helps someone:</p>\n\n<p>Using the <a href="http://docs.angularjs.org/api/ng.filter%3afilter">filter</a> filter you won\'t be able to pass in a parameter but there are at least two things you can do.</p>\n\n<p><strong>1) Set the data you want to filter by in a scope variable and reference that in your filter function like <a href="http://jsfiddle.net/4PYZa/1/">this fiddle</a>.</strong></p>\n\n<p>JavaScript:</p>\n\n<pre><code>$scope.status = 1;\n$scope.users = [{name: \'first user\', status: 1},\n                {name: \'second user\', status: 2},\n                {name: \'third user\', status: 3}];\n\n$scope.isStatus = function(user){\n    return (user.status == $scope.status);\n};\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Html:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;li ng-repeat="user in users | filter:isStatus"&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>OR</p>\n\n<p><strong>2) Create a new filter that takes in a parameter like <a href="http://jsfiddle.net/ZMkQY/2/">this fiddle</a>.</strong></p>\n\n<p>JavaScript:</p>\n\n<pre><code>var myApp = angular.module(\'myApp\', []);\nmyApp.filter(\'isStatus\', function() {\n  return function(input, status) {\n    var out = [];\n      for (var i = 0; i &lt; input.length; i++){\n          if(input[i].status == status)\n              out.push(input[i]);\n      }      \n    return out;\n  };\n});\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Html:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;li ng-repeat="user in users | isStatus:3"&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Note this filter assumes there is a <code>status</code> property in the objects in the array which might make it less reusable but this is just an example. You can read <a href="http://docs.angularjs.org/guide/dev_guide.templates.filters.creating_filters">this</a> for more info on creating filters.</p>',
	              'comments': [u"fyi both fiddles don't work",
	                           u'@mcranston18 the 3 fiddles I linked to work for me in the latest version of Chrome. Where is it breaking for you?',
	                           u'For 2), it might be useful to know that ',
	                           u', even from templates.',
	                           u'Thanks for the original answer, the 1) was useful to me'],
	              'extid': 11997076,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11996857/how-to-use-parameters-within-the-filter-in-angularjs/11997076#11997076',
	              'user_id': 1207991,
	              'vote': 89},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>This question is almost identical to <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11753321/passing-arguments-to-angularjs-filters/">Passing arguments to angularjs filters</a>, to which I already gave an answer. But I\'m gonna post one more answer here just so that people see it.</p>\n\n<p>Actually there is another (maybe better solution) where you can use the angular\'s native \'filter\' filter and still pass arguments to your custom filter.</p>\n\n<p>Consider the following code:</p>\n\n<pre><code>    &lt;li ng-repeat="user in users | filter:byStatusId(3)"&gt;\n        &lt;span&gt;{{user.name}}&lt;/span&gt;\n    &lt;li&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>To make this work you just define your filter as the following:</p>\n\n<pre><code>$scope.byStatusId = function(statusId) {\n    return function(user) {\n        return user.status.id == statusId;\n    }\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>This approach is more versatile because you can do comparisons on values that are nested deep inside the object.</p>\n\n<p>Checkout <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13464809/reverse-polarity-of-an-angular-js-filter/17811582#17811582">Reverse polarity of an angular.js filter</a> to see how you can use this for other useful operations with filter.</p>',

	                           u"??? <--This doesn't work",

	                           u'. Is that what you mean?',
	                           u'@DenisPshenov The problem I was having was in the visibility of ',
	                           u' when using an additional variable. I took a different approach using ',
	                           u' and '],

2015-01-03 09:40:37+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27695685/rails4-nokogiri-pismo-gem> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:40:37+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27695685/rails4-nokogiri-pismo-gem>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>According to my experience in case of encoding problem with <em>Nokogiri</em> / <em>RestClient</em> or other web scraping gems it helps to find what encoding document says it uses. This info is usually located at the meta tag, eg: <code>&lt;meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=Windows-1251"&gt;</code>. This will not always be true (encoding may be different), but it\'s worth a try if you can find a meta tag at all. (Or you could try a few different encodings!)</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p>Then get a response (eg <code>doc = Nokogiri::HTML(open-uri(http://example.com))</code>) and try:  </p>\n\n<p><code>doc.force_encoding(\'Windows-1251\').encode(\'UTF-8\')</code>   </p></li>\n<li><p>Or you setting Nokogiri\'s encoding explicitly could help: </p>\n\n<p><code>doc = Nokogiri.XML(open-uri(http://example.com), nil, \'Windows-1251\')</code></p></li>\n</ol>',
	              'comments': [],

2015-01-03 09:40:38+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751339/how-do-i-prevent-character-escaping-in-php-xslt> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:40:38+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751339/how-do-i-prevent-character-escaping-in-php-xslt>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>You must have some error in the parts of the code that you haven\'t shared with your question, as when given that source XML:</p>\n\n<pre><code>$source = &lt;&lt;&lt;XML\n&lt;source&gt;\n&lt;BiographicalNote&gt;\n &amp;lt;p&amp;gt;This text includes escaped HTML entities.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;\n&lt;/BiographicalNote&gt;\n&lt;/source&gt;\nXML;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>and given that first stylesheet:</p>\n\n<pre><code>$xsltA = &lt;&lt;&lt;XSLT\n&lt;xsl:stylesheet version="1.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform"&gt;\n    &lt;xsl:template match="BiographicalNote"&gt;\n        &lt;AuthorBio&gt;\n            &lt;xsl:value-of select="normalize-space(.)" disable-output-escaping="yes" /&gt;\n        &lt;/AuthorBio&gt;\n    &lt;/xsl:template&gt;\n&lt;/xsl:stylesheet&gt;\nXSLT;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>and given that second stylesheet:</p>\n\n<pre><code>$xsltB = &lt;&lt;&lt;XSLT\n&lt;xsl:stylesheet version="1.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform"&gt;\n    &lt;xsl:template match="AuthorBio"&gt;\n         &lt;ParagraphStyleRange&gt;\n              &lt;xsl:apply-templates select="./node()"/&gt;\n              &lt;Br/&gt;\n         &lt;/ParagraphStyleRange&gt;\n    &lt;/xsl:template&gt;\n\n    &lt;xsl:template match="p/text()|text()"&gt; &lt;!-- Not all HTML paragraphs have actual &lt;p&gt; tags. --&gt;\n        &lt;CharacterStyleRange&gt;\n            &lt;Content&gt;&lt;xsl:value-of select="."/&gt;&lt;/Content&gt;\n        &lt;/CharacterStyleRange&gt;\n    &lt;/xsl:template&gt;\n&lt;/xsl:stylesheet&gt;\nXSLT;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Performing the application:</p>\n\n<pre><code>echo $source2 = Proc::create($xsltA)-&gt;transform($source), "\\n----\\n";\necho $source3 = Proc::create($xsltB)-&gt;transform($source2), "\\n";\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Results in the following beautified output:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;AuthorBio&gt;&lt;p&gt;This text includes escaped HTML entities.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/AuthorBio&gt;\n----\n&lt;ParagraphStyleRange&gt;\n  &lt;CharacterStyleRange&gt;\n    &lt;Content&gt;This text includes escaped HTML entities.&lt;/Content&gt;\n  &lt;/CharacterStyleRange&gt;\n  &lt;Br/&gt;\n&lt;/ParagraphStyleRange&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p>Full example code:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;?php\n/**\n * http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751339/how-do-i-prevent-character-escaping-in-php-xslt\n */\n\n/**\n * Class Proc\n *\n * XSLT Processor\n */\nclass Proc\n{\n    private $proc;\n\n    /**\n     * @param string $xslt\n     *\n     * @return Proc\n     */\n    public static function create($xslt)\n    {\n        return new self($xslt);\n    }\n\n    public function __construct($xslt)\n    {\n        $proc = new XSLTProcessor();\n        $proc-&gt;importStylesheet(\n            $this-&gt;docFromString($xslt)\n        );\n\n        $this-&gt;proc = $proc;\n    }\n\n    public function transform($source)\n    {\n        $result = $this-&gt;proc-&gt;transformToDoc(\n            $this-&gt;docFromString($source)\n        );\n\n        $result-&gt;formatOutput       = true;\n        $result-&gt;preserveWhiteSpace = false;\n        return $result-&gt;saveXML($result-&gt;documentElement);\n    }\n\n    private function docFromString($string)\n    {\n        $doc = new DOMDocument();\n        $doc-&gt;loadXML($string);\n        return $doc;\n    }\n}\n\n$source = &lt;&lt;&lt;XML\n&lt;source&gt;\n&lt;BiographicalNote&gt;\n &amp;lt;p&amp;gt;This text includes escaped HTML entities.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;\n&lt;/BiographicalNote&gt;\n&lt;/source&gt;\nXML;\n\n$xsltA = &lt;&lt;&lt;XSLT\n&lt;xsl:stylesheet version="1.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform"&gt;\n    &lt;xsl:template match="BiographicalNote"&gt;\n        &lt;AuthorBio&gt;\n            &lt;xsl:value-of select="normalize-space(.)" disable-output-escaping="yes" /&gt;\n        &lt;/AuthorBio&gt;\n    &lt;/xsl:template&gt;\n&lt;/xsl:stylesheet&gt;\nXSLT;\n\n$xsltB = Not all HTML paragraphs have actual &lt;p&gt; tags. --&gt;\n        &lt;CharacterStyleRange&gt;\n            &lt;Content&gt;&lt;xsl:value-of select="."/&gt;&lt;/Content&gt;\n        &lt;/CharacterStyleRange&gt;\n    &lt;/xsl:template&gt;\n&lt;/xsl:stylesheet&gt;\nXSLT;\n\necho $source2 = Proc::create($xsltA)-&gt;transform($source), "\\n----\\n";\necho $source3 = 	              'comments': [],

	 'body': u'<p>I have a large, complex XML document that needs to be transformed twice with XSLT to achieve the desired result. 2015-01-03 09:40:39+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27747781/java-8-method-references-called-on-a-local-variable>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p><a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se8/html/jls-15.html#jls-15.13.3">JLS 15.13.5</a> may hold the explanation:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>The timing of method reference expression evaluation is more complex than that of lambda expressions (\xa715.27.4). When a method reference expression has an expression (rather than a type) preceding the :: separator, that subexpression is evaluated immediately. The result of evaluation is stored until the method of the corresponding functional interface type is invoked; at that point, the result is used as the target reference for the invocation. This means the expression preceding the :: separator is evaluated only when the program encounters the method reference expression, and is not re-evaluated on subsequent invocations on the functional interface type. </p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>As I understand it, since in your case <code>transformer</code> is the expression preceding the :: separator, it is evaluated just once and stored. Since it doesn\'t have to be re-evaluated in order to invoke the referenced method, it doesn\'t matter that <code>transformer</code> is later assigned null.</p>',
	              'comments': [u"I don't see why they couldn't do the same thing for the lambda case: capture the value of ",
	                           u' (or any other variable) when the lambda is evaluated and store it in some internal ',
	                           u" field. This is effectvely what the method reference must do. You can then restrict that variables can only be changed outside the body of the lambda expression. I feel like I'm missing something though.",
	                           u'@SotiriosDelimanolis the lambda is ',
	                           u' evaluated immediately; it is only the call site which is generated at compile time. The actual linkage only happens the first time the lambda is ',
	                           u'ed.',
	                           u'@fge I did not mean ',
	                           u'. The lambda expression is ',
	                           u' to produce an instance of the functional interface. The compiler (and then JVM) can simply close over the value of any ',
	                           u' variable and store it locally, ie. in the instance.',
	                           u'@SotiriosDelimanolis I ',
	                           u' mean invoked. From what I understand, nothing guarantees that the lambda will be invoked at once. Which means that the compiler needs to ensure that the reference is still valid when the linkage is done. Evaluating the lambda only creates the call site, it does not link it.',
	                           u'@SotiriosDelimanolis but lambdas behave differently; they are indy call sites, therefore they use a bootstrap method which is called only when the linkage is actually performed. This is ',
	                           u' different from what an anonymous class does. The only thing that the compiler does is generate this bootstrap method.'],
	              'extid': 27748129,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27747781/java-8-method-references-called-on-a-local-variable/27748129#27748129',
	              'user_id': 1221571,
	              'vote': 16},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Wild guess but to me, here is what happens...</p>\n\n<p>The compiler cannot assert that the created stream is synchronous at all; it sees this as a possible scenario:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>create stream from <code>relationships</code> argument;</li>\n<li>reaffect <code>transformer</code>;</li>\n<li>stream unrolls.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>What is generated at compile time is a call site; it is linked only when the stream unrolls.</p>\n\n<p>In your first lambda, you refer to a local variable, but this variable is <em>not</em> part of the call site.</p>\n\n<p>In the second lambda, since you use a method reference, it means the generated call site will have to keep a reference to the method, therefore the class instance holding that method. The fact that it was referred by a local variable which you change afterwards does not matter.</p>\n\n<p>My two cents...</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27748067,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27747781/java-8-method-references-called-on-a-local-variable/27748067#27748067',
	              'user_id': 1093528,
	              'vote': 4},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>In your first example <code>transformer</code> is referenced every time the mapping function is called, so once for every relationship.</p>\n\n<p>In your second example <code>transformer</code> is referenced only once, when <code>transformer::transformRelationship</code> is passed to <code>map()</code>. So it doesn\'t matter if it changes afterwards.</p>\n\n<p>Those are <strong>not</strong> <em>"the two ways to write the lambda expression"</em> but a lambda expression and a method reference, two distinct features of the language.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27748207,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27747781/java-8-method-references-called-on-a-local-variable/27748207#27748207',
	              'user_id': 2151351,
	              'vote': 3}],
	 'body': u'<p>I am in the process of learning Java 8 and I came across something that I find a bit strange.\nImagine the following snippet:</p>\n\n<pre><code>private MyDaoClass myDao;\n\npublic void storeRelationships(Set&lt;Relationship&lt;ClassA, ClassB&gt;&gt; relationships) {\n\n    RelationshipTransformer transformer = new RelationshipTransformerImpl();\n\n    myDao.createRelationships(\n            relationships.stream()\n            .map((input) -&gt; transformer.transformRelationship(input))\n            .collect(Collectors.toSet())\n    );\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Basically, I need to map the input set called relationships to a different type in order to\nconform to the API of the DAO I\'m using. For the conversion, I would like to use an existing RelationshipTransformerImpl class that I instantiate as a local variable.</p>\n\n<p>Now, here\'s my question:\nIf I was to modify the above code like so:</p>\n\n<pre><code>public void storeRelationships(Set&lt;Relationship&lt;ClassA, ClassB&gt;&gt; relationships) {\n\n    RelationshipTransformer transformer = new RelationshipTransformerImpl();\n\n    myDao.createRelationships(\n            relationships.stream()\n            .map((input) -&gt; transformer.transformRelationship(input))\n            .collect(Collectors.toSet())\n    );\n\n    transformer = null;  //setting the value of an effectively final variable\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>I would obviously get a compiler error, since the local variable "transformer" is no longer "effectively final". However, if I change the lambda so that it uses a method reference:</p>\n\n<pre><code>public void storeRelationships(Set&lt;Relationship&lt;ClassA, ClassB&gt;&gt; relationships) {\n\n    RelationshipTransformer transformer = new RelationshipTransformerImpl();\n\n    myDao.createRelationships(\n            relationships.stream()\n            .map(transformer::transformRelationship)\n            .collect(Collectors.toSet())\n    );\n\n    transformer = null;  //setting the value of an effectively final variable\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Then I no longer get a compilation error! Why does this happen? I thought the two ways to write the lambda expression should be equivalent, but there\'s clearly something more going on.</p>',

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Floating point numbers are approximations of real numbers that can represent larger ranges than integers but use the same amount of memory, at the cost of lower precision. If your question is about small arithmetic or decimal conversion errors, please read the "learn more..." page linked below before posting.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Many questions asked here about floating point math are about small inaccuracies in floating point arithmetic. To use the example from the excerpt, <code>0.1 + 0.1 + 0.1</code> might result in <code>0.300000001</code> instead of the expected <code>0.3</code>. Errors like these are caused by the way floating point numbers are represented in computers\' memory.</p>\n\n<p>Integers are stored as exact values of the numbers they represent. Floating point numbers are stored as two values: a significand and an exponent. It is not possible to find a significand-exponent pair that matches every possible real number. As a result, some approximation, and therefore inaccuracy, is unavoidable.</p>\n\n<p>Two commonly cited introductory-level resources about floating point math are <a href="http://download.oracle.com/docs/cd/E19957-01/806-3568/ncg_goldberg.html" rel="nofollow">What Every Computer Scientist Should Know About Floating-Point Arithmetic</a> and the <a href="http://floating-point-gui.de/" rel="nofollow">floating-point-gui.de</a>.</p>\n\n<p>FAQs:</p>\n\n<p><a href="http://www.exploringbinary.com/why-0-point-1-does-not-exist-in-floating-point/" rel="nofollow">Why 0.1 does not exist in floating point</a></p>',
	 'name': 'floating-point',
	 'qcount': 6381,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/floating-point/info'}

2015-01-03 09:40:41+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/bash/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753408/xclip-and-trailing-spaces)
2015-01-03 09:40:41+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/bash/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>The Bourne-again shell (Bash) is a Bourne shell (sh) implementation with numerous additions. Bash is the default shell in many Linux distributions and on Mac OS X. It is available on most modern operating systems, and has been ported to Windows.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<h1>About Bash</h1>\n\n<p>There are a variety of interpreters that receive commands either interactively or as a sequence of commands from a file. The <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bash_%28Unix_shell%29" rel="nofollow">Bourne-again shell</a> (Bash) is one such interpreter. Bash implements the standard <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bourne_shell" rel="nofollow">Bourne Shell</a> (sh), and offers numerous additions.</p>\n\n<p>From the Free Software Foundation\'s <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/bash/" rel="nofollow">Bash page</a>:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>Bash is an sh-compatible shell that incorporates useful features from the KornShell (ksh) and C shell (csh). It is intended to conform to the IEEE POSIX P1003.2/ISO 9945.2 Shell and Tools standard. It offers functional improvements over sh for both programming and interactive use. In addition, most sh scripts can be run by Bash without modification.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>Read the <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/" rel="nofollow">Bash manual</a> for technical details.</p>\n\n<h1>Before asking about problematic code</h1>\n\n<p>To help the kind people who assist you, to ensure that future readers can benefit from your question, and to help ensure your question is voted up as useful for that lovely karma, please make your question as simple and universal as possible:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p><strong>Check whether your script or data has DOS style end-of-line characters</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>Use <code>cat -v yourfile</code> or <code>echo "$yourvariable" | cat -v</code> . </p>\n\n<p>DOS carriage returns will show up as <code>^M</code> after each line.</p>\n\n<p>If you find them, delete them using <code>dos2unix</code> (a.k.a. <code>fromdos</code>) or <code>tr -d \'\\r\'</code></p></li>\n</ul></li>\n<li><p><strong>Make sure you run the script with <code>bash</code>, not <code>sh</code></strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>The first line in the script must be <code>#!/bin/bash</code> or <code>#!/usr/bin/env bash</code>.</p>\n\n<p>It <strong>must not</strong> be <code>#!/bin/sh</code></p></li>\n<li><p>Run the script with <code>./yourscript</code> or <code>bash yourscript</code>.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Do not</strong> run it with <code>sh yourscript</code>.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>This applies even when <code>sh</code> is a symlink to <code>bash</code>. </p></li>\n<li><p><strong>Find a <a href="http://www.sscce.org/" rel="nofollow">small, self-contained example</a>.</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Don\'t include sections and commands unrelated to your problem.</li>\n<li>Avoid complex commands that just serve to produce a value (include the value directly).</li>\n<li>Avoid relying on external files. Create the files on the fly, include the data directly, or post a small example of a file in your question.</li>\n</ul></li>\n<li><p><strong>Test your example.</strong> Make sure it runs and still shows the problem. <em>Do not brush this off</em>.</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Reformatting for clarity often sidesteps pitfalls related to spacing and naming.</li>\n<li>Refactoring for simplicity often sidesteps pitfalls related to subshells.</li>\n<li>Mocking out files and data often sidesteps problems related to special characters.</li>\n<li>Hours spent trying multiple things often leads to posting code from one version and errors from another.</li>\n</ul></li>\n<li><p><strong>Check the example for common problems</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Run your example through <a href="http://www.shellcheck.net" rel="nofollow">shellcheck</a> to automatically check for common mistakes.</li>\n<li>Browse <a href="http://mywiki.wooledge.org/BashPitfalls" rel="nofollow">Bash pitfalls</a> and <a href="http://wiki.bash-hackers.org/scripting/newbie_traps" rel="nofollow">Bash beginner\'s mistakes</a> for checklists of common issues.</li>\n<li>Check your data for special characters, using <code>cat -v yourfile</code> or <code>cat -v &lt;&lt;&lt; "$yourvar"</code>. Be especially careful with carriage returns (shown as <code>^M</code>). </li>\n</ul></li>\n</ol>\n\n<h1>How to turn a bad script into a good question</h1>\n\n<p>For example, let\'s say you have a script for alerting you when a server is idle, but it keeps alerting even when the machine is not idle:</p>\n\n<pre><code># Avoid code like this when asking about a problem\n# It has irrelevant code and external dependencies, and is hard to read and run\n\nwhile true\ndo\n  load=$(wget -O - "http://$1/load.php" | grep "^load:" | cut -d: -f 2)\n  if [[ $load=="0" ]]\n  then \n    mailx -s "System is idle" user@example.com &lt;&lt;&lt; "The server is idle"\n    break\n  else\n    echo "Waiting..."\n    sleep 60\n  fi\ndone\n</code></pre>\n\n<ol>\n<li>The problem still occurs without the loop: Remove the loop from your question. </li>\n<li>The problem still occurs if you skip asking the server: Hard code the response (e.g. <code>load=42</code>)</li>\n<li>The problem still occurs without emailing: Use <code>echo "Why does this run?"</code></li>\n<li>The problem still occurs when removing the else branch. Shorten it</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>We\'re now left with this <strong>small, self-contained example</strong>:</p>\n\n<pre><code># Prefer code like this when asking about a problem\n# It\'s small, simple and self contained, making it easy to read and run.\n\nload=42\nif [[ $load=="0" ]]\nthen\n  echo "Why does this run?"\nfi\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><strong>Thanks for making your question simple and useful! Enjoy your upvotes!</strong> </p>\n\n<p>(However, note that this example is simple to compare against the relevant entry in <a href="http://mywiki.wooledge.org/BashPitfalls#pf10" rel="nofollow">Bash pitfalls</a> and the error is automatically caught by <a href="http://www.shellcheck.net" rel="nofollow">shellcheck</a>, so now you don\'t actually need to ask!)</p>\n\n<h1>Popular Questions</h1>\n\n<p>Some frequently asked Bash questions include:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/818255/in-the-bash-shell-what-is-21">In the shell, what is " 2&gt;&amp;1 "?</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/951336/how-to-debug-a-bash-script">How to debug a bash script?</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/169511/how-do-i-iterate-over-a-range-of-numbers-defined-by-variables-in-bash">How do I iterate over a range of numbers defined by variables in bash?</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/59895/can-a-bash-script-tell-what-directory-its-stored-in">Can a Bash script tell what directory it\'s stored in?</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/638975/how-do-i-tell-if-a-file-does-not-exist-in-bash">How do I tell if a file does not exist in bash?</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/26717870/why-does-bin-sh-behave-differently-to-bin-bash-even-if-one-points-to-the-other">Why does /bin/sh behave differently to /bin/bash even if one points to the other?</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h1>Books and Resources</h1>\n\n<p>Additional reading materials include:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/" rel="nofollow">Bash In most cases the tag for a specific framework should be used instead of this tag.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<h1>Framework</h1>\n\n<p>A framework is a set of code or libraries which provide functionality common to a whole class of applications. While one library will usually provide one specific piece of functionality, frameworks will offer a broader range which are all often used by one type of application. Rather than rewriting commonly used logic, a programmer can leverage a framework which provides often used functionality, limiting the time required to build an application and reducing the possibility of introducing new bugs.</p>\n\n<h2>Resources</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_framework" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://docforge.com/wiki/Framework" rel="nofollow">DocForge</a></li>\n</ul>',

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Python is a dynamic and strongly typed programming language that is designed to emphasize usability. Two similar but incompatible versions of Python are in widespread use (2 and 3). Please consider mentioning the version and implementation that you are using when asking a question about Python.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://python.org" rel="nofollow"><strong>Python</strong></a> is a <a href="https://wiki.python.org/moin/Why%20is%20Python%20a%20dynamic%20language%20and%20also%20a%20strongly%20typed%20language" rel="nofollow"><strong>dynamic and strongly typed</strong></a> programming language that is used for <a href="http://python.org/about/apps" rel="nofollow"><strong>a wide range of applications</strong></a>. It is a general-purpose, high-level programming language that is designed to emphasize usability.</p>\n\n<p>Python allows programmers to express concepts in fewer lines of code than would be possible in languages such as <a href="/questions/tagged/c" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c\'" rel="tag">c</a>, and the language has constructs intended to be used to create clear programs in a variety of domains.</p>\n\n<p>Two similar but incompatible versions of Python are in widespread use (2 and 3). Please consider mentioning the version and implementation that you are using when asking a question about Python.</p>\n\n<p>Python supports multiple programming paradigms, including object-oriented, imperative and functional programming styles. It features a fully dynamic type system and automatic memory management, similar to that of <a href="/questions/tagged/scheme" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'scheme\'" rel="tag">scheme</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/ruby" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ruby\'" rel="tag">ruby</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/perl" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'perl\'" rel="tag">perl</a> and <a href="/questions/tagged/tcl" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'tcl\'" rel="tag">tcl</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Like other <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_programming_language" rel="nofollow">dynamic languages</a>, Python is often used as a <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/scripting/info">scripting language</a>, but is also used in a wide range of non-scripting contexts. Using third-party tools, Python code can be packaged into standalone executable programs. Python interpreters are available for many operating systems.</p>\n\n<p><a href="/questions/tagged/cpython" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cpython\'" rel="tag">cpython</a>, the reference implementation of Python, is free and open source software and has a community-based development model, as do nearly all of its alternative implementations. There are a wide variety of implementations more suited for specific environments or tasks.</p>\n\n<p>The philosophy of Python is succinctly formulated in <a href="http://python.org/dev/peps/pep-0020" rel="nofollow"><em>The Zen of Python</em></a> written by Tim Peters, which can be revealed by issuing this command at the interactive interpreter:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&gt;&gt;&gt; import this\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>The documentation can also be accessed offline for your installation of Python in the following manner:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>Going into <code>Your_Python_install_dir/Doc</code>. There is a complete Python documentation present for the version of Python installed on your computer.</li>\n<li>Running <code>pydoc x</code> or <code>python -m pydoc x</code> from the command prompt or terminal displays documentation for module <code>x</code>.</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>Unlike many other languages Python uses an indentation based syntax and this may take some getting used to for programmers familiar with braces for syntax.</p>\n\n<pre><code>&gt;&gt;&gt; from __future__ import braces\n  File "&lt;stdin&gt;", line 1\nSyntaxError: not a chance\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>To help with the transition it is a recommendation to use a properly configured text-editor created for programmers or an IDE. Python comes with a basic IDE called <a href="http://docs.python.org/2/library/idle.html" rel="nofollow">IDLE</a> to get you started. Other popular examples are the charity-ware <a href="/questions/tagged/vim" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'vim\'" rel="tag">vim</a>, the free GNU <a href="/questions/tagged/emacs" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'emacs\'" rel="tag">emacs</a> and <a href="/questions/tagged/eclipse" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'eclipse\'" rel="tag">eclipse</a>+<a href="/questions/tagged/pydev" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'pydev\'" rel="tag">pydev</a>. Take a look at this <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_integrated_development_environments_for_Python#Python" rel="nofollow">IDE comparison list</a> for many other alternatives.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>Tagging recommendation:</h2>\n\n<p>Use the <a href="/questions/tagged/python" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'python\'" rel="tag">python</a> tag for all Python related questions. If you believe your question includes issues specific to incompatibilities between Python 2.x and Python 3.x, use <a href="/questions/tagged/python-2.x" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'python-2.x\'" rel="tag">python-2.x</a> or <a href="/questions/tagged/python-3.x" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'python-3.x\'" rel="tag">python-3.x</a> in addition to the main <a href="/questions/tagged/python" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'python\'" rel="tag">python</a> tag. If you believe your question may be even more specific, you can include a version specific tag such as <a href="/questions/tagged/python-2.7" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'python-2.7\'" rel="tag">python-2.7</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Also, consider including the tag for the specific implementation you are using other than <a href="/questions/tagged/cpython" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cpython\'" rel="tag">cpython</a>, as the use of <a href="/questions/tagged/cpython" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cpython\'" rel="tag">cpython</a> is assumed unless explicitly stated otherwise.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>References</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Official documentation for the current stable versions: <a href="http://docs.python.org/2.7/" rel="nofollow">2.7.8</a> and <a href="http://docs.python.org/3.4/" rel="nofollow">3.4.1</a>.</li>\n<li>Release notes for the current stable versions: <a href="http://python.org/download/releases/2.7.8" rel="nofollow">2.7.8</a> and <a href="https://www.python.org/download/releases/3.4.1" rel="nofollow">3.4.1</a>.</li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Python_%28programming_language%29" rel="nofollow">Python (programming language)</a> (Wikipedia)</li>\n<li><a href="http://wiki.python.org/moin/BeginnersGuide/Programmers" rel="nofollow">Python for Programmers</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.tutorialspoint.com/python/python_quick_guide.htm" rel="nofollow">Python - Quick Guide</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://docs.python.org/3.3/howto/pyporting.html" rel="nofollow">Porting Python 2 Code to Python 3</a></li>\n<li>The non-profit <a href="http://www.python.org/psf/" rel="nofollow">Python Software Foundation</a> manages <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CPython" rel="nofollow">CPython</a>.</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.python.org/psf/" rel="nofollow">PSF</a> License Agreement for Python <a href="http://docs.python.org/2.7/license.html" rel="nofollow">2.7.8</a> and <a href="http://docs.python.org/3.4/license.html" rel="nofollow">3.4.1</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>Popular <a href="http://wiki.python.org/moin/WebFrameworks" rel="nofollow">web frameworks</a> based on Python</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><a href="http://www.djangoproject.com" rel="nofollow"><strong>Django</strong></a> <a href="/questions/tagged/django" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'django\'" rel="tag">django</a></p>\n\n<p>The Web framework for perfectionists (with deadlines). Django makes it easier to build better Web apps more quickly and with less code. Django is a high-level Python Web framework that encourages rapid development and clean, pragmatic design. It lets you build high-performing, elegant Web applications quickly. Django focuses on automating as much as possible and adhering to the DRY (Don\'t Repeat Yourself) principle.</p></li>\n<li><p><a href="http://flask.pocoo.org" rel="nofollow"><strong>Flask</strong></a> <a href="/questions/tagged/flask" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'flask\'" rel="tag">flask</a></p>\n\n<p>Flask is a micro-framework for Python based on Werkzeug, Jinja 2 and good intentions.</p></li>\n<li><p><a href="http://www.cherrypy.org" rel="nofollow"><strong>CherryPy</strong></a> <a href="/questions/tagged/cherrypy" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cherrypy\'" rel="tag">cherrypy</a></p>\n\n<p>CherryPy is a pythonic, object-oriented web framework that enables developers to build web applications in much the same way they would build any other object-oriented Python program. This results in smaller source code developed in less time. CherryPy has been in use for over 7 years and it is being used in production by many sites, from the simplest to the most demanding.</p></li>\n<li><p><a href="http://www.pylonsproject.org/projects/pyramid/about" rel="nofollow"><strong>Pyramid</strong></a> <a href="/questions/tagged/pyramid" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'pyramid\'" rel="tag">pyramid</a></p>\n\n<p>A lightweight Web framework emphasizing flexibility and rapid development. It combines the very best ideas from the worlds of Ruby, Python and Perl, providing a structured but extremely flexible Python web framework. It\'s also one of the first projects to leverage the emerging WSGI standard, which allows extensive re-use and flexibility but only if you need it.</p></li>\n<li><p><a href="http://webpy.org" rel="nofollow"><strong>web.py</strong></a> <a href="/questions/tagged/web.py" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'web.py\'" rel="tag">web.py</a></p>\n\n<p>web.py is a web framework for Python that is as simple as it is powerful. web.py is in the public domain; you can use it for whatever purpose with absolutely no restrictions. web.py lets you write web apps in Python.</p></li>\n<li><p><a href="http://grok.zope.org" rel="nofollow"><strong>Grok</strong></a> <a href="/questions/tagged/grok" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'grok\'" rel="tag">grok</a></p>\n\n<p>Built on the existing Zope 3 libraries, but aims to provide an easier learning curve and a more agile development experience. Grok does this by placing an emphasis on convention over configuration and DRY (Don\'t Repeat Yourself).</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Popular Mathematical/Scientific computing libraries in Python</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><a href="http://www.numpy.org" rel="nofollow"><strong>NumPy</strong></a> <a href="/questions/tagged/numpy" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'numpy\'" rel="tag">numpy</a></p>\n\n<p>NumPy is the fundamental package for scientific computing with Python. It contains among other things:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>a powerful N-dimensional array object</li>\n<li>sophisticated (broadcasting) functions</li>\n<li>tools for integrating C/C++ and Fortran code</li>\n<li>useful linear algebra, Fourier transform, and random number capabilities</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>These features also make it possible to use NumPy in general-purpose database applications.</p></li>\n<li><p><a href="http://scipy.org" rel="nofollow"><strong>SciPy</strong></a> <a href="/questions/tagged/scipy" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'scipy\'" rel="tag">scipy</a></p>\n\n<p>SciPy is an open source library for the Python programming language consisting of mathematical algorithms and functions often used in science and engineering. SciPy includes algorithms and tools for tasks such as optimization, clustering, discrete Fourier transforms, linear algebra, signal processing and multi-dimensional image processing. SciPy is closely related to NumPy and depends on many NumPy functions, including a multidimensional array that is used as the basic data structure in SciPy.</p></li>\n<li><p><a href="http://matplotlib.org/" rel="nofollow"><strong>matplotlib</strong></a> <a href="/questions/tagged/matplotlib" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'matplotlib\'" rel="tag">matplotlib</a></p>\n\n<p>matplotlib is a plotting library for the Python programming language and its NumPy numerical mathematics extension. It provides an object-oriented API for embedding plots into applications using general-purpose GUI toolkits like wxPython, Qt, or GTK. There is also a procedural "pylab" interface based on a state machine (like OpenGL), designed to closely resemble that of MATLAB.</p></li>\n<li><p><a href="http://pandas.pydata.org/" rel="nofollow"><strong>pandas</strong></a> <a href="/questions/tagged/pandas" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'pandas\'" rel="tag">pandas</a></p>\n\n<p>pandas, the Python Data Analysis Library, is an open source, BSD-licensed library providing high-performance, easy-to-use data structures and data analysis tools for the Python programming language.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>Community</h2>\n\n<h3>Chat Rooms</h3>\n\n<p>Chat about Python with other Stack Overflow users in the <a href="http://chat.stackoverflow.com/rooms/6/python">Python chat room</a>.</p>\n\n<h3>Other Sites</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://python.org/community/lists/#tutor" rel="nofollow">Tutor mailing list</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://python.org/community/lists/#python-help" rel="nofollow">python-help mailing list</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.pycon.org" rel="nofollow">PyCon</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.pythonweekly.com" rel="nofollow">Python Weekly</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://pycoders.com" rel="nofollow">Pycoder\'s Weekly</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/comp.lang.python" rel="nofollow">Python Google Group</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>Free Python programming Books</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Non-Programmer%27s_Tutorial_for_Python_2.6" rel="nofollow">Wikibooks\' Non-Programmers Tutorial for Python</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://docs.python.org/tutorial" rel="nofollow">The Official Python Tutorial</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.itmaybeahack.com/homepage/books/python.html" rel="nofollow">Building Skills in Python Version 2.6</a> (Steven F. Lott)</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.swaroopch.org/notes/Python" rel="nofollow">A Byte of Python</a> (Swaroop C H.)</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.brpreiss.com/books/opus7/html/book.html" rel="nofollow">Data Structures and Algorithms in Python</a> (Bruno R. Shaw)</li>\n<li><a href="http://inventwithpython.com/pygame" rel="nofollow">Making Games with Python &amp; Pygame</a> (Albert Sweigart)</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.nltk.org/book" rel="nofollow">Natural Language Processing with Python</a> (Steven Bird, Ewan Klein, and Edward Loper)</li>\n<li><a href="http://openbookproject.net/pybiblio" rel="nofollow">Python Bibliotheca</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://openbookproject.net/py4fun" rel="nofollow">Python for Fun</a> (Chris Meyers)</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.briggs.net.nz/snake-wrangling-for-kids.html" rel="nofollow">Snake Wrangling For Kids</a> (Jason R. 2015-01-03 09:40:42+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/angularjs/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>AngularJS is an open-source JavaScript framework. Its goal is to augment browser-based applications with Model\u2013View\u2013Whatever(MV*) capability and reduce the amount of JavaScript needed to make web applications functional. These types of apps are also frequently known as Single-Page Applications.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://angularjs.org/" rel="nofollow">AngularJS</a> is an open-source JavaScript framework for building <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Create,_read,_update_and_delete" rel="nofollow">CRUD</a>-centric <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajax_(programming)" rel="nofollow">AJAX</a>-style web applications. Its goal is to <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shim_(computing)" rel="nofollow">shim</a> the browser to augment the HTML vocabulary with <a href="http://docs.angularjs.org/guide/directive" rel="nofollow">directives</a> useful for building dynamic web applications.</p>\n\n<p>Angular ships with directives which add two-way data binding, DOM control and unrolling, code-behind DOM, form validation, and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_linking" rel="nofollow">deep linking</a>. </p>\n\n<h3>AngularJS\'s Philosophy</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li>The AngularJS philosophy encourages developers to create their own directives, turning the HTML into a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain-specific_language" rel="nofollow">DSL</a> suited to building their kind of application. The result significantly reduces the amount and complexity of JavaScript needed to build web applications.</li>\n<li>The AngularJS philosophy is that UI is best described in declarative form (HTML), and that behavior is best described in imperative form (JavaScript) and that the two should never meet.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Notable features</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Teach your browser new tricks by adding behavior to HTML tags/attributes</li>\n<li>Controllers provide code-behind DOM with clear separation from the view</li>\n<li>Two-way data binding without the need to extend or wrap the model objects</li>\n<li>Dependency injection assembles the application <a href="http://blog.angularjs.org/2012/08/getting-rid-of-main.html" rel="nofollow">without <code>\'main\'</code> method</a></li>\n<li>Promises/futures remove many callbacks from code when communicating with server</li>\n<li>Form validation</li>\n<li>Strong focus on testability</li>\n<li>Extend HTML with your own behavior</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Bits</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Source code: <a href="https://github.com/angular/angular.js" rel="nofollow">GitHub</a> (<a href="https://github.com/angular/angular.js/issues" rel="nofollow">Issue Tracker</a>)</li>\n<li>Download: <a href="http://code.angularjs.org" rel="nofollow">the files</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Community</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Follow us: <a href="http://twitter.com/angularjs" rel="nofollow">Twitter</a>, <a href="https://plus.google.com/u/0/110323587230527980117" rel="nofollow">Google+</a></li>\n<li>Subscribe: <a href="http://groups.google.com/group/angular" rel="nofollow">angular@googlegroups.com</a></li>\n<li>Hangout: <a href="http://webchat.freenode.net/?channels=angularjs&amp;uio=d4" rel="nofollow">IRC</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Asking a question</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Mention which version of AngularJS you\'re using</li>\n<li>Reduce your issue to a small example</li>\n<li>Post a reduced working code on <a href="http://plnkr.co/" rel="nofollow">plnkr.co</a> or <a href="http://jsfiddle.net/IgorMinar/ADukg/" rel="nofollow">jsfiddle.net</a></li>\n<li>Don\'t know how? Clone one of these existing <a href="https://github.com/angular/angular.js/wiki/JsFiddle-Examples" rel="nofollow">jsfiddles</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Getting Started</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://docs.angularjs.org/tutorial" rel="nofollow">Tutorial</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://github.com/angular/angular-seed" rel="nofollow">Seed application</a> project</li>\n<li><a href="https://github.com/joshdmiller/ng-boilerplate/" rel="nofollow">Angular Boilerplate</a> for kickstarting your new AngularJS application</li>\n<li><a href="https://github.com/yeoman/generator-angular" rel="nofollow">Yeoman angular-generator</a> for boilerplate examples </li>\n<li>Learn by example and other AngularJS <a href="https://github.com/angular/angular.js/wiki/JsFiddle-Examples" rel="nofollow">jsfiddles</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://todomvc.com/" rel="nofollow">TodoMVC</a> in many JavaScript frameworks</li>\n<li><a href="https://github.com/angular-app/angular-app/" rel="nofollow">AngularApp</a> for CRUD MVC example</li>\n<li><a href="http://toddmotto.com/ultimate-guide-to-learning-angular-js-in-one-day/" rel="nofollow">A good introduction</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://tech-blog.maddyzone.com/category/javascript/angularjs" rel="nofollow">Learning steps for AngularJS</a></li>\n<li>Dedicated YouTube channel: <a href="http://www.youtube.com/user/angularjs" rel="nofollow">http://www.youtube.com/user/angularjs</a></li>\n<li>github repo with links to blog posts, articles, videos (<a href="https://github.com/jmcunningham/angularjs-learning" rel="nofollow">https://github.com/jmcunningham/angularjs-learning</a>)</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Debugging:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/ng-inspector-for-angularj/aadgmnobpdmgmigaicncghmmoeflnamj" rel="nofollow">ng-inspector, a browser extension that displays the AngularJS scope hierarchy in the current page</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/angularjs-batarang/ighdmehidhipcmcojjgiloacoafjmpfk?hl=en" rel="nofollow">Batarang, a chrome extension to debug Angular applications</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Presentations</h2>\n\n<h3>Recent</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/user/ngconfvideos" href="https://www.codeschool.com/courses/shaping-up-with-angular-js" rel="nofollow">Shaping Up with AngularJS</a> - A small free course for AngularJS</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Who is 2015-01-03 09:40:42+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/javascript/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>JavaScript (not to be confused with Java) is a dynamically-typed language commonly used for client-side scripting. Use this tag for questions regarding ECMAScript and its various dialects/implementations (excluding ActionScript). Unless a tag for a framework/library is also included, a pure JavaScript answer is expected.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><strong><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JavaScript" rel="nofollow">JavaScript</a></strong> is a dynamic, object-oriented, prototype-based, weakly typed language commonly used for client-side scripting in web browsers. Despite the name, it is unrelated to the <strong><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_programming_language" rel="nofollow">Java programming language</a></strong> and shares only superficial similarities.</p>\n\n<p>Unless a tag for a framework or library is also included, a pure JavaScript answer is expected for questions with the <a href="/questions/tagged/javascript" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'javascript\'" rel="tag">javascript</a> tag.</p>\n\n<p>JavaScript runs on nearly every Operating System, and an engine is included in almost every mainstream web browser. Developed in 1995 by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brendan_Eich" rel="nofollow">Brendan Eich</a> at Netscape Communications, it was originally called <a href="http://livescript.net/" rel="nofollow">LiveScript</a> but was renamed to JavaScript due to Netscape\'s friendly relationship with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun_Microsystems" rel="nofollow">Sun Microsystems</a> at the time.</p>\n\n<p>Standalone JavaScript engines or interpreters are available as well, including:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Mozilla\'s <a href="/questions/tagged/spidermonkey" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'spidermonkey\'" rel="tag">spidermonkey</a>, the first JavaScript engine ever written, currently used in <em>Mozilla Firefox</em>.</li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/v8" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'v8\'" rel="tag">v8</a>, Google\'s JavaScript interpreter, used in Google Chrome.</li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/node.js" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'node.js\'" rel="tag">node.js</a>, a platform which enables server-side applications to be written in JavaScript.</li>\n<li>Windows includes a <a href="/questions/tagged/jscript" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jscript\'" rel="tag">jscript</a>, a JavaScript variant in <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Script_Host" rel="nofollow">Windows Script Host</a>.</li>\n<li>Mozilla also offers <a href="/questions/tagged/rhino" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'rhino\'" rel="tag">rhino</a>, an implementation of JavaScript built in Java, typically embedded into Java applications to provide scripting to end users.</li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/webkit" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'webkit\'" rel="tag">webkit</a> (except for the Chromium project) implements the <a href="/questions/tagged/javascriptcore" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'javascriptcore\'" rel="tag">javascriptcore</a> engine.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>The <a href="http://developer.mozilla.org/" rel="nofollow">Mozilla Developer Network</a> contains high-quality <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en/JavaScript" rel="nofollow">documentation on JavaScript</a>.</p>\n\n<p>JavaScript is typically used to manipulate the <a href="http://www.w3.org/DOM/DOMTR.html" rel="nofollow">Document Object Model</a> (DOM) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascading_Style_Sheets" rel="nofollow">Cascading Style Sheets</a> (CSS) within the browser, offering user interface scripting, animation, automation, client-side validation, and much more.</p>\n\n<p>However, with the recent emergence of platforms such as <a href="http://nodejs.org/" rel="nofollow">Node.js</a>, JavaScript can now be used to write server-side applications.</p>\n\n<h2>Nomenclature</h2>\n\n<p>People often use the term <em>JavaScript</em> informally. The language and the term originated from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netscape" rel="nofollow">Netscape</a>. ECMAScript, JavaScript, and JScript are terms that are easy to confuse.</p>\n\n<p><strong><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECMAScript" rel="nofollow">ECMAScript</a></strong> was developed as a standardization of Netscape\'s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JavaScript" rel="nofollow">JavaScript</a> and Microsoft\'s independently-developed <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/yek4tbz0.aspx" rel="nofollow">JScript</a>. The canonical reference is the <a href="http://www.ecma-international.org/publications/standards/Ecma-262.htm" rel="nofollow">ECMA-262 Language Specification</a>. While JavaScript and JScript aim to be compatible with ECMAScript, they also provide additional features (and <a href="http://wiki.ecmascript.org/lib/exe/fetch.php?id=resources:resources&amp;cache=cache&amp;media=resources:jscriptdeviationsfromes3.pdf" rel="nofollow">other deviations</a>) not described in the ECMA specifications. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECMAScript#Dialects" rel="nofollow">Other implementations</a> of ECMAScript also exist.</p>\n\n<p>The differences today for those who use JavaScript are negligible; people generally do not distinguish the JavaScript and JScript variations from ECMAScript.</p>\n\n<h3>ECMAScript versions</h3>\n\n<p>Most modern browsers implement JavaScript based on the <a href="/questions/tagged/ecmascript-5" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ecmascript-5\'" rel="tag">ecmascript-5</a> specification. However, older browsers such as Internet Explorer 8 implement the ECMAScript 3 specification, which does not contain functions such as <code>Function.prototype.bind</code> and even <code>JSON.parse</code>, amongst others.</p>\n\n<p>The current version of ECMAScript is version 5, however there have been <a href="http://wiki.ecmascript.org/doku.php?id=harmony:specification_drafts" rel="nofollow">numerous draft versions</a> of the upcoming <a href="/questions/tagged/ecmascript-6" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ecmascript-6\'" rel="tag">ecmascript-6</a> specification, which will add numerous new features to JavaScript implementations, such as arrow functions and class syntax.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h3>When asking a JavaScript question, you should:</h3>\n\n<ol>\n<li>Debug your JavaScript code (see <a href="http://www.creativebloq.com/javascript/javascript-debugging-beginners-3122820" rel="nofollow">Creativebloq</a> &amp; <a href="https://developers.google.com/chrome-developer-tools/docs/javascript-debugging" rel="nofollow">Google</a>).</li>\n<li>Isolate the problematic code and reproduce it in a <a href="http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2014/09/introducing-runnable-javascript-css-and-html-code-snippets/"><strong>Stackoverflow code snippet</strong></a> or an external online environment such as <a href="http://jsfiddle.net/" rel="nofollow"><strong>JSFiddle</strong></a> or <a href="http://jsbin.com/" rel="nofollow"><strong>JS Bin</strong></a>.</li>\n<li>If a library or framework is used, then tag the question with the appropriate tags: <a href="/questions/tagged/jquery" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jquery\'" rel="tag">jquery</a> for jQuery, <a href="/questions/tagged/prototypejs" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'prototypejs\'" rel="tag">prototypejs</a> for Prototype, <a href="/questions/tagged/mootools" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'mootools\'" rel="tag">mootools</a> for MooTools, and so on. However, if a framework is not used or necessary, do not include these tags.</li>\n<li>Mention which browser the code is having problems on, and what error messages, if any, were thrown by the browser. If the question is browser-specific, use tags <a href="/questions/tagged/firefox" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'firefox\'" rel="tag"><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/WcBXc.png" height="16" width="18" alt="" class="sponsor-tag-img">firefox</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/google-chrome" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'google-chrome\'" rel="tag"><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/dmHl0.png" height="16" width="18" alt="" class="sponsor-tag-img">google-chrome</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/internet-explorer" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'internet-explorer\'" rel="tag"><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/BfCOt.png" height="16" width="18" alt="" class="sponsor-tag-img">internet-explorer</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/opera" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'opera\'" rel="tag">opera</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/safari" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'safari\'" rel="tag">safari</a>, etc.</li>\n<li>Only tag the question as <a href="/questions/tagged/css" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'css\'" rel="tag">css</a> or <a href="/questions/tagged/html" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'html\'" rel="tag">html</a> if you are asking about an issue that concerns the combination of one of those with JavaScript and could only be answered with information specifically regarding either of those subjects.</li>\n</ol>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h3>Learning JavaScript</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://eloquentjavascript.net/" rel="nofollow">Eloquent JavaScript</a>: A Modern Introduction to Programming</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.klauskomenda.com/code/javascript-programming-patterns/" rel="nofollow">JavaScript Programming Patterns</a>: Collection of Design Patterns for JavaScript</li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en/JavaScript/Guide" rel="nofollow">The MDN JavaScript Guide</a>: A Comprehensive JavaScript Guide at the Mozilla Developer Network</li>\n<li><a href="http://quirksmode.org/js/contents.html" rel="nofollow">quirksmode.org - JavaScript</a>: Good introduction to JavaScript and other technologies used in the browser (e.g. DOM).</li>\n<li><a href="http://javascript.info/" rel="nofollow">JavaScript Tutorial</a>: A pure JavaScript book that covers <em>nearly</em> everything.</li>\n<li><a href="http://dev.opera.com/articles/view/programming-the-real-basics/" rel="nofollow">JavaScript Core Skills</a> from <a href="http://dev.opera.com/articles/view/1-introduction-to-the-web-standards-cur/" rel="nofollow">the Web Standards Curriculum</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.quirksmode.org/js/introevents.html" rel="nofollow">quirksmode.org | Introduction to Events</a>: A comprehensive description of the various types of event  handling. Includes overview of different ways to attach event handlers and points out quirks between different browsers. A must-read if you want to understand event handling.</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3.org/wiki/Category:Tutorials" rel="nofollow">W3C Wiki | JavaScript basics, DOM</a>: <a href="http://www.w3.org/wiki/Programming_-_the_real_basics" rel="nofollow">Programming - the real basics</a>, <a href="http://www.w3.org/wiki/Creating_and_modifying_HTML" rel="nofollow">Creating and modifying HTML</a>, <a href="http://www.w3.org/wiki/Handling_events_with_JavaScript" rel="nofollow">Handling events with JavaScript</a>.</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.netmagazine.com/tutorials/javascript-debugging-beginners" rel="nofollow">JavaScript Debugging for Beginners</a>: A good introduction to debugging JavaScript. A must-read!</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.larryullman.com/books/modern-javascript-develop-and-design/" rel="nofollow">Modern JavaScript: Develop and Design</a>: A modern guide to learning JavaScript using practical examples and approaches that should be used today.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Useful Tools</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://getfirebug.com/" rel="nofollow">Firebug</a> Add-on for 2015-01-03 09:40:43+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/web-crawler/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27695685/rails4-nokogiri-pismo-gem)
2015-01-03 09:40:43+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/web-crawler/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>A Web crawler also known as web spider is a computer program that browses the World Wide Web in a methodical, automated manner or in an orderly fashion. Other terms for Web crawlers are ants, automatic indexers, bots, Web spiders, Web robots, or &amp;ndash; especially in the FOAF community &amp;ndash; Web scutters.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>A <em>Web crawler</em> is a computer program that browses the <em>World Wide Web</em> in a methodical, automated manner or in an orderly fashion.</p>\n\n<p>Other terms for Web crawlers are <em>ants</em>, <em>automatic indexers</em>, <em>bots</em>, <em>Web spiders</em>, <em>Web robots</em>, or <em>\u2013</em> especially in the FOAF community \u2013 <em>Web scutters</em>.</p>\n\n<p>This process is called <em>Web crawling</em> or <em>spidering</em>. Many sites, in particular search engines, use spidering as a means of providing up-to-date data. Web crawlers are mainly used to create a copy of all the visited pages for later processing by a search engine that will index the downloaded pages to provide fast searches. Crawlers can also be used for automating maintenance tasks on a Web site, such as checking links or validating HTML code. Also, crawlers can be used to gather specific types of information from Web pages, such as harvesting e-mail addresses (usually for sending spam).</p>\n\n<p>A Web crawler is one type of bot, or software agent. In general, it starts with a list of URLs to visit, called the seeds. As the crawler visits these URLs, it identifies all the hyperlinks in the page and adds them to the list of URLs to visit, called the crawl frontier. URLs from the frontier are recursively visited according to a set of policies.</p>\n\n<p>The large volume implies that the crawler can only download a limited number of the Web pages within a given time, so it needs to prioritize its downloads. The high rate of change implies that the pages might have already been updated or even deleted.</p>\n\n<p>The number of possible crawlable URLs being generated by server-side software has also made it difficult for web crawlers to avoid retrieving duplicate content. Endless combinations of HTTP GET (URL-based) parameters exist, of which only a small selection will actually return unique content. For example, a simple online photo gallery may offer three options to users, as specified through HTTP GET parameters in the URL. If there exist four ways to sort images, three choices of thumbnail size, two file formats, and an option to disable user-provided content, then the same set of content can be accessed with 48 different URLs, all of which may be linked on the site. This mathematical combination creates a problem for crawlers, as they must sort through endless combinations of relatively minor scripted changes in order to retrieve unique content.</p>\n\n<p>More : <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_crawler" rel="nofollow">Wiki Link</a></p>',
	 'name': 'web-crawler',
	 'qcount': 3775,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/web-crawler/info'}
2015-01-03 09:40:43+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/amazon-s3/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753411/aws-s3-delete-object-using-javascript)
2015-01-03 09:40:43+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/amazon-s3/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Amazon S3 (simple storage service) is an online storage service from Amazon Web Services.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://aws.amazon.com/s3/" rel="nofollow"><strong>Amazon S3</strong> (Simple Storage Service)</a> is an online storage web service offered by <a href="http://aws.amazon.com/" rel="nofollow">Amazon Web Services</a>. Amazon S3 provides storage through a simple web services interface.  It gives any developer access to the same highly scalable, reliable, secure, fast, inexpensive infrastructure that Amazon uses to run its own global network of web sites.</p>\n\n<p><strong>References</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://aws.amazon.com/documentation/s3/" rel="nofollow">Documentation</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://aws.amazon.com/code/developertools?_encoding=UTF8&amp;jiveRedirect=1" rel="nofollow">Developer Tools</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_S3" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia</a></li>\n</ul>',

2015-01-03 09:40:44+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/xml/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751339/how-do-i-prevent-character-escaping-in-php-xslt)
2015-01-03 09:40:44+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/xml/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Extensible Markup Language (XML) is a flexible structured document format that defines human- and machine-readable encoding rules.\r\n</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<h1>Extensible Markup Language</h1>\n\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XML" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia</a> defines XML as follows:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p><b>XML</b> (Extensible Markup Language) is a set of rules for encoding documents in both human-readable and machine-readable form. It is defined in the XML 1.0 Specification produced by the <a href="http://www.w3.org/" rel="nofollow">W3C</a>, and several other related specifications, all gratis open standards.</p>\n  \n  <p><b>Extensible</b> - XML is extensible. It lets you define your own tags.</p>\n  \n  <p><b>Markup</b> - The most attractive feature of XML has to be its ability to allow its user to create their own tags. The tags that can be created will be similar to tags in HTML. But with XML you are afforded the opportunity to define your own tags.</p>\n  \n  <p><b>Language</b> - XML is a language that is very similar to HTML. But it\u2019s much more flexible because it allows to create custom tags. In this way XML acts like a meta-language: a language that allows us to create or define other languages. For example, with XML we can create other languages, such as RSS.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>In short, XML is:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>designed to transport and store data; and</li>\n<li>a flexible text format derived from SGML (ISO 8879).</li>\n<li>a markup language much like HTML</li>\n<li>designed to be self-descriptive</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>The design goals of XML emphasize simplicity, generality, and usability over the Internet. It is a textual data format with strong support via Unicode for the languages of the world. Although the design of XML focuses on documents, it is widely used for the representation of arbitrary data structures \u2013 for example in web services, configuration/settings, and GUI, workflow, and task definition.</p>\n\n<p>Many application programming interfaces (APIs) have been developed to aid software developers with processing XML data, and several <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XML_schema_languages" rel="nofollow">schema languages</a> exist to aid in the definition of XML-based languages. Schemas are usually defined with an external namespace, but XML also allows you to define tags within the document itself.</p>\n\n<p><b>XML Technologies</b></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XQuery" rel="nofollow">XQuery</a> (the XML Query language) is a language for querying XML documents much like querying relational databases.</li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XPath" rel="nofollow">XPath</a> (the XML Path language) is a language for finding information in an XML document; it is a subset of of XQuery.</li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/XSLT" rel="nofollow">XSLT</a> (eXtensible Stylesheet Language Transformations) is used to transform XML documents.</li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XLink" rel="nofollow">XLink</a> (the XML Linking language) defines methods for creating links within XML documents.</li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XPointer" rel="nofollow">XPointer</a> (the XML Pointer language) allows hyperlinks to point to specific parts (fragments) of XML documents.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Example Document</h2>\n\n<p>The following text is defined using <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/" rel="nofollow">XHTML</a> and <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/xml/#dt-entref" rel="nofollow">entity references</a>; the text serves as an example of XML syntax and structure:</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-xml prettyprint-override"><code>&lt;?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?&gt;\n&lt;!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN"\n  "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd" [\n  &lt;!ENTITY hello "Hello, World!"&gt;\n]&gt;\n&lt;html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"&gt;\n  &lt;head&gt;\n    &lt;meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" /&gt;\n    &lt;title&gt;&amp;hello;&lt;/title&gt;\n  &lt;/head&gt;\n  &lt;body&gt;\n    &lt;div&gt;&amp;hello;&lt;/div&gt;\n  &lt;/body&gt;\n&lt;/html&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<h2>Resources</h2>\n\n<p>The following links provide additional information to learn about XML:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3.org/XML/" rel="nofollow">W3C\'s XML overview</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/xml/" rel="nofollow">W3C\'s XML specification</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xml_namespace" rel="nofollow"><em>XML namespace</em> on Wikipedia</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/xml/" rel="nofollow">XML resources on IBM developerWorks</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/XML" rel="nofollow">XML in the Mozilla Developer Network (MDN) Glossary</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.jclark.com/xml/" rel="nofollow">James Clark\'s XML Resources</a></li>\n</ul>',
	 'name': 'xml',
	 'qcount': 105688,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/xml/info'}
2015-01-03 09:40:44+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/xslt/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751339/how-do-i-prevent-character-escaping-in-php-xslt)
2015-01-03 09:40:44+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/xslt/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>XSLT is a transformation language for XML designed to transform structured documents into other formats (such as XML, HTML, and plain text). Questions should use one of the xslt-1.0, xslt-2.0, or xslt-3.0 tags as appropriate.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<h1>XSLT</h1>\n\n<p>Extensible Stylesheet Language Transformations (XSLT) is a programming language for transforming <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XML" rel="nofollow">XML</a> documents into other XML documents, text documents, or <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Html" rel="nofollow">HTML</a> documents. Other output formats are possible (e.g., <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portable_Document_Format" rel="nofollow">PDF</a> transformations using <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XSL_Formatting_Objects" rel="nofollow">XSL-FO</a>).</p>\n\n<p>The original document is not changed; rather, a new document is created based on the content of an existing one. Typically, input documents are XML files, but anything from which the processor can build an XQuery and XPath Data Model can be used, for example relational database tables, or geographical information systems.</p>\n\n<p>A typical transformation is accomplished as follows:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>A stylesheet is created (typically a <code>.xsl</code> file).</li>\n<li>An XML data source is created (such as a <code>.xml</code> file).</li>\n<li>The XSLT processor is loaded with both the XSL and XML content.</li>\n<li>The XML document is parsed into an XPath Data Model (<a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-datamodel" rel="nofollow">XDM</a>) tree (XDM is similar to <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Document_Object_Model" rel="nofollow">DOM</a>).</li>\n<li>The XDM tree is traversed to produce a resulting document.</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>XSLT syntax is based on XML, which means that XSL documents also are well-formed XML documents. XSLT, with heavy emphasis on recursion, borrows principles from functional languages, including: declarative programming, pattern matching, and immutable variables. </p>\n\n<p>As XSL is written in an XML format, its verbosity does not make it the first choice for general-purpose programming. When used correctly, XSL transformations produce elegant solutions to complex problems that are harder to solve in imperative languages.</p>\n\n<h2>XSLT Processors and Libraries</h2>\n\n<p>Various XSL transformation processors and libraries include:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.saxonica.com/" rel="nofollow">SAXON</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://xml.apache.org/xalan-j/" rel="nofollow">Xalan-Java</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.xml.xsl.aspx" rel="nofollow">MSXSL</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.exslt.org/" rel="nofollow">EXSLT</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://fxsl.sourceforge.net/" rel="nofollow">FXSL</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://xsltsl.sourceforge.net/" rel="nofollow">XSLT Standard Library</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://kernowforsaxon.sourceforge.net/" rel="nofollow">Kernow</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://johannburkard.de/software/xsltjs/" rel="nofollow">xslt.js</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>History</h2>\n\n<p>XSLT was proposed by the <a href="http://www.w3.org/" rel="nofollow">W3C</a> and has three standards: <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/xslt" rel="nofollow">1.0</a>, <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/xslt20/" rel="nofollow">2.0</a> and <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/xslt-30/" rel="nofollow">3.0</a> (This has been recently standardised).</p>\n\n<h2>Question Tags</h2>\n\n<p>Questions should use one of the <a href="/questions/tagged/xslt-1.0" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'xslt-1.0\'" rel="tag">xslt-1.0</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/xslt-2.0" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'xslt-2.0\'" rel="tag">xslt-2.0</a>, or <a href="/questions/tagged/xslt-3.0" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'xslt-3.0\'" rel="tag">xslt-3.0</a> tags as appropriate to clarify what XSLT version the question requires or references.</p>\n\n<h2>Resources</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3.org/standards/xml/transformation" rel="nofollow">XML Transformation resources on the W3C</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XSLT" rel="nofollow">XSLT on Wikipedia</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XML" rel="nofollow">XML on Wikipedia</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3schools.com/xsl/tryxslt.asp?xmlfile=cdcatalog&amp;xsltfile=cdcatalog" rel="nofollow">Online XSLT Editor for Learning Purpose</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Online Training Courses</h2>\n\n<ol>\n<li><strong><a href="http://pluralsight.com/training/Courses/TableOfContents/xslt-foundations-part1" rel="nofollow">Foundations of XSLT 2 and XSLT 1</a></strong>    A Pluralsight course by Dimitre Novatchev</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.pluralsight.com/courses/xpath-3-0-whats-new" rel="nofollow"><strong>The Evolution of XPath: What\u2019s New in XPath 3.0</strong></a> -- A Pluralsight video-course (4.5h)</li>\n</ol>',
	 'name': 'xslt',
	 'qcount': 19665,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/xslt/info'}
