2015-01-03 09:40:46+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27747449/32-bit-c-kernel-weird-continous-redrawing-when-rendering-to-vga> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c)
2015-01-03 09:40:46+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:46+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/assembly/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:46+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/kernel/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:47+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27747449/32-bit-c-kernel-weird-continous-redrawing-when-rendering-to-vga>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>The most obvious issue I see is that your logic for addressing VGA memory is wonky.</p>\n\n<p>You declare a pointer to video memory as a <code>unsigned char *</code>:</p>\n\n<pre><code>unsigned char* terminal_buffer;\n...\nstatic unsigned char* const VGA_MEMORY = (unsigned char*) 0xB8000;\n...\nterminal_buffer = VGA_MEMORY;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>However, you are then trying to write full VGA character values into each position, e.g. in <code>terminal_init()</code>:</p>\n\n<pre><code>  const unsigned int index = r * VGA_WIDTH + c;\n  terminal_buffer[index] = make_vga_entry(\' \', terminal_color);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>You aren\'t multiplying the index by 2, so this ends up writing the lower 8 bits of a VGA entry (in this case, <code>0x20</code>) into each memory location in the VGA buffer. This causes strange results when you start writing text to the terminal, as every other byte ends up interpreted as an attribute pair instead of a character!</p>\n\n<p>Thankfully, the solution is simple: declare <code>terminal_buffer</code> as an array of 16-bit elements:</p>\n\n<pre><code>uint16_t *terminal_buffer = VGA_MEMORY;\n^^^^^^^^\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>(P.S: I recommend taking a look at <a href="http://wiki.osdev.org/VGA_Hardware" rel="nofollow">the OSDev article on VGA hardware</a>.)</p>',
	              'comments': [u"I don't have support for uint16_t, is there any way to get around this? Also, I tried multiplying my index by 2 every time I use it in the video buffer but my problem still occurs, any thoughts?",
	                           u' to define that type.',
	                           u'This still does not help, I changed terminal_buffer to be of type uint16_t* and my emulator is still constantly redrawing everything. I did notice that when I multiply my index by 2, I can see every other letter of the emulator start up text disappear and reappear in the constant redrawing. Any clue as to the issue then?'],
	              'extid': 27747893,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27747449/32-bit-c-kernel-weird-continous-redrawing-when-rendering-to-vga/27747893#27747893',
	              'user_id': 149341,
	              'vote': 1}],
	 'body': u'<p>I am having trouble setting up any kind of functionality to my Kernel that I am writing in C. 2015-01-03 09:40:47+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27747768/gtk-issues-closing-on-callback-not-supposed-cairo-not-drawing-separators-do>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>The <code>GtkMenuItem *</code> witdget\'s name is <code>help_manual</code> it conflicts with the function name, and in the scope of the <code>main()</code> function you are passing a pointer to <code>GtkMenuItem</code> instead of a callback since there your <code>help_manual</code> is a pointer of type <code>GtkMenuItem</code> and not a function, the fix is to rename the callback</p>\n\n<pre><code>static void\nhelp_manual_callback(GtkMenuItem *item, gpointer data)\n{\n  fprintf(stderr, "ajuda!\\n");\n\n  if (fork() == 0)\n  {\n    system("xdg-open GCDmanual.pdf");\n    _exit(0);\n  }\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>and to connect</p>\n\n<pre><code>  g_signal_connect(G_OBJECT(help_manual), "activate", \n                       G_CALLBACK(help_manual_callback), NULL);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>and always do that, add a suffix or prefix to identify the variable type, it makes it easier to keep track of types.</p>\n\n<p>This will fix the crash, the drawing issue is something that depends on geometry and other stuff so you should check it to see if it\'s drawing to the right place.</p>\n\n<p>The visibility of the separator could be a theme issue, may be those aren\'t visible with your current theme.</p>\n\n<p>Also, you should <code>fork()</code> to show the manual in a new process and keep your process running, you could use threads but I don\'t think they are useful in this simple situation. <code>fork()</code> + <code>system()</code> is ok here. Although you might want to make it more robust by specifiying  the full path to the help pdf file.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Extra</strong>: you must make your code follow it\'s own logic, I would create functions for each GUI part, for instance <code>createToolbar()</code> and <code>createMenu()</code> and such. It makes it easier to read.</p>',
	              'comments': [u'It does not make much sense to downvoate the ',
	                           u' answer without commenting, since that may confuse the OP.',
	                           u'They worked, the only issue now is the drawing, which was supposed to be in vbox3_field',
	                           u"@allg18 try to check your code, and if you find any thing you don't understand ask another question, this question as is looks to me like ",
	                           u' so you should be ',
	                           u', I can try to help you I have some ',
	                           u' drawing knowledge, ask another question and I can see.'],

2015-01-03 09:40:48+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748519/why-do-the-following-have-the-same-value-the-pointer-to-an-array-the-dereferen>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>In this statement</p>\n\n<pre><code>int (*ptr)[5] = &amp;array;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>pointer ptr is initialized by the address of the array. The address of the array is the address of its first element that is of the first row.</p>\n\n<p>Expression</p>\n\n<pre><code>*ptr;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>gives you reference to this first element that is to the one-dimensional array - the first row or more precisely to the original array..</p>\n\n<p>In turn in expressions arrays are converted to pointers to their first elements and <code>*ptr</code> that is equivalent to expression <code>array</code> is converted to rvalue of type pointer that points to the first element of array <code>*ptr</code>.:)\nThat is expression <code>*ptr</code> will have type <code>int *</code>\nThe address of the first row and the address of the first element of the first row is the same.\nNow you have two pointers, <code>ptr</code> and <code>*ptr</code> the first one has type <code>int ( * )[5]</code> while the second one has type <code>int *</code> but the both have the same value.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27748796,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748519/why-do-the-following-have-the-same-value-the-pointer-to-an-array-the-dereferen/27748796#27748796',
	              'user_id': 2877241,
	              'vote': 2},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>If you look at the memory layout of a 1D array such as </p>\n\n<pre><code>int array[5];\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>it will make sense.</p>\n\n<pre><code>        array\n          |\n          V \n+---+---+---+---+---+---+\n|   |   |   |   |   |   |\n+---+---+---+---+---+---+\n\n  array[0]\n  |\n  V \n+---+---+---+---+---+---+\n|   |   |   |   |   |   |\n+---+---+---+---+---+---+\n\nAddress of array\n|\nV \n+---+---+---+---+---+---+\n|   |   |   |   |   |   |\n+---+---+---+---+---+---+\n\nAddress of array[0]\n|\nV \n+---+---+---+---+---+---+\n|   |   |   |   |   |   |\n+---+---+---+---+---+---+\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>i.e. <code>&amp;array == &amp;array[0] == array decayed to a pointer</code></p>\n\n<p>With a pointer declared as:</p>\n\n<pre><code>int (*ptr)[5] = &amp;array;\n\nptr == &amp;array\n*ptr == array decayed to a pointer == &amp;array[0] == &amp;array\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>That\'s why you see the same value printed when you use:</p>\n\n<pre><code>printf("%p, %p", *ptr, ptr);\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27748717,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748519/why-do-the-following-have-the-same-value-the-pointer-to-an-array-the-dereferen/27748717#27748717',
	              'user_id': 434551,
	              'vote': 1},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Since <code>printf</code> is a variadic function, the <a href="http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/variadic_arguments" rel="nofollow">ellipsis conversion sequences</a> are applied to the arguments. In particular, arrays are <a href="http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/array#Array_to_pointer_decay" rel="nofollow">decayed</a> to a pointer of the underlying type : IOW, it is implicitly converted to a pointer to the first element of the array. Thus, when you call <code>printf("%p, %p", *ptr, ptr);</code>, <code>*ptr</code>, which is of type <code>int[5]</code> is converted to an <code>int*</code> with value <code>&amp;array[0]</code>.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27748858,

	              'vote': 1}],

Why is this?</p>',

	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<pre class="lang-c prettyprint-override"><code>#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n#include &lt;string.h&gt;\n#include &lt;unistd.h&gt;\n#include &lt;sys/socket.h&gt;\n#include &lt;sys/un.h&gt;\n#include &lt;netinet/in.h&gt;\n#include &lt;netdb.h&gt;\n\n\nvoid decode_iaddr(char ** phost, char ** pip, unsigned short * pp,\n                  struct sockaddr_in nom) {\n    union {\n        uint32_t unb;\n        unsigned char qnb[4];\n    } aip;\n    struct hostent * info=gethostbyaddr((char *)&amp;nom.sin_addr.s_addr,4,AF_INET);\n    if (info) asprintf(phost,"%s",info-&gt;h_name);\n    else asprintf(phost,"%s","(unknown)");\n    *pp=ntohs(nom.sin_port);\n    aip.unb=nom.sin_addr.s_addr;\n    asprintf(pip,"%d.%d.%d.%d", aip.qnb[0], aip.qnb[1], aip.qnb[2], aip.qnb[3]);\n}\n\n\nint main () {\n  int sock;\n  int taille=sizeof(struct sockaddr_un), connexion;\n  struct sockaddr_in serv_addr, cli_addr;\n    char * hostname, * ip;\n    unsigned short port;\n\n  //initialize  socket-serveur\n\n  sock = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0);\n    bzero((char *) &amp;serv_addr, sizeof(serv_addr));\n    serv_addr.sin_family        = AF_INET;\n    serv_addr.sin_addr.s_addr   = htonl(INADDR_ANY);\n    serv_addr.sin_port      = htons(6500);\n\n  bind(sock, (struct sockaddr *) &amp;serv_addr, sizeof(serv_addr));\n\n  taille = sizeof(cli_addr);\n\n  listen(sock,5);\n\n  while (1) {\n    connexion= accept(sock, (struct sockaddr *) &amp;cli_addr,&amp;taille);\n    if (!fork()) { printf("ok\\n");\n      decode_iaddr(&amp;hostname,&amp;ip,&amp;port,cli_addr);\n      fprintf(stderr,"%d : connecting with %s(%s):%d\\n",\n      getpid(),hostname,ip,port);\n    dup2(connexion,STDIN_FILENO);\n    dup2(connexion,STDOUT_FILENO);\n    execl("your_command","your_command",0);\n    exit(1);\n      }\n      close(connexion);\n\n  }\n}\n</code></pre>',

2015-01-03 09:40:51+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748986/easiest-way-to-simulate-the-maximum-cpu-load> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c)
2015-01-03 09:40:51+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:51+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/multithreading/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:51+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/simulation/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:51+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/cpu-usage/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:51+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748986/easiest-way-to-simulate-the-maximum-cpu-load>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>Your code is serial. You have eight available threads (4 cores * 2 threads per core = 8 total threads), and your current code uses one of them for <code>1 thread / 8 available = 12.5%</code> of your CPU. If you have to write your own code (and not use a pre-existing intensive code as already suggested by others), I would recommend putting a <code>#pragma omp parallel</code> above your <code>while</code> loop and compiling with the <code>-fopenmp</code> flag (assuming you are using MinGW, if not, the exact option may vary) so that you use all of the available threads instead.</p>',
	              'comments': [u"Wow! Why didn't I think of OpenMP?! It did instantly use 100% of my i7 when I compiled this code with /openmp on MSVC2013. I think this will as well work with Linux... Going to try right now.",
	                           u"@MarkMiles: Indeed it should work with Linux as well, unless you've changed the environment variable ",
	                           u' to be something less than the maximum number of threads available on the machine.',
	                           u'In fact it works. Thanks!'],
	              'extid': 27749078,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748986/easiest-way-to-simulate-the-maximum-cpu-load/27749078#27749078',
	              'user_id': 125405,
	              'vote': 2},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>It depends a bit on what you mean by "maximum CPU load".</p>\n\n<p>With regards to CPU usage, basically anything will work. Just keep in mind that you\'ll need as many threads (or as many instances of the executable) as your CPU has cores.</p>\n\n<p>What you will need to keep in mind, though, is that CPU usage is not the be-all and end-all of power usage in a SoC. Other aspects which you will need to keep in mind include:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>Memory access. The application you\'re currently using doesn\'t touch memory at all.</p></li>\n<li><p>Other on-die peripherals, such as flash controllers, SPI/I2C/UART drivers, etc.</p></li>\n<li><p>A GPU, if your SoC includes one. (This will easily dwarf the power usage of everything else I\'ve mentioned so far!)</p></li>\n<li><p>Off-die peripherals: flash, memory, display, battery chargers, whatever else is in your device.</p></li>\n</ul>',
	              'comments': [u"It's all correct, but I have mentioned the CPU alone because the final application of this SoC will mostly employ the CPU and not all the rest. The GPU won't work at all since the OS is GUI-less; the disk will only be used for booting up; memory and other controllers will have a minor usage. 2015-01-03 09:40:52+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:52+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/regex/info

2015-01-03 09:40:52+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748999/regex-matching-in-c>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>The code is using the POSIX regular expression code from <code>&lt;regex.h&gt;</code>.  You can find the information about <a href="http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/functions/regcomp.html" rel="nofollow"><code>regcomp()</code></a> and <code>regexec()</code> online.</p>\n\n<p>There are two problems with the code posted:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/users/1324/paul-roub">Paul Roub</a> correctly <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748999/regex-matching-in-c#comment43909345_27748999">identified</a> that the slashes in the regex string are not required.</p></li>\n<li><p><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/users/15168/jonathan-leffler">Jonathan Leffler</a> correctly <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748999/regex-matching-in-c#comment43909424_27748999">identified</a> that the regular expressions processed by <code>regcomp()</code> and <code>regexec()</code> are \'basic regular expressions\' or BRE, but the notation is trying to use \'extended regular expressions\' or ERE.  And the way to request ERE support is via the <code>REG_EXTENDED</code> flag as one of the flags in the third argument to <code>regcomp()</code>.</p></li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>In a <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748999/regex-matching-in-c#comment43909464_27748999">comment</a>, <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/users/3486006/user3486006">user3486006</a> confirms that both changes (and adding <code>REG_NOSUB</code> to the <code>regcomp()</code>) means that it works.  See the manual page for what <code>REG_NOSUB</code> does; the match would have worked with or without the flag, but adding the flag is sensible in this context.</p>\n\n<p><sup><em>Community Wiki answer: if Paul posts an answer, accept it, please.</em></sup></p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27749259,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748999/regex-matching-in-c/27749259#27749259',
	              'user_id': None,
	              'vote': 1}],
	 'body': u'<p>I\'m writing a parser that analyze the content passed in parameter and compare to a regex.\nThis parser should return boolean if found a structure of variable :</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>int a;</p>\n  \n  <p>double abc;</p>\n  \n  <p>char test;</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>Those variables should match but not...</p>\n\n<p>Here is my code, I thought my regex is true..</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include "includes.h"\n\nint check_match_var(char *str)\n{\n  int err;\n  int match;\n  regex_t preg;\n  char err_buf[BUFSIZ];\n  const char *regex = "/^(int|char|float|double) [a-zA-Z0-9]{1,};/";\n\n  err = regcomp(&amp;preg, regex, 0);\n  printf("Err : %d\\n", err);\n  if (err == 0)\n    {\n      match = regexec(&amp;preg, str, 0, NULL, 0);\n      regfree(&amp;preg);\n      if (match == 0)\n    printf("Match !\\n");\n      else\n    printf("No match !\\n");\n    }\n  else\n    {\n      regerror(err, &amp;preg, err_buf, BUFSIZ);\n      printf("regcomp: %s\\n", err_buf);\n      return (1);\n    }\n  return (0);\n}\n\nint marvin(char **av)\n{\n  check_match_var(av[1]);\n  return (0);\n}\n\nint main(int ac, char **av)\n{\n  if (ac == 2)\n    {\n      marvin(av);\n    }\n  else\n    printf("\\n");\n  return (0);\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Anyway it return 1 (no match), I want it return 0 (match)..</p>\n\n<p>Includes file :</p>\n\n<pre><code>#ifndef INCLUDES_H_\n\n#define INCLUDES_H_\n#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n#include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;\n#include &lt;string.h&gt;\n#include &lt;regex.h&gt; \n#endif\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Thanks for help</p>',
	 'comments': [u"I don't think POSIX regexes want the leading/trailing ",
	              u' characters - they may be treated as part of the actual regex pattern.',
	              u"I've added them after the bug, trying to see if changes something",
	              u"The slashes are one problem, but where there's one, there are often several, and this is no exception.  Since you don't include REG_EXTENDED in the third argument to ",
	              u', the ',
	              u' and ',
	              u' and ',
	              u' are not metacharacters.',
	              u"Works with mine / @JonathanLeffler's suggestions: ",
	              u'Thanks @JonathanLeffler! Worked adding REG_NOSUB | REG_EXTENDED'],

	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>I assume that you mean that you have:</p>\n\n<pre><code>char *name = "fred";\nchar *format = "/home/user/Desktop/name.jpg";\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>And you\'d like to take that and then <em>do something</em> such that you have as a result:</p>\n\n<pre><code>char *result = "/home/user/Desktop/fred.jpg";\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>To do this, you need to allocate some memory (or allocate enough somewhere else), and then use <code>sprintf()</code> or <code>snprintf()</code>:</p>\n\n<pre><code>char *name   = "fred";\nchar *format = "/home/user/Desktop/%s.jpg";\n\nchar *result = malloc(strlen(format) - 2 + strlen(name) + 1);\nsprintf(result, format, name);\n\nprintf("%s\\n", result); // Output is "/home/user/Desktop/fred.jpg"\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [u'How did you understand that? this is the right answer.'],

The first thing that comes to mind is <code>memcpy</code></p>\n\n<pre><code>char* name = "/home/user/Desktop/name.jpg"; \nchar* path;\n\nsize_t len = strlen(name);\npath = malloc(len + 1); /* plus 1 for the null terminator */\n\nif(path == NULL) exit(1);\n\nmemcpy(path, name, 1 + len);\n\n/* do whatever */\n\nfree(path);\n</code></pre>',

	              u' is not, in general, wrong, and does what you ask for.',
	              u'Be careful here - the issue is string handling in C is not obvious.  A char * is just a pointer to the first character in the string; somehow, there needs to be memory allocated to the thing at which it points.  strdup() is a safe way to copy an existing string.  Scanf() is dangerous for reading into a string buffer as it can easily overflow the target buffer unless the format string limits the input properly.',

	              'body': u"<p>The linker only includes used objects in the final binary, if the array isn't used it won't be included. </p>\n\n<p>Cast it to void somewhere:</p>\n\n<pre><code> main()\n   {\n    (void)funcarray;\n\n   }\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>then it will count as being used.</p>",
	              'comments': [],

2015-01-03 09:40:55+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27749381/passing-as-an-argument-to-a-program-in-bash> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c)
2015-01-03 09:40:55+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:55+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/linux/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:55+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/bash/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:55+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27749381/passing-as-an-argument-to-a-program-in-bash>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>This appears to be a known bug in bash, fixed in version 4.3.16. It occurs only if the <code>extglob</code> feature is enabled, for example if you have a command like</p>\n\n<pre><code>shopt -s extglob\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>in your <code>.bashrc</code> or some other init file.</p>\n\n<p>I can reproduce it consistently with bash 4.3.11 on Linux Mint 17:</p>\n\n<pre><code>$ bash --norc\nbash-4.3$ mkdir empty\nbash-4.3$ cd empty\nbash-4.3$ echo *()\nbash: syntax error near unexpected token `(\'\nbash-4.3$ shopt -s extglob\nbash-4.3$ echo *()\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>The shell hangs after the last command.  Note that I ran it in an empty directory; the problem also occurs in a non-empty directory.</p>\n\n<p>The bash manual documents a form of wildcard that\'s enabled only when <code>extglob</code> is enabled:</p>\n\n<pre><code>`*(PATTERN-LIST)\'\n     Matches zero or more occurrences of the given patterns.\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Given <code>*()</code>, that\'s zero or more occurrences of the empty string. Since there are infinitely many occurrences of the empty string in any string, I can see how that might cause an infinite loop if there\'s no special-case code to avoid it.</p>\n\n<p>And it appears to have been fixed in a later version. I see the problem in 4.3.11 but not in 4.3.30. rici\'s comment suggests that patch 016 is likely to have fixed it. And the <a href="http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/bug-bash/2014-04/msg00100.html" rel="nofollow">bug report</a> corresponding to the patch includes this:</p>\n\n<pre><code>1) bash gets stuck\n\nshopt -s extglob\necho !(*/) # never returns, cannot be interrupted\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>which I\'d say confirms that that\'s the bug.</p>',

	              'body': u"<pre><code>int i = 0; j = 1, k, n = (your value);\n\nif ( n &gt; 0 )\n{\n    while ( 2 * j &lt; n) \n    {\n        j = 2 * j; \n        i++;\n    }\n\n    k = n - j;\n}\n\n// replace '&lt;' with '&lt;=' if k = 0 is desired where n is a pure power of 2\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>(nb: there is no exponentiation operator in Standard C)</p>",

	              'extid': 27750416,

	              'vote': 2},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Elegance is in the mind of the beholder.</p>\n\n<pre><code>unsigned long find_remnant(unsigned long n) {\n  for (unsigned long j, k = 0;\n       (j = n&amp;-n) != n;\n       n -= j, k += j ) {\n  }\n  return k;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>This is based on the fact that <code>n&amp;-n</code> is the lowest-order <code>1</code> bit in the binary representation of n. So the loop strips off the one-bits from n, one at a time, accumulating them in k, until only a single one-bit is left, which must be 2^i.</p>\n\n<p>Since the loop executes once per set bit in <code>n</code>, rather than once per bit in <code>n</code>, it might be faster.</p>\n\n<p>In case it is an issue, since <code>0&amp;-0</code> is 0, if called with an argument of <code>0</code> (contrary to the problem specification), the function will simply return <code>0</code>, which is not an unreasonable result. </p>',
	              'comments': [],

2015-01-03 09:40:57+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/3686271/rob> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c)
2015-01-03 09:40:57+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c/info

2015-01-03 09:40:57+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/precedence/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:57+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750063/precedence-functions-and-order-of-evaluation-kr>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>They mean that it is up to the C compiler implementation whether to evaluate the left side of the <code>+</code> first over the right side, or vice versa before applying the <code>+</code> operator to those results.  This is important if <code>f()</code> and <code>g()</code> perform what are called <em>side effects</em>.  If <code>f()</code> modifies some global variable, and <code>g()</code> modifies the same global variable, the modification performed by <code>f()</code> will prevail if the C compiler evaluates right-to-left, while the modification performed by <code>g()</code> will prevail if the compiler evaluates left-to-right.</p>',
	              'comments': [u"It is worth noting that the compiler doesn't have to treat the same expression the same way each time it encounters it; it may choose to compile the code differently depending on surrounding context.  New runs of the same compiler, or new versions of the compiler, or different compilers -- all of those may also give different results.  While most compilers are in fact deterministic, they're not obliged to be as long as they follow the 'as if' rule."],
	              'extid': 27750097,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750063/precedence-functions-and-order-of-evaluation-kr/27750097#27750097',
	              'user_id': 1009479,
	              'vote': 4},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>What is confusing is that the standard says that <code>+</code> associates left-to-right, but this does not means that each sub expression of a sum is evaluated from left to right! Order of evaluation of sub-expressions is not specified. Thus if you have:</p>\n\n<pre><code>f() + g() + h()\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>then the compiler is free to generate something like:</p>\n\n<pre><code>t1 = h()\nt2 = f()\nt3 = g()\n(t2+t3)+t1\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>It is the same problem for expressions like <code>i++ + ++i</code> for which many programmers fail about.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753479,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750063/precedence-functions-and-order-of-evaluation-kr/27753479#27753479',
	              'user_id': 719263,
	              'vote': 0}],
	 'body': u'<p>I read from the book <strong><em>K&amp;R</em></strong> an example of precedence: </p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p><code>x = f() + g();</code><br></p>\n  \n  <p>f may be evaluated before g or vice versa</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>What I know is that the order of evaluation of paraentheses <code>()</code> is higher than the <code>+</code> and after that comes the <code>=</code> . Besides for the <code>()</code> the order of evaluation will be from <strong>left to right</strong>. So if I am right why did he say <strong>may be evaluated</strong> as if it is <strong>not certain</strong> ? </p>\n\n<p>The question is a little bit silly but very important for me to clear the unclear.</p>',
	 'comments': [u"There's no sequence points between ",
	              u' and ',
	              u', so the compiler can do what it likes.  Expressions in C, as a general rule, are ',
	              u' evaluated left-to-right.',
	              u'See also ',
	              u"For the binary operators, the 'left to right' note in the table of precedences means that ",
	              u' has to be interpreted as ',
	              u' rather than as ',
	              u'.  It also means that ',
	              u' is interpreted as ',
	              u' rather than ',
	              u".  However, that doesn't stop ",
	              u' being evaluated before either ',
	              u' or ',
	              u'; the order in which the operands are evaluated is still up to the compiler.',
	              u'Thanks I just found it ! :D',
	              u'In the context shown (',
	              u'), you have a comma operator.  The comma operator is defined to evaluate its LHS (',
	              u") completely, then there's a sequence point, and then it evaluates its RHS (",
	              u') completely, and assigns that to ',
	              u'.  Now, ',
	              u' could be evaluated before either ',
	              u' or ',
	              u', or after both ',
	              u' and ',
	              u'; in theory, it could probably be evaluated elsewhere in the expression too, but it is pretty unlikely that the compiler would do that.  However, all of ',
	              u' is evaluated before anything of ',
	              u' is evaluated.'],
	 'extid': 27750063,
	 'tags': [u'c', u'function', u'operator-precedence', u'precedence'],
	 'title': u'precedence functions and order of evaluation K&R',
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750063/precedence-functions-and-order-of-evaluation-kr',
	 'user_id': 827263,
	 'vote': 0}

2015-01-03 09:40:58+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750206/value-of-pointer-still-available-after-function-call>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>Nested functions are not standard c, it\'s an <a href="http://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Nested-Functions.html" rel="nofollow">extension</a> of gcc, so your code wont always compile, and it does work because of the gcc extension.</p>\n\n<p>The reason why that is true has nothing to do with nested functions, if you execute the following you will observe the exact same behavior</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n\nchar *foo()\n{\n    char* test="Hello";\n    printf("value of test: %p\\n",test);\n    return test;\n\n}\n\nint main()\n{\n    // why does this work? is test off the stack, but Hello in mem is still there?\n    char *work = foo();\n\n    printf("value of work after work has been initalized by foo(): %p\\n",work);\n    printf("%s\\n",work);\n\n    return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>the function <code>foo()</code> is returning the address to a static string which remains through the lifetime of the program.</p>\n\n<p>I your instead create an array, you would return the address to a local variable which is not possible</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n\nint main()\n{\n\n    char *foo()\n    {\n        char test[] = "Hello";\n\n        printf("value of test: %p\\n", test);\n        printf("value of foo: %p\\n", foo);\n\n        return test;\n    }\n\n    // why does this work? is test off the stack, but Hello in mem is still there?\n    char *work = foo();\n\n    printf("value of work after work has been initalized by foo(): %p\\n",work);\n    printf("%s\\n",work);\n\n    return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>the compiler will issue a warning in the last case and <code>printf("%s\\n",work);</code> would print garbage although <code>printf("value of work after work has been initalized by foo(): %p\\n",work);</code> would print the same address, the data will be destroyed with the stack frame of <code>foo</code>.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27750265,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750206/value-of-pointer-still-available-after-function-call/27750265#27750265',
	              'user_id': 1983495,
	              'vote': 6},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>(As it has been noted, nested functions are not allowed in C language.)</p>\n\n<p>Nevertheless, in C language string literals are object with static storage duration. They are not stored "on the stack", as you seem to incorrectly assume. They are stored in static memory, just like global variables.</p>\n\n<p>The code of your <code>foo</code> function is equivalent to</p>\n\n<pre><code>static char unnamed_string_literal[] = { \'H\', \'e\', \'l\', \'l\', \'o\', \'\\0\' };\n\nchar* foo()\n{\n  char* test = unnamed_string_literal;\n  printf("value of test: %p\\n", test);\n  return test;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>This is why value of the string literal <code>"Hello"</code> will always be available as long as your program runs. And every time you call your <code>foo</code>, you will get back exactly the same pointer value.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27750469,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750206/value-of-pointer-still-available-after-function-call/27750469#27750469',
	              'user_id': 187690,
	              'vote': 2},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Your foo() function is returning the static string "Hello" which is typically stored in the program text segment.</p>\n\n<p>Since the actual string storage does not live on the stack it survives the function call.</p>\n\n<p>The variable <code>test</code> whilst out of scope is just a pointer and since that pointer value is returned to the caller, the caller now has the location of the string storage.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27750440,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750206/value-of-pointer-still-available-after-function-call/27750440#27750440',
	              'user_id': 2238268,
	              'vote': 1},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Nonstandard nested function definitions notwithstanding, the behavior you\'re seeing here is because the string constant "Hello" is part of the program executable, and is mapped into memory along with the program code when the program is executed.  The pointer simply holds the location in memory at runtime that the string is stored in.  That constant string is part of the program and doesn\'t spring into and out of existence like a stack variable would.  The stack variable is the <em>address</em> of "Hello", and it is passed to the calling stack via return value.  </p>',
	              'comments': [u"It's called static area same space with global variables."],
	              'extid': 27750372,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750206/value-of-pointer-still-available-after-function-call/27750372#27750372',
	              'user_id': 1726083,
	              'vote': 0}],
	 'body': u'<pre><code>#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n//needed so we can use the built in function strcpy\n#include &lt;string.h&gt;\nint main()\n{\nchar* foo()\n    {\n        char* test="Hello";\n        printf("value of test: %p\\n",test);\n        return test;\n\n    }\n\n\n    //why does this work? is test off the stack, but Hello in mem is still there?\n    work=foo();\n    printf("value of work after work has been initalized by foo(): %p\\n",work);\n    printf("%s\\n",work);\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>In the above code, \'work=foo()\', works I noticed that the value of \'test\' and \'work\' are the same. Meaning that they are pointing to the same point in memory, but after the function call \'test\' is out of scope and not allowed to be accessed. Why is \'test\' not allowed to be accessed, but its value/ memory location is? I\'m assuming \'test\' is not allowed to be accessed due to being off the stack after the function call? I\'m new to pointers so if my terminology or anything is off please correct me. </p>',
	 'comments': [u"It's probably because the compiler stores ",
	              u" in some global memory. However, don't rely on such lucky coincidences. What you are trying is cause for undefined behavior.",
	              u"@RSahu No, it's not a lucky coincidence, this behavior(not counting the use of a nested function) is guaranteed. string literals have static storage duration.",
	              u'Thank you, did not realize C did not support nested functions, and was unfamiliar with static memory.'],

2015-01-03 09:40:58+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750532/remove-struct-from-mmaped-array-of-structs>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>The actual changes in functionality?  There were a couple.  First, you must nullify the last entry in the data after you\'ve copied it down the list.  Second, you must recompute the number of entries after you\'ve deleted some.</p>\n\n<p>At the moment, you don\'t have a good way other than EOF of stopping inputs.  That meant I added data with one run of the program; I then had to run the program a second time to delete some data.  However, it seems to work correctly.  I added keys 1, 2, 3, 4 and then removed 2, 4 and the list left was 1, 3, which seems about right to me.</p>\n\n<p><sup><em>I was asked about this by email as a result of answering the related question <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/q/27697228">mmap and struct in C</a>.</em></sup></p>\n\n<pre><code>#define _XOPEN_SOURCE 800\n#include &lt;fcntl.h&gt;\n#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n#include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;\n#include &lt;string.h&gt;\n#include &lt;sys/mman.h&gt;\n#include &lt;sys/stat.h&gt;\n#include &lt;unistd.h&gt;\n\n#define FILEPATH "/tmp/mmapped.bin"\n#define NUM_MEDS 1000\n#define FILESIZE (NUM_MEDS * sizeof(struct med))\n\nstruct med\n{\n    int key;\n    char name[25];\n    int quant_min;\n    int quant;\n};\n\nstatic int find_num_entries(struct med *map, int max_meds);\nstatic int get_new_key(struct med *map, int num_meds, int *key);\nstatic int med_in_map(struct med *map, int num_meds, int key);\nstatic int remove_key_med(struct med *map, int num_meds, int *key);\nstatic int remove_med(struct med *map, int num_meds, int key);\nstatic void insert_med_mmap(void);\nstatic void interface(void);\nstatic void list_meds_mmap(void);\nstatic void load_meds_mmap(void);\nstatic void print_med(char *tag, const struct med *med);\nstatic void remove_med_mmap(void);\nstatic void search_med_mmap(void);\n\nint main(void)\n{\n    interface();\n    return 0;\n}\n\n// interface\nvoid interface(void)\n{\n    printf("\\n");\n    printf("=&gt; Management and administration of Meds \\n");\n    printf("\\n");\n    printf("=&gt; Mmap version \\n");\n    printf("\\n");\n    printf("Choose your operation \\n");\n    printf("1- Insert med \\n");\n    printf("2- Remove med \\n");\n    printf("3- Search med \\n");\n    printf("4- List meds ordered by name \\n");\n    printf("5- Load meds \\n");\n    printf("6- Exit \\n");\n\n    int a;\n    scanf("%d", &amp;a);\n    switch (a)\n    {\n    case 1:\n        printf("\\n");\n        printf("Insert med \\n");\n        insert_med_mmap();\n        break;\n    case 2:\n        printf("\\n");\n        printf("Remove med \\n");\n        remove_med_mmap();\n        break;\n    case 3:\n        printf("\\n");\n        printf("Search med \\n");\n        search_med_mmap();\n        break;\n    case 4:\n        printf("\\n");\n        printf("List meds ordered by name \\n");\n        list_meds_mmap();\n        break;\n    case 5:\n        printf("\\n");\n        load_meds_mmap();\n        break;\n    case 6:\n        return;\n    }\n}\n\nstatic void print_med(char *tag, const struct med *med)\n{\n    printf("%s: %4d: Q(%2d, min %2d): %s\\n",\n           tag, med-&gt;key, med-&gt;quant, med-&gt;quant_min, med-&gt;name);\n}\n\nstatic int med_in_map(struct med *map, int num_meds, int key)\n{\n    int i;\n    for (i = 0; i &lt; num_meds; i++)\n    {\n        if (key == map[i].key)\n        {\n            printf("The med with key %d already exists in the file. \\n", key);\n            return 1;\n        }\n    }\n    return 0;\n}\n\nstatic int get_new_key(struct med *map, int num_meds, int *key)\n{\n    while (printf("Type the key of med: ") &gt; 0 &amp;&amp; scanf("%d", key) == 1)\n    {\n        if (med_in_map(map, num_meds, *key) == 0)\n            return 0;\n    }\n    return EOF;\n}\n\nstatic int find_num_entries(struct med *map, int max_meds)\n{\n    int i;\n    for (i = 0; i &lt; max_meds; i++)\n    {\n        if (map[i].key == 0)\n            break;\n    }\n    return i;\n}\n\nstatic int remove_med(struct med *map, int num_meds, int key)\n{\n    int i;\n    for (i = 0; i &lt; num_meds; i++)\n    {\n        if (key == map[i].key)\n        {\n            for ( ; i &lt; num_meds - 1; i++)\n            {\n                map[i] = map[i + 1];\n            }\n            printf("Med %d removed with sucess\\n", key);\n            map[i].key = 0;\n            map[i].name[0] = \'\\0\';\n            map[i].quant = 0;\n            map[i].quant_min = 0;\n            return 0;\n        }\n    }\n    return 1;\n}\n\nstatic int remove_key_med(struct med *map, int num_meds, int *key)\n{\n    while (printf("Type the key of med: ") &gt; 0 &amp;&amp; scanf("%d", key) == 1)\n    {\n        if (remove_med(map, num_meds, *key) == 0)\n            return 0;\n    }\n    return EOF;\n}\n\n// load meds\nvoid load_meds_mmap(void)\n{\n    printf("Test \\n");\n}\n\n// insert med with mmap\nvoid insert_med_mmap(void)\n{\n    int fd;\n    int result;\n    struct med *map;  /* mmapped array of structs */\n\n    fd = open(FILEPATH, O_RDWR | O_CREAT, (mode_t)0600);\n    if (fd == -1)\n    {\n        perror("Error opening file for writing");\n        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);\n    }\n\n    result = ftruncate(fd, FILESIZE);\n    if (result == -1)\n    {\n        close(fd);\n        perror("Error calling lseek() to \'stretch\' the file");\n        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);\n    }\n\n    map = (struct med *)mmap(0, FILESIZE, PROT_READ | PROT_WRITE, MAP_SHARED, fd, 0);\n    if (map == MAP_FAILED)\n    {\n        close(fd);\n        perror("Error mmapping the file");\n        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);\n    }\n\n    /* Input loop */\n    int num_meds;\n    for (num_meds = find_num_entries(map, NUM_MEDS); num_meds &lt; NUM_MEDS; num_meds++)\n    {\n        struct med m;\n        memset(&amp;m, \'\\0\', sizeof(m));\n\n        if (get_new_key(map, num_meds, &amp;m.key) == EOF)\n            break;\n\n        printf("Name of med: ");\n        if (scanf("%s", m.name) != 1)\n            break;\n        printf("Quant. min. of med: ");\n        if (scanf("%d", &amp;m.quant_min) != 1)\n            break;\n        printf("Quant. of med: ");\n        if (scanf("%d", &amp;m.quant) != 1)\n            break;\n\n        map[num_meds] = m;\n\n        printf("Med %d saved.\\n", m.key);\n    }\n\n    /* Output loop */\n    printf("\\nRecorded meds:\\n");\n    int i;\n    for (i = 0; i &lt; num_meds; i++)\n    {\n        char buffer[32];\n        snprintf(buffer, sizeof(buffer), "M%.4d", i);\n        print_med(buffer, &amp;map[i]);\n    }\n\n    /* Don\'t forget to free the mmapped memory */\n    if (munmap(map, FILESIZE) == -1)\n    {\n        perror("Error un-mmapping the file");\n        /* Decide here whether to close(fd) and exit() or not. Depends... */\n    }\n\n    /* Un-mmapping doesn\'t close the file, so we still need to do that.  */\n    close(fd);\n}\n\n// remove med with mmap\nvoid remove_med_mmap(void)\n{\n    int fd;\n    int result;\n    struct med *map;  /* mmapped array of structs */\n\n    fd = open(FILEPATH, O_RDWR | O_CREAT, (mode_t)0600);\n    if (fd == -1)\n    {\n        perror("Error opening file for writing");\n        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);\n    }\n\n    result = ftruncate(fd, FILESIZE);\n    if (result == -1)\n    {\n        close(fd);\n        perror("Error calling lseek() to \'stretch\' the file");\n        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);\n    }\n\n    /* Now the file is ready to be mmapped.  */\n    map = (struct med *)mmap(0, FILESIZE, PROT_READ | PROT_WRITE, MAP_SHARED, fd, 0);\n    if (map == MAP_FAILED)\n    {\n        close(fd);\n        perror("Error mmapping the file");\n        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);\n    }\n\n    /* Input loop */\n    int num_meds;\n    for (num_meds = find_num_entries(map, NUM_MEDS); num_meds &lt; NUM_MEDS; num_meds++)\n    {\n        struct med m;\n        memset(&amp;m, \'\\0\', sizeof(m));\n\n        if (remove_key_med(map, num_meds, &amp;m.key) == EOF)\n            break;\n    }\n\n    /* Partial bug fix */\n    num_meds = find_num_entries(map, NUM_MEDS);\n\n\n    /* Output loop */\n    printf("\\nRecorded meds:\\n");\n    int i;\n    for (i = 0; i &lt; num_meds; i++)\n    {\n        char buffer[32];\n        snprintf(buffer, sizeof(buffer), "M%.4d", i);\n        print_med(buffer, &amp;map[i]);\n    }\n\n    /* Don\'t forget to free the mmapped memory */\n    if (munmap(map, FILESIZE) == -1)\n    {\n        perror("Error un-mmapping the file");\n        /* Decide here whether to close(fd) and exit() or not. Depends... */\n    }\n\n    /* Un-mmapping doesn\'t close the file, so we still need to do that.  */\n    close(fd);\n    return;\n}\n\nvoid search_med_mmap(void)\n{\n    printf("Test \\n");\n}\n\nvoid list_meds_mmap(void)\n{\n    printf("Test \\n");\n}\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [u'Thank you very much!'],

	 'body': u'<p><b>Problem</b>: I have a struct called "med" to keep information about meds (Key, Name, MinimalQuantity and Quantity), with each med having a unique key. I stored an array of these structs in a memory mapped file, using mmap. Now I want to remove a specific med (struct) from the array, but it is not working...</p>\n\n<p><b> Code </b>:</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include &lt;fcntl.h&gt;\n#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n#include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;\n#include &lt;string.h&gt;\n#include &lt;sys/mman.h&gt;\n#include &lt;sys/stat.h&gt;\n#include &lt;unistd.h&gt;\n\n#define NUM_MEDS 1000 \n#define FILESIZE (NUM_MEDS * sizeof(struct med))\n\nstruct med\n{\n   int key;\n   char name[25];\n   int quant_min;\n   int quant;\n};\n\nint main(void)\n{\n    int fd;\n    int result;\n    struct med *map;  /* mmapped array of structs */\n\n    fd = open("meds.dat", O_RDWR | O_CREAT, (mode_t)0600);\n    if (fd == -1)\n    {\n        perror("Error opening file for writing");\n        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);\n    }\n\n    result = ftruncate(fd, FILESIZE); \n    if (result == -1)\n    {\n        close(fd);\n        perror("Error calling lseek() to \'stretch\' the file");\n        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);\n    }\n\n    /* Now the file is ready to be mmapped.  */\n    map = (struct med *)mmap(0, FILESIZE, PROT_READ | PROT_WRITE, MAP_SHARED, fd, 0);\n    if (map == MAP_FAILED)\n    {\n        close(fd);\n        perror("Error mmapping the file");\n        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);\n    }\n\n    struct med m;\n\n    printf("Please enter the code of med: ");\n    scanf("%d",&amp;m.key);\n\n    int j;\n    for (j = 0; j &lt; NUM_MEDS; j++)\n    {\n        if (m.key == map[j].key)\n        {\n            for(j; j &lt; NUM_MEDS - 1; j++)\n            {\n            map[j] = map[j+1];\n            }\n            printf("Med %d removed with success\\n",m.key);\n            break;\n        }\n     }\n\n     if (munmap(map, FILESIZE) == -1)\n     {\n         perror("Error un-mmapping the file");\n     }\n\n      close(fd);\n      return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Can anybody help?</p>',

2015-01-03 09:40:59+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750655/c-memory-management-queue> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c)
2015-01-03 09:40:59+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:59+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/algorithm/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:59+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/memory/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:59+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/segmentation-fault/info 
2015-01-03 09:40:59+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750655/c-memory-management-queue>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>Your segmentaion fault because of this</p>\n\n<pre><code>int *aux;\n\n*aux = -1;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>you should</p>\n\n<pre><code>aux = malloc(sizeof(int));\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>before</p>\n\n<pre><code>*aux = -1;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>but I don\'t think that is what you want, instead you should just do it</p>\n\n<pre><code>int aux = -1;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>and when calling <code>dequeue</code></p>\n\n<pre><code>dequeue(teste, &amp;aux);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Also I would recomend you fix these other issues</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>You don\'t need to cast <code>malloc</code></li>\n<li>You should check that <code>malloc</code> didn\'t return <code>NULL</code> otherwise you will dereference a \n<code>NULL</code> pointer which is undefined behavior.</li>\n<li><p>Also, your <code>malloc</code> call is passing the wrong size. A possible fix is to use </p>\n\n<pre><code>Queue q = malloc(sizeof(*q));\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>But I would actually recommend to avoid hiding the fact that variables are pointers completely.</p></li>\n<li>You do have a memory leak but that is not a cause for a segmentaion fault, you should just call <code>free(teste)</code> at the end of <code>main()</code>.</li>\n<li>Your <code>main()</code> doesn\'t return you should, also add <code>return 0;</code> at the end of <code>main()</code> after <code>free()</code></li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>I fixed your code, hope this helps</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;\n#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n\n#define MaxQ 100\n\ntypedef {\n    int array[MaxQ];\n    int front;\n    int back;\n    int size;\n} *Queue;\n\n\nQueue init() {\n    Queue q = malloc(sizeof(*q));\n    if (q == NULL)\n        return NULL;\n    q-&gt;front = 0;\n    q-&gt;back = 0;\n    q-&gt;size = 0;\n    return q;\n}\n\nint enqueue(Queue q, int v) { \n    if (q == NULL)\n        return 0;\n    if(q-&gt;size==MaxQ)\n        return 0;\n    q-&gt;array[q-&gt;back] = v;\n    q-&gt;back++;\n    if(q-&gt;back == MaxQ)\n        q-&gt;back = 0;\n    q-&gt;size++;\n    return 1;\n\n}\n\nint dequeue(Queue q, int *v) {\n    if (q == NULL)\n        return 0;\n    if(q-&gt;size == 0)\n        return 0;\n    *v = q-&gt;array[q-&gt;front];\n    q-&gt;front++;\n    if(q-&gt;front == MaxQ)\n        q-&gt;front =0;\n    q-&gt;size--;\n    return 1;\n}\n\nint front(Queue q, int *v) {\n    if (q == NULL)\n        return 0;\n    if(q-&gt;size==0)\n        return 0;\n    *v = q-&gt;array[q-&gt;front];\n    return 1;\n}\n\nint isEmpty(Queue q) {\n    if (q == NULL)\n        return 0;\n    if(q-&gt;size == 0)\n        return 1;\n    return 0;\n}\n\nint main(){\n    Queue teste = init();\n    if (teste == NULL)\n        return -1;\n    int aux;\n\n    aux = -1;\n    printf("Value : %d\\n", aux);\n\n    enqueue(teste,5);\n    enqueue(teste,10);\n    enqueue(teste,15);\n    front(teste, &amp;aux);\n\n    printf("Next costumer: %d\\n", aux );\n\n    dequeue(teste, &amp;aux);\n\n    printf("Costumer %d left queue\\n", aux );\n\n    dequeue(teste, &amp;aux);\n\n    printf("Costumer %d left queue\\n", aux );\n\n    dequeue(teste, &amp;aux);\n\n    printf("Costume %d left queue\\n", aux );\n\n    int random = 10;\n    if(random == 10)\n        printf("asdasdasd\\n");\n    free(teste);\n\n    return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>',

	              'user_id': 4282669,
	              'vote': 3},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>The termination status of the program is handled by the hosting environment in a platform-specific way, i.e. in any way it sees fit. Development environments will usually display the programs\'s termination status. Regular terminals by default do not. </p>\n\n<p>So, stop expecting anything to be printed in response to the returned <code>0</code>. It is not supposed to be printed. You are not supposed to "know" what was returned, unless you take special deliberate steps to find out.</p>\n\n<p>In most cases the termination status will be handled quietly, meaning that most of the time you will not print it. You will analyze it in execution environment and make further decisions based on the results of that analysis. But if you want the hosting execution environment to print it, you can ask it explicitly, by doing <code>echo $?</code> in *nix terminals or <code>echo %ERRORLEVEL%</code> in Windows ones.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27750950,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750906/in-c-should-return-0-print-anything-to-the-console/27750950#27750950',
	              'user_id': 187690,
	              'vote': 2},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u"<p>The return value from <code>main()</code> is the exit code of the program, it's not meant to be printed.</p>\n\n<p>Xcode is reporting the exit code of the program.</p>\n\n<p>If you want to print it on the console just do</p>\n\n<pre><code>./a.out\necho $?\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>If you want to notify the program invoker that something went wrong, then you can <code>return SOME_ERROR_CODE;</code> from <code>main()</code> it's equivalent to <code>exit(SOME_ERROR_CODE);</code>  but it's cleaner to <code>return</code> an error code from <code>main()</code>. </p>\n\n<p>Xcode will just tell you about the <code>exit</code> code of your program and in case you need to know why the program exited then a meaningful <code>exit</code> code value would help.</p>\n\n<p>In the console the <code>$?</code> is a special variable where the exit code of the last command is stored, in <code>sh</code> scripts you will find that often a check for <code>$?</code> is made right after executing a command.</p>",

2015-01-03 09:41:00+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750973/remove-adjacent-words>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>This line is wrong</p>\n\n<pre><code>strcpy(words[k], words[k + 1]);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>the <code>strcpy</code> is doing nothing but copying a word over itself.</p>\n\n<p>You should just check for each word in a <code>while</code> loop until the end of the words array leaving the firs occurance and continuing to seek for the next, also you was not skipping two consecutive spaces, by adding <code>if (strcmp(words[j], " ") != 0) j++</code>  you can skip them</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n#include &lt;string.h&gt;\n\nint equal(char* a, char* b) {\n  if((a[0] == \',\') || (a[0] == \'.\')\n    || (a[0] == \';\') || (b[0] == \',\')\n    || (b[0] == \'.\') || (b[0] == \';\'))\n    return 0;\n  int i = 0, equal = 1;\n  for(; a[i]; ++i) {\n    if((a[i] == \',\') || (a[i] == \'.\')\n      || (a[i] == \';\') || (b[i] == \',\')\n      || (b[i] == \'.\') || (b[i] == \';\'))\n      continue;\n    if(a[i] != b[i])\n      equal = 0;\n  }\n  return equal;\n}\n\nvoid remove_adj_duplicates(char* str)\n{\n  char words[100][256];\n  int i = 0, j = 0, k = 0, n = 0;\n\n  /* copying each and every word from the string */\n  while (str[i] != \'\\0\')\n  {\n    if (str[i] == \' \')\n    {\n      if (strlen(words[j]) == 0)\n        words[j][k++] = \' \';\n      words[j][k] = \'\\0\';\n\n      k = 0;\n      if (strcmp(words[j], " ") != 0)\n      {\n        j++;\n      }\n    } else {\n      words[j][k++] = str[i];\n    }\n    i++;\n  }\n  words[j][k] = \'\\0\';\n  if (strcmp(words[j], " ") != 0)\n  {\n    j++;\n  }\n  n = ++j;\n\n  /* remove duplicate words in the given string */\n  for (i = 0 ; i &lt; n ; i++)\n  {\n    int m;\n\n    m = 1;\n    while (((i + m) &lt; n) &amp;&amp; (equal(words[i], words[i + m]) != 0))\n    {\n      words[i + m][0] = \'\\0\';\n      m++;\n    }\n    i += m - 1;\n  }\n\n  /* print the unique adjacent words */\n  j = 0;\n  for (i = 0; i &lt;= n; i++)\n  {\n    for(k = 0 ; words[i][k] ; ++k)\n      str[j++] = words[i][k];\n    str[j++] = \' \';\n  }\n  str[--j] = \'\\0\';\n}\n\nint main()\n{\n  char string[256] = "its subfields foo can be divided into a variety foo foo  foo foo  foo foo  foo foo  foo foo  foo foo.";\n\n  remove_adj_duplicates(string);\n\n  printf("Result:\\n|%s|\\n", string);\n  printf("However, the result I must get is:\\n");\n  printf("|its subfields foo can be divided into a variety foo    .|\\n");\n  printf("That\'s five whitespaces, one for every double whitespace initially.\\n");\n  return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>',

	              'body': u'<p>Here\'s another take on it:</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n#include &lt;ctype.h&gt;\n\nint main() {\n    char s[256] = "its subfields foo can be divided into a variety foo foo  foo foo  foo  foo  foo foo  foo foo  foo foo.";\n    int w0 = 0;     // offset in s to start of "last" word\n    int len0  = 0;  // length of "last" word (0 if there isn\'t one, like at start and after punctuation)\n    int wx = 0;     // offset in s to write current word (and spaces and punctuation) to\n    int w1 = 0;     // offset in s to "current" word\n\n    while ( 1 ) {\n        int len1, same;\n\n        while ( isblank(s[w1]) ) {  // skip leading whitespace\n            s[wx++] = s[w1];\n            w1++;\n        }\n        if ( s[w1] == 0 )   // at end of message\n            break;\n        if ( !isalpha(s[w1]) ) { // punctuation\n            s[wx++] =s[w1++];\n            w0 = w1;\n            len0 = 0;\n            continue;\n        }\n        same = 1;   // assume current word same as last\n        len1 = 0;\n        while ( isalpha( s[w1+len1] ) ) {   // scan &amp; copy current word\n            s[wx++] = s[w1+len1];\n            if ( s[w0+len1] != s[w1+len1] )\n                same = 0;\n            len1++;\n        }\n        if ( same  &amp;&amp; (len0==len1) ) {  // reset "output"\n            wx -= len1;\n        } else {    // save curent word to last one\n            w0 = w1;\n            len0 = len1;\n        }\n        w1 += len1;\n    }\n    s[wx] = 0;\n    puts( s );\n    return 0;   \n}\n</code></pre>',

	              'extid': 27751417,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750973/remove-adjacent-words/27751417#27751417',
	              'user_id': 535275,
	              'vote': 1},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>By introducing the notion of a token, the code becomes reasonably straightforward. A token represents a span of text that consists of some whitespace and then either some letters, or some non-letters (but never a mix of the two). A well-chosen abstraction can go a long way in making it easy to decompose problems down into manageable parts.</p>\n\n<p>I\'ve also included a <code>main</code> that runs through test cases and prints the results out. I find that makes it easy to develop the code, and are a simple way to get the benefit of unit tests even if you\'re not using a unit test framework.</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n#include &lt;ctype.h&gt;\n#include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;\n#include &lt;string.h&gt;\n\n// A tok is whitespace followed by a word or symbols.\ntypedef struct tok {\n    const char* p;\n    int ws;  // how many bytes of whitespace\n    int len;  // total length of whitespace + word or symbols.\n} tok;\n\n// next_tok returns the next token starting at p.\ntok next_tok(const char* p) {\n    const char *q = p;\n    while (isspace(*q)) q++;\n    int ws = q - p;\n    while (isalpha(*q)) q++;\n    if (q - p == ws) {\n        while (*q &amp;&amp; !isalpha(*q) &amp;&amp; !isspace(*q)) q++;\n    }\n    tok result = {p, ws, q-p};\n    return result;\n}\n\n// toks_equal returns whether a and b are the same word, ignoring whitespace.\nint toks_equal(tok a, tok b) {\n    if (!a.p || !b.p) return 0;\n    if (a.len - a.ws != b.len - b.ws) return 0;\n    return !strncmp(a.p + a.ws, b.p + b.ws, b.len - b.ws);\n}\n\n// remove_dups returns a string that\'s like p, but with the second\n// and subsequent duplicate word separated by whitespace removed.\nchar* remove_dups(const char* p) {\n    char* result = malloc(strlen(p) + 1);\n    char* q = result;\n    tok no_word = {0};\n    tok last_word = no_word;\n    while(1) {\n        tok this_word = next_tok(p);\n        p += this_word.len;\n        if (this_word.len == 0) {\n            *q = \'\\0\';\n            return result;\n        }\n        if (toks_equal(this_word, last_word)) {\n            continue;\n        }\n        memcpy(q, this_word.p, this_word.len);\n        q += this_word.len;\n        last_word = isalpha(this_word.p[this_word.ws]) ? this_word : no_word;\n    }\n}\n\nint main(int argc, char *argv[]) {\n    const char* cases[] = {\n        "able was i ere i saw elba",\n        "the the quick brown fox. fox",\n        "hello     hello     hello world",\n        "some spaces spaces at end end   ",\n    };\n    for (int i = 0; i &lt; sizeof(cases)/sizeof(cases[0]); i++) {\n        char* p = remove_dups(cases[i]);\n        printf("\'%s\' -&gt; \'%s\'\\n", cases[i], p);\n        free(p);\n    }\n    return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27751610,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27750973/remove-adjacent-words/27751610#27751610',
	              'user_id': 1400793,
	              'vote': 1},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>This is a suggestion. 	 'body': u'<p>The goal is to remove all the adjacent duplicate words (that are separated with one or two whitespaces) from a sentence in C, that has all letters in lowercase.</p>\n\n<p>From the collection of adjacent duplicate words, the first one should be left in the sentence and the others should be discarded.</p>\n\n<p>The problem I have is when the words are separated by two whitespaces, instead of one. However, I am not allowed to discard the double whitespaces.</p>\n\n<p>Here is my code, with an example string.</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n#include &lt;string.h&gt;\n\nint equal(char* a, char* b) {\n  if((a[0] == \',\') || (a[0] == \'.\')\n    || (a[0] == \';\') || (b[0] == \',\')\n    || (b[0] == \'.\') || (b[0] == \';\'))\n    return 0;\n  int i = 0, equal = 1;\n  for(; a[i]; ++i) {\n    if((a[i] == \',\') || (a[i] == \'.\')\n      || (a[i] == \';\') || (b[i] == \',\')\n      || (b[i] == \'.\') || (b[i] == \';\'))\n      continue;\n    if(a[i] != b[i])\n      equal = 0;\n  }\n  return equal;\n}\n\nvoid remove_adj_duplicates(char* str) {\n  char words[100][256];\n  int i = 0, j = 0, k = 0, n = 0;\n\n  /* copying each and every word from the string */\n  while (str[i] != \'\\0\') {\n    if( (str[i] == \' \') ) {\n      if(!strlen(words[j]))\n        words[j][k++] = \' \';\n      words[j][k] = \'\\0\';\n      //printf("|%s| %d\\n", words[j], strlen(words[j]));\n\n      k = 0;\n      j++;\n    } else {\n      words[j][k++] = str[i];\n    }\n    i++;\n  }\n\n  words[j][k] = \'\\0\';\n  //printf("|%s|\\n", words[j]);\n  n = j;\n\n  /* remove duplicate words in the given string */\n  for (i = 0; i &lt; n; i++) {\n    if(equal(words[i], words[i + 1])) {\n      // keep the last occurance of the duplicate,\n      // since it might be of the form "of of.".\n      strcpy(words[i], words[i + 1]);\n      for (k = i + 1; k &lt; n; k++) {\n        strcpy(words[k], words[k + 1]);\n      }\n      n--, i--;\n    }\n  }\n\n  for(i = 0; str[i]; ++i) {\n    str[i] = \'\\0\';\n  }\n  /* print the unique adjacent words */\n  j = 0;\n  for (i = 0; i &lt;= n; i++) {\n    if(strcmp(words[i], " ")) {\n      for(k = 0; words[i][k]; ++k) {\n        str[j++] = words[i][k];\n      }\n    }\n    str[j++] = \' \';\n  }\n  str[--j] = \'\\0\';\n}\n\nint main() {\n  char string[256] = "its subfields foo can be divided into a variety foo foo  foo foo  foo foo  foo foo  foo foo  foo foo.";\n\n  remove_adj_duplicates(string);\n\n  printf("Result:\\n|%s|\\n", string);\n  printf("However, the result I must get is:\\n");\n  printf("|its subfields foo can be divided into a variety foo    .|\\n");\n  printf("That\'s five whitespaces, one for every double whitespace initially.\\n");\n  return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Output:</p>\n\n<pre><code>Result:\n|its subfields foo can be divided into a variety foo  foo  foo  foo  foo  foo.|\nHowever, the result I must get is:\n|its subfields foo can be divided into a variety foo    .|\nThat\'s five whitespaces, one for every double whitespace initially.\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>I don\'t care if I have to re-write the whole function, I just want to take the desired result, as stated in the output above.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p>EDIT</p>\n\n<p>"A I I A" should become "A A".</p>\n\n<p>"foo. foo" should be left as is.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p>EDIT_no.2</p>\n\n<p>The proposing solution will not work for something like this:</p>\n\n<p><code>|its subfields can be divided into a variety of of  of of  of of  of of  of of  of of. |</code></p>\n\n<p>It gave me:</p>\n\n<pre><code>Result:\n|its subfields can be divided into a variety of|\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>where it should give me:</p>\n\n<pre><code>|its subfields can be divided into a variety of     . |\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>The answer of Meninx gave me this:</p>\n\n<p><code>its subfields of can be divided into a variety of           .</code></p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p>EDIT_no_3</p>\n\n<p>If we have <code>foo_foo_a</code>, where <code>_</code> is a 	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<pre><code>0x0001\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>is a value of <code>1</code> of type <code>int</code></p>\n\n<pre><code>((uint16_t)0x0001)\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>is also a value of <code>1</code> but of type <code>uint16_t</code></p>',
	              'comments': [u'Note: I ',
	                           u' going to comment that ',
	                           u' was ',
	                           u' - but this is correct: ',
	                           u'.  2 nice answers - the long and short of it.'],
	              'extid': 27751034,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751021/what-does-this-statement-mean-in-cuint16-t0x0001/27751034#27751034',
	              'user_id': 1119701,
	              'vote': 1},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>That\'s not a statement. It\'s a preprocessor directive, specifically a macro definition.</p>\n\n<pre><code>#define something ((uint16_t)0x0001)\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>This does nothing by itself. It means that if the word <code>something</code> appears later in the program, it will be replaced by the token sequence <code>((uint16_t)0x0001)</code>.</p>\n\n<p><code>0x00001</code> is just another way of writing <code>1</code>. It\'s a constant of type <code>int</code>, with the value <code>1</code>. (The <code>0x</code> prefix means it\'s hexadecimal rather than decimal.)</p>\n\n<p><code>uint16_t</code> is a <em>typedef</em>, defined in the standard header <code>&lt;stdint.h&gt;</code>. It\'s a 16-bit unsigned integer type.</p>\n\n<p><code>(uint16_t)</code> is a <em>cast operator</em>. It specifies a conversion of its operand to the specified type.</p>\n\n<p>Putting that all together, the expression <code>((uint16_t)0x0001)</code> is a constant expression of type <code>uint16_t</code> with the value <code>1</code>. And given the macro definition, any occurrence of <code>something</code> is replaced by that expression.</p>\n\n<p>So it\'s just a number of a specific type. By itself, it\'s not going to let you "change and control a single bit", but you might be able to use it for that purpose if you use it properly.</p>\n\n<p>I hope the actual macro has a more meaningful name than <code>something</code>. if you had shown us how it\'s used (perhaps as a bit mask?), we might have been able to provide more information.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27751078,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751021/what-does-this-statement-mean-in-cuint16-t0x0001/27751078#27751078',
	              'user_id': 827263,
	              'vote': 1}],

	 'comments': [u'This statement doesn\'t "reset" anything, it just defines a macro that expands to a number. How it affects other values depends on the expression it\'s used in.',
	              u'When you use ',
	              u" in your code, it's just replaced by ",
	              u" literaly. So it's equivalent to writing it directly, and hence it has nothing to do with reseting something. The value ",
	              u' must have somethig to do, and if you want to reset all the bits I think it should then be ',
	              u' since if ',
	              u' is resetting the last bit then I suppose that binary ',
	              u' will reset the 16 bits.',
	              u'You can set the least significant bit of a variable ',
	              u' using ',
	              u'.  Subject to some constraints, you can reset the least significant bit in ',
	              u' using ',
	              u'.  You can flip the least significant bit using ',
	              u'; and you can find the value of the least significant bit using ',
	              u'.',
	              u'Note that many embedded processors have alternate addresses for special function registers where writing a 1 sets (or for another address, clears) a bit in the main register  while writing a 0 has no affect.  So the original idea may be right, it is just hardware rather than the C language which accomplishes it.  This can make things like twiddling GPIOs both faster and more atomic than the read-modify-write otherwise needed to change a single bit in a register whose state is not already known.'],

	              'vote': -3}],
	 'body': u'<p>I am currently looking into sorting algorithms and found Merge Insertion Sort.\nI could barely find anything for it, but only a few papers and references to Books.\nSo this algorithm was discovered by Lester Ford, Jr. and Selmer Johnson.\nIt\'s partly described here: <a href="http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/fac/sci/dcs/teaching/material/cs341/FJ.pdf" rel="nofollow">http://www2.warwick.ac.uk/fac/sci/dcs/teaching/material/cs341/FJ.pdf</a></p>\n\n<p>My problem right now is understanding how the insertion part works and additionally what number sequence the 1, 3, 5, 11 is, mentioned in the explanation how to insert. It looks so familiar, but I just can\'t remember what it was.</p>\n\n<p>What I have as of now code-wise is like that:</p>\n\n<pre><code>//pointer to array, array size, element size, compare function pointer\nvoid sort(void *data, size_t n, size_t s, int (*fcomp)(void*, void*))\n{\n  if(!data) return;\n  if(n &lt; 2 || s == 0) return;\n\n  size_t i = 0, j = 0, k = 0, l = 0, r = 0, m = 0;\n\n  void *be = malloc((n/2)*s); //elements greater in pair comparison\n  void *le = malloc((n/2 + n%2)*s);//elements lesser in pair comparison\n  void *mc = malloc(n*s); //main chain\n\n  //compare pair-wise K_1:K_2, ... , K_N:K_N-1\n  for(i = 0; i &lt; n; i+=2)\n  {\n    if(fcomp(voidAdd(data, s, i), voidAdd(data, s, i+1)) &gt;= 0)\n    {\n      //element at i bigger than i+1 so, put it in be and i+1 in le\n      memcpy(voidAdd(be, s, k++), voidAdd(data, s, i), s);\n      memcpy(voidAdd(le, s, j++), voidAdd(data, s, i+1), s);\n    }\n    else\n    {\n      //element i+1 bigger than i so put it in be and i in le\n      memcpy(voidAdd(be, s, k++), voidAdd(data, s, i+1), s);\n      memcpy(voidAdd(le, s, j++), voidAdd(data, s, i), s);\n    }\n  }\n\n  sort(be, n/2, s, fcomp); //recursivly repeat process for bigger elements\n  /*\n  now we have chain a_1, ..., a_n/2 and b_1, ..., b_n/2 with a_i &gt; b_i and\n  a_1 &lt; ... a_n/2\n  */\n\n  memcpy(mc, le, s); //insert b_1 into the main-chain\n  memcpy(voidAdd(mc, s, 1), be, (n/2)*s); //copy a_1, ... a_n/2 in main chain\n  //now we have b_1, a_1, ..., a_n/2 as main chain\n\n  //start insertion here\n  j = n/2 + 1;\n  for(i = 1; i &lt; n/2; i++)\n  {\n    k = ...;//number from sequence 1, 3, 5, 11, ...\n  }\n\n  memcpy(data, mc, n*s);\n  free(mc);\n  free(be);\n  free(le);\n\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>From what is written in the linked pdf, it needs to insert b_3, b_2, b_5, b_4 ... into the main chain now with binary insertion, but I\'m not sure how to do that exactly and where they take these numbers from.</p>',

2015-01-03 09:41:03+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c++/info 
2015-01-03 09:41:03+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c/info
