2015-01-03 09:41:03+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751221/inconsistent-strcmp-return-value-when-passing-strings-as-pointers-or-as-litera>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>You are most likely seeing the result of a compiler optimization. If we <a href="http://goo.gl/iLBLuI">test the code using gcc on godbolt</a> we can see for the first case it does not call <code>strcmp</code>:</p>\n\n<pre><code>movl    $-1, %esi   #,\nmovl    $.LC0, %edi #,\nmovl    $0, %eax    #,\ncall    printf  #\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Since your are using constants as arguments to <code>strcmp</code> the compiler is able for perform <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constant_folding">constant folding</a> and call a compiler intrinsic at compile time and generates the <code>-1</code> then, instead of having to call <code>strcmp</code> at run-time which is implemented in the standard library and will have a different implementation then a likely more simple compile time <code>strcmp</code>.</p>\n\n<p>In the second case it does generate a call to <code>strcmp</code>:</p>\n\n<pre><code>call    strcmp  #\nmovl    %eax, %esi  # D.2047,\nmovl    $.LC0, %edi #,\nmovl    $0, %eax    #,\ncall    printf  #\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>This is consistent with the fact that <a href="https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Other-Builtins.html">gcc has a builtin for strcmp</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Of course both results are entirely conformant results as we can see by going to the draft C99 standard section <code>7.21.4.2</code> The strcmp function which says (<em>emphasis mine</em>):</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>The strcmp function returns an integer greater than, equal to, <strong>or less\n  than zero</strong>, accordingly as the string pointed to by s1 is greater than,\n  equal to, or <strong>less than the string</strong> pointed to by s2.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>Just in the first case the optimizer can take a short-cut and performs the calculation during compile time.</p>',
	              'comments': [u'While this is interesting, it is not really important to the answer. Even if strcmp were called in both cases, it would be perfectly valid for it to return different values for the same input string (so long as the return values were both the same sign etc).',
	                           u'@davmac, seems like the OP wanted to know why the values are different (even though they are both negative)',
	                           u'@asimes my point is that this is only part of the explanation as to why they are different. Or, if you prefer, it is one explanation of why they could be different (remember that different compilers, platforms etc might give different results). But the question implies that the OP does not understand why they ',
	                           u' be different, and that it would be wrong to assume that the numerical result must always be the same for the same input strings.'],
	              'extid': 27751263,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751221/inconsistent-strcmp-return-value-when-passing-strings-as-pointers-or-as-litera/27751263#27751263',
	              'user_id': 1708801,
	              'vote': 25},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>I think you believe that the value returned by <code>strcmp</code> should somehow depend on the input strings passed to it in a way that is not defined by the function specification. This isn\'t correct. See for instance the POSIX definition:</p>\n\n<p><a href="http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/009695399/functions/strcmp.html" rel="nofollow">http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/009695399/functions/strcmp.html</a></p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>Upon completion, strcmp() shall return an integer greater than, equal to, or less than 0, if the string pointed to by s1 is greater than, equal to, or less than the string pointed to by s2, respectively.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>This is exactly what you are seeing. The implementation does not need to make any guarantee about the <em>exact</em> return value - only that is less than zero, equal to zero, or greater than zero as appropriate.</p>',
	              'comments': [u'so it returns a random negative number then? i think it should be anyway deterministic, and there should be an explanation for the observed bahvior.',
	                           u'@iharob : It is not "random", in the second case, it is the result of \'f\' - \'a\', but that is itself the result of the specific ',
	                           u" (though I doubt implementations differ in this respect).  The first result is explained by Shafic's answer and is compiler (or compiler option) dependent.  Either way, you cannot rely on any result other than that guaranteed by the function's standard specification.",
	                           u'@iharob: returning a random negative number would indeed satisfy the spec, but that\'s not what\'s happening here. The "explanation for the observed behavior" is that the ',
	                           u' implementation(s) returned different values on different occasions - in other words, the observed behavior is dependent on the implementation of the function. We could poke into various reasons why an implementation might give different numerical results (see Shafik\'s answer) but I personally think the key takeaway is "don\'t make assumptions about behavior that aren\'t explicit in the spec".'],
	              'extid': 27751262,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751221/inconsistent-strcmp-return-value-when-passing-strings-as-pointers-or-as-litera/27751262#27751262',
	              'user_id': 388661,
	              'vote': 9}],
	 'body': u'<p>I was playing around with <code>strcmp</code> when I noticed this, here is the code.</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include &lt;string.h&gt;\n#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n\nint main(){\n\n    //passing strings directly\n    printf("%d\\n", strcmp("ahmad", "fatema"));\n\n    //passing strings as pointers \n    char *a= "ahmad";\n    char *b= "fatema";\n    printf("%d\\n",strcmp(a,b));\n\n    return 0;\n\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>the output is:</p>\n\n<pre><code>-1\n\n-5\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>shouldn\'t <code>strcmp</code> work the same? why is it that I am given different value when I pass strings as "ahmad" or as char* a = ahmad. when you pass values to a function they are allocated in its stack right? 	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>You\'ll need more than 2 characters for file modes: "r+" and the like (NUL terminator). Be careful to avoid buffer overflow. </p>\n\n<pre><code>   char mode[3];\n   fgets(mode, sizeof(mode), stdin);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>And the behaviour of fclose on a non-open file is undefined.</p>\n\n<pre><code>if (fp == NULL) {\n    printf("Failed to open\\n");\n} else {\n    printf("Succesfully opened\\n");\n    fclose(fp); /* only close if fp != NULL, and only close once */\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>all together:</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n#include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;\n#include &lt;string.h&gt;\n\n\nint main(int argc, char **argv) {\n    char filename[100];\n    char mode[3];\n    char *p;\n\n    printf("Enter filename:\\n&gt;");\n    fgets(filename, sizeof(filename), stdin);\n    if ((p = strchr(filename, \'\\n\')) != NULL) {\n      *p = \'\\0\'; /* remove any newline */\n    }\n\n    printf("Select a mode from the list:\\n"\n        "r reading\\n"\n        "w writing\\n"\n        "a append\\n"\n        "r+ reading &amp; writing (at beginning, overwriting)\\n"\n        "w+ reading &amp; writing (overwrite on existing)\\n"\n        "a+ reading &amp; appending (new data appended at end of file)\\n&gt;");\n\n    fgets(mode, sizeof(mode), stdin);\n    if ((p = strchr(mode, \'\\n\')) != NULL) {\n      *p = \'\\0\';\n    }\n\n    printf("opening %s with mode %s.\\n", filename, mode);\n    FILE *fp = fopen(filename, mode);\n\n    if (fp == NULL) {\n        printf("Failed to open\\n");\n    } else {\n        printf("Succesfully opened\\n");\n        fclose(fp);\n    }\n    return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>',

2015-01-03 09:41:05+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751359/c-stack-odd-behavior> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c)
2015-01-03 09:41:05+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c/info 
2015-01-03 09:41:05+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/segmentation-fault/info 
2015-01-03 09:41:05+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/stack/info 
2015-01-03 09:41:05+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751359/c-stack-odd-behavior>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>This rather looks like a stack overflow on an x86-64 system without adress space layout randomization. If the stack begins at <code>0x7ffffffff000</code>, as they do on such systems, <code>0x7fffff7feff8</code> is suspiciously close to 8 MB below the beginning of the stack, which is a common default thread stack size on Linux systems.</p>\n\n<p>Dump the contents of <code>/proc/self/maps</code> and check if the start of the stack matches this (it is listed at the bottom), and check <code>ulimit -s</code> to see the stack size new processes get. If <code>/proc/self/maps</code> lists <code>0x7ffffffff000</code> as end of the stack address range and<code>ulimit -s</code> prints <code>8192</code>, what you have is simply a stack overflow. In this event, a quick fix would be to increase the stack size of new processes (subprocesses of the active shell) like so:</p>\n\n<pre><code>ulimit -Ss size_in_kilobytes\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>This will work up to a hard limit <code>root</code> may or may not impose. In the long run, it would probably be a good idea to rewrite the code in a less excessively recursive manner.</p>\n\n<p>Also, if all this hits home, you should probably enable ASLR (<code>sysctl kernel.randomize_va_sapce=1</code>. If that complains, your system is in dire need of an upgrade. Write <code>kernel.randomize_va_space = 1</code> to <code>/etc/sysctl.conf</code> to make it permanent).</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27751747,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751359/c-stack-odd-behavior/27751747#27751747',
	              'user_id': 4301306,
	              'vote': 0}],

2015-01-03 09:41:05+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751402/progress-bar-with-sha256-hashing-in-ansi-c>
	{'answers': [],
	 'body': u'<p>For a project that I am working on right now, I was wondering how I could add a progress indicator to the Openssl SHA256 hashing function. I will be working with some large files (1-10+ GB) and would like to be able to see the progress completed versus left. I have implemented the Stack Overflow questions <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2262386/generate-sha256-with-openssl-and-c" title="here">here</a> and <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9284420/how-to-use-sha1-hashing-in-c-programming" title="here">here</a>, and have the SHA256 hash generating working correctly (it only lacks a progress indicator).</p>\n\n<p>I am fairly new to C, so this will be a learning experience for me. I thought that I might be able to use fread or SHA256_Update somehow, but I am having trouble understanding exactly how I would get a response of how much of the file has been read. </p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<pre><code>char _genSHA256Hash(char *path, char outputBuffer[65])\n{\n  FILE *file = fopen(path, "rb");\n  if(!file) return -1;\n\n  unsigned char hash[SHA256_DIGEST_LENGTH];\n  SHA256_CTX sha256;\n  SHA256_Init(&amp;sha256);\n  const int bufSize = 32768;\n  char *buffer = malloc(bufSize);\n  int bytesRead = 0;\n  if(!buffer) return -1;\n  while((bytesRead = fread(buffer, 1, bufSize, file)))\n  {\n      SHA256_Update(&amp;sha256, buffer, bytesRead);\n  }\n  SHA256_Final(hash, &amp;sha256);\n\n  sha256_hash_string(hash, outputBuffer);\n\n  //fclose(file);\n  //free(buffer);\n\n  return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p>Thank you,</p>\n\n<p>Tim</p>',
	 'comments': [u"You'll need a ",
	              u' or some such to tell you how big the file is, then do the math for delta yourself while the loop iterates.'],
	 'extid': 27751402,
	 'tags': [u'c', u'hash', u'sha256'],
	 'title': u'Progress Bar With SHA256 Hashing in ANSI C',

	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u"<pre><code>int merge(int *ar,int low,int mid, int high){\n    int temp[8];\n\n    int i,j,index,k;\n    k=0;\n    index=0;//temp's index start 0;\n    i=low;\n    j=mid+1;\n    while(i&lt;=mid &amp;&amp; j&lt;=high){\n        if(ar[i]&lt;ar[j]){\n            temp[index++] = ar[i];\n            i++;\n        }else{\n            temp[index++] = ar[j];\n            j++;\n        }\n    }\n    while(i&lt;=mid){\n        temp[index++] = ar[i];\n        i++;\n    }\n    while(j&lt;=high){\n        temp[index++] = ar[j];\n        j++;\n    }\n\n    for(k=low, index=0;k&lt;=high;k++){//k include high\n        ar[k]=temp[index++];\n    }\n}\n</code></pre>",
	              'comments': [u'pls explain this part                                            for(k=low, index=0;k<=high;k++){//k include high         ar[k]=temp[index++];     }',
	                           u'@raton ',
	                           u' --> ',
	                           u', because ',
	                           u' is included in the sorted range. I think of the index of the ',
	                           u" was in from 0's that it is easy to understand general purpose.(You will need to be modified to ensure it is not the size of the future original sequence.)"],
	              'extid': 27751698,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751620/implementation-of-merge-sort-not-working/27751698#27751698',

	              'vote': 1},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>your while conditions are off, need to empty the arrays <code>while (j&lt;i)</code> is never true.</p>\n\n<pre><code>while (i &lt;= mid) { \n    temp[index++] = ar[i];\n    i++;\n}\n\nwhile (j &lt;= high) {\n    temp[index++] = ar[j];\n    j++;\n}\n</code></pre>',

	              'vote': 2}],
	 'body': u'<p>My array is not sorted after running the code. What\'s wrong?</p>\n\n<p>Result: 3,8,9,6,11,3,22,95.</p>\n\n<p>I have tried long but all in vain.</p>\n\n<pre><code>   int main(int argc, char const *argv[]){\n        int i;\n        int my[]={3,11,19,22,8,9,13,95};\n        msort(my,0,7);\n\n        for(i=0;i&lt;8;i++){\n           printf("%d,",my[i]);\n          }\n       return 0;\n }\n\n int msort(int *ar,int low, int high){\n       int mid;\n       if(low&lt;high){\n          mid = (low+high)/2;\n\n        msort(ar,low,mid);\n        msort(ar,mid+1,high);\n        merge(ar,low,mid,high);\n     }\n  }\n\n\nint merge(int *ar,int low,int mid, int high){\n//int ar[]={3,11,19,22};\n//int ar2[]={8,9,13,95};\nint temp[8];\n\nint i,j,index,k;\nk=0;\nindex=low;\ni=low;\nj=mid+1;\nwhile(i&lt;=mid &amp;&amp; j&lt;=high){\n    if(ar[i]&lt;ar[j]){\n        temp[index++] = ar[i];\n        i++;\n    }else{\n        temp[index++] = ar[j];\n        j++;\n    }\n}\nwhile(i&lt;j){\n    temp[index++] = ar[i];\n    i++;\n\n}\nwhile(j&lt;i){\n    temp[index++] = ar[j];\n\n    j++;\n}\n\n  //here i am updating my array with temp;\n\nfor(k=low;k&lt;high;k++){\n    ar[k]=temp[k];\n}\n\n\n\n  }\n</code></pre>',
	 'comments': [u"I can't stress enough how this gets easier if you just use a base pointer and length rather than a pointer, mid, and high. I.e., did you notice ",
	              u' is ',
	              u" the same value? It doesn't have to be if you use ",
	              u' for the mid-point adjustments when recursing.',
	              u'Read this article  ',
	              u'Regarding my prior comment, ',
	              u'. Apart from the pointer-usage, you may find copy-removal of the high-end of the merge interesting. If the low end finishes first, the remaining high end is already in place. It makes no sense to copy it to temp just to copy it back to the high end of the source array. Anyway, best of luck.'],

2015-01-03 09:41:07+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751707/how-to-detect-if-a-syscall-exists-on-linux-programmatically> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c)
2015-01-03 09:41:07+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c/info 
2015-01-03 09:41:07+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/linux/info 
2015-01-03 09:41:07+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Ignoring link (depth > 3): http://stackoverflow.com/tags/system-calls/info 
2015-01-03 09:41:07+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751707/how-to-detect-if-a-syscall-exists-on-linux-programmatically>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u"<p>That depends. It is rather rare that system calls are invoked directly (the <code>syscalls (2)</code> man page even makes note of this); it is more common to use library wrappers such as <code>write</code>, <code>read</code>, <code>open</code>, <code>close</code> and others. If you attempt to to use a wrapper function for a syscall that doesn't exist on the system in question, it is likely that the wrapper also does not exist, in which case your program will not get past the runtime linker and fail to start.</p>\n\n<p>If, on the other hand, you invoke system calls (more or less) directly through the <code>syscall</code> function, e.g.</p>\n\n<pre><code>syscall(SYS_write, fd, buffer, size);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>instead of</p>\n\n<pre><code>write(fd, buffer, size);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>then <code>syscall</code> will return <code>-1</code> if you attempt to invoke a nonexistent system call, and <code>errno</code> will be set to <code>ENOSYS</code>.</p>\n\n<p>If you use a <code>libc</code> that is new enough to contain the wrapper function with a kernel that is old enough to not support the corresponding system call, the wrapper function will probably hand down this error. Check the documentation of the wrapper function in question.</p>",
	              'comments': [u'Thank you very much!'],
	              'extid': 27751822,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751707/how-to-detect-if-a-syscall-exists-on-linux-programmatically/27751822#27751822',
	              'user_id': 4301306,
	              'vote': 3}],
	 'body': u'<p>I am trying to compile a C program that will be run on some older version of kernel. The kernel where I compile the program is not the same version as the kernel version where my program will be run.\nIf I call a syscall that only on newer version of kernel, will the program crash, or return a error value?</p>',
	 'comments': [u'perhaps use the kernel headers for the apropriate kernel version',
	              u" might be useful for you, as a supplement to @Wintermute's answer below."],
	 'extid': 27751707,
	 'tags': [u'c', u'linux', u'system-calls'],
	 'title': u'How to detect if a syscall exists on linux programmatically?',
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751707/how-to-detect-if-a-syscall-exists-on-linux-programmatically',
	 'user_id': 1285639,
	 'vote': 1}

	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Here\'s a relatively dumb example, but it does have a different result:</p>\n\n<pre><code>#define Streq(s1, s2) (strcmp((s1), (s2)) == 0)\n#define MyStreq(s1, s2) (strcmp(s1, s2) == 0)\n#define s1 "foo", "blah"\n\nint main() {\n    Streq(s1, "blah"); // Compiles and compares equal.\n    MyStreq(s1, "blah"); // Compiler error. Too many parameters.\n}\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27752438,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752386/can-we-remove-parentheses-around-s1-and-s2-in-the-c-macro-define-streqs1-s2/27752438#27752438',
	              'user_id': 47453,
	              'vote': 10},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Parentheses do sometimes matter, and it is a good idea to unconditionally insert them. Consider the following poor macro:</p>\n\n<pre><code>#define OP(a, b) (a * b) /* BAD */\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Invoked as <code>OP(x + 1, y + 1)</code> it will expand to x + 1 * y + 1, breaking the intended grouping. Parentheses prevent this problem.</p>\n\n<p>If you read a macro definition with parentheses around each argument use, the author certainly had this issue in mind - even if those parens happen to be redundant for that macro.</p>',
	              'comments': [u'While this answer is not specific to the question, it demonstrates a crucial point that pertains to the question. +1'],

	              'vote': 1}],

	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>when coding <code>"literalstring" + 3</code> you get the 4<sup>th</sup> (since 4 = 3+1 and arrays index start at 0) and following bytes of the <code>"literalstring"</code> (which is terminated by a zero-byte) so you get <code>"eralstring"</code>, hence</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><code>"%d" + 0</code> is <code>"%d"</code></li>\n<li><code>"%d" + 1</code> is <code>"d"</code>, notice that <code>printf("d", 1)</code> <em>ignores</em> the argument 1!</li>\n<li><code>"%d" + 2</code> is <code>""</code>  an empty string</li>\n<li><code>"%d" + 3</code> points to an undefined location and dereferencing it (like <code>printf</code> probably does) is <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Undefined_behavior" rel="nofollow">undefined behavior</a> ...</li>\n</ul>',

	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>You don\'t need use <code>&amp;</code> when passing a string as a <code>char *</code>, since arrays decay to pointers when passed as parameters.</p>\n\n<p>So:</p>\n\n<pre><code>scanf("%s",&amp;check);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>should be:</p>\n\n<pre><code>scanf("%s", check);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>And some general advice: turn on compiler warnings to help catch simple mistakes such as this, and learn basic debugging techniques (stepping through code in your debugger, adding strategic <code>printf</code> statements, etc).</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27752909,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752890/pangram-function-is-not-working-in-c/27752909#27752909',
	              'user_id': 253056,
	              'vote': 3},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p><code>scanf</code> cannot get strings with spaces. So use <code>fgets</code></p>\n\n<pre><code>fgets(check,sizeof(check),stdin);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Or use</p>\n\n<p><code>scanf("%[^\\n]s",check);</code></p>\n\n<p>This reads a string till a newline character is encountered.\nThe default scanf stops reading when a <code>space</code> is encountered.</p>',
	              'comments': [u'never use gets(). use fgets() instead',
	                           u'Also a good idea to specify field width when reading strings with ',
	                           u', for the same reasons as avoiding ',
	                           u"I've edited it stating to use fgets"],
	              'extid': 27752938,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752890/pangram-function-is-not-working-in-c/27752938#27752938',
	              'user_id': 4405757,
	              'vote': 1},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u"<p><code>scanf()</code> with the <code>%s</code> format specifier will stop at whitespace.  Try <code>fgets(check,100,stdin)</code> instead... that will read (up to) a full line, and limit the number of characters to 99 + nul so you won't exceed the size of <code>check</code>.  It may leave a newline as the last character, but your algorithm would ignore that anyway.</p>\n\n<p>Additionally, in <code>IsPangram()</code>, <code>c</code> should be an <code>int</code> instead of a <code>char</code> (to match <code>tolower()</code> etc.), and change this:</p>\n\n<pre><code> // for converting the uppper case letter to the small one\nfor(i=0;i&lt;size;i++){\n    c=tolower(string[i]);\n    if(islower(c)){\n        flags[string[i]-'a']=true;\n    }     \n   }\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>...to this:</p>\n\n<pre><code> // for converting the uppper case letter to the small one\nfor(i=0;i&lt;size;i++){\n    c=tolower(string[i]);  /* &lt;== c will always be lowercase */\n    if(isalpha(c)){        /* &lt;== Check that c is a letter */\n        flags[c-'a']=true; /* &lt;== use c, as string[i] may be uppercase */\n    }     \n   }\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>...for the reasons indicated in the added comments.</p>",
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753144,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752890/pangram-function-is-not-working-in-c/27753144#27753144',

	              'vote': 0}],

2015-01-03 09:41:13+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753162/read-a-variable-in-another-program-using-c>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>It is <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operating_system" rel="nofollow">operating system</a> specific, and you generally should avoid doing that -even when possible-. Prefer other <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inter-process_communication" rel="nofollow">inter-process communication</a> facilities (e.g. pipes, sockets, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_passing" rel="nofollow">message passing</a>)</p>\n\n<p>On most OSes, each <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_%28computing%29" rel="nofollow">process</a> has its <em>own</em> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Address_space" rel="nofollow">address space</a> in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_memory" rel="nofollow">virtual memory</a>, so a process A cannot change any data in process B. BTW, two processes can run simultaneously (on different cores) or quasi-simultaneously (with their tasks scheduled by the kernel), so sharing without care a variable does not make any sense.</p>\n\n<p>Some OSes provide <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shared_memory" rel="nofollow">shared memory</a> facilities, but then you should care about <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization" rel="nofollow">synchronization</a> (e.g. with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semaphore_%28programming%29" rel="nofollow">semaphores</a>).</p>\n\n<p>For Linux, read <a href="http://advancedlinuxprogramming.com/" rel="nofollow">Advanced Linux Programming</a> and <a href="http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/shm_overview.7.html" rel="nofollow">shm_overview(7)</a> &amp; <a href="http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/sem_overview.7.html" rel="nofollow">sem_overview(7)</a></p>\n\n<p>Generally, you need to design and adapt both programs to make them communicate. For <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_security" rel="nofollow">security</a> reasons you don\'t want (and your OS <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel_%28operating_system%29" rel="nofollow">kernel</a> forbids) arbitrary processes to be able to glance in other processes\' address space.</p>\n\n<p><sup>For example, you don\'t want your game software to be able to access your banking data in your browser without your consent.</sup></p>\n\n<p>Alternatively, merge the two programs into a single <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thread_%28computing%29#Multithreading" rel="nofollow">multi-threaded</a> application. You\'ll be concerned by synchronization and probably would need to use <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_exclusion" rel="nofollow">mutexes</a>. Read e.g. some <a href="https://computing.llnl.gov/tutorials/pthreads/" rel="nofollow">POSIX threads tutorial</a>.</p>\n\n<p>See also <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_Passing_Interface" rel="nofollow">MPI</a>. BTW, you might use some <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database" rel="nofollow">database</a> to share the common data (look into <a href="http://postgresql.org/" rel="nofollow">PostGreSQL</a>, <a href="http://mongodb.org/" rel="nofollow">MongoDB</a>, etc...) or adapt a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Client%E2%80%93server_model" rel="nofollow">client-server model</a></p>',
	              'comments': [u'So what should I do if I want to read a variable in another program?',
	                           u'You cannot do that in general. You need to adapt both programs to agree on some IPC.'],
	              'extid': 27753222,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753162/read-a-variable-in-another-program-using-c/27753222#27753222',
	              'user_id': 841108,
	              'vote': 5}],

	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>Why are these "issues"? The language clearly says that certain things lead to <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Undefined_behavior">undefined behavior</a>. There is no problem, there is no "should" involved. If the undefined behavior changes when one of the involved variables is declared <code>volatile</code>, that doesn\'t prove or change anything. It is <em>undefined</em>; you cannot reason about the behavior.</p>\n\n<p>Your most interesting-loooking example, the one with</p>\n\n<pre><code>u = (u++);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>is a text-book example of undefined behavior (see Wikipedia\'s entry on <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequence_point">sequence points</a>).</p>',
	              'comments': [u"+max_int. Use statements which the language standard actually tells you what they will do. Do not use undefined behaviour and then wonder what's going on.",
	                           u'I knew it was undefined, (The idea of seing this code in production frighten me :)) but I tried to understand what was the reason for these results. Especially why u = u++ incremented u. In java for example:   u = u++ returns 0 as (my brain) expected :)    Thanks for the sequence points links BTW.',
	                           u'Obviously because of the brackets around the u++ the compiler has decided to incerement u and then return it. As it is undefined behaviuor in C this is ligitimate. A different compiler or even a different machine and the same one may give a different answer.  I do not know java, but perhaps the behaviour is clearly defined.',
	                           u'@PiX: Things are undefined for a number of possible reasons. These include: there is no clear "right result", different machine architectures would strongly favour different results, existing practice is not consistent, or beyond the scope of the standard (e.g. what filenames are valid).',
	                           u'The spirit of C: Trust the programmer... no matter how insane he is.'],
	              'extid': 949443,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/949433/why-are-these-constructs-using-undefined-behavior/949443#949443',
	              'user_id': 139746,
	              'vote': 237},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Read this Question from the C FAQ.</p>\n\n<p><a href="http://c-faq.com/expr/seqpoints.html">Q: How can I understand complex expressions like the ones in this section, and avoid writing undefined ones? What\'s a "sequence point"?</a></p>\n\n<p>A: A sequence point is a point in time at which the dust has settled and all side effects which have been seen so far are guaranteed to be complete. The sequence points listed in the C standard are:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>at the end of the evaluation of a full expression (a full expression is an expression statement, or any other expression which is not a subexpression within any larger expression);</li>\n<li>at the <code>||</code>, <code>&amp;&amp;</code>, <code>?:</code>, and comma operators; and</li>\n<li>at a function call (after the evaluation of all the arguments, and just before the actual call). </li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>The Standard states that</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>Between the previous and next sequence\n  point an object shall have its stored\n  value modified at most once by the\n  evaluation of an expression.\n  Furthermore, the prior value shall be\n  accessed only to determine the value\n  to be stored.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>These two rather opaque sentences say several things. First, they talk about operations bounded by the "previous and next sequence points"; such operations usually correspond to full expressions. (In an expression statement, the "next sequence point" is usually at the terminating semicolon, and the "previous sequence point" is at the end of the previous statement. An expression may also contain intermediate sequence points, as listed above.)</p>\n\n<p>The first sentence rules out both the examples</p>\n\n<pre><code>i++ * i++\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>and</p>\n\n<pre><code>i = i++\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>from questions 3.2 and 3.3--in both cases, i has its value modified twice within the expression, i.e. between sequence points. (If we were to write a similar expression which did have an internal sequence point, such as</p>\n\n<pre><code>i++ &amp;&amp; i++\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>it would be well-defined, if questionably useful.)</p>\n\n<p>The second sentence can be quite difficult to understand. It turns out that it disallows code like</p>\n\n<pre><code>a[i] = i++\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>from question 3.1. (Actually, the other expressions we\'ve been discussing are in violation of the second sentence, as well.) To see why, let\'s first look more carefully at what the Standard is trying to allow and disallow.</p>\n\n<p>Clearly, expressions like</p>\n\n<pre><code>a = b\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>and</p>\n\n<pre><code>c = d + e\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>which read some values and use them to write others, are well-defined and legal. Clearly, [footnote] expressions like</p>\n\n<pre><code>i = i++\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>which modify the same value twice are abominations which needn\'t be allowed (or in any case, needn\'t be well-defined, i.e. we don\'t have to figure out a way to say what they do, and compilers don\'t have to support them). Expressions like these are disallowed by the first sentence.</p>\n\n<p>It\'s also clear [footnote] that we\'d like to disallow expressions like</p>\n\n<pre><code>a[i] = i++\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>which modify i and use it along the way, but not disallow expressions like</p>\n\n<pre><code>i = i + 1\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>which use and modify i but only modify it later when it\'s reasonably easy to ensure that the final store of the final value (into <code>i</code>, in this case) doesn\'t interfere with the earlier accesses.</p>\n\n<p>And that\'s what the second sentence says: if an object is written to within a full expression, any and all accesses to it within the same expression must be directly involved in the computation of the value to be written. This rule effectively constrains legal expressions to those in which the accesses demonstrably precede the modification. For example, the old standby <code>i = i + 1</code> is allowed, because the access of <code>i</code> is used to determine <code>i</code>\'s final value. The example</p>\n\n<pre><code>a[i] = i++\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>is disallowed because one of the accesses of i (the one in <code>a[i]</code>) has nothing to do with the value which ends up being stored in <code>i</code> (which happens over in <code>i++</code>), and so there\'s no good way to define--either for our understanding or the compiler\'s--whether the access should take place before or after the incremented value is stored. Since there\'s no good way to define it, the Standard declares that it is undefined, and that portable programs simply must not use such constructs. </p>',
	              'comments': [u'Much better answer than the accepted one, IMHO.',
	                           u'could you mention the sequence points in this statement ',
	                           u' ?'],

	              'body': u'<p>Just compile and disassemble your line of code, if you are so inclined to know how exactly it is you get what you are getting.</p>\n\n<p>This is what I get on my machine, together with what I think is going on:</p>\n\n<pre><code>$ cat evil.c\nvoid evil(){\n  int i = 0;\n  i+= i++ + ++i;\n}\n$ gcc evil.c -c -o evil.bin\n$ gdb evil.bin\n(gdb) disassemble evil\nDump of assembler code for function evil:\n   0x00000000 &lt;+0&gt;:   push   %ebp\n   0x00000001 &lt;+1&gt;:   mov    %esp,%ebp\n   0x00000003 &lt;+3&gt;:   sub    $0x10,%esp\n   0x00000006 &lt;+6&gt;:   movl   $0x0,-0x4(%ebp)  // i = 0   i = 0\n   0x0000000d &lt;+13&gt;:  addl   $0x1,-0x4(%ebp)  // i++     i = 1\n   0x00000011 &lt;+17&gt;:  mov    -0x4(%ebp),%eax  // j = i   i = 1  j = 1\n   0x00000014 &lt;+20&gt;:  add    %eax,%eax        // j += j  i = 1  j = 2\n   0x00000016 &lt;+22&gt;:  add    %eax,-0x4(%ebp)  // i += j  i = 3\n   0x00000019 &lt;+25&gt;:  addl   $0x1,-0x4(%ebp)  // i++     i = 4\n   0x0000001d &lt;+29&gt;:  leave  \n   0x0000001e &lt;+30&gt;:  ret\nEnd of assembler dump.\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>(I... suppose that the 0x00000014 instruction was some kind of compiler optimization?)</p>',

	              'body': u'<p>I think the relevant parts of the C99 standard are 6.5 Expressions, \xa72</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>Between the previous and next sequence point an object shall have its stored value\n  modified at most once by the evaluation of an expression. Furthermore, the prior value\n  shall be read only to determine the value to be stored.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>and 6.5.16 Assignment operators, \xa74:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>The order of evaluation of the operands is unspecified. If an attempt is made to modify\n  the result of an assignment operator or to access it after the next sequence point, the\n  behavior is undefined. </p>\n</blockquote>',
	              'comments': [u'Would the above imply that \'i=i=5;" would be Undefined Behavior?',
	                           u'@supercat as far as I know ',
	                           u' is also undefined behavior',
	                           u'@Zaibis: The rationale I like to use for most places rule applies that in theory a mutli-processor platform could implement something like ',
	                           u' as "Write-lock A; Write-Lock B; Store 5 to A; store 5 to B; Unlock B; Unock A;", and a statement like ',
	                           u' as "Read-lock A; Read-lock B; Compute A+B; Unlock A and B; Write-lock C; Store result; Unlock C;".  That would ensure that if one thread did ',
	                           u' while another did ',
	                           u' the latter thread would either see both writes as having taken place or neither.  Potentially a useful guarantee.  If one thread did ',
	                           u', however, ...',
	                           u"... and the compiler didn't notice that both writes were to the same location (if one or both lvalues involve pointers, that may be hard to determine), the generated code could deadlock. I don't think any real-world implementations implement such locking as part of their normal behavior, but it would be permissible under the standard, and if hardware could implement such behaviors cheaply it might be useful.  On today's hardware such behavior would be way too expensive to implement as a default, but that doesn't mean it would always be thus.",
	                           u"@supercat but wouldn't the sequence point access rule of c99 alone be enough to declare it as undefined behavior? So it doesn't matter what technically the hardware could implement?"],
	              'extid': 949508,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/949433/why-are-these-constructs-using-undefined-behavior/949508#949508',
	              'user_id': 48015,
	              'vote': 21},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>The behavior can\'t really be explained because it invokes both <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unspecified_behavior">unspecified behavior</a> and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Undefined_behavior">undefined behavior</a>, so we can not make any general predictions about this code, although if you read <em>Olve Maudal\'s</em> work such as <a href="http://www.slideshare.net/olvemaudal/deep-c">Deep C</a> and <a href="http://www.pvv.org/~oma/UnspecifiedAndUndefined_ACCU_Apr2013.pdf">Unspecified and Undefined</a> sometimes you can make good guesses in very specific cases with a specific compiler and environment but please don\'t do that anywhere near production.</p>\n\n<p>So moving on to <em>unspecified behavior</em>, in <a href="http://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg14/www/docs/n1256.pdf">draft c99 standard</a> section<code>6.5</code> paragraph <em>3</em> says(<em>emphasis mine</em>):</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>The grouping of operators and operands is indicated by the syntax.74) Except as specified\n  later (for the function-call (), &amp;&amp;, ||, ?:, and comma operators), <strong>the order of evaluation of subexpressions and the order in which side effects take place are both unspecified.</strong></p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>So when we have a line like this:</p>\n\n<pre><code>i = i++ + ++i;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>we do not know whether <code>i++</code> or <code>++i</code> will be evaluated first. This is mainly to give the compiler <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/a/12540468/1708801">better options for optimization</a>.</p>\n\n<p>We also have <em>undefined behavior</em> here as well since the program is modifying variables(<code>i</code>, <code>u</code>, etc..) more than once between <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequence_point">sequence points</a>. From draft standard section <code>6.5</code> paragraph <em>2</em>(<em>emphasis mine</em>):</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p><strong>Between the previous and next sequence point an object shall have its stored value\n  modified at most once</strong> by the evaluation of an expression. Furthermore, <strong>the prior value\n  shall be read only to determine the value to be stored</strong>.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>it cites the following code examples as being undefined:</p>\n\n<pre><code>i = ++i + 1;\na[i++] = i; \n</code></pre>\n\n<p>In all these examples the code is attempting to modify an object more than once in the same sequence point, which will end with the <code>;</code> in each one of these cases:</p>\n\n<pre><code>i = i++ + ++i;\n^   ^       ^\n\ni = (i++);\n^    ^\n\nu = u++ + ++u;\n^   ^       ^\n\nu = (u++);\n^    ^\n\nv = v++ + ++v;\n^   ^       ^\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><em>Unspecified behavior</em> is defined in the <a href="http://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg14/www/docs/n1256.pdf">draft c99 standard</a> in section <code>3.4.4</code> as:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>use of an unspecified value, or other behavior where this International Standard provides\n  two or more possibilities and imposes no further requirements on which is chosen in any\n  instance</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>and <em>undefined behavior</em> is defined in section <code>3.4.3</code> as:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>behavior, upon use of a nonportable or erroneous program construct or of erroneous data,\n  for which this International Standard imposes no requirements</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>and notes that:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>Possible undefined behavior ranges from ignoring the situation completely with unpredictable results, to behaving during translation or program execution in a documented manner characteristic of the environment (with or without the issuance of a diagnostic message), to terminating a translation or execution (with the issuance of a diagnostic message).</p>\n</blockquote>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 18260171,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/949433/why-are-these-constructs-using-undefined-behavior/18260171#18260171',
	              'user_id': 1708801,
	              'vote': 13},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>While it is unlikely that any compilers and processors would actually do so, it would be legal, under the C standard, for the compiler to implement "i++" with the sequence:</p>\n\n<pre><code>In a single operation, read `i` and lock it to prevent access until further notice\nCompute (1+read_value)\nIn a single operation, unlock `i` and store the computed value\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>While I don\'t think any processors support the hardware to allow such a thing to be done efficiently, one can easily imagine situations where such behavior would make multi-threaded code easier (e.g. it would guarantee that if two threads try to perform the above sequence simultaneously, <code>i</code> would get incremented by two) and it\'s not totally inconceivable that some future processor might provide a feature something like that.</p>\n\n<p>If the compiler were to write <code>i++</code> as indicated above (legal under the standard) and were to intersperse the above instructions throughout the evaluation of the overall expression (also legal), and if it didn\'t happen to notice that one of the other instructions happened to access <code>i</code>, it would be possible (and legal) for the compiler to generate a sequence of instructions that would deadlock.  To be sure, a compiler would almost certainly detect the problem in the case where the same variable <code>i</code> is used in both places, but if a routine accepts references to two variables <code>i</code> and <code>j</code>, and uses <code>i</code> and <code>j</code> in the above expression (rather than using <code>i</code> twice) the compiler would not be required to recognize or avoid the deadlock that would occur if the same variable were passed for both <code>i</code> and <code>j</code>.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 13729991,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/949433/why-are-these-constructs-using-undefined-behavior/13729991#13729991',
	              'user_id': 363751,
	              'vote': 7},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Please read K &amp; R. it clearly states that such behaviour is undefined. Some compilers like gcc do follow some conventions but its compiler dependent. So better avoid changing and using the values of variables in single command coz same memory location cant be read or written at same time</p>',
	              'comments': [u'Did K&R specifically say it was UB, or did they simply decline to specify the sequence in which things would happen?  The architectural issues that could cause it to be "truly" Undefined Behavior didn\'t become relevant until long after ANSI took over, so if K&R did regard it as genuine "UB" that would seem prophetic.'],
	              'extid': 16787634,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/949433/why-are-these-constructs-using-undefined-behavior/16787634#16787634',
	              'user_id': 1814300,
	              'vote': 0},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>The C standard says that a variable should only be assigned at most once between two sequence points. A semi-colon for instance is a sequence point. <br>\nSo every statement of the form:<br></p>\n\n<pre><code>i = i++;\ni = i++ + ++i;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>and so on violate that rule. The standard also says that behavior is undefined and not unspecified. Some compilers do detect these and produce some result but this is not per standard.<br></p>\n\n<p>However, two different variables can be incremented between two sequence points.<br></p>\n\n<pre><code>while(*src++ = *dst++);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>The above is a common coding practice while copying/analysing strings.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 25787635,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/949433/why-are-these-constructs-using-undefined-behavior/25787635#25787635',

2015-01-03 09:41:28+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/852828/jrturton> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:41:28+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27459750/contextmenu-with-recyclerview-and-cardviews-in-it>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<blockquote>\n  <p>hello guys,\n  you can\'t directly implement these method like <strong>onClickListener</strong>, \n  <strong>OnContextMenuListener</strong> etc. because <strong>RecycleView</strong> extends <strong>android.view.ViewGroup</strong>\n  so we cant directly use these method.\n  we can implement these methods in <strong>ViewHolder</strong> adapter class. \n  we can use context menu in RecycleView like this way</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<pre><code>public static class ViewHolder extends RecyclerView.ViewHolder implements OnCreateContextMenuListener {\nTextView tvTitle;\nImageView ivImage;\n    public ViewHolder(View v) {\n        super(v);\n        tvTitle =(TextView)v.findViewById(R.id.item_title);\n        v.setOnCreateContextMenuListener(this);\n\n\n    }\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Now we follow the same procedure while implements the context menu.</p>\n\n<pre><code>@Override\n    public void onCreateContextMenu(ContextMenu menu, View v,\n            ContextMenuInfo menuInfo) {\n\n        menu.setHeaderTitle("Select The Action");    \n        menu.add(0, v.getId(), 0, "Call");//groupId, itemId, order, title   \n        menu.add(0, v.getId(), 0, "SMS"); \n\n    }\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>if you get any difficulties ask in comment. </p>',

Then add that table to your outer table and let it do all the scrolling. <code>UITableView</code> is a subclass of <code>UIScrollView</code> so look into the scrollview methods to help you configure the tableview to work within another.</p>',

	 'body': u'<p>I have a UITableView, for whom some (not all) UITableViewCells contain their own UITableView.</p>\n\n<p>The default behavior I\'m finding is, when trying to single-tap scroll (UIScrollViewPanGestureRecognizer) the outermost table, scrolling works just fine, but only when the tap begins on a cell not containing a nested UITableView.  When the cell does contain a nested UITableView, that inner table\'s PanGestureRecognizer is invoked.  This behavior is understandable and expected.</p>\n\n<p>My desire is to disable all scrolling on the inner tables, <em>and</em> have any pan gestures that begin on them instead trigger/invoke scrolling on the outer table.</p>\n\n<p>I have researched and tried several solutions, but without success.</p>\n\n<p>Disabling all interaction in the nested cell isn\'t an option, because I need the ability to tap-select or swipe-delete cells within the nested table.</p>\n\n<p>I was able to find and remove the inner table\'s UIScrollViewPanGestureRecognizer.  This successfully disabled scrolling for the inner table.  However, I couldn\'t get the outer table\'s UIScrollViewPangestureRecognizer to be invoked.  Instead my outer table basically had "dead spots" (the cells having a nested table) where scrolling on the outer table wouldn\'t take place.</p>\n\n<p>Everything I\'ve read about the view hierarchy and hit-testing suggests that the above solution should simply work:  the UITouch is wrapped in a UIEvent, and all possible receivers in the view hierarchy are thus queried.  Strangely enough, from the debugger, my view hierarchy appears to be severed at the point of the inner UITableView.  That is, for the UITableViewCell in question, its superview chain only leads to nil, not to the outermost table.  Yet, using the Reveal App (www.revealapp.com), I have confirmed that my view hierarchy is indeed connected (which makes sense, otherwise the inner table wouldn\'t be rendering).</p>\n\n<p>Lastly, I tried this code:</p>\n\n<pre><code>[innerTable.panGestureRecognizer requireGestureRecognizerToFail:outerTable.panGestureRecognizer];\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Based on my references, this should do exactly what I\'m seeking here -- the inner table won\'t capture the pan-gesture unless the outer table defers.  But this code has no effect.</p>\n\n<p>Any help you can provide is most appreciated -- this has been a confounding UI mystery for many days now!</p>',

2015-01-03 09:41:29+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753369/gcd-of-an-array> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:41:29+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/4412997/user162091> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:41:29+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753369/gcd-of-an-array>
	{'answers': [],
	 'body': u'<p>You are given an array A of integers of size N. You will be given Q queries where each query is represented by two integers L, R. 2015-01-03 09:41:30+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/3553665/jaspreet21anand> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:41:30+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27746935/add-a-field-to-wordpress-post>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>First of all, you shouldn\'t modify the core table, as a lot of people already mentioned. You can do a select using join from both tables like that:</p>\n\n<pre><code> $querystr = "\n    SELECT $wpdb-&gt;posts.* \n    FROM $wpdb-&gt;posts, $wpdb-&gt;postmeta\n    WHERE $wpdb-&gt;posts.ID = $wpdb-&gt;postmeta.post_id \n    AND $wpdb-&gt;postmeta.meta_key = \'tag\' \n    AND $wpdb-&gt;postmeta.meta_value = \'email\' \n    AND $wpdb-&gt;posts.post_status = \'publish\' \n    AND $wpdb-&gt;posts.post_type = \'post\'\n    AND $wpdb-&gt;posts.post_date &lt; NOW()\n    ORDER BY $wpdb-&gt;posts.post_date DESC\n ";\n\n $pageposts = $wpdb-&gt;get_results($querystr, OBJECT);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>More about it here: <a href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Displaying_Posts_Using_a_Custom_Select_Query" rel="nofollow">http://codex.wordpress.org/Displaying_Posts_Using_a_Custom_Select_Query</a></p>\n\n<p>Other than that, what exactly is your problem? To display a custom checkbox you can use <a href="http://codex.wordpress.org/add_meta_box" rel="nofollow">add_meta_box</a> function. To update it you need to add your function to <code>wp_insert_post_data</code> hook and then insert your data to the database, something like that:</p>\n\n<pre><code>    add_filter(\'wp_insert_post_data\', \'so27747402_save_data\');\n\n    function so27747402_save_data($post_san){\n        global $wpdb;\n        global $post;\n\n        $checkbox = (isset($_POST[\'so27747402_checkbox\']) &amp;&amp; $_POST[\'so27747402_checkbox\'] == 1);\n        update_post_meta($post-&gt;ID, \'_so27747402_checkbox\', $checkbox);\n        return $post_san;\n    }\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Or like that if you insist on doing it via changes to the core table:</p>\n\n<pre><code>    add_filter(\'wp_insert_post_data\', \'so27747402_save_data\');\n\n    function so27747402_save_data($post_san){\n        global $wpdb;\n        global $post;\n\n        $checkbox = (isset($_POST[\'so27747402_checkbox\']) &amp;&amp; $_POST[\'so27747402_checkbox\'] == 1);\n        $wpdb-&gt;query("UPDATE $wpdb-&gt;posts SET checkbox = $checkbox WHERE ID = $post-&gt;ID");\n        return $post_san;\n    }\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>But yeah, it\'s a pretty bad way. You should use <code>update_post_meta</code> instead.</p>',

And as per experience there is no event 'hover' <code>.on()</code>, so you got to use two events.\nThis works like, you have selected a static element #sortable and you are selecting dynamically <code>.sortable</code> elements.</p>",

2015-01-03 09:41:31+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27746259/actionmailer-not-delivering-mail-when-smtp-settings-configured-dynamically>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>This won\'t work because you\'re modifying the smtp settings on an instance of your mailer but the underlying mail gem reads it from the mailer class level attribute. The supported way to do this in Rails 4.0 and above is to pass a custom header called :delivery_method_options to the mail call, e.g:</p>\n\n<pre><code>class MyCustomMailer &lt; Devise::Mailer\n  before_filter set_default_host\n\n  def example_mailer(record)\n    mail to: record.email,\n         from: app_mailer_sender,\n         subject: "Example",\n         delivery_method_options: app_smtp_settings\n  end\n\n  private\n\n  def app_settings\n    @app_settings || AppSettings.first\n  end\n\n  def app_domain_address\n    app_settings.domain_address\n  end\n\n  def app_mailer_sender\n    app_settings.mailer_sender\n  end\n\n  def app_smtp_settings\n    self.smtp_settings = {\n      address:              app_settings.smtp_address,\n      port:                 app_settings.smtp_port,\n      domain:               app_settings.smtp_domain,\n      user_name:            app_settings.smtp_username,\n      password:             app_settings.smtp_password,\n      authentication:       "plain",\n      enable_starttls_auto: true\n    }\n  end\n\n  def set_default_host\n    default_url_options[:host] = app_settings.domain_address\n  end\nend\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>end</p>\n\n<p>One little tip - don\'t repeatedly call AppSettings.first since that re-queries the database (actually it\'ll be caught by the AR query cache but a new instance will be created every time). But you knew that right ;-)</p>',
	              'comments': [u'Indeed! Just a note that you have a typo in the ',
	                           u' options. It should be ',
	                           u' instead of ',
	                           u'Fixed it, thanks!',
	                           u"Though the fact that all the delivery methods have *_settings methods suggests to me that it should've been delivery_method_settings :-)"],
	              'extid': 27747088,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27746259/actionmailer-not-delivering-mail-when-smtp-settings-configured-dynamically/27747088#27747088',
	              'user_id': 185681,
	              'vote': 3}],
	 'body': u'<p>I\'m trying to set up ActionMailer\'s SMTP settings to be able to be configured at run time, but when that happens it doesn\'t seem to connect to the 3rd party service to deliver the mail. Below are 2 scenarios, the first of which the mail will send and deliver, the second of which nothing happens. I\'m using the development environment for testing</p>\n\n<p><strong>This configuration is common to both scenarios</strong></p>\n\n<pre><code># config/environments/development.rb\n\nconfig.action_mailer.perform_deliveries = true\nconfig.action_mailer.raise_delivery_errors = false\nconfig.action_mailer.default :charset =&gt; "utf-8"\nconfig.action_mailer.delivery_method = :smtp\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><strong>This works:</strong></p>\n\n<pre><code># config/environments/development.rb\n\nconfig.action_mailer.default_url_options = { host: \'www.mysite.com\' }\nconfig.action_mailer.smtp_settings = {\n  :address              =&gt; "smtp.thirdpartyservice.com",\n  :port                 =&gt; 587,\n  :domain               =&gt; \'mysite.com\',\n  :user_name            =&gt; "me@mysite.com",\n  :password             =&gt; "my-password",\n  :authentication       =&gt; "plain",\n  :enable_starttls_auto =&gt; true\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>This delivers the mail, but also when tailing the logs, there is a slight delay in the request so I know the request is being made to the third party service.</p>\n\n<p><strong>This doesn\'t work:</strong></p>\n\n<p>This is the setup I want, using a custom mailer that I\'m using.</p>\n\n<pre><code>class MyCustomMailer &lt; Devise::Mailer\n  before_filter :use_smtp_settings\n\n  def example_mailer(record)\n    Rails.logger.warn self.smtp_settings\n    @resource = record\n    mail(to: record.email,\n     from: AppSettings.first.mailer_sender,\n     subject: "Example")\n  end\n\n  private\n\n  def use_smtp_settings\n    self.default_url_options[:host] = AppSettings.first.domain_address\n    self.smtp_settings = {\n      :address              =&gt; AppSettings.first.smtp_address,\n      :port                 =&gt; AppSettings.first.smtp_port,\n      :domain               =&gt; AppSettings.first.smtp_domain,\n      :user_name            =&gt; AppSettings.first.smtp_username,\n      :password             =&gt; AppSettings.first.smtp_password,\n      :authentication       =&gt; "plain",\n      :enable_starttls_auto =&gt; true\n    }\n  end\nend\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>The rails logger in the <code>#example_mailer()</code> method shows the same attributes that are used in the first example, albeit loaded from the <code>app_settings</code> table. However when tailing the logs this time, there is no delay so ActionMailer doesn\'t seem to even try making a request to the third party service.</p>',

It is a container for large sets of views that can be recycled and scrolled very efficiently. </p>\n\n<p>Yo use a <code>RecyclerView</code>, an adapter (extending <code>RecyclerView.Adapter</code>) and a layout manager (extending <code>RecyclerView.LayoutManager</code>) must be provided. By default, <code>RecyclerView</code>  provides <code>LinearLayoutManager</code>, which shows the items in a vertical or horizontal scrolling list.</p>',

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>UIPanGestureRecognizer is a concrete subclass of UIGestureRecognizer that looks for panning (dragging) gestures. The user must be pressing one or more fingers on a view while they pan it. Clients implementing the action method for this gesture recognizer can ask it for the current translation and velocity of the gesture.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>A panning gesture is continuous. It begins (UIGestureRecognizerStateBegan) when the minimum number of fingers allowed (minimumNumberOfTouches) has moved enough to be considered a pan. It changes (UIGestureRecognizerStateChanged) when a finger moves while at least the minimum number of fingers are pressed down. It ends (UIGestureRecognizerStateEnded) when all fingers are lifted.</p>\n\n<p>Clients of this class can, in their action methods, query the UIPanGestureRecognizer object for the current translation of the gesture (translationInView:) and the velocity of the translation (velocityInView:). They can specify the view whose coordinate system should be used for the translation and velocity values. Clients may also reset the translation to a desired value.</p>\n\n<p>Whole document - <a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/UIKit/Reference/UIPanGestureRecognizer_Class/Reference/Reference.html" rel="nofollow">UIPanGestureRecognizer</a></p>',
	 'name': 'uipangesturerecognizer',
	 'qcount': 459,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/uipangesturerecognizer/info'}

2015-01-03 09:41:34+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/uigesturerecognizer/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>UIGestureRecognizer is an abstract base class for concrete gesture-recognizer classes. A gesture-recognizer object (or, simply, a gesture recognizer) decouples the logic for recognizing a gesture and acting on that recognition. When one of these objects recognizes a common gesture or, in some cases, a change in the gesture, it sends an action message to each designated target object.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<blockquote>\n  <p>The <code>UIGestureRecognizer</code> class defines a set of common behaviors that\n  can be configured for all concrete gesture recognizers. It can also\n  communicate with its delegate (an object that adopts the\n  <code>UIGestureRecognizerDelegate</code> protocol), thereby enabling finer-grained\n  customization of some behaviors.</p>\n  \n  <p>A gesture recognizer operates on touches hit-tested to a specific view\n  and all of that view\u2019s subviews. It thus must be associated with that\n  view. To make that association you must call the <code>UIView</code> method\n  <code>addGestureRecognizer:</code>. A gesture recognizer does not participate in\n  the view\u2019s responder chain.</p>\n  \n  <p>A gesture recognizer has one or more target-action pairs associated\n  with it. If there are multiple target-action pairs, they are discrete,\n  and not cumulative. Recognition of a gesture results in the dispatch\n  of an action message to a target for each of those pairs. The action\n  methods invoked must conform to one of the following signatures:</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<pre><code> - (void)handleGesture;\n - (void)handleGesture:(UIGestureRecognizer *)gestureRecognizer;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Resources:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/UIKit/Reference/UIGestureRecognizer_Class/Reference/Reference.html" rel="nofollow">Class Reference</a></li>\n</ul>',

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>An algorithm is a sequence of well-defined steps that defines an abstract solution to a problem. Use this tag when your issue is related to algorithm design.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>An algorithm is a set of ordered instructions based on a formal language with the following conditions:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Finite</strong>. The number of instructions must be finite.</li>\n<li><strong>Executable</strong>. All instructions must be executable in some language-dependent way, in a finite amount of time.</li>\n<li><strong>Deterministic</strong>. The algorithm must be predictable.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>An algorithm can be expressed in many ways: as a sequence of instructions; as a block-scheme; as a code in an existing or new programming language; as a piece of text in a human language; or in other, similar ways.</p>\n\n<p>An algorithm can solve a class of problems. For example, both "sum 1 and 3" and "sum 4 and 5" are problems in the same class: "sum two integer numbers." Furthermore, a given class of problems can generally be solved by a variety of algorithms.</p>\n\n<p>One important aspect of algorithm design is performance. For large datasets a good algorithm may outperform a poor algorithm by several orders of magnitude. Algorithm performance is often rated with <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_O_notation" rel="nofollow">Big O or \u0398 notation</a>, but one should be cautious with asymptotic notation, since big constants may be involved.</p>\n\n<p>A key algorithm classification is known as <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_complexity_theory" rel="nofollow">Algorithm Complexity</a>.</p>\n\n<h1>Related Links</h1>\n\n<p>Additional resources on algorithms include:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithm" rel="nofollow">Algorithm on Wikipedia</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://computer.howstuffworks.com/question717.htm" rel="nofollow">Algorithm on Howstuffworks</a></li>\n</ul>',

2015-01-03 09:41:36+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/java/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753369/gcd-of-an-array)
2015-01-03 09:41:36+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/java/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Java is a general-purpose programming language designed to be used in conjunction with the Java Virtual Machine (JVM). "Java platform" is the name for a computing system that has installed tools for developing and running Java programs. Use this tag for questions referring to Java programming language or Java platform tools.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://www.java.com/en/" rel="nofollow">Java</a> is a <em>high-level</em>, <em>platform-independent</em>, <em>object-oriented programming</em> language and run-time environment. The Java language derives much of its syntax from <a href="/questions/tagged/c" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c\'" rel="tag">c</a> and <a href="/questions/tagged/c%2b%2b" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c++\'" rel="tag">c++</a>, but its object model is simpler than that of <a href="/questions/tagged/c%2b%2b" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c++\'" rel="tag">c++</a> and it has fewer low-level facilities. Java applications are typically compiled to <strong>bytecode</strong> (called <strong>class</strong> files) that can be executed by a Java Virtual Machine <a href="/questions/tagged/jvm" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jvm\'" rel="tag">jvm</a>, independent of computer architecture. The <a href="/questions/tagged/jvm" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jvm\'" rel="tag">jvm</a> manages memory with the help of a <strong>garbage collector</strong> (see <a href="/questions/tagged/garbage-collection" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'garbage-collection\'" rel="tag">garbage-collection</a>) in order to handle object removal from memory when not used anymore. Java\'s <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_system" rel="nofollow">typing discipline</a> is static, strong, safe, nominative, and manifest. Java supports features such as reflection and interfacing with C and C++ via <a href="/questions/tagged/jni" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jni\'" rel="tag">jni</a>.</p>\n\n<p><a href="/questions/tagged/java" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'java\'" rel="tag">java</a> is designed to have as few implementation dependencies as possible, intended to allow application developers to "<strong>write once, run anywhere</strong>" (<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Write_once,_run_anywhere" rel="nofollow">WORA</a>): code that executes on one platform does not need to be recompiled to run on another machine. Java was originally developed by <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Gosling" rel="nofollow">James Gosling</a> at Sun Microsystems (which merged with Oracle Corporation on April 20, 2009) and was released in 1995 as a core component of Sun Microsystems\' Java platform.</p>\n\n<p>The <a href="http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Java_Programming/The_Java_Platform" rel="nofollow">Java platform</a> is the name given by Sun (now Oracle) to computing systems that have installed tools for developing and running Java programs. The platform features a wide variety of tools that can help developers work efficiently with the Java programming language.</p>\n\n<p>The platform consists of two essential software packages:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>the <strong>Java Runtime Environment (JRE)</strong>, which is needed to <em>run</em> Java applications and applets; and,</li>\n<li>the <strong>Java Development Kit (JDK)</strong>, which is needed to <em>develop</em> Java applications and applets. The JDK comes with a JRE.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>In this section, we will explore in further detail what these two software components of the Java platform do.</p>\n\n<h2>Background</h2>\n\n<p>The main reference implementation of Java is open source (the <a href="http://openjdk.java.net/" rel="nofollow">OpenJDK</a>), and is supported by major companies including Oracle, Apple, SAP and IBM.</p>\n\n<p>Very few computers can run Java programs directly. Therefore, the Java environment is normally made available by installing a suitable software component. On Windows computers, this is usually done by downloading the free Java Runtime Environment (JRE) from <a href="http://www.java.com/en/" rel="nofollow">java.com</a>. On Macintosh computers, the user is prompted to download Java when an application requiring it is started. On <a href="/questions/tagged/linux" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'linux\'" rel="tag">linux</a>-like systems, Java is typically installed via the package manager.</p>\n\n<p>Developers frequently need additional tools, which are available in the free Java Development Kit, which for Windows and Mac must be downloaded from <a href="http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html" rel="nofollow">Oracle</a> and installed manually.</p>\n\n<p>Java is compiled into bytecode, which is interpreted by the JVM by compiling it into native code. The compilation is done <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Just-in-time_compilation" rel="nofollow">just-in-time</a> (JIT). This was initially viewed as a performance hit, but JVM and JIT compilation improvements have made this less of a concern. In some cases, the JVM may even be faster than native code compiled to target an older version of a processor for backward-compatibility reasons.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Note:</strong> Other vendors exist, though almost all have license fees. For <a href="/questions/tagged/linux" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'linux\'" rel="tag">linux</a> and other platforms, consult the operating system documentation.</p>\n\n<h2>Versions</h2>\n\n<p><strong>Notable Java versions, code names, and release dates include:</strong></p>\n\n<pre class="lang-none prettyprint-override"><code>JDK 1.0                  (January 23, 1996)\nJDK 1.1                  (February 19, 1997)\nJ2SE 1.2    [Playground] (December 8, 1998)\nJ2SE 1.3    [Kestrel]    (May 8, 2000)\nJ2SE 1.4    [Merlin]     (February 6, 2002)\nJ2SE 5.0    [Tiger]      (September 30, 2004)\nJava SE 6   [Mustang]    (December 11, 2006)\nJava SE 7   [Dolphin]    (July 28, 2011)\nJava SE 8   [JSR 337]    (March 18, 2014)\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><strong>Latest Stable Versions:</strong></p>\n\n<pre class="lang-none prettyprint-override"><code>Java Standard Edition 8 Update 25 (1.8.0_25) - (October 14, 2014)\nJava Standard Edition 7 Update 72 (1.7.0_72) - (October 14, 2014)\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>For more code names and release dates, visit <a href="http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/codenames-136090.html" rel="nofollow">J2SE Code Names</a>. To see release notes for each version of the JDK, visit the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_version_history" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia article</a> on Java version history.</p>\n\n<p>Java SE 8 is now released and is <a href="http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html" rel="nofollow">available for download</a>.</p>\n\n<p>The <a href="http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/eol-135779.html" rel="nofollow">End Of Public Updates</a> (Formerly called End Of Life) dates are:</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-none prettyprint-override"><code>J2SE 1.4   -  Oct 2008\nJ2SE 5.0   -  Oct 2009\nJava SE 6  -  Feb 2013\nJava SE 7  -  Apr 2015\nJava SE 8  -  Mar 2017\n</code></pre>\n\n<h2>Initial help</h2>\n\n<p>New to Java or need help to get your first Java program running? See the <a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/getStarted/index.html" rel="nofollow">Oracle Java Tutorials section on Getting Started</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Before asking a question, please use the search box in the upper-right corner to see if it has been asked before (we have many duplicates), and read the <a href="http://msmvps.com/blogs/jon_skeet/archive/2010/08/29/writing-the-perfect-question.aspx" rel="nofollow">Writing the perfect question</a> article to learn how to get Jon Skeet to answer your question.</p>\n\n<h2>Naming conventions</h2>\n\n<p>Java programs should adhere to the following <a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se8/html/jls-6.html" rel="nofollow">naming conventions</a> to increase readability and decrease chances of accidental errors. By following these naming conventions, you will make it easier for others to understand your code and help you.</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Type names</strong> (classes, interfaces, enums, etc.) should begin with a capital letter, and capitalize the first letter of each subsequent word. Examples include: <code>String</code>, <code>ThreadLocal</code>, and <code>NullPointerException</code>. This is sometimes known as pascal case.</li>\n<li><strong>Method names</strong> should be camelCased; that is, they should begin with a lowercase letter and capitalize the first letter of each subsequent word. Examples: <code>indexOf</code>, <code>printStackTrace</code>, <code>interrupt</code>.</li>\n<li><strong>Field names</strong> should be camelCased just like method names.</li>\n<li><strong>Constant expression names</strong> (<code>static final</code> immutable objects) should be written in ALL_CAPS, with underscores separating each word. Examples: <code>YELLOW</code>, <code>DO_NOTHING_ON_CLOSE</code>. This also applies to values of an <code>Enum</code> class. However, <code>static final</code> references to <em>non</em>-immutable objects should be camelCased. </li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Hello World - Your first program</h2>\n\n<p>Code of <strong>Hello World</strong> program:</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-java prettyprint-override"><code>public class HelloWorld {\n    public static void main(String[] args) {\n        System.out.println("Hello, World!");\n    }\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Compilation and invocation of <strong>Hello World</strong> program:</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-bash prettyprint-override"><code>javac -d . HelloWorld.java\njava -cp . HelloWorld\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Java source code is compiled to an intermediate form (bytecode instructions for the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_virtual_machine" rel="nofollow">Java Virtual Machine</a>) that can be executed with the <code>java</code> command.</p>\n\n<p>More information:  </p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_%28programming_language%29" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia on Java</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Development_Kit" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia on the JDK</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_virtual_machine#Execution_environment" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia on the JRE</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html" rel="nofollow">Download Java from Oracle</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Useful IDEs for Java</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a Original ActionMailer is written in Ruby, but there is also implementation for ASP.NET MVC.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Action Mailer is a framework for designing email service layers. These layers are used to consolidate code for sending out forgotten passwords, welcome wishes on signup, invoices for billing, and any other use case that requires a written notification to either a person or another system.</p>\n\n<p>Action Mailer is in essence a wrapper around Action Controller and the Mail gem. It provides a way to make emails using templates in the same way that Action Controller renders views using templates.</p>\n\n<p>Additionally, an Action Mailer class can be used to process incoming email, such as allowing a blog to accept new posts from an email (which could even have been sent from a phone).</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://github.com/rails/rails/tree/master/actionmailer" rel="nofollow">ActionMailer for Ruby on Rails on GitHub</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://bitbucket.org/swaj/actionmailer.net/wiki/Home" rel="nofollow">ActionMailer port to ASP.NET MVC on BitBucket</a></li>\n</ul>',

The typing and their checks can be performed at compile-time or at run-time.  </p>\n\n<p><strong>See also</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/datatypes" class="post-tag" title="show
