2015-01-03 09:41:38+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/regex/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Regular expressions (often shortened to "regex") are expressions written in a declarative language used for matching patterns within strings. General reference: http://stackoverflow.com/q/22937618 Remember to include a tag specifying the programming language or tool you are using.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<h2>Regular and Irregular Expressions</h2>\n\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regular_expression" rel="nofollow">Regular expression</a> is a powerful form of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Declarative_programming" rel="nofollow">declarative programming languages</a>, mainly used for pattern-matching within strings. Its corresponding machine model is the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite-state_machine" rel="nofollow">finite automaton</a>. </p>\n\n<p>There are <a href="http://www.regular-expressions.info/refflavors.html" rel="nofollow">many different dialects</a> (called <strong>flavors</strong>) of regular expressions, all subtly different. Therefore, when asking questions, <strong><em>always</em> include the tag for the specific programming language or tool</strong> (<em>e.g.,</em> Perl, Ruby, Python, Java, JavaScript, vi, Emacs, sed, Lex, grep, <em>etc.</em>) you are using. Otherwise, you may get answers that won\'t work for you.</p>\n\n<p>Depending on which flavor you\u2019re using, modern regular expression engines can support advanced features like <a href="http://www.regular-expressions.info/backref.html" rel="nofollow">backreferences</a>, <a href="http://www.regular-expressions.info/conditional.html" rel="nofollow">conditional subpatterns</a>, regular expression <a href="http://www.regular-expressions.info/subroutine.html" rel="nofollow">subroutines</a>, <a href="http://www.regular-expressions.info/pcre.html#callout" rel="nofollow">code callouts</a>, positive and negative <a href="http://www.regular-expressions.info/lookaround.html" rel="nofollow">lookahead/lookbehind assertions</a>, and even <a href="http://www.regular-expressions.info/recurse.html" rel="nofollow">recursion</a>. This rich feature-set allows them to parse far more than the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regular_language" rel="nofollow">strictly regular languages</a> for which they were originally named.</p>\n\n<p>Today, we still call these pattern-matching languages <em>regular expressions</em> (or <em>regexes</em> for short), even if they may no longer be <em>regular</em> in the computer scientific sense.</p>\n\n<p>Regular expressions are used for two purposes: input validation and data extraction. Regular expressions for input validation must accept <em>all</em> input allowed by standard (if any) or requirement and reject everything else, and it must do so correctly on arbitrary input string, without any assumption. Such regular expressions can be very complex, but their strictness makes them full-fledged parsers capable of extracting data. On the other hand, regular expression for data extraction only needs to work correctly on a certain input domain, which may or may not be well-defined. Such regular expression usually comes with assumptions on certain features of the data, which makes it fragile and subject to breakage on unexpected change in the input domain.</p>\n\n<h2>Fools Rush in Where Angels Fear to Tread</h2>\n\n<p>The tremendous power and expressiveness of modern regular expressions can seduce the gullible \u2014 or the foolhardy \u2014 into trying to use regular expressions on every string-related task they come across. This is a bad idea in general, and a <em>very</em> bad idea in one particular area.  Although it is perfectly appropriate to use regular expressions on <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/q/1732348/3622940"><em>specific</em> XML or HTML of known characteristics</a>, attempting to fully and correctly parse <em>arbitrary</em> XML or HTML using regular expressions alone has been known to <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/a/1732454/3622940">induce madness</a> in those attempting this <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Herculean#Adjective" rel="nofollow">Herculean</a> and <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Sisyphean#Adjective" rel="nofollow">Sisyphean</a> task.</p>\n\n<p>For <strong>general parsing of arbitrary XML or HTML,</strong> it is therefore always better to use a dedicated parser \u2014 like an <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_API_for_XML#XML_processing_with_SAX" rel="nofollow">event-driven SAX parser</a> or a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Document_Object_Model" rel="nofollow">DOM parser</a> \u2014 than it is to use regular expressions.</p>\n\n<h2>How to ask regex-based questions</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>Different languages have different regex implementations. So it\'s wise to mention the language in which you want your regex to work. If you are not specific about the language, do mention it.</p></li>\n<li><p>Regex questions are best explained with examples than elaborate sentences. Give us examples of what needs to be matched and what shouldn\'t.</p></li>\n<li><p>Even if you are not well versed in regexes, it\'s better to show us what you\'ve tried than simply asking the community to solve your problem.</p></li>\n<li><p>Use online tools like <a href="http://regex101.com/" rel="nofollow">Regex101</a> <a href="http://gskinner.com/RegExr/" rel="nofollow">RegExr</a> and <a href="http://regexpal.com/" rel="nofollow">RegexPal</a> to verify your regex patterns. You can even paste links from these sites to show us what you tried and what are the results.</p></li>\n<li><p>Ensure your question is a regular expression and not a filename expansion (tag: <a href="/questions/tagged/glob" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'glob\'" rel="tag">glob</a>) often used on command lines to match files to pass as parameters to a command.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Useful links</h2>\n\n<h3>Learning regular expressions</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://regex.learncodethehardway.org/book/" rel="nofollow">Learn Regex The Hard Way (Online book)</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://txt2re.com/" rel="nofollow">Text2Re \u2013 Generate Regular expressions based on a string</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://swtch.com/~rsc/regexp/regexp1.html" rel="nofollow">Basic concept of how RegularExpression parsing works</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regular_expression" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia entry on regular expressions</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://shop.oreilly.com/product/9780596528126.do" rel="nofollow">O\'Reilly \u2013 Mastering Regular Expressions (e-book)</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920023630.do" rel="nofollow">O\'Reilly \u2013 Regular Expressions Cookbook (e-book)</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://shop.oreilly.com/product/9780596514273.do" rel="nofollow">O\'Reilly \u2013 Regular Expression Pocket Reference (e-book)</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.cs.colorado.edu/~schenkc/UNIX_Regular_Expressions.pdf" rel="nofollow">A Tao Of Regular Expressions (e-book)</a> (pdf link)</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.regular-expressions.info/" rel="nofollow">Regular-Expressions.info</a> (informative website for learning regular expressions)</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.rexegg.com/" rel="nofollow">RexEgg</a> (a regular expressions tutorial that goes deep into advanced features)</li>\n<li><a href="http://regexone.com/" rel="nofollow">RegexOne</a> ("learn regular expressions with simple, interactive examples")</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Documentation for javascript</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-US/library/9dthzd08(v=vs.94).aspx" rel="nofollow">Microsoft Developer Network</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Online sandboxes (for testing and publishing regexes online)</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.regexplanet.com/" rel="nofollow">RegexPlanet</a> (supports a variety of flavors to choose from)</li>\n<li><a href="http://regexpal.com/" rel="nofollow">Regexpal</a> (ECMAScript flavor, as implemented by JavaScript)</li>\n<li><a href="http://regexhero.net/tester/" rel="nofollow">Regexhero</a> (.NET flavor)</li>\n<li><a (in JavaScript, \xe0 la jsFiddle)</li>\n<li><a href="http://rubular.com/" rel="nofollow">Rubular</a> (Ruby flavor)</li>\n<li><a href="http://myregexp.com/" rel="nofollow">myregexp.com</a> (Java-applet with source code)</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.regexe.com/" rel="nofollow">regexe.com</a> (German; probably Java flavor)</li>\n<li><a href="http://regex101.com/" rel="nofollow">regex101</a> (in JavaScript, Python, PCRE-compatible, generates explanation of pattern)</li>\n<li><a href="http://regexper.com/" rel="nofollow">regexper.com</a> (generates graphical representation for ECMAScript flavor)</li>\n<li><a href="http://debuggex.com/" rel="nofollow">debuggex</a> (generates graphical representation and shows processing of pattern \u2013 JavaScript, Python, and PCRE-compatible)</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Other links</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/pcre" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'pcre\'" rel="tag">pcre</a> \u2013 <a href="http://regexlib.com/" rel="nofollow">Regular Expression Library</a> \u2013 a searchable library of pre-made regular expressions. If you need to write a commonly-needed regex, searching this library might be more efficient than asking a question here.</li>\n</ul>',

2015-01-03 09:41:38+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/string/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>A string is a finite sequence of symbols, commonly used for text, though sometimes for arbitrary data.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>A string is a finite sequence of symbols, commonly used for text, though sometimes for arbitrary data.</p>\n\n<p>Most programming languages provide a dedicated string data type or more general facilities and conventions for handling strings; as well as providing a way to denote string literals. In some programming languages <a href="http://wiki.tcl.tk/3018" rel="nofollow">everything is a string</a>, for example in Tcl. A dedicated support library of differing sophistication is mostly provided as well.</p>\n\n<p>String representations vary widely in the features they offer; the right string type can easily decrease the order of algorithms, while the wrong one might not even be able to accommodate your string data at all.</p>\n\n<p>The following are some hand-picked representatives:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Zero-terminated Strings (aka. C-strings, ASCIZ, sz) are arrays of non-null elements, terminated by a special, null element (variants using a different terminating symbol are mostly restricted to old systems, e.g. DOS supported <code>$</code>).</li>\n<li>Counted String (aka Pascal Strings) are arrays of arbitrary bytes, prefixed by a length indicator. Nowadays, the size for counted strings is restricted by available address space, though it was quite common to use a single byte for length (implying maximum length of 255).</li>\n<li>Ropes, which are lists of segments (for example length + pointers into modifiable and non-modifiable buffers), for efficient insertion and deletion.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Many (especially functional) languages support strings as a list of base symbols.</p>\n\n<p>For <a href="/questions/tagged/unicode" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'unicode\'" rel="tag">unicode</a> support, a special string of the strings type is getting common, as Unicode characters can be of arbitrary length, even in <a href="/questions/tagged/utf32" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'utf32\'" rel="tag">utf32</a>. This enables efficient character-indexing by pushing the complexities of the character set into the string type.</p>\n\n<p>In most languages, strings can be iterated over, similar to lists/arrays. In some high-level languages (in which strings are a data type unto themselves), strings are immutable, so string operations create new strings.</p>\n\n<p>For text strings, many encodings are in used, though modern usage is converging on <a href="/questions/tagged/unicode" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'unicode\'" rel="tag">unicode</a>, using <a href="/questions/tagged/utf-8" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'utf-8\'" rel="tag">utf-8</a> (some early adopters of Unicode instead transitioned form <a href="/questions/tagged/ucs2" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ucs2\'" rel="tag">ucs2</a> to <a href="/questions/tagged/utf-16" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'utf-16\'" rel="tag">utf-16</a> as a persistence format).</p>\n\n<p>Windows software often adopts the WinAPI convention of using UTF-16 internally, converting for external data and persistence instead of system calls.</p>\n\n<p>When a string appears literally in source code, it is known as a string literal and has a representation that denotes it as such.</p>\n\n<h3>Useful Links:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/String_(computer_science)" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia entry on String</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C_string_handling" rel="nofollow">String Handling</a></li>\n</ul>',
	 'name': 'string',
	 'qcount': 70406,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/string/info'}

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Email is a method of exchanging digital messages from a sender to one or more recipients.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Electronic mail, commonly called email or e-mail, is a method of exchanging digital messages from a sender to one or more recipients.</p>\n\n<p>Modern email operates across the Internet or other computer networks. Some early email systems required that the sender and the recipient both be online at the same time - a system currently known as Instant messaging. Today\'s email systems are based on a store-and-forward model. Email servers accept, forward, deliver and store messages. Neither the users nor their computers are required to be online simultaneously; they need connect only briefly, typically to an email server, for as long as it takes to send or receive messages.</p>\n\n<p>In other words e-mail is an Internet service that allows those people who have an e-mail address (accounts) to send and receive electronic letters. Those are much like postal letters, except that they are delivered much faster than snail mail when sending over long distances, and are usually free.</p>\n\n<h2>References</h2>  \n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Email" rel="nofollow">Email (Wikipedia)</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://simple.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-mail" rel="nofollow">http://simple.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-mail</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://computer.howstuffworks.com/e-mail-messaging/email.htm" rel="nofollow">http://computer.howstuffworks.com/e-mail-messaging/email.htm</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>Tag usage</h2>\n\n<p>The tag <a href="/questions/tagged/email" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'email\'" rel="tag">email</a> can be used for all web based programming related problems in implementing feature of emailing a message from one client to another client. The tag can also be used for setting up a simple mail server. Please note that <a href="http://serverfault.com/">http://serverfault.com/</a> is another Stack Exchange website where you can ask e-mail server related specific problems.</p>\n\n<h2>Related Tags</h2>\n\n<p><a href="/questions/tagged/pop" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'pop\'" rel="tag">pop</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/smtp" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'smtp\'" rel="tag">smtp</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/imap" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'imap\'" rel="tag">imap</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/mailto" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'mailto\'" rel="tag">mailto</a></p>',

2015-01-03 09:41:39+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/ruby-on-rails/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Ruby on Rails is an open source full-stack web application framework written in Ruby. It follows the popular MVC framework model and is known for its "convention over configuration" approach to application development.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://rubyonrails.org/" rel="nofollow">Ruby on Rails</a> is an open source full-stack web application framework created by <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Heinemeier_Hansson" rel="nofollow">David Heinemeier Hansson</a> (DHH) in 2004 using the <a href="http://www.ruby-lang.org/en/" rel="nofollow">Ruby</a> programming language. It is an optimized framework aimed at programmer happiness and sustainable productivity by making use of <em>CoC</em> (<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convention_over_configuration" rel="nofollow">Convention over configuration</a>), <em>DRY</em> (<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don\'t_repeat_yourself" rel="nofollow">Don\'t Repeat Yourself</a>), <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_record_pattern" rel="nofollow">Active record pattern</a> and <em>REST</em> (<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representational_state_transfer" rel="nofollow">Representational State Transfer</a>) philosophies.</p>\n\n<p>It is based on the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model%E2%80%93view%E2%80%93controller" rel="nofollow">MVC Architectural Design Pattern</a>, which separates web applications into three different modules:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>model</li>\n<li>view</li>\n<li>controller</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>This helps to isolate business logic from presentation and makes code maintenance significantly easier.</p>\n\n<h2><code>Ruby != Ruby on Rails</code></h2>\n\n<p>The <a href="/questions/tagged/ruby-on-rails" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ruby-on-rails\'" rel="tag">ruby-on-rails</a> tag is for questions related to the Ruby on Rails framework. This tag is particularly appropriate for questions about:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Rails MVC patterns</li>\n<li>Rails objects</li>\n<li>Rails methods</li>\n<li>Rails gems</li>\n<li>Rails views</li>\n<li>ActiveRecord object-relational mapping (ORM)</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Questions about Ruby on Rails should not be tagged with <a href="/questions/tagged/ruby" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ruby\'" rel="tag">ruby</a> unless the question is about the Ruby language in general, its syntax and libraries, or other questions not specific to the Ruby on Rails MVC framework.</p>\n\n<p>Please see the <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/ruby/info">Ruby tag wiki</a> for more information about when it\'s appropriate to tag a question with <a href="/questions/tagged/ruby" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ruby\'" rel="tag">ruby</a> instead of <a href="/questions/tagged/ruby-on-rails" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ruby-on-rails\'" rel="tag">ruby-on-rails</a>.</p>\n\n<h3>Specific Versions</h3>\n\n<p>Questions regarding specific versions of Ruby on Rails can also be asked on the appropriate tags: <a href="/questions/tagged/ruby-on-rails-3" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ruby-on-rails-3\'" rel="tag">ruby-on-rails-3</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/ruby-on-rails-3.1" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ruby-on-rails-3.1\'" rel="tag">ruby-on-rails-3.1</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/ruby-on-rails-3.2" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ruby-on-rails-3.2\'" rel="tag">ruby-on-rails-3.2</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/ruby-on-rails-4" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ruby-on-rails-4\'" rel="tag">ruby-on-rails-4</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/ruby-on-rails-4.1" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ruby-on-rails-4.1\'" rel="tag">ruby-on-rails-4.1</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/ruby-on-rails-4.2" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ruby-on-rails-4.2\'" rel="tag">ruby-on-rails-4.2</a></p>\n\n<h3>Where to start:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://guides.rubyonrails.org/getting_started.html" rel="nofollow">Getting Started with Rails</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://guides.rubyonrails.org/" rel="nofollow">Rails Guides</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://railscasts.com/" rel="nofollow">Rails Screencasts</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://guides.rubyonrails.org/testing.html" rel="nofollow">A Guide to Testing Rails Applications</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Interactive Ruby:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.codecademy.com/tracks/ruby" rel="nofollow">Codecademy</a> - Learn the fundamentals of Ruby and dynamic programming</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Online Courses:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://www.coursera.org/course/webapplications" rel="nofollow">Web Application Architectures</a> - Learn how to build and deploy modern web application architectures \u2013 applications that run over the Internet, in the "cloud," using a browser as the user interface. We\'re going to learn about web apps through the Ruby on Rails framework.  Rails is a framework for creating web applications that is built on top of the Ruby programming language.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Resources:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://weblog.rubyonrails.org/" rel="nofollow">Riding Rails official blog</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://api.rubyonrails.org/" rel="nofollow">API documentation</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://apidock.com/" rel="nofollow">Collaborative API documentation</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://github.com/rails/rails/" rel="nofollow">Rails Source Code</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://github.com/rails/rails/issues" rel="nofollow">Rails GitHub Issue Tracker</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://ruby.railstutorial.org/ruby-on-rails-tutorial-book" rel="nofollow">Ruby on Rails Tutorial: Learn Rails By Example</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rubyonrails.org/community" rel="nofollow">Community</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ruby_on_Rails" rel="nofollow">Ruby on Rails</a> - Wikipedia</li>\n<li><a href="http://railsforzombies.org/" rel="nofollow">Rails for Zombies</a> - Code School</li>\n<li><a href="http://railscasts.com" rel="nofollow">Railscasts</a> - Ruby on Rails screencasts</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Books:</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/097669400X" rel="nofollow">Agile Web Development with Rails </a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0977616614" rel="nofollow">Everyday Scripting with Ruby</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/1934356476" rel="nofollow">Metaprogramming Ruby: Program Like the Ruby Pros</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://pragprog.com/book/ruby4/programming-ruby-1-9-2-0" rel="nofollow">Programming Ruby 1.9 &amp; 	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>jQuery is a popular cross-browser JavaScript library that facilitates DOM (HTML Structure) traversal, event handling, animation and AJAX interactions by minimizing the discrepancies across browsers and providing an easy-to-use API.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://jquery.com" rel="nofollow">jQuery</a>, formally known as jQuery Core, is a cross-browser <a href="/questions/tagged/javascript" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'javascript\'" rel="tag">javascript</a> library, created by <a href="http://ejohn.org" rel="nofollow">John Resig</a>, which provides abstractions for common client-side tasks such as <a href="/questions/tagged/dom" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'dom\'" rel="tag">dom</a> traversal, <a href="/questions/tagged/dom" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'dom\'" rel="tag">dom</a> manipulation, <a href="/questions/tagged/event-handling" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'event-handling\'" rel="tag">event-handling</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/animation" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'animation\'" rel="tag">animation</a>, and <a href="/questions/tagged/ajax" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ajax\'" rel="tag">ajax</a>. jQuery also provides a platform to create plugins that <a href="/questions/tagged/extend" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'extend\'" rel="tag">extend</a> jQuery\'s capabilities beyond those already provided by the library. The development of jQuery and related projects is coordinated by the <a href="https://jquery.org" rel="nofollow">jQuery Foundation</a>.</p>\n\n<h2>Features</h2>\n\n<p>jQuery includes the following features:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>DOM element selections using the multi-browser open source selector engine Sizzle, a spin-off of the jQuery project</li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/dom-traversal" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'dom-traversal\'" rel="tag">dom-traversal</a> and modification (including support for CSS 1\u20133)</li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/dom-manipulation" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'dom-manipulation\'" rel="tag">dom-manipulation</a> based on <a href="/questions/tagged/css-selectors" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'css-selectors\'" rel="tag">css-selectors</a> that uses node <a href="/questions/tagged/elements" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'elements\'" rel="tag">elements</a> name and node elements attributes (id and class) as criteria to build selectors</li>\n<li>Events</li>\n<li>Effects and animations</li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/ajax" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ajax\'" rel="tag">ajax</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/json-parsing" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'json-parsing\'" rel="tag">json-parsing</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/extensibility" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'extensibility\'" rel="tag">extensibility</a> through plug-ins</li>\n<li>Utilities - such as <a href="/questions/tagged/user-agent" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'user-agent\'" rel="tag">user-agent</a> information, <a href="/questions/tagged/feature-detection" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'feature-detection\'" rel="tag">feature-detection</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/compatibility" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'compatibility\'" rel="tag">compatibility</a> methods that are natively available in modern browsers but need fall backs for older ones - For example the inArray() and each() functions.</li>\n<li>Multi-browser (not to be confused with <a href="/questions/tagged/cross-browser" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cross-browser\'" rel="tag">cross-browser</a>) support.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Support</h2>\n\n<p>Both version 1.x and 2.x of jQuery support "current-1 versions" (meaning the current stable version of the browser and the version that preceded it) of <a href="/questions/tagged/firefox" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'firefox\'" rel="tag"><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/WcBXc.png" height="16" width="18" alt="" class="sponsor-tag-img">firefox</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/chrome" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'chrome\'" rel="tag">chrome</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/safari" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'safari\'" rel="tag">safari</a>, and <a href="/questions/tagged/opera" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'opera\'" rel="tag">opera</a>. The version 1.x also supports <a href="/questions/tagged/internet-explorer-6" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'internet-explorer-6\'" rel="tag">internet-explorer-6</a> or higher. However, jQuery version 2.x dropped Internet Explorer 6\u20138 support (which represents less than 28% of all browsers in use) and can run only with IE 9 or higher.</p>\n\n<h3>Versions</h3>\n\n<p>The <a href="http://jquery.com" rel="nofollow">jQuery</a> library keeps getting updated, so the library should be used carefully. Some functions become deprecated with newer versions of <a href="http://jquery.com" rel="nofollow">jQuery</a>. Follow the release notes to be on track of the features. The latest version is v2.1.1 for IE &gt; 8 and 1.11.1 for all browsers.</p>\n\n<h3>Hello World</h3>\n\n<p>Showing <code>Hello world!</code> in the alert box on each link click after the DOM is ready:</p>\n\n<pre><code>$(function () { // callback for document load\n    $("a").click(function(event) { // select anchors and set click handler\n        event.preventDefault(); // prevent link default action(redirecting to another page)\n        alert("Hello world!"); // show the message\n    });\n});\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><a href="http://jsfiddle.net/Ufh8y/" rel="nofollow">See JSFiddle here.</a></p>\n\n<h3>When asking jQuery questions, you should:</h3>\n\n<ol>\n<li>Read the <a href="http://api.jquery.com" rel="nofollow">jQuery API documentation</a> carefully and <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/search">search Stack Overflow</a> for duplicates before asking.</li>\n<li>Isolate the problematic code and reproduce it in an online environment such as <a href="http://jsfiddle.net" rel="nofollow">JSFiddle</a>, <a href="http://jsbin.com" rel="nofollow">JSBin</a>, or <a href="http://codepen.io" rel="nofollow">CodePen</a>. However, be sure to include the problematic code in your question \u2014 don\'t just link to the online environment.</li>\n<li>Tag the question appropriately; always include <a href="/questions/tagged/jquery" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jquery\'" rel="tag">jquery</a>, and use the other web development tags \u2014 <a href="/questions/tagged/html" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'html\'" rel="tag">html</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/javascript" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'javascript\'" rel="tag">javascript</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/ajax" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ajax\'" rel="tag">ajax</a> \u2014 as applicable. The most popular plugins also have their own tags, such as <a href="/questions/tagged/jquery-ui" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jquery-ui\'" rel="tag">jquery-ui</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/jquery-mobile" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jquery-mobile\'" rel="tag">jquery-mobile</a>, and <a href="/questions/tagged/jquery-validate" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jquery-validate\'" rel="tag">jquery-validate</a>; for every other plugin include the tag <a href="/questions/tagged/jquery-plugins" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jquery-plugins\'" rel="tag">jquery-plugins</a>.</li>\n<li>Indicate the version of the jQuery library used, so that any answers can provide version-appropriate solutions.</li>\n<li>Mention which browser the code is having problems on and what error messages, if any, were thrown by the browser.</li>\n</ol>\n\n<h3>Resources</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/qunit" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'qunit\'" rel="tag">qunit</a>)</li>\n<li><a href="http://sizzlejs.com" rel="nofollow">Sizzle</a> (<a href="/questions/tagged/sizzle" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'sizzle\'" rel="tag">sizzle</a>)</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Best Practices and Commonly Made Mistakes</h2>\n\n<p>Related question: <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1229259/jquery-pitfalls-to-avoid">jQuery pitfalls to avoid</a></p>\n\n<h3>Remember to use <code>$(document).ready</code></h3>\n\n<p>If your code is somehow manipulating the DOM, then you need to either wrap it in a </p>\n\n<pre><code>$(document).ready(function() {...});\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>block or move it to the end of your HTML. Note that <code>$(function () {})</code> means the same thing as <code>$(document).ready(function () {})</code>, when a function is passed as the only argument to <code>$()</code>.</p>\n\n<h3>Remember to use <code>$.noConflict();</code> and/or alias <code>jQuery</code> as something else such as <code>$j</code></h3>\n\n<p>If your code is conflicting with another framework that uses the <code>$</code> syntax, then use <a href="http://learn.jquery.com/using-jquery-core/avoid-conflicts-other-libraries/" rel="nofollow">the noConflict() Method</a>, and also change</p>\n\n<pre><code>$(document).ready(function()\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>to</p>\n\n<pre><code>jQuery(document).ready(function($)\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>to work. Alternatively, you can call <code>$jq = jQuery.noConflict();</code> and use <code>$jq</code>. </p>\n\n<h3>Cache your jQuery Objects and Chain Whenever Possible</h3>\n\n<p>Calling the jQuery function <code>$()</code> is expensive. Calling it <em>repeatedly</em> is <strong>extremely inefficient</strong>. Avoid doing this: </p>\n\n<pre><code>$(\'.test\').addClass(\'hello\');\n$(\'.test\').css(\'color\', \'orange\');\n$(\'.test\').prop(\'title\', \'Hello world\');\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Instead cache your jQuery object in a variable: </p>\n\n<pre><code>var $test = $(\'.test\');\n\n$test.addClass(\'hello\');\n$test.css(\'color\', \'orange\');\n$test.prop(\'title\', \'Hello world\');\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Or better yet, use chaining to reduce repetition: </p>\n\n<pre><code>$(\'.test\').addClass(\'hello\').css(\'color\', \'orange\').prop(\'title\', \'Hello world\');\n</code></pre>\n\n<h3>Variable Naming Conventions</h3>\n\n<p>jQuery wrapped variables are usually named starting with <code>$</code> to distinguish them from standard JavaScript objects.</p>\n\n<pre><code>var $this = $(this);\n</code></pre>\n\n<h3>Know Your DOM Properties and Functions</h3>\n\n<p>While one of the goals of jQuery is to abstract away the DOM, knowing DOM properties can be extremely useful. One of the most commonly made mistakes by those who learn jQuery without learning about the DOM is to <a href="http://whattheheadsaid.com/2010/10/utilizing-the-awesome-power-of-jquery-to-access-properties-of-an-element" rel="nofollow">utilize jQuery to access properties of an element</a>:</p>\n\n<pre><code>$(\'img\').click(function() {\n    $(this).attr(\'src\');  // Bad!\n});\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>In the above code, <code>this</code> refers to the element from which the click event handler was fired. The code above is both slow and verbose; the code below functions identically and is much shorter, faster and readable. </p>\n\n<pre><code>$(\'img\').click(function() {\n    this.src; // Much, much better\n});\n</code></pre>\n\n<h3>Idiomatic Syntax for Creating Elements</h3>\n\n<p>Although the following two examples seem to be functionally equivalent and syntactically correct, the first example is preferred: </p>\n\n<pre><code>$(\'&lt;p&gt;\', {\n    text: \'This is a \' + variable, \n    "class": \'blue slider\', \n    title: variable, \n    id: variable + i\n}).appendTo(obj);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>By comparison, a string concatenation approach is much less readable and far more brittle:</p>\n\n<pre><code>$(\'&lt;p class="blue slider" id="\' + variable + i + \'" title="\' + variable + \'"&gt;This is a \' + variable + \'&lt;/p&gt;\').appendTo(obj);\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>While the first example will be slower than the second, the benefits of greater clarity will likely outweigh the nominal speed differences in all but the most performance-sensitive applications. </p>\n\n<p>Moreover, the idiomatic syntax is robust against the injection of special characters.\nFor instance, in the 2nd example, a quote character in <code>variable</code> would prematurely close the  attributes. Doing the <a href="https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_%28Cross_Site_Scripting%29_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet#RULE_.231_-_HTML_Escape_Before_Inserting_Untrusted_Data_into_HTML_Element_Content" rel="nofollow">proper encoding by yourself</a> remains possible even if not recommended because it is prone to error.</p>\n\n<h2>Chat Rooms</h2>\n\n<p>Chat about jQuery with other Stack Overflow users:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://chat.stackoverflow.com/rooms/42482/web-developers">Web Developers</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://chat.stackoverflow.com/rooms/42620/jquery-mobile">jQuery Mobile</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://chat.stackoverflow.com/rooms/44929/java-spring-struts-hibernate-php-jquery-javascript-beginners">Java, Spring,Struts,Hibernate, PHP, jQuery &amp; Javascript Beginners</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Frequently asked questions</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/48239/getting-the-id-of-the-element-that-fired-an-event-using-jquery">Getting the ID of the element that fired an event using jQuery</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://remysharp.com/2007/04/12/jquerys-this-demystified" rel="nofollow">Difference between this and $(this)</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/a/4083362/1083946">Difference between jQuery() and jQuery.fn</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12627443/jquery-click-vs-onclick">jQuery.click() vs onClick - jQuery vs HTML</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13199231/scope-in-an-ajax-callback-function">Scope in an $.ajax callback function</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14220321/how-to-return-the-response-from-an-ajax-call">How to return the response from an AJAX call</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/253689/switching-a-div-background-image-with-jquery">Switching a DIV background image with jQuery</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/q/8110934/86072">using jQuery.on / event delegation</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/q/24173440/1026459">Save access to this scope</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>jQuery and ASP.NET</h2>\n\n<p>To use jQuery as part of an ASP.NET website, you can install the library using its <a href="http://nuget.org/packages/jQuery" rel="nofollow">NuGet package</a>.</p>\n\n<h2>jQuery - Struts2 Plugin for Java</h2>\n\n<p><a href="http://code.google.com/p/struts2-jquery" rel="nofollow">The Struts2 Plugin</a> for the popular Java web framework struts2 provides Ajax functionality and UI Widgets based on the jQuery JavaScript framework.</p>',

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>A context menu is a menu in a graphical user interface that appears upon user interaction, such as a right mouse click or middle click mouse operation.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>A context menu is a menu in a graphical user interface that appears upon user interaction, such as a right mouse click or middle click mouse operation.  A context menu offers a limited set of choices that are available in the current state, or context, of the operating system or application. Usually the available choices are actions related to the selected object.</p>\n\n<p>Source: <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context_menu" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia</a></p>',

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>`UITableView` is a class used for displaying and editing hierarchical lists on iOS.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><code>UITableView</code> is a class used for displaying and editing hierarchical lists on iOS (<a href="/questions/tagged/ios" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios\'" rel="tag">ios</a>).  It uses an efficient architecture that reuses existing cell objects (<code>UITableViewCell</code>s) as they scroll offscreen, improving memory usage and performance during fast scrolling.</p>\n\n<h3>Resources:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/uikit/reference/UITableView_Class/Reference/Reference.html" rel="nofollow">UITableView Class Reference</a></li>\n<li>Apple\'s <a href="http://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/TableView_iPhone/AboutTableViewsiPhone/AboutTableViewsiPhone.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40007451" rel="nofollow">Table View Programming Guide</a></li>\n</ul>',

2015-01-03 09:41:41+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/ios/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>iOS is Apple\'s operating system for mobile devices, such as the iPhone, iPod touch, iPad and Apple TV (2nd generation and up). Much is shared with OS X, but iOS is optimized for touch-based interfaces.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><strong><a href="http://www.apple.com/ios/" rel="nofollow">iOS</a></strong> is Apple\'s operating system for mobile devices.</p>\n\n<p>iOS Latest Stable Release : <a href="https://www.apple.com/in/ios/" rel="nofollow">iOS 8</a></p>\n\n<p>iOS is a derivative of Apple\'s <a href="/questions/tagged/mac-os-x" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'mac-os-x\'" rel="tag">mac-os-x</a> desktop operating system, with which it shares many (but not all) common frameworks and other components, such as Cocoa Touch (the counterpart of the OS X Cocoa UI Framework), the Mach/Darwin/XNU kernel and code from the Berkeley Software Distribution (BSD). </p>\n\n<p>Applications for <a href="/questions/tagged/ios" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios\'" rel="tag">ios</a> are written for the <a href="/questions/tagged/cocoa-touch" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cocoa-touch\'" rel="tag">cocoa-touch</a> framework (as opposed to OS X\'s <a href="/questions/tagged/cocoa" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cocoa\'" rel="tag">cocoa</a> framework) using the same <a href="/questions/tagged/xcode" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'xcode\'" rel="tag">xcode</a> IDE for official use (i. e. for submitting applications to Apple\'s App Store) or using unofficial (mostly command-line only) toolchains for various operating systems (including Linux) for unofficial/jailbroken development. OS X is based on the Darwin-OS foundation, itself based on several <a href="/questions/tagged/unix" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'unix\'" rel="tag">unix</a> descendants. Starting with iOS 8, you can now develop using their <a href="/questions/tagged/swift" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'swift\'" rel="tag">swift</a> language.</p>\n\n<p>Each iOS application runs in its own secure <a href="/questions/tagged/sandbox" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'sandbox\'" rel="tag">sandbox</a> to prevent (accidentally or intentionally) altering other applications, the operating system, or any other data. <a href="/questions/tagged/ios" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios\'" rel="tag">ios</a> is optimized for the power, graphics, processor, and memory constraints of mobile devices.</p>\n\n<p>The user interface of <a href="/questions/tagged/ios" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios\'" rel="tag">ios</a> is based on the concept of direct manipulation through multi-touch gestures. Interface control elements consist of sliders, switches, and buttons, all included in Apple\'s <a href="/questions/tagged/uikit" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'uikit\'" rel="tag">uikit</a> framework. Interaction with the OS includes gestures such as swipe, tap, pinch, and reverse pinch, all of which have specific definitions within the context of the <a href="/questions/tagged/ios" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios\'" rel="tag">ios</a> operating system and its multi-touch interface.</p>\n\n<p>Internal accelerometers and gyroscopes can be used by applications to respond to the user shaking the device (one application is the undo command) or rotating it in three dimensions (one common result is switching from portrait to landscape mode, or autorotation).</p>\n\n<p>Apple initially adapted features from OS X to create <a href="/questions/tagged/ios" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios\'" rel="tag">ios</a>, but that cycle is now bidirectional. Many features on OS X 10.7 <a href="/questions/tagged/osx-lion" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'osx-lion\'" rel="tag">osx-lion</a> were implemented first in <a href="/questions/tagged/ios" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios\'" rel="tag">ios</a>, including application sandboxing, an OS X <a href="/questions/tagged/app-store" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'app-store\'" rel="tag">app-store</a> (and the implied widespread third party app code signing), the content-centric ("natural") scrolling direction, along with AV Foundation, Core Location, and a few other frameworks.</p>\n\n<p>Use the tag <a href="/questions/tagged/cisco-ios" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cisco-ios\'" rel="tag">cisco-ios</a> for questions about Cisco\'s IOS operating system for <a href="/questions/tagged/cisco" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cisco\'" rel="tag">cisco</a> network routers.</p>\n\n<p>Please follow the article <a href="http://www.raywenderlich.com/10209/my-app-crashed-now-what-part-1" rel="nofollow">My App crashed. Now what?</a> by Ray Wenderlich, before posting any questions relating to app crashes. It explains how to properly debug an iOS-App. It\'s pointless to ask questions relating to crashes when you don\'t have a <em>proper</em> backtrace and exception message.</p>\n\n<h2>Resources</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IOS" rel="nofollow">iOS</a> at Wikipedia (overview, history, features, built-in apps, etc.)</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.apple.com/ios/" rel="nofollow">iOS</a> at Apple (updates, gallery, etc.)</li>\n<li><a href="http://developer.apple.com/library/ios/navigation/" rel="nofollow">Developer Library</a> at Apple (architecture, frameworks, media layer, core services, etc.)</li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/iPhone/Conceptual/iPhoneOSProgrammingGuide/Introduction/Introduction.html" rel="nofollow">Developer Library to start development</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/miscellaneous/conceptual/iphoneostechoverview/Introduction/Introduction.html" rel="nofollow">iOS Technologies</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/MobileHIG/Introduction/Introduction.html" rel="nofollow">iOS Human Interface Guidelines</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://goo.gl/hi6QLd" rel="nofollow">iOS Design Patterns</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.appcoda.com/ios-programming-course/" rel="nofollow">iOS Programming Course - AppCoda</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://mobile.tutsplus.com/category/tutorials/iphone/" rel="nofollow">iOS Mobiletuts+</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.raywenderlich.com/tutorials" rel="nofollow">Tutorials for iPhone / iOS Developers and Gamers</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/navigation/#section=Resource%20Types&amp;topic=Sample%20Code" rel="nofollow">iOS Sample Codes</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/videos/" rel="nofollow">WWDC video</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Chat Rooms</h2>\n\n<p>Chat about iOS with other Stack Overflow users</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://chat.stackoverflow.com/rooms/682/iphone-ipad">iPhone and iPad Chat</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://chat.stackoverflow.com/rooms/15942/nschat">iOS and Mac OS developers</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://chat.stackoverflow.com/rooms/15038/ios-developer-family">iOS Developer Family</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://chat.stackoverflow.com/rooms/18907/ioskerala">iOS Kerala</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Related Tags</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/ios5" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios5\'" rel="tag">ios5</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/ios6" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios6\'" rel="tag">ios6</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/ios7" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios7\'" rel="tag">ios7</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/ios8" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios8\'" rel="tag">ios8</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/app-store" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'app-store\'" rel="tag">app-store</a></li>\n</ul>',

2015-01-03 09:41:42+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27686410/sed-how-to-change-lines-to-blank>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<h1><a href="/questions/tagged/sed" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'sed\'" rel="tag">sed</a> : Stream EDitor</h1>\n\n<p>Using sed, you could <strong>address</strong> a line by its number <strong>or</strong> its content:</p>\n\n<pre><code>\'/keyword/s/.*//\'\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Mean:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>On lines containing <em>keyword</em>, replace everything by nothing.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2><code>c\\</code> command</h2>\n\n<p>I didn\'t already used <code>c\\</code> syntax... For rightly answer to this question, I\'ve tried this:</p>\n\n<pre><code>seq 1 5 |  sed \'/3/c\\\'| hd\n00000000  31 0a 32 0a 34 0a 35 0a                           |1.2.4.5.|\n00000008\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>wich don\'t give expected result.</p>\n\n<pre><code>seq 1 5 |  sed \'/3/c\\ \'| hd\n00000000  31 0a 32 0a 20 0a 34 0a  35 0a                    |1.2. .4.5.|\n0000000a\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Reflect the meaning of this question,</p>\n\n<pre><code>seq 1 5 |  sed -e \'/3/c\\\\n\'| hd\n00000000  31 0a 32 0a 0a 0a 34 0a  35 0a                    |1.2...4.5.|\n0000000a\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Don\'t give attended result, and finaly</p>\n\n<pre><code>seq 1 5 |  sed \'/3/c\\\\\'| hd\n00000000  31 0a 32 0a 0a 34 0a 35  0a                       |1.2..4.5.|\n0000000a\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>seem to be <strong>the right answer</strong> to this question: <em>You have to add a leading backslash to <code>c\\</code> command in order to produce an empty line.</em></p>\n\n<pre><code>sed -e \'/keyword/c\\\\\'\n</code></pre>\n\n<h2>Other <a href="/questions/tagged/sed" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'sed\'" rel="tag">sed</a> ways</h2>\n\n<h3>Replace strings</h3>\n\n<p>My first idea was to <em>replace everything</em> by <em>emtpy string</em> by using</p>\n\n<pre><code>sed -e \'/keyword/s/.*//\'\n</code></pre>\n\n<h3>Delete line</h3>\n\n<p>The question suggest to use <code>c\\</code> command:</p>\n\n<pre><code>sed -e \'/keyword/c\\\\\'\n</code></pre>\n\n<h3>Using empty <em>hold space</em></h3>\n\n<p>@Kalanidhi suggest to use <em>hold</em> buffer, wich could work if they is empty, but by using <code>g</code> instead of <code>G</code> command, </p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>from <code>info sed</code>:</p>\n  \n  <p>`g\' Replace the contents of the pattern space with the contents of the\n       hold space</p>\n  \n  <p>`G\' Append a newline to the contents of the pattern space, and then\n       append the contents of the hold space to that of the pattern space.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>So the command using this idea could be:</p>\n\n<pre><code>sed -e \'/keyword/g\'\n</code></pre>\n\n<h3>Emptying the content of pattern space</h3>\n\n<p>But I think re-reading <code>info sed</code> pages, that the more appropriated command was suggested by @potong <em>(+1)</em>, by using <code>z</code> command</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>from <code>info sed</code>:</p>\n  \n  <p>`z\' This command empties the content of pattern space</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<pre><code>sed -e \'/keyword/z\'\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [u'not exactly the same between ',
	                           u'and ',
	                           u' because ',
	                           u' send the new line(s) directly to the output where ',
	                           u' empty the buffer that could be printed or manipulated. In this case, the result is the same due to simple output result without other manipulation except that loop is direct to next line after a ',
	                           u' (performance interest)',
	                           u'@NeronLeVelu yes, this is why I suggest to use ',
	                           u' instead of ',
	                           u'on my aix, `c\\` is not allowed (not posix i guess)'],

2015-01-03 09:41:42+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/3016485/hitesh> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:41:42+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27720613/can-i-install-self-signed-drivers-on-64-bit-windows-without-test-mode-if-the-sel>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>you are correct, if you create a self signed certificate and save it in user store (or machien store) as a Trusted CA, it will work for you... but keep in mind that:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>Secure boot will not work for you.</li>\n<li>This is a security breach, if someone get a hold of the certificate, they will have to run kernel mode code on your system.</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>Other option, is to buy Trusted Code Signing Certificate from <a href="https://www.godaddy.com/ssl/code-signing-certificate.aspx" rel="nofollow">GoDaddy</a> :)</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753441,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27720613/can-i-install-self-signed-drivers-on-64-bit-windows-without-test-mode-if-the-sel/27753441#27753441',
	              'user_id': 34369,
	              'vote': 0}],
	 'body': u'<p>Here is a great SO answer which covers the creation of self-signed CA and then signing executables with the obtained certificates: <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/84847/how-do-i-create-a-self-signed-certificate-for-code-signing-on-windows">How do I create a self-signed certificate for code signing on Windows?</a>.</p>\n\n<p>I have read a lot of discussions online on how the driver signing works and the answer seems to be almost unequivocally that you can\'t load unsigned or self-signed drivers without having the test mode enabled. However, the answer I linked to and especially one comment by Roger Lipscombe seems to provide a contradicting view: </p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>If you want to use this for signing drivers, you need to import the CA\n  certificate into the machine store. My example imports it into the\n  user store, which is fine for most software, for test/internal\n  purposes.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>To me, it looks like I would be able to install drivers with self-signed certificates (issued by a self-signed CA) as long as the CA cert was imported to the machine store. I won\'t have to make any other changes to the system (disabling test mode by pressing F8 on boot menu, messing with boot configuration flags such as TESTSIGNING or NOINTEGRITYCHECKS).</p>\n\n<p>Am I correct? What are the obstacles, if any, that this method is not used more widely when people need to load drivers that have no proper digital signatures provided (such as old printer drivers etc.). Instead, people rely on booting to test mode or a third-party software (DSEO) which tampers with your system files to run such drivers. </p>\n\n<p>What are the drawbacks of this method? The process described in the above SO question needs admin privileges but installing drivers should need them anyway. Trusting a self-signed CA might be a security risk - but won\'t disabling all signature checks be even bigger security risk?</p>',
	 'comments': [u'Good question. MSDN ',
	              u' also states that self-signed drivers can be installed that way, so long as they are time-stamped.',

More so, it provides a link which contains the following statement: "The 64-bit versions of Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2 have special signature requirements for kernel mode device drivers. If you use a 64-bit version of Windows, then you cannot create your own certificate for signing. Instead, you must use a Software Publishing Certificate that chains to an approved certification authority (CA)". Perhaps it is not possible?',
	              u'On 64 bit you have to cross sign your driver, so self signing is not possible.',
	              u"That seems to be the case. If someone bothers to write an answer which describes the situation clearly with proper references, I'll accept it."],

Where am I going wrong? Shouldn\'t it not happen if downloaded from the play store? Can someone please this up for me?</p>\n\n<p>Here\'s what my code contains.</p>\n\n<pre><code>private static final String BASE64_PUBLIC_KEY="KEY_HERE"\n\nprivate static final byte[] SALT  = "SALT_HERE"\n\nprivate Handler mHandler;\n    private LicenseChecker mChecker;\n    private LicenseCheckerCallback mLicenseCheckerCallback;\n    boolean licensed;\n    boolean checkingLicense;\n    boolean didCheck;\n\nIntent serviceIntent = null;\n        try {\n            serviceIntent = new Intent(\n                    new String(Base64.decode("Y29tLmFuZHJvaWQudmVuZGluZy5saWNlbnNpbmcuSUxpY2Vuc2luZ1NlcnZpY2U=")));\n        } catch (Base64DecoderException e) {\n            e.printStackTrace();\n        }\n        if (serviceIntent != null) {\n            serviceIntent.setPackage("com.android.vending");\n        }\n\n        mHandler = new Handler();\n        mLicenseCheckerCallback = new MyLicenseCheckerCallback();\n        mChecker = new LicenseChecker(this, new ServerManagedPolicy(this,\n                new   AESObfuscator(SALT, getPackageName(), deviceId)), BASE64_PUBLIC_KEY);\n\n\n        if(!prefs.getBoolean("firstTime", false)) {\n            doCheck();\n        }\n\nprivate void doCheck() {\n\n        didCheck = false;\n        checkingLicense = true;\n        setSupportProgressBarIndeterminateVisibility(true);\n\n        mChecker.checkAccess(mLicenseCheckerCallback);\n    }\n\n\n    private class MyLicenseCheckerCallback implements LicenseCheckerCallback {\n\n        @Override\n        public void allow(int reason) {\n            if (isFinishing()) {\n                SharedPreferences.Editor editor = prefs.edit();\n                editor.putBoolean("firstTime", true);\n                editor.apply();\n                // Don\'t update UI if Activity is finishing.\n                return;\n            }\n            Log.i("License","Accepted!");\n\n            //You can do other things here, like saving the licensed status to a\n            //SharedPreference so the app only has to check the license once.\n\n            licensed = true;\n            checkingLicense = false;\n            didCheck = true;\n\n        }\n\n        @SuppressWarnings("deprecation")\n        @Override\n        public void dontAllow(int reason) {\n            if (isFinishing()) {\n                // Don\'t update UI if Activity is finishing.\n                return;\n            }\n            Log.i("License","Denied!");\n            Log.i("License","Reason for denial: "+reason);\n\n            //You can do other things here, like saving the licensed status to a\n            //SharedPreference so the app only has to check the license once.\n\n            licensed = false;\n            checkingLicense = false;\n            didCheck = true;\n\n            showDialog(0);\n\n        }\n\n        @SuppressWarnings("deprecation")\n        @Override\n        public void applicationError(int reason) {\n            Log.i("License", "Error: " + reason);\n            if (isFinishing()) {\n                // Don\'t update UI if Activity is finishing.\n                return;\n            }\n            licensed = true;\n            checkingLicense = false;\n            didCheck = false;\n\n            showDialog(0);\n        }\n\n\n    }\n    @SuppressWarnings("deprecation")\n    protected Dialog onCreateDialog(int id) {\n        // We have only one dialog.\n        return new AlertDialog.Builder(this)\n                .setTitle("UNLICENSED APPLICATION DIALOG TITLE")\n                .setMessage("This application is not licensed, please buy it from the play store.")\n                .setPositiveButton("Buy", new DialogInterface.OnClickListener() {\n                    public void onClick(DialogInterface dialog, int which) {\n                        Intent marketIntent = new Intent(Intent.ACTION_VIEW, Uri.parse(\n                                "http://market.android.com/details?id=" + getPackageName()));\n 2015-01-03 09:41:43+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753246/match-vs-exec-in-javascript> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:41:43+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753246/match-vs-exec-in-javascript>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<ol>\n<li><p><code>string.match</code> finds the first match and returns it with the actual match, the index at which the text was found and the actual input, <em>when the global flag is not used.</em></p></li>\n<li><p><code>string.match</code> just returns all the matches, <em>when the global flag is used.</em></p>\n\n<pre><code>var myString = "[22].[44].[33].";\n\nconsole.log(myString.match(/\\d+/));\n# [ \'22\', index: 1, input: \'[22].[44].[33].\' ]\nconsole.log(myString.match(/\\d+/g));\n# [ \'22\', \'44\', \'33\' ]\n</code></pre></li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>The main difference between <code>string.match</code> and <code>regex.exec</code> is, the <code>regex</code> object will be updated of the current match with <code>regex.exec</code> call. For example,</p>\n\n<pre><code>var myString = "[22].[44].[33].", myRegexp = /\\d+/g, result;\n\nwhile (result = myRegexp.exec(myString)) {\n    console.log(result, myRegexp.lastIndex);\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>will return</p>\n\n<pre><code>[ \'22\', index: 1, input: \'[22].[44].[33].\' ] 3\n[ \'44\', index: 6, input: \'[22].[44].[33].\' ] 8\n[ \'33\', index: 11, input: \'[22].[44].[33].\' ] 13\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>As you can see, the <code>lastIndex</code> property is updated whenever a match is found. So, keep two things in mind when you use <code>exec</code>, or <strong>you will run into an infinite loop.</strong></p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p>If you don\'t use <code>g</code> option, then you will always get the first match. So, the following will run into an infinite loop.</p>\n\n<pre><code>var myString = "[22].[44].[33].", myRegexp = /\\d+/, result;\n\nwhile (result = myRegexp.exec(myString)) {\n    console.log(result, myRegexp.lastIndex);\n}\n</code></pre></li>\n<li><p>Don\'t forget to use the same regular expression object with subsequent calls. Because, the regex object updated everytime, if you pass new object every time, again the program will run into an infinite loop.</p>\n\n<pre><code>var myString = "[22].[44].[33].", result;\n\nwhile (result = /\\d+/g.exec(myString)) {\n    console.log(result);\n}\n</code></pre></li>\n</ol>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753327,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753246/match-vs-exec-in-javascript/27753327#27753327',
	              'user_id': 1903116,
	              'vote': 4}],
	 'body': u'<p>I need some clarification for match Vs exec in JavaScript; <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9214754/what-is-the-difference-between-regexp-s-exec-function-and-string-s-match-fun">here</a> some one says that </p>\n\n<p><em>"exec with a global regular expression is meant to be used in a loop"</em> but first of all as you see in my example this is not the case; in my example exec with global regular expression is returning all of the matches in an array! Secondly they say that for String.match it returns all of the matches with  no need of looping through! But again that\'s not happening in my example and it is just returning the input string? Have I misunderstood/done something wrong?</p>\n\n<pre><code>var myString = "[22].[44].[33].";\nvar myRegexp = /.*\\[(\\d*)*\\].*\\[(\\d*)*\\].*\\[(\\d*)*\\].*/g;\n\nvar execResult = myRegexp.exec(myString);\nconsole.log(execResult.length);\nconsole.log(execResult[1]);// returns 22 and execResult has all of my matches from index 1 to the length of array\n\n\nvar matchResult = myString.match(myRegexp);\nconsole.log(matchResult.length);\nconsole.log(matchResult);// returns just myString which is "[22].[44].[33]."! Why is that?\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Thanks for calrification</p>',
	 'comments': [u"@BatScream Thats what I'm pointing too; I have already put the link to there since there is a confusion based on my example and that link!",
	              u'Vote retracted.'],
	 'extid': 27753246,
	 'tags': [u'javascript', u'regex'],
	 'title': u'match Vs exec in JavaScript',
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753246/match-vs-exec-in-javascript',
	 'user_id': 3399784,
	 'vote': 4}

2015-01-03 09:41:45+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/2861345/chandru> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:41:45+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751533/sdl2-threading-seg-fault>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Some platforms (e.g. Windows) don\'t allow interacting with windows from threads other than the one that created them.</p>\n\n<p>The <a href="https://wiki.libsdl.org/CategoryThread" rel="nofollow">documentation</a> explicitly says this:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>NOTE: You should not expect to be able to create a window, render, or receive events on any thread other than the main one.</p>\n</blockquote>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753443,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751533/sdl2-threading-seg-fault/27753443#27753443',
	              'user_id': 1484212,
	              'vote': 0}],
	 'body': u'<p>I am working on a rendering library for SDL2 and I am running into a seg fault when I try to do anything with the renderer. Through debugging I have determined that it is created correctly from the window (now...) However I cannot figure out why SDL2 is seg faulting when I call <code>SDL_RenderClear(data-&gt;renderer)</code></p>\n\n<p>The main thread calls:</p>\n\n<pre><code>int RenderThread::start(std::string title, int x, int y, int w, int h, Uint32 flags) {\n    data.window = SDL_CreateWindow(title.c_str(), x, y, w, h, flags);\n    if(data.window == NULL) return -2;\n    data.renderer = SDL_CreateRenderer(data.window, -1, 0);\n    if(data.renderer == NULL) return -3;\n    data.rlist-&gt;setRenderer(data.renderer);\n\n    data.run = true;\n\n    if(thread == NULL)\n        thread = SDL_CreateThread(renderThread, "RenderThread", (void*)(&amp;data));\n    else return 1;\n\n    return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Then the actual thread is:</p>\n\n<pre><code>int RenderThread::renderThread(void* d) {\n    RenderData* data = (RenderData*)d;\n    data-&gt;rlist-&gt;render(true);\n    SDL_SetRenderDrawColor(data-&gt;renderer, 0xFF, 0xFF, 0xFF, 0xFF);\n    SDL_RenderClear(data-&gt;renderer);\n    while(data-&gt;run) {\n        data-&gt;rlist-&gt;render();\n        SDL_RenderPresent(data-&gt;renderer);\n        SDL_Delay(data-&gt;interval);\n    }\n    return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>If you need to see more of the code it is all on <a href="https://github.com/Eadword/libSDL2_RenderList" rel="nofollow">github</a>.</p>',

2015-01-03 09:41:47+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/sed/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Sed (Stream EDitor) is a command line editor for POSIX environment. Sed processes one or more files according to an editing script and writes the results to standard output. Created at Bell Labs, it has been around since the mid-70s.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Sed (Stream EDitor) was created at Bell Labs by Lee McMahon in 1973 or 1974. It is one of the basic tools in the POSIX environment\u2014it processes one or more files according to an editing script and writes the results to standard output.</p>\n\n<p>Sed is normally required when the existing text file must be modified without user interactions by some script (<code>bash</code> script, for instance). For instance, the commands</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-sh prettyprint-override"><code> export ARG=17\n sed "s/b/${ARG}/g" s.sh\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>will print the text of <code>s.sh</code> where all occurrences of <code>b</code> are replaced by the value of the environment variable <code>ARG</code>, 17 (sed prints to <code>stdout</code> rather than overwriting the input file). </p>\n\n<h3>Resources</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/sed/manual/" rel="nofollow">GNU sed user\'s manual</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://sed.sourceforge.net/sedfaq.html" rel="nofollow">The Sed FAQ</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://sed.sourceforge.net/" rel="nofollow">All Things Sed</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.rtfiber.com.tw/~changyj/sed/" rel="nofollow">SED &amp; Regular Expressions</a> </li>\n<li><a href="http://en.literateprograms.org/Turing_machine_simulator_%28Sed%29" rel="nofollow">Turing machine simulator (Sed)</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://unix.stackexchange.com/tags/sed/info">Further Related Questions</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Free Sed Book</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.grymoire.com/Unix/Sed.html" rel="nofollow">Sed - An Introduction and Tutorial</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>See also</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/awk" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'awk\'" rel="tag">awk</a> (A kindred tool often mentioned in the same breath)</li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/regex" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'regex\'" rel="tag">regex</a> (The notation used by <code>sed</code> and other commands to perform search (and replace) operations.</li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/grep" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'grep\'" rel="tag">grep</a> (A command line text search utility)</li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/tr" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'tr\'" rel="tag">tr</a> (A command line utility for translating or deleting characters)</li>\n</ul>',

A self-signed certificate is usually signed by an own, custom generated private key. Usually, a public key is also available from the certificating authority - it provides the option for the user or organization to test it against the own private key which is used for signing.</p>',

This tag should only be used for questions related to driver development, as questions about finding or installing drivers are off-topic for StackOverflow.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>A driver typically communicates with the device through the computer bus or communications subsystem to which the hardware connects. When a calling program invokes a routine in the driver, the driver issues commands to the device. Once the device sends data back to the driver, the driver may invoke routines in the original calling program. Drivers are hardware-dependent and operating-system-specific. They usually provide the interrupt handling required for any necessary asynchronous time-dependent hardware interface.</p>\n\n<p>A device driver simplifies programming by acting as translator between a hardware device and the applications or operating systems that use it. Programmers can write the higher-level application code independently of whatever specific hardware device.</p>\n\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Device_driver" rel="nofollow">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Device_driver</a></p>\n\n<p>This tag should only be used for questions related to driver development, as questions about finding or installing drivers are off-topic for StackOverflow. Assistance with identifying, locating, and installing drivers may be obtained at <a href="http://superuser.com/">SuperUser</a>, <a href="http://unix.stackexchange.com/">Unix &amp; Linux Exchange</a> or in the case of server-related and enterprise-level hardware, <a href="http://serverfault.com/">ServerFault</a>.</p>',

	{'answers': [],
	 'body': u"<p>How can we determine if protocol conforms to a specific subtype based on user provided instances, if it's not possible this way, any alternate solutions. </p>\n\n<p><strong>API</strong></p>\n\n<pre><code>protocol Super {}\n\nprotocol Sub: Super {} //inherited by Super protocol\n\nclass Parent: Super {}\n\nclass Child: Sub {} //conforms to sub protocol\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>//inside a class</p>\n\n<pre><code>func store(instances: [() -&gt; Super]) {\n    self.instances = instances\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>//when it's time to call</p>\n\n<pre><code>func go(instances: [() -&gt; Super]) {\n    for instance in instances {\n        if instance is Super {\n            //do something\n        } else { //it's Sub\n            //do something else\n        }\n    }\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><strong>users of the api</strong></p>\n\n<pre><code>class Imp1: Parent {}\nclass Imp2: Child {}\n\nvar instances: [() -&gt; Super] = [ { Imp1() }, { Imp2() } ]\nstore(instances)\n</code></pre>",
	 'comments': [u'why do you use an array of functions that return the object and not an array of the objects itself?',

	              u' and could be calles with ',
	              u'. Would be simpler.',

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Swift is a programming language designed by Apple for creating iOS and OS X apps. Swift retains some elements from C and Objective-C, but offers many modern features such as generics, closures, optionals, tuples, type inference, and operator overloading.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="https://developer.apple.com/swift/" rel="nofollow">Swift</a> is an application programming language for Apple\'s iOS and OS X operating systems, introduced by Apple at WWDC on 2nd June 2014. Please use the <a href="/questions/tagged/openstack-swift" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'openstack-swift\'" rel="tag">openstack-swift</a> tag for questions relating to OpenStack\'s object/blob store and/or <a href="/questions/tagged/swift-scripting" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'swift-scripting\'" rel="tag">swift-scripting</a> tag for questions relating to <a href="http://swift-lang.org/main/" rel="nofollow">parallel scripting language</a>.</p>\n\n<p>The language uses the LLVM compiler, with Swift code transformed into native code.\nSwift promises to modernize the developer experience over what Objective-C provides, offering features like:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>generics</li>\n<li>type safety</li>\n<li>type inference</li>\n<li>namespaces</li>\n<li>improved safety (some protection from overflow, use-before-initialization, etc.)</li>\n<li>functional programming elements (map, filter)</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>... among others.</p>\n\n<p>The Swift syntax retains some elements from Objective-C, while providing an extensive new vocabulary for its new features.</p>\n\n<p>The language can use existing iOS and OS X frameworks, like Cocoa and Cocoa Touch, and can sit side-by-side with Objective-C in applications. Swift applications compile into standard binaries and can be run on OS X 10.9 and iOS 7 (or higher).</p>\n\n<p>Apple provides documentation here:</p>\n\n<p><strong>References</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/swift/" rel="nofollow">Introduction to Swift</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/prerelease/ios/documentation/Swift/Conceptual/Swift_Programming_Language/GuidedTour.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40014097-CH2-XID_1" rel="nofollow">A Swift Tour</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/prerelease/ios/documentation/Swift/Conceptual/BuildingCocoaApps/index.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40014216-CH2-XID_0" rel="nofollow">Using Swift with Objective-C</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/swift/blog/" rel="nofollow">Swift Blog by Apple</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/swift/resources/" rel="nofollow">Swift Resources</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>Books</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/prerelease/ios/documentation/Swift/Conceptual/Swift_Programming_Language/" rel="nofollow">The Swift Programming Language</a> (<a href="https://itunes.apple.com/us/book/swift-programming-language/id881256329?mt=11" rel="nofollow">iBooks</a>)</li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/documentation/General/Reference/SwiftStandardLibraryReference/index.html" rel="nofollow">Swift Standard Library Reference</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/documentation/Swift/Conceptual/BuildingCocoaApps/" rel="nofollow">Using Swift with Cocoa and Objective-C</a> (<a href="https://itunes.apple.com/us/book/using-swift-cocoa-objective/id888894773?mt=11" rel="nofollow">iBooks</a>)</li>\n</ul>',

2015-01-03 09:41:49+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/osx/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>OS X (also called Mac OS X) is the desktop operating system from Apple, found on Macintosh computers.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OS_X" rel="nofollow">OS X</a> (formerly known as Mac OS X) is the desktop operating system from Apple Inc, found on Macintosh computers. Use this tag for questions about writing and debugging programs on OS X. Questions relating to using or troubleshooting OS X are off-topic.</p>\n\n<p>OS X consists of a Mach/BSD-based kernel, operating system interfaces primarily based on FreeBSD (<a href="/questions/tagged/freebsd" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'freebsd\'" rel="tag">freebsd</a>), and additional frameworks (written in C (<a href="/questions/tagged/c" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c\'" rel="tag">c</a>), C++ (<a href="/questions/tagged/c%2b%2b" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c++\'" rel="tag">c++</a>) and Objective-C (<a href="/questions/tagged/objective-c" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'objective-c\'" rel="tag">objective-c</a>)) providing user interface and application-level services.</p>\n\n<p>It was the successor to Mac OS 9 and here the \'X\' means 10.  OS X is based upon the NeXTSTEP/OPENSTEP OSes developed in the 1980s and 1990s by NeXT Inc., which Apple purchased in 1996. Questions relating to using or troubleshooting OS X are off-topic.</p>\n\n<h3>More information:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OS_X" rel="nofollow">OS X Wikipedia Article</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.apple.com/osx/" rel="nofollow">OS X website</a></li>\n</ul>',

The new version comes with lots of new features such as full 3D hardware acceleration and the less restrictive zlib license.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>SDL has the word "layer" in its title because it is actually a wrapper around operating-system-specific functions. The main purpose of SDL is to provide a common framework for accessing these functions. For further functionality beyond this goal, many libraries have been created to work on top of SDL.</p>\n\n<p>The Simple DirectMedia Layer library (SDL) is a general API that provides low level access to audio, keyboard, mouse, joystick, 3D hardware via OpenGL, and 2D framebuffer across multiple platforms.</p>\n\n<p>The current version supports Windows XP/Vista/7/8, Mac OS X, Linux, iOS, and Android. The code contains support for other operating systems but those are not officially supported.</p>\n\n<p>Software developers use it to write computer games and other multimedia applications that can run on many operating systems: Android, iOS, Linux, Mac OS X, Windows and other platforms. It manages video, events, digital audio, CD-ROM, threads, shared object loading, networking and timers.</p>',
