	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Segmentation faults occur when accessing memory which does not belong to your process. They are typically the result of an incorrect use of pointers or a buffer overflow.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Segmentation faults occur when accessing memory which does not belong to your process.  They are very common and are typically the result of:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>using a pointer to something that has been deallocated;</li>\n<li>using an uninitialized hence bogus pointer;</li>\n<li>using a <a href="/questions/tagged/null" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'null\'" rel="tag">null</a> pointer;</li>\n<li>overflowing a buffer; or</li>\n<li>attempting to write to read-only memory</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>The error does not arise when manipulating the pointer itself, but when accessing the memory it points to (i.e. dereferencing). To generate the segmentation fault, <a href="/questions/tagged/linux-kernel" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'linux-kernel\'" rel="tag">linux-kernel</a> will deliver <a href="/questions/tagged/signal" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'signal\'" rel="tag">signal</a> 11 to the process which has made illegal memory access. The <a href="http://unixhelp.ed.ac.uk/CGI/man-cgi?signal%207" rel="nofollow">default action</a> of having segmentation fault is <a href="/questions/tagged/coredump" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'coredump\'" rel="tag">coredump</a>.</p>\n\n<p>If the program crashed due to </p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>unauthorized memory access</li>\n<li>using out-of-bound memory location</li>\n<li><p>using of uninitialized memory</p>\n\n<p>and it has received SIGSEGV and/or coredump is getting generated, mark your questions using this tag.</p></li>\n</ol>',
	 'name': 'segmentation-fault',
	 'qcount': 4954,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/segmentation-fault/info'}

(Without the impact of turning off the pretty option, that is)</li>\n<li>if not, is it a fundamental Slim restriction ("by design") or something which is on the roadmap and would be potentially implemented in the future? </li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Much appreciated.</p>',

2015-01-03 09:41:52+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/multithreading/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751533/sdl2-threading-seg-fault)
2015-01-03 09:41:52+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/multithreading/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Multi-threading is how work performed by a computer can be divided into multiple concurrent streams of execution (generally referred to as threads).</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Multi-threading is a common model to implement SM in multi-cored machines, where threads share memory through shared variables. In this model in parallel programming a processor can create multiple threads that will be executed in parallel. Each thread has its own stack, variables and ID, considered private state. For every thread there is a unique heap shared by all, then considered shared memory. </p>\n\n<p>In order to allow a volume of work to be most effectively and safely divided into multiple concurrent streams of execution, a number of critical areas need to be addressed. </p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Scheduling</strong>: ensure worker tasks are able to progress independently and effectively (e.g. deadlock/livelock avoidance)</li>\n<li><strong>Publication</strong>: ensure data altered in one thread is only visible to others as expected</li>\n<li><strong>Synchronization</strong>: ensure critical regions are protected from multiple concurrent updates causing data loss/corruption.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>The underlying tenet of concurrent processing is Amdahl\'s law (<a href="http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ea/AmdahlsLaw.svg" rel="nofollow">graph</a>).  This law governs the diminishing amount of throughput that can be achieved by greater numbers of concurrent processors/cores. Therefore the overall aim of multi-threading is to minimize the amount of serial execution (exclusive locking) within any concurrent system.</p>\n\n<h1>Frequently Asked Questions</h1>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/588866/atomic-vs-nonatomic-properties">What\'s the difference between the atomic and nonatomic attributes?</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/229554/whats-the-difference-between-invoke-and-begininvoke">What\'s the difference between Invoke() and BeginInvoke()</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/541487/java-implements-runnable-vs-extends-thread">"implements Runnable" vs. "extends Thread"</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1036754/difference-between-wait-and-sleep">Difference between wait() and sleep()</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/301160/what-are-the-differences-between-various-threading-synchronization-options-in-c">What are the differences between various threading synchronization options in C#?</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/200469/what-is-the-difference-between-a-process-and-a-thread">What is the difference between a process and a thread</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/261683/what-is-meant-by-thread-safe-code">What is meant by "thread-safe" code?</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34510/what-is-a-race-condition">What is a race condition?</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2118090/what-are-the-things-to-know-when-diving-into-multi-threaded-programming-in-c">What are the "things to know" when diving into multi-threaded programming in C++</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12159/how-should-i-unit-test-threaded-code">How should I unit test threaded code?</a>\n<a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2213340/what-is-daemon-thread-in-java">What is Daemon thread in java</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h1>Books</h1>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.albahari.com/threading/" rel="nofollow">"Threading in C#"</a> (free e-book)</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.javaconcurrencyinpractice.com/" rel="nofollow">"Java Concurrency in Practice"</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.manning.com/williams/" rel="nofollow">"C++ Concurrency in Action"</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/032131283X" rel="nofollow">"Principles of Concurrent and Distributed Programming"</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/032143482X" rel="nofollow">"Concurrent Programming on Windows"</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://shop.oreilly.com/product/9780596007829.do" rel="nofollow">Java Threads,  By Scott Oaks, Henry Wong</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h1>More information:</h1>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multithreading_%28software%29#Multithreading" rel="nofollow">Multithreading (software)</a> (Wikipedia)</li>\n</ul>',

2015-01-03 09:41:53+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753367/using-jquery-inarray-and-hiding-an-option-value> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)

	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>You need to check value of the currently iterated option referenced by <code>this</code> in the loop, and also compare it with <code>-1</code> returned by <a href="http://api.jquery.com/jquery.inarray/" rel="nofollow"><code>inArray</code></a>:</p>\n\n<pre><code>function initialStrandOptions() {\n    if ($(\'#component_id_1\').prop(\'checked\') == true) {\n        var strand_options = $(\'.strand_options\').find(\'option\')\n        strand_options.each(function () {\n            if (jQuery.inArray(this.value, [\'4\', \'5\', \'6\', \'7\']) &gt; -1) {\n                $(this).hide();\n            }\n        });\n    }\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><strong><a href="http://jsfiddle.net/zkv3szpz/1/" rel="nofollow">Demo</a></strong></p>',

This will make sure that certain of your EJB's startup when the server does, and that will load some of your configuration as necessary.  Is that what you are looking for?</p>",

	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Oh ok.  That makes more sense.  Well, what you really want then is the ability to set up (ie, configure) the WAS container, and then deploy your application.  IBM actually provides a way to do this.  There is a shell script/batch file (depending on your OS) that gets you into the WAS administration area without having to get to the admin console.  It is called wsadmin.  You can fire that up with whatever parms you need to (depends on if you are running WAS Base or WAS ND, etc.) so you connect to the right cell/node/server and profile.  You can then pass in a Jython script (which is IBM\'s recommendation for configuring WAS).  This script can configure WAS and even deploy your applications.  We use it all the time here.  If you are unfamiliar with Jython, there is a "cheat" method to get you started.  In your local RAD or RSA install, when you "deploy" your code locally (ie, only works if you export your EAR and then try to install it through the admin console), there is a link off to the top right of the screen of the admin console that shows you the Jython script necessary for the steps you just performed.  We used that to give us a jump start on the commands necessary to perform certain things.</p>\n\n<p>I know it isn\'t NSIS script, but you will really get better support from IBM if you stick to Jython.  Let me know if this was helpful.  If it doesn\'t seem to make sense, give a holler.</p>',

	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>You can use regular expressions, implemented in the <a href="https://docs.python.org/2/library/re.html" rel="nofollow"><strong><code>re</code> module</strong></a></p>\n\n<p><strong>Better solution</strong></p>\n\n<pre><code>&gt;&gt;&gt; re.findall(r\'[bcdfghjklmnprstvyz]+\', "concertation", re.IGNORECASE)\n[\'c\', \'nc\', \'rt\', \'t\', \'n\']\n</code></pre>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><code>[bcdfghjklmnprstvyz]+</code> matches any sequence of one or more characters from the character class</p></li>\n<li><p><code>re.IGNORECASE</code> enables a case in sensitive match on the characters. That is </p>\n\n<pre><code>&gt;&gt;&gt; re.findall(r\'[bcdfghjklmnprstvyz]+\', "CONCERTATION", re.IGNORECASE)\n[\'C\', \'NC\', \'RT\', \'T\', \'N\']\n</code></pre></li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p><strong>Another Solution</strong></p>\n\n<pre><code>&gt;&gt;&gt; import re\n&gt;&gt;&gt; re.findall(r\'[^aeiou]+\', "concertation",)\n[\'c\', \'nc\', \'rt\', \'t\', \'n\']\n</code></pre>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><code>[^aeiou]</code> Negated character class. Matches anything character other than the one in this character class. That is in short Matches consonents in the string</p></li>\n<li><p><code>+</code> quantifer <code>+</code> matches one or more occurence of the pattern in the string</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>Note</strong> This will also find the non alphabetic, adjacent characters in the solution. As the character class is <em>anything</em> other than vowels</p>\n\n<p>Example</p>\n\n<pre><code>&gt;&gt;&gt; re.findall(r\'[^aeiou]+\', "123concertation",)\n[\'123c\', \'nc\', \'rt\', \'t\', \'n\']\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>If you are sure that the input always contain alphabets, this solution is ok</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<pre><code> re.findall(pattern, string, flags=0)\n\n    Return all non-overlapping matches of pattern in string, as a list of strings. \n    The string is scanned left-to-right, and matches are returned in the order found. \n</code></pre>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p>If you are curious about how the result is obtained for </p>\n\n<p><code>re.findall(r\'[bcdfghjklmnprstvyz]+\', "concertation")</code></p>\n\n<pre><code>concertation\n|\nc\n\nconcertation\n |\n # o is not present in the character class. Matching ends here. Adds match, \'c\' to ouput list\n\n\nconcertation\n  |\n  n\n\nconcertation\n   |\n   c\n\n\nconcertation\n    |\n     # Match ends again. Adds match \'nc\' to list \n     # And so on\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [u'I am not sure if the OP knows something about irregular expresses',
	                           u'You really should clarify that the difference with the second one is in relation to non-alphanumeric characters or alphabets beyond the English one.',

	              'extid': 27744905,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27744882/finding-consecutive-consonants-in-a-word/27744905#27744905',
	              'user_id': 106104,
	              'vote': 15},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>You could do this with regular expressions and the <code>re</code> module\'s <code>split</code> function:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&gt;&gt;&gt; import re\n&gt;&gt;&gt; re.split(r"[aeiou]+", "concertation")\n[\'c\', \'nc\', \'rt\', \'t\', \'n\']\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>This method splits the string whenever one or more consecutive vowels are matched. </p>\n\n<p>To explain the regular expression <code>"[aeiou]+"</code>: here the vowels have been collected into a class <code>[aeiou]</code> while the <code>+</code> indicates that one or more occurrence of any character in this class can be matched. Hence the string <code>"concertation"</code> is split at <code>o</code>, <code>e</code>, <code>a</code> and <code>io</code>.</p>\n\n<p><em>Note added later</em>: One thing to keep in mind is that this method implicitly assumes that the word contains only vowels and consonants. Numbers and punctuation will be treated as non-vowels/consonants. To match <em>only</em> consecutive consonants, instead use <code>re.findall</code> with the consonants listed in the character class (as noted in other answers).</p>',
	              'comments': [],

	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>Keep in mind that Foundation\'s types are different from Swift\'s types. A <code>String</code> in Swift is not an <code>NSString</code>, and a <code>Range</code> is not an <code>NSRange</code>. This does work:</p>\n\n<pre><code>let country = self.appStoreCountry // if self.appStoreCountry is an NSString\nlet country: NSString = self.appStoreCountry // if self.appStoreCountry is a Swift string\n\nlet replaced = str.stringByReplacingOccurrencesOfString("[A-Za-z]{2}", withString: "", options: .RegularExpressionSearch, range: NSMakeRange(0, 2))`\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Also note the short-hand notation for <code>.RegularExpressionSearch</code>, which makes using enums in Swift a bit easier.</p>',

	              'body': u'<p>You can add new row to HTML table by <code>HtmlTableRow</code> , just for example do something like this:</p>\n\n<pre><code>        HtmlTableRow row ;\n        HtmlTableCell cell;\n        for (int i = 0; i &lt; ds.Tables[0].Rows.Count; i++)\n        {\n            row = new HtmlTableRow();\n            cell = new HtmlTableCell();\n            cell.Controls.Add(new LiteralControl(drIndentID[i]["RecommentedQuantity"].ToString()));\n            row.Cells.Insert(0, cell);\n\n            cell = new HtmlTableCell();\n            cell.Controls.Add(new LiteralControl(drIndentID[i]["ProductID"].ToString()));\n            row.Cells.Insert(1, cell);\n\n            cell = new HtmlTableCell();\n            cell.Controls.Add(new LiteralControl(drIndentID[i]["ProductRequiredDate"].ToString()));\n            row.Cells.Insert(2, cell);\n            dataTable.Rows.Insert(i, row);//If you want to add new rows after the exist tr use dataTable.Rows.Insert(i+1, row);\n        }\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Gridview is most powerful and useful control for sorting, paging, editing, delete, and formatting as well as you can working with dropdown, checkbox and textbox controls in GridView</p>\n\n<p>See this below links:</p>\n\n<p><a href="http://www.dotnetgallery.com/kb/resource14-Dropdown-checkbox-and-textbox-controls-in-aspnet-editable-Gridview.aspx" rel="nofollow">GridView Example1</a></p>\n\n<p><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms972948.aspx" rel="nofollow">GridView Example2</a></p>\n\n<p><a href="http://www.codeproject.com/Articles/37207/Editable-Gridview-with-Textbox-CheckBox-Radio-Butt" rel="nofollow">GridView Example3</a></p>',

2015-01-03 09:41:56+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748268/django-passing-parameters-from-template-to-view-not-working> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=1&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:41:56+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/1903366/lukasgeiter> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=1&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:41:56+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748268/django-passing-parameters-from-template-to-view-not-working>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>You have error in urls.py. In named group pattern you miss <code>?P</code> prefix. See <a href="https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.7/topics/http/urls/#named-" rel="nofollow">doc for reference</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Instead of </p>\n\n<pre><code>url(r\'^addFriend/(&lt;requested_friend&gt;[a-z]*)/\', views.addFriend, name=\'addFriend\'),\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>It should be:</p>\n\n<pre><code>url(r\'^addFriend/(?P&lt;requested_friend&gt;[a-z]*)/\', views.addFriend, name=\'addFriend\'),\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [u"Hmm I have that now and it's still not working.",
	                           u"url(r'^addFriend/(?P<requested_friend>[a-z]*)/', views.addFriend, name='addFriend'),  am I doing something wrong? Thanks"],
	              'extid': 27748394,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748268/django-passing-parameters-from-template-to-view-not-working/27748394#27748394',
	              'user_id': 342473,
	              'vote': 0},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>When you change <code>(&lt;requested_friend&gt;[a-z]*)</code> to <code>(?P&lt;requested_friend&gt;[0-9A-Za-z_\\-]+)</code> than everything looks fine.</p>\n\n<p>But remember to use <code>+</code> instead of <code>*</code> in the pattern. <code>*</code> matches also a empty string (<code>addFriend//</code> is matched) but with <code>+</code> the string must have at least one character (<code>addFriend//</code> isn\'t matched) </p>\n\n<p>You can add <code>$</code> on the end of url pattern <code>r\'^addFriend/(?P&lt;requested_friend&gt;[0-9A-Za-z_\\-]+)/$\'</code> <a href="https://docs.python.org/2/library/re.html#regular-expression-syntax" rel="nofollow">Here</a> you can find why.</p>\n\n<p>Also check if the link in browser has correct value <code>/events/addFriend/&lt;user_name&gt;/</code> maybe is something wrong with <code>{{ user.username }}</code> </p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753447,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748268/django-passing-parameters-from-template-to-view-not-working/27753447#27753447',
	              'user_id': 2154023,
	              'vote': 0}],

GCC also includes front ends for C++ (including a large amount of experimental support for C++11), Objective-C, Fortran, Java, Ada, and Go, as well as libraries for these languages (libstdc++, libgcj,...). 2015-01-03 09:41:57+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/inheritance/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c++/info)
2015-01-03 09:41:57+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/inheritance/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Inheritance is the system in object oriented programming that allows objects to support operations defined by anterior types without having to provide their own definition. It is the major vector for polymorphism in object-oriented programming.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Inheritance is the main method by which object-oriented systems provide <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polymorphism_%28computer_science%29" rel="nofollow">polymorphism</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Where a class <code>Sub</code> inherits from another class (or other object, as in Self or JavaScript) <code>Base</code>, <code>Sub</code> will share some or all of the operations (possibly including data access and storage) provided by <code>Base</code>. It is usually the case that <code>Sub</code> will receive at least the full public interface of <code>Base</code> in order to allow any object of type <code>Sub</code> to stand in place of an object of type <code>Base</code> in any code written to work on objects of type <code>Base</code> (refer to the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liskov_substitution_principle" rel="nofollow">Liskov Substitution Principle</a>).</p>\n\n<p>This facility is orthogonal to the type of type system used, the function binding regime (whether late or early), whether or not there is a privacy regime, or indeed the evaluation (whether lazy or weak).</p>\n\n<p>See <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inheritance_(object-oriented_programming)" rel="nofollow">Inheritance on Wikipedia</a>.</p>',
	 'name': 'inheritance',
	 'qcount': 18578,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/inheritance/info'}

It started as an exercise to see how much could be removed from a standard html template (&lt;, &gt;, closing tags, etc...). As more people took an interest in Slim, the functionality grew and so did the flexibility of the syntax.</p>\n\n<p>Slim will strive to maintain simplicity, but not everyone\'s definition of a readable syntax is the same. The docs will show you the options.</p>\n\n<p>Slim uses Temple and Tilt. If you want to learn how Slim works, you\'ll need to study these projects.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Source:</strong>  <a href="http://slim-lang.com/about.html" rel="nofollow">Slim-lang.com (About)</a></p>',

It can be used as a standalone HTML generation tool or as a template rendering engine in a web framework such as Ruby on Rails or Ramaze.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://haml.info/" rel="nofollow"><strong>HAML (HTML Abstraction Markup Language)</strong></a> is an indentation based, terse page description markup. It features among other things autoclosing of tags and convenient shorthands to set class and id attributes. </p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h3>Example</h3>\n\n<p><a href="/questions/tagged/erb" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'erb\'" rel="tag">erb</a> page and its conversion :</p>\n\n<p><strong>erb</strong> </p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;div id=\'content\'&gt;\n  &lt;div class=\'left column\'&gt;\n    &lt;h2&gt;Welcome to our site!&lt;/h2&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;&lt;%= print_information %&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\n  &lt;/div&gt;\n  &lt;div class="right column"&gt;\n    &lt;%= render :partial =&gt; "sidebar" %&gt;\n  &lt;/div&gt;\n&lt;/div&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><strong>HAML</strong></p>\n\n<pre><code>#content\n  .left.column\n    %h2 Welcome to our site!\n    %p= print_information\n  .right.column\n    = render :partial =&gt; "sidebar"\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><strong>Where to start:</strong></p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><a href="http://haml.info/tutorial.html" rel="nofollow">Getting Started Tutorial</a></li>\n</ol>',

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>NSIS (Nullsoft Scriptable Install System) is a professional open source system to create Windows installers. It is designed to be as small and flexible as possible and is therefore very suitable for internet distribution.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><strong>Details</strong></p>\n\n<p>Being a user\'s first experience with your product, a stable and reliable installer is an important component of succesful software. With NSIS you can create such installers that are capable of doing everything that is needed to setup your software.</p>\n\n<p>NSIS is script-based and allows you to create the logic to handle even the most complex installation tasks. Many plug-ins and scripts are already available: you can create web installers, communicate with Windows and other software components, install or update shared components and more</p>\n\n<p><strong>Getting Started</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/Main_Page" rel="nofollow">NSIS Website</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/Screenshots" rel="nofollow">Screenshots</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/Features" rel="nofollow">Features</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/Docs/" rel="nofollow">Documentation</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://forums.winamp.com/forumdisplay.php?s=&amp;forumid=65" rel="nofollow">Official Forum</a> </li>\n<li><a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/Category%3aCode_Examples" rel="nofollow">Examples</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/Category%3aTutorials" rel="nofollow">Tutorials</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/Download" rel="nofollow"><strong>Download</strong></a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>IDE</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/EclipseNSIS_-_NSIS_plugin_for_Eclipse" rel="nofollow">NSIS has an eclipse plugin</a> </li>\n<li><a href="http://hmne.sourceforge.net/" rel="nofollow">Another open source editor.HM NIS EDIT.</a> : Even has a small wizard allowing quick setup template.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>Plugins</strong></p>\n\n<p><a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/Category%3aPlugins" rel="nofollow">NSIS comes with a variety of plugins</a></p>\n\n<p>Plugins are usually one <code>.dll</code> file and an <code>.nsh</code> file. To Install Plugins you need to copy the <code>dll</code> to <em>C:\\Program Files\\NSIS\\Plugins</em> and the <code>nsh</code> file to <em>C:\\Program Files\\NSIS\\Include</em><br>\nSee : <a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/How_can_I_install_a_plugin" rel="nofollow">How do I install a Plugin</a></p>\n\n<p><strong>Useful Plugins</strong> </p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/DotNet_plug-in" rel="nofollow">Dotnet Plugin</a> </li>\n<li><a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/GetVersion_%28Windows%29_plug-in" rel="nofollow">Get Windows Version (this one is much more verbose and gets Service Pack Details)</a>  </li>\n<li><a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/UAC_plug-in" rel="nofollow">UAC Plugin</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/DumpLog_plug-in" rel="nofollow">DumpLog (Creates a log file out of the details printed)</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>Tips</strong></p>\n\n<ol>\n<li><p>You can use the the <a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/LogicLib" rel="nofollow"><em>LogicLib</em></a> which comes as part of the installation to use <code>if</code> conditions in your script (this is not directly available). All you need to do is: </p>\n\n<p><code>!include \'LogicLib.nsh\'</code><br>\n<a href="http://nsis.sourceforge.net/LogicLib" rel="nofollow">See this for details.</a></p></li>\n</ol>',

2015-01-03 09:41:58+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/html/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the principal markup language used for structuring web pages and formatting content. The most recent revision to the HTML specification is HTML5.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<hr>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>Questions regarding HTML should include a <a href="http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/269753/feedback-requested-runnable-code-snippets-in-questions-and-answers">Stack Snippet</a>, a <a href="http://jsfiddle.net" rel="nofollow">JSFiddle</a> or a <a href="http://jsbin.com" rel="nofollow">JSBin</a> demo of relevant code if requesting debugging help.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p>HTML (<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML" rel="nofollow">HyperText Markup Language</a>) is the main markup language (similar to <a href="/questions/tagged/xml" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'xml\'" rel="tag">xml</a>) for creating web pages and other information to be displayed in a web browser. It was invented by Tim Berners-Lee while at CERN to enable researchers to share their findings. The latest version for HTML is <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/html5" rel="nofollow">HTML5</a>, which supports many new features.</p>\n\n<p>HTML elements form the building blocks of all websites. HTML allows images and objects to be embedded and can be used to create interactive forms. It provides a means to create structured documents by denoting structural semantics for text such as headings, paragraphs, lists, links, quotes and other items. It can embed scripts written in languages such as JavaScript which affect the behavior of HTML web pages. All the webpages that are written in different programming languages (PHP, JSP, VF etc.) get rendered as HTML on the browser.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h3>Syntax</h3>\n\n<p>HTML is written in the form of HTML elements consisting of tags (and their attributes) enclosed in angle brackets (like <code>&lt;html&gt;</code>), within the web page content. Angle brackets are also referred to as left &amp; right guillemets or chevrons.</p>\n\n<p>HTML tags most commonly come in pairs like <code>&lt;h1&gt;</code> and <code>&lt;/h1&gt;</code>, although some tags, known as empty elements, are unpaired, for example <code>&lt;img&gt;</code>, these are usually closed by putting a <code>/</code> at the end (Ex. <code>&lt;img src=\'image.jpg\'/&gt;</code>). The first tag in a pair is the start tag, the second tag is the end tag (they are also called opening tags and closing tags). In between these tags authors can add text, tags, comments and other types of text-based content.</p>\n\n<p>The purpose of a web browser is to read HTML documents and compose them into visible or audible web pages. The browser does not display the HTML tags, but uses the tags to interpret the content of the page.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h3>Standards</h3>\n\n<p>HTML standards, as well as those for many other web technologies, are maintained by the <a href="http://www.w3.org/" rel="nofollow">World Wide Web Consortium</a> (<a href="/questions/tagged/w3c" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'w3c\'" rel="tag">w3c</a>). </p>\n\n<p><a href="/questions/tagged/html4" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'html4\'" rel="tag">html4</a> was introduced in 1997, and the latest iteration, <a href="/questions/tagged/html5" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'html5\'" rel="tag">html5</a> was recently developed by the W3C. What W3C calls <em>HTML5</em> is a subset of the HTML-Living-Standard which is specified by the <a href="http://www.whatwg.org/" rel="nofollow">Web Hypertext Application Technology Working Group</a> (WHATWG).</p>\n\n<p>The language specification and standards documents for HTML5 are available online <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/" rel="nofollow">here</a>.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h3>FAQ</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/HTML/HTML5/HTML5_element_list" rel="nofollow">HTML5 Elements List</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/html5">HTML5-tagged on StackOverflow</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>References</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3.org/wiki/HTML/Specifications" rel="nofollow">W3C HTML/Specifications</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://validator.w3.org/" rel="nofollow">W3C HTML Validator</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en/HTML/" rel="nofollow">HTML Reference at the Mozilla Developer Network (MDN)</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.webplatform.org/" rel="nofollow">WebPlatform</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/aa740473.aspx" rel="nofollow">Web development features - IE Dev Center</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://reference.sitepoint.com/html" rel="nofollow">SitePoint HTML Reference</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3.org/community/webed/wiki/Main_Page" rel="nofollow">Web Education Community Group Wiki</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20/" rel="nofollow">W3C Web Content Accessibility Guidelines</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/buglist.cgi?product=HTML.next" rel="nofollow">HTML Feature Requests</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Free HTML Books</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://diveintohtml5.info/" rel="nofollow">Dive Into HTML5</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.htmldog.com/" rel="nofollow">HTML Dog Tutorials</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Related Tags :</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/html5" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'html5\'" rel="tag">html5</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/xhtml" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'xhtml\'" rel="tag">xhtml</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/markup" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'markup\'" rel="tag">markup</a></li>\n</ul>',

WinForms provides access to the native Microsoft Windows interface elements by wrapping the existing Windows API in managed code.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>WinForms is the informal name given to Windows Forms, the graphical application programming interface (API) included as a part of Microsoft\'s <a href="/questions/tagged/.net" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'.net\'" rel="tag">.net</a> framework, which provides access to the native Microsoft Windows interface elements by wrapping the existing <a href="/questions/tagged/windows-api" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'windows-api\'" rel="tag">windows-api</a> in managed code.<sup><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Forms" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia</a></sup></p>\n\n<p>A Windows Forms application is an event-driven application supported by Microsoft\'s .NET Framework. 2015-01-03 09:42:00+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/objective-c/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24042144/stringbyreplacingoccurrencesofstring-is-not-working)
2015-01-03 09:42:00+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/objective-c/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>This tag should be used only on questions that are about Objective-C features or depend on code in the language. The tags "cocoa" and "cocoa-touch" should be used to ask about Apple\'s frameworks or classes. Use the related tags [ios] and [osx] for issues specific to those platforms.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Objective-C" rel="nofollow">Objective-C</a> is an object-oriented programming language combining features of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C" rel="nofollow">C</a> (<a href="/questions/tagged/c" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c\'" rel="tag">c</a>) and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smalltalk" rel="nofollow">Smalltalk</a> (<a href="/questions/tagged/smalltalk" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'smalltalk\'" rel="tag">smalltalk</a>). It is a strict superset of C (any valid C code is equally valid Objective-C code), and it inherits its object-oriented capabilities from Smalltalk. All procedural syntax is identical to that of C, and all object-oriented syntax is an implementation of Smalltalk messaging.</p>\n\n<p>Objective-C was created primarily by <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brad_Cox" rel="nofollow">Brad Cox</a> and Tom Love in the early 1980s at their company <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stepstone" rel="nofollow">Stepstone</a>. It is now primarily developed by <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc." rel="nofollow">Apple, Inc</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Objective-C is a general-purpose, high-level, object-oriented programming language that adds Smalltalk-style messaging to the C programming language. It is the main programming language used by Apple for <a href="/questions/tagged/osx" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'osx\'" rel="tag">osx</a> and <a href="/questions/tagged/ios" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios\'" rel="tag">ios</a> and their respective APIs, <a href="/questions/tagged/cocoa" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cocoa\'" rel="tag">cocoa</a> and <a href="/questions/tagged/cocoa-touch" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cocoa-touch\'" rel="tag">cocoa-touch</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Objective-C inherits the syntax, primitive types, and flow control statements of C and adds syntax for defining classes and methods. It also adds language-level support for object graph management and object literals while providing dynamic typing and binding, deferring many responsibilities until runtime.</p>\n\n<h1>Hello world in Objective C</h1>\n\n<pre class="lang-objective-c prettyprint-override"><code>#import &lt;stdio.h&gt;\n\nint main(void)\n{\n    NSLog(@"Hello, world!\\n");\n    return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<h2>Syntax</h2>\n\n<p>Objective-C is a thin layer on top of C, and moreover is a strict superset of C; it is possible to compile any C program with an Objective-C compiler, and to freely include C code within an Objective-C class.\nObjective-C derives its object syntax from Smalltalk. All of the syntax for non-object-oriented operations (including primitive variables, pre-processing, expressions, function declarations, and function calls) are identical to that of C, while the syntax for object-oriented features is an implementation of Smalltalk-style messaging.</p>\n\n<h2>References</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/ProgrammingWithObjectiveC/Introduction/Introduction.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40011210" rel="nofollow">Programming with Objective-C</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/General/Conceptual/CocoaEncyclopedia/Introduction/Introduction.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40010810" rel="nofollow">Concepts in Objective-C Programming</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://developer.apple.com/mac/library/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/MemoryMgmt/Articles/mmRules.html" rel="nofollow">Cocoa Memory Management Programming Guide</a>, an essential read, especially the part about <a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/documentation/CoreFoundation/Conceptual/CFMemoryMgmt/Concepts/Ownership.html" rel="nofollow">Ownership Policy</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://cocoadevcentral.com/d/learn_objectivec/" rel="nofollow">Learn Objective-C</a> from Cocoa Dev Central, an introductory tutorial to the language</li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/OOP_ObjC/Introduction/Introduction.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40005149" rel="nofollow">Object-Oriented Programming with Objective-C</a></li>\n<li>WWDC 2012 videos on <a href="https://developer.apple.com/videos/wwdc/2012/?id=405" rel="nofollow">Modern Objective-C</a> and <a href="https://developer.apple.com/videos/wwdc/2012/?id=413" rel="nofollow">Migrating to Modern Objective-C</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/#documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/MemoryMgmt/Articles/MemoryMgmt.html" rel="nofollow">Advanced Memory Management Programming Guide</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://tryobjectivec.codeschool.com" rel="nofollow">Learn Objective-C basics from CodeSchool</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rypress.com/tutorials/objective-c/index.html" rel="nofollow">Ry\u2019s Objective-C Tutorial</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://matteomanferdini.com/objective-c-guide-for-developers-part-1/" rel="nofollow">Objective-C Guide For Developers</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.raywenderlich.com/4872/objective-c-cheat-sheet-and-quick-reference" rel="nofollow">Objective-C Cheat Sheet and Quick Reference</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Stack Overflow questions with links to resources</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7571/cocoa-and-objective-c-resources">Cocoa and Objective-C resources?</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Frequently posted questions in the Obj-C tag</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/588866/atomic-vs-nonatomic-properties">What\'s the difference between the atomic and nonatomic 2015-01-03 09:42:00+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/asp.net/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>ASP.NET is a Microsoft web application development framework that allows programmers to build dynamic web sites, web applications and web services. </p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>ASP.NET was first released in <strong>January 2002</strong> with <em>version 1.0</em> of the <a href="/questions/tagged/.net-framework" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'.net-framework\'" rel="tag">.net-framework</a>, and is the successor to <strong>Microsoft\'s</strong> Active Server Pages (ASP) technology. ASP.NET is built on the <strong><em>Common Language Runtime</em></strong> (<a href="/questions/tagged/clr" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'clr\'" rel="tag">clr</a>), allowing programmers to write ASP.NET code using any supported .NET language.</p>\n\n<p>Typically, ASP.NET uses a web forms style of development, which was also the original method of developing web applications in ASP.NET.  Web forms is a model which mimics the control/event model of classic <a href="/questions/tagged/winforms" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'winforms\'" rel="tag">winforms</a> development, providing the illusion of stateful pages.</p>\n\n<p>However, in March of 2009 Microsoft released version 1.0 of the <a href="/questions/tagged/asp.net-mvc" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'asp.net-mvc\'" rel="tag">asp.net-mvc</a> Framework.  As an alternate model to web forms, this framework applies the Model-View-Controller pattern to web applications in ASP.NET.</p>\n\n<p>As ASP.NET includes its own controls library, wrapping HTML controls and adding functionality to them, any ASP.NET controls have as markup <code>&lt;asp:ctrl_name&gt;&lt;/asp:ctrl_name&gt;</code>. </p>\n\n<p>For example:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;asp:Label ID="Label1" runat="server"&gt;&lt;/asp:label&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Will be rendered like a <code>&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;</code></p>\n\n<p>More information at: <a href="http://www.asp.net" rel="nofollow">www.asp.net</a></p>\n\n<p><strong>Development Tips:</strong> </p>\n\n<p><a href="http://www.sitepoint.com/complete-guide-reducing-page-weight/" rel="nofollow">Tips</a> for good website design, which loads and works faster</p>\n\n<h3>Initial release:</h3>\n\n<p>January 2002</p>\n\n<h3>Stable Release:</h3>\n\n<p><code>Stable release 4.5</code> (15 August 2012)</p>\n\n<h2>Important Questions</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/649428/asp-net-special-tags">ASP.NET "special" tags</a> - This is reflected in the Visual Basic .NET version numbering, continuing from VB6. </p>\n\n<p>To date, the following versions of VB.NET have been released: </p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>2003 (VB 7.1)</li>\n<li>2005 (VB 8.0)</li>\n<li>2008 (VB 9.0)</li>\n<li>2010 (VB 10.0)</li>\n<li>2012 (VB 11.0)</li>\n<li>2013 (VB 12.0)</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>VB.NET is supported in a wide range of platforms:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><strong><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.NET_Framework" rel="nofollow">Microsoft .NET Framework for Windows</a></strong> - Windows desktops and servers</li>\n<li><strong><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mono_%28software%29" rel="nofollow">Mono</a></strong> - Open-source framework for desktops, servers, and mobile devices on various platforms</li>\n<li><strong><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Silverlight" rel="nofollow">Microsoft Silverlight</a></strong> - Web browsers and mobile devices</li>\n<li><strong><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moonlight_%28runtime%29" rel="nofollow">Moonlight</a></strong> - Open-source framework for web browsers and mobile devices</li>\n<li><strong><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.NET_Compact_Framework" rel="nofollow">Microsoft .NET Compact Framework</a></strong> - Windows mobile devices</li>\n<li><strong><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.NET_Micro_Framework" rel="nofollow">.NET Micro Framework</a></strong> - Open-source framework for mobile and embedded devices on various platforms</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>VB.NET should not be confused with <a href="/questions/tagged/vb6" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'vb6\'" rel="tag">vb6</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/vba" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'vba\'" rel="tag">vba</a>, or <a href="/questions/tagged/vbscript" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'vbscript\'" rel="tag">vbscript</a>.  Although those languages share a similar syntax with VB.NET, they are entirely different technologies. </p>\n\n<h2>Popular VB.NET questions on Stack Overflow</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2599680/ive-caught-an-exception-now-what">Exception handling - I\'ve caught an exception. 2015-01-03 09:42:01+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/deployment/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>A series of activities that makes a program available for use (usually in test or production environments)</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Deployment consists in a series of activities needed to get a program available for use outside a development environment (for example on web sites, PCs, smartphones and/or tablets).</p>\n\n<p>At a high level, deployment activities need to:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>compile the program in a suitable packaging format;</li>\n<li>distribute the program to the final environment (e.g. via the Internet, an app store or CDs);</li>\n<li>install dependencies (usually libraries, runtimes and application servers);</li>\n<li>configure the target environment (e.g. where the database is or runtime parameters of the application server).</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>A deployment can be done in several ways according to the program type, for example: </p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>to deploy a web application written in Java we can add JARs to web containers;</li>\n<li>to deploy a desktop application on Windows we can create a setup program and burn it to CDs;</li>\n<li>to deploy an application to a cloud environment (like Heroku or Windows Azure) we can use ad-hoc programs or widely known programs like <code>git</code> that trigger a series of operations on the server side;</li>\n<li>to deploy an application to an app store we may need to send the application to the store owner for approval. If the application is approved then the store owner will publish the new version, making it available to the users;</li>\n<li>a deployment may require to distribute specially configured virtual machines with the right version of software and dependencies.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>There are many challenges in deployment revolving around two main themes:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>ensure that programs exhibit the same behavior in production as they do in testing and development. To achieve this, usually there are several test environments (beyond development) in which the software is deployed and tested thoroughly before being released in the production environment. <a href="/questions/tagged/canary-deployment" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'canary-deployment\'" rel="tag">canary-deployment</a> is the strategy of deploying to a subset of users to detect production-only errors with minimal user impact.</li>\n<li>being able to rollback to a previous stable version in case the current version behaves erratically. The deployment environment may help by providing some facilities to retain previous versions and install them when needed. <a href="/questions/tagged/blue-green-deployment" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'blue-green-deployment\'" rel="tag">blue-green-deployment</a> is a deployment strategy which enables fast, robust release and rollback.</li>\n</ul>',
	 'name': 'deployment',
	 'qcount': 11824,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/deployment/info'}

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Django is an open source web application framework, written in Python. Django is designed to reduce the effort required to create complex database-driven websites.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Django is the Web framework for perfectionists with deadlines.</p>\n\n<p>Django is an open source Web 2.0 application framework, written in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Python_%28programming_language%29" rel="nofollow">Python</a> and maintained by the non-profit <a href="https://www.djangoproject.com/foundation/" rel="nofollow">Django Software Foundation (DSF)</a>.\nIts primary goal is to ease the creation of complex database-driven websites.</p>\n\n<p>Django follows the MVC (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model%E2%80%93view%E2%80%93controller" rel="nofollow">model-view-controller</a>) architectural pattern.<br>\nThis consists of:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>an <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-relational_mapping" rel="nofollow">object-relational mapper</a> that mediates between data models<br>\n(Python classes) and a relational database ("Model")</p></li>\n<li><p>a system for processing requests with a web templating system ("View")  </p></li>\n<li><p>a regular-expression-based URL dispatcher ("Controller")</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Django\'s latest <strong>major version is 1.7</strong> and was released on the 2nd of September 2014</p>\n\n<h3>Resources</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a 2015-01-03 09:42:02+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/class/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c++/info)
2015-01-03 09:42:02+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/class/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>A template for creating new objects that describes the common state(s) and behaviour(s).</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>In <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-oriented_programming" rel="nofollow">object-oriented programming</a> (see: <a href="/questions/tagged/oop" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'oop\'" rel="tag">oop</a>), a class is a construct that is used as a <strong>blueprint</strong> (or a <strong>template</strong>) to create objects of that class. This blueprint describes the <strong>state</strong> and <strong>behavior</strong> that the objects of the class all share. An object of a given class is called an <strong>instance</strong> of the class. The class that contains (and was used to create) that instance can be considered as the <strong>type</strong> of that object, e.g. an object instance of the <code>Fruit</code> class would be of the type <code>Fruit</code>.</p>\n\n<p>A class usually represents a noun, such as a person, place or (possibly quite abstract) thing - it is a model of a concept within a computer program. Fundamentally, it encapsulates the state and behavior of the concept it represents. It encapsulates state through data placeholders called <strong>attributes</strong> (or member variables or instance variables or fields); it encapsulates behavior through reusable sections of code called <strong>methods</strong>.</p>\n\n<p>More technically, a class is a cohesive package that consists of a particular kind of metadata. A class has both an <strong>interface</strong> and a <strong>structure</strong>. The interface describes how to interact with the class and its instances using methods, while the structure describes how the data is partitioned into attributes within an instance. A class may also have a representation (metaobject) at run time, which provides run time support for manipulating the class-related metadata. In object-oriented design, a class is the most specific type of an object in relation to a specific layer.</p>\n\n<p>Example of class declaration in C#:</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-C# prettyprint-override"><code>/// &lt;summary&gt;\n/// Class which objects will say "Hello" to any target :)\n/// &lt;/summary&gt;\nclass HelloAnything\n{\n    /// &lt;summary&gt;\n    /// Target for "Hello". Private attribute that will be set only once\n    ////when object is created. Only objects of this class can access\n    /// their own target attribute.\n    /// &lt;/summary&gt;\n    private readonly string target;\n\n    /// &lt;summary&gt;\n    /// Constructor. Code that will execute when instance of class is created.\n    /// &lt;/summary&gt;\n    /// &lt;param name="target"&gt;Target for "Hello". If nothing specified then\n    /// will be used default value "World".&lt;/param&gt;\n    public HelloAnything(string target = "World")\n    {\n        //Save value in the inner attribute for using in the future.\n        this.target = target;\n    }\n\n    /// &lt;summary&gt;\n    /// Returns phrase with greeting to the specified target.\n    /// &lt;/summary&gt;\n    /// &lt;returns&gt;Text of greeting.&lt;/returns&gt;\n    public string SayHello()\n    {\n        return "Hello, " + target + "!";\n    }\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Using example of the defined class:</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-C# prettyprint-override"><code>class Program\n{\n    static void Main(string[] args)\n    {\n        //Say hello to the specified target.\n        HelloAnything greeting = new HelloAnything("Stack Overflow");\n        Console.WriteLine(greeting.SayHello());\n\n        //Say hello to the "default" target.\n        greeting = new HelloAnything();\n        Console.WriteLine(greeting.SayHello());\n    }\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Output result:</p>\n\n<pre><code>Hello, Stack Overflow!\nHello, World!\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Computer programs usually model aspects of some real or abstract world (the Domain). Because each class models a concept, classes provide a more natural way to create such models. Each class in the model represents a noun in the domain, and the methods of the class represent verbs that may apply to that noun.</p>\n\n<p>For example in a typical business system, various aspects of the business are modelled, using such classes as <code>Customer</code>, <code>Product</code>, <code>Worker</code>, <code>Invoice</code>, <code>Job</code>, etc. An <code>Invoice</code> may have methods like <code>Create</code>, <code>Print</code> or <code>Send</code>, a <code>Job</code> may be <code>Perform</code>-ed or <code>Cancel</code>-led, etc.</p>\n\n<p>Once the system can model aspects of the business accurately, it can provide users of the system with useful information about those aspects. Classes allow a clear correspondence (mapping) between the model and the domain, making it easier to design, build, modify and understand these models. Classes provide some control over the often challenging complexity of such models.</p>\n\n<p>Classes can accelerate development by reducing redundant program code, testing and bug fixing. If a class has been thoroughly tested and is known to be a \'solid work\', it is usually true that using or extending the well-tested class will reduce the number of bugs - as compared to the use of freshly-developed or ad hoc code - in the final output. In addition, efficient class reuse means that many bugs need to be fixed in only one place when problems are discovered.</p>\n\n<p>Another reason for using classes is to simplify the relationships of interrelated data. Rather than writing code to repeatedly call a graphical user interface (GUI) window drawing subroutine on the terminal screen (as would be typical for structured programming), it is more intuitive. With classes, GUI items that are similar to windows (such as dialog boxes) can simply inherit most of their functionality and data structures from the window class. The programmer then need only add code to the dialog class that is unique to its operation. Indeed, GUIs are a very common and useful application of classes, and GUI programming is generally much easier with a good class framework.</p>\n\n<p><em>Source: <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Class" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia</a>.</em></p>\n\n<p>See also:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/object" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'object\'" rel="tag">object</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/record" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'record\'" rel="tag">record</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/struct" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'struct\'" rel="tag">struct</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/instance" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'instance\'" rel="tag">instance</a></li>\n</ul>',
	 'name': 'class',
	 'qcount': 32554,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/class/info'}

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>OpenGL is a graphics standard and API which is platform independent and available for desktop, workstation and mobile devices. It is designed to provide hardware-accelerated rendering, and hence gives greatly improved performance over traditional software rendering.\r\nOpenGL is used for applications like CAD software and computer games. The OpenGL standard, as well as OpenGL ES, is controlled by the Khronos group.\r\n</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><strong>OpenGL</strong> (Open Graphics Library) is an API used to interact with GPUs (Graphics Processing Units). Originally developed by <a href="http://www.sgi.com/" rel="nofollow">SGI (Silicon Graphics Inc.)</a> in the early 90\'s, the current API is being developed by the <a href="http://www.khronos.org/" rel="nofollow">Khronos Group</a>.</p>\n\n<p>OpenGL is platform independent and available for desktop, workstation and mobile devices. It is designed to provide hardware-accelerated rendering and is typically used for applications such as CAD software and computer games.</p>\n\n<p>When posting in the <a href="/questions/tagged/opengl" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'opengl\'" rel="tag">opengl</a> tag, remember to always specify your target OpenGL version in order to get more precise answers. The tags <a href="/questions/tagged/opengl-1.x" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'opengl-1.x\'" rel="tag">opengl-1.x</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/opengl-2.0" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'opengl-2.0\'" rel="tag">opengl-2.0</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/opengl-3" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'opengl-3\'" rel="tag">opengl-3</a>, and <a href="/questions/tagged/opengl-4" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'opengl-4\'" rel="tag">opengl-4</a> exist for this purpose. OpenGL ES (OpenGL for Embedded Systems) has its own tag - <a href="/questions/tagged/opengl-es" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'opengl-es\'" rel="tag">opengl-es</a>.</p>\n\n<h3>Official Documentation</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li>The Red Book - Tutorial GL</li>\n<li>The Orange Book - Tutorial for GLSL</li>\n<li>The Green Book - Tutorial for GLX</li>\n<li>The Blue Book - API references for GL (out of print; 	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>The Vector class implements a grow-able array of objects. Like an array, it contains components that can be accessed using an integer index. However, the size of a Vector can grow or shrink as needed to accommodate adding and removing items after the Vector has been created. Use \'vector-graphics\' for graphic display.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>The Vector class implements a grow-able array of objects. Like an array, it contains components that can be accessed using an integral index. However, the size of a vector can grow, or shrink, as needed to accommodate adding and removing items after the vector has been created. </p>\n\n<p>The applicable C++ Standard Library container class is called <code>std::vector</code> and emulates a C-style array. It has advantages offer an array; such as the additional functionality of resizing itself when inserting or removing elements. As with the traditional array, the memory backing the <code>std::vector</code> is guaranteed to be contiguous, hence it is also often used to interoperate with older C-style APIs whilst maintaining the resources required.</p>\n\n<p>Java also has the old Vector collection that, differently from ArrayList, is synchronized (so safer for multithreading), but slower. However headers or documentation for C, FORTRAN code also often name usual, fixed size arrays as "vectors".</p>\n\n<p>The term "Vector" originated from using the array data structure to represent a geometric vector the starts at the coordinate origin (0,0,0) and points to the point, determined by the values, stored in this array (x,y,z). </p>\n\n<p>This is distinct from:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>(mathematical) vectors, used in computer graphics</li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/vector-graphics" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'vector-graphics\'" rel="tag">vector-graphics</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>See also: <a href="/questions/tagged/array" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'array\'" rel="tag">array</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/matrix" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'matrix\'" rel="tag">matrix</a></p>',
	 'name': 'vector',

It was officially launched by Intel in 1999 and is now supported by Itseez.\r\n\r\nUses include: Human-Computer Interaction; Object Identification, Segmentation and Recognition; Face Recognition; Gesture Recognition; Motion Tracking, Motion Understanding; Stereo and Multi-Camera Calibration and Depth Computation; Mobile Robotics. </p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>OpenCV is the most popular and advanced code library for Computer Vision related applications today, spanning from many very basic tasks (capture and pre-processing of image data) to high-level algorithms (feature extraction, motion tracking, machine learning). It is free software and provides a rich API in C, C++, Java and Python. Other wrappers are available. The library itself is platform-independent and often used for real-time image processing and computer vision (e.g. tracking in videos).</p>\n\n<p>OpenCV was officially launched by Intel in 1999 and is now supported by Itseez.\nVersion 2.0 (2009) was an important landmark as it introduced the new, comprehensive C++ interface, which since then is also to be used internally in the library. Since this release, OpenCV saw a strong acceleration of development in improving the library and adding new features.\nMore information may be found <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenCV" rel="nofollow">in Wikipedia</a>.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Homepage:</strong> <a href="http://opencv.org" rel="nofollow">http://opencv.org</a></p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h3>Some Frequently Asked 2015-01-03 09:42:03+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/stl/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>The Standard Template Library, or STL, is a C++ library of generic containers, iterators, algorithms, and function objects.\r\n\r\nWhen C++ was standardised, large parts of the STL were adopted into the Standard Library, and these parts in the Standard Library are also sometimes referred to collectively as "the STL".</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>The <strong>Standard Template Library,</strong> or <strong>STL</strong>, is a C++ library of generic containers, iterators, algorithms, and function objects. Originally designed by Alexander Stepanov and Meng Lee and published by HP in 1995. Large parts of the STL were adopted with modifications into the ISO C++ Standard Library. </p>\n\n<p>Note that the name STL is ambiguous, as it may refer to different things. The following are the typical intended meanings (suggested tagging in brackets):</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>The original HP implementation (<a href="/questions/tagged/stl" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'stl\'" rel="tag">stl</a> or <a href="/questions/tagged/hp-stl" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'hp-stl\'" rel="tag">hp-stl</a>)</li>\n<li>The SGI STL library (<a href="/questions/tagged/stl" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'stl\'" rel="tag">stl</a> or <a href="/questions/tagged/sgi-stl" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'sgi-stl\'" rel="tag">sgi-stl</a>)</li>\n<li>The HP STL derived portions of the C++ standard library (<a href="/questions/tagged/stl" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'stl\'" rel="tag">stl</a> and <a href="/questions/tagged/stdlib" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'stdlib\'" rel="tag">stdlib</a>)</li>\n<li>The template portions of the C++ standard library (<a href="/questions/tagged/stl" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'stl\'" rel="tag">stl</a> and <a href="/questions/tagged/stdlib" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'stdlib\'" rel="tag">stdlib</a>)</li>\n<li>The entire C++ standard library (<a href="/questions/tagged/stdlib" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'stdlib\'" rel="tag">stdlib</a>)</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>The last two definitions are, strictly speaking, incorrect; the C++ standard never mentions either "STL" or "Standard Template Library". In practice, however, people rarely need to refer to the HP library, and so "STL" is nearly always used to describe the STL-derived parts of the standard library instead (the algorithms, iterators and containers), or the template portions.</p>\n\n<h3>Resources</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/" rel="nofollow">A C++ Standard Library Reference</a>*</li>\n<li><a href="http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp" rel="nofollow">Another C++ Standard Library Reference Wiki</a>*</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.sgi.com/tech/stl/" rel="nofollow">The SGI Standard Template Library Documentation</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><sub>*This reference is non-normative. </sub></p>',

2015-01-03 09:42:03+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/linux/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>GNU/Linux, commonly shortened as Linux, is an open source operating system. Use this tag only if your question relates to using Linux APIs or Linux-specific behavior. Questions relating to using or troubleshooting Linux are off topic.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><strong>GNU/Linux</strong> is a Unix-like computer operating system which consists of necessary user-space libraries and programs provided by <a href="https://www.gnu.org/" rel="nofollow">GNU</a> in Cambridge, Massachusetts and a kernel, developed by Linus Torvalds in Helsinki, Finland.</p>\n\n<p>The GNU/Linux naming controversy is a dispute among members of the free and open source software community over how to refer to the computer operating system commonly called Linux.</p>\n\n<h3>Design</h3>\n\n<p>A GNU/Linux-based system is a modular Unix-like operating system. It derives much of its basic design from principles established in Unix during the 1970s and 1980s. Such a system uses a monolithic kernel which handles process control, networking, and peripheral and file system access. Device drivers are either integrated directly with the kernel or added as modules loaded while the system is running.</p>\n\n<p>Separate projects that interface with the kernel provide much of the system\'s higher-level functionality. The GNU user-land is an important part of most GNU/Linux-based systems, providing the most common implementation of the C library, a popular shell, and many of the common Unix tools which carry out many basic operating system tasks. The graphical user interface (or GUI) used by most GNU/Linux systems is built on top of an implementation of the X Window System.</p>\n\n<h3>Tag Usage</h3>\n\n<p>The <a href="/questions/tagged/linux" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'linux\'" rel="tag">linux</a> tag on Stack Overflow is generally used for questions about:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>programming against the APIs supplied by the operating system</li>\n<li>the implementation of the kernel</li>\n<li>programming tools and techniques for use <em>on</em> a GNU/Linux system.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Notable questions that probably don\'t belong are:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>questions about using a desktop or laptop GNU/Linux system are better directed towards <a href="https://superuser.com/">Super User</a></li>\n<li>questions about administering GNU/Linux systems for other users and networking GNU/Linux systems in a context more complicated then a minimal home network are better directed towards <a href="https://serverfault.com/">Server Fault</a>.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Many questions about GNU/Linux can <em>also</em> be properly tagged as <a href="/questions/tagged/unix" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'unix\'" rel="tag">unix</a>, but some features are specific to GNU/Linux and are not found on other Unix\u2122 and Unix-like operating systems.</p>\n\n<p>A fair number of <a href="/questions/tagged/linux" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'linux\'" rel="tag">linux</a> questions are really questions about the command shell (<code>bash</code> by default on many systems), and are probably better tagged with <a href="/questions/tagged/shell" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'shell\'" rel="tag">shell</a> and/or the particular shell you are interested in (<a href="/questions/tagged/bash" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'bash\'" rel="tag">bash</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/zsh" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'zsh\'" rel="tag">zsh</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/tcsh" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'tcsh\'" rel="tag">tcsh</a>, etc...).</p>\n\n<p>Questions about the internals of the GNU/Linux kernel or regarding writing GNU/Linux kernel modules should be tagged <a href="/questions/tagged/linux-kernel" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'linux-kernel\'" rel="tag">linux-kernel</a>.</p>\n\n<h3>Free Linux Books</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.advancedlinuxprogramming.com/" rel="nofollow">Advanced Linux Programming</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://www.sourceware.org/autobook/download.html" rel="nofollow">GNU Autoconf, Automake and Libtool</a></li>\n<li><a rel="nofollow">Linux Device Drivers</a> by Jonathan Corbet, Alessandro Rubini, and Greg Kroah-Hartman</li>\n<li><a href="http://tldp.org/LDP/lkmpg/2.6/html/" rel="nofollow">The Linux Kernel Module Programming Guide</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.dwheeler.com/secure-programs/Secure-Programs-HOWTO.html" rel="nofollow">Secure Programming for Linux and Unix</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Linux rel="nofollow">Oracle Linux</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><a href="https://distrowatch.com/" rel="nofollow">Distrowatch</a> aggregates new release notices from these and hundreds of other Linux 2015-01-03 09:42:04+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/pointers/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>A pointer is a data type that "points to" another value stored in memory using its address.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>A pointer is a data type that "points to" another value stored in memory using its address. Pointers have a variety of performance benefits in repetitive operations. For example, copying a pointer is "cheaper" than copying the value that it points to because only the address must be copied. Pointers are an important concept in many high-level programming languages, including C and C++. The <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pointer_%28computer_programming%29" rel="nofollow" title="Wikipedia page for pointers">Wikipedia page for pointers</a> has a fairly in-depth introduction to the concept.</p>\n\n<h3>Please see the below references for explanations of pointers</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5727/what-are-the-barriers-to-understanding-pointers-and-what-can-be-done-to-overcome">What are the barriers to Understanding Pointers and What Can be Done to Overcome them?</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://ericlippert.com/2014/05/12/what-are-the-fundamental-rules-of-pointers/" rel="nofollow">Eric Lippert: What are the fundamental rules of pointers?</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>See also</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/references" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'references\'" rel="tag">references</a></li>\n</ul>',

	 'qcount': 21765,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/pointers/info'}

This tag is for questions about developing native Windows applications using the Win32 API.  </p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>The <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_API" rel="nofollow">Windows API</a>, informally WinAPI, is Microsoft\'s core set of application programming interfaces (APIs) available in the Microsoft Windows operating systems. It was formerly called the Win32 API; however, the name Windows API more accurately reflects its roots in 16-bit Windows and its support on 64-bit Windows. Almost all Windows programs interact with the Windows API.  You can find more help on the <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ff818516%28v=vs.85%29.aspx" rel="nofollow">Windows API Documentation</a>.</p>',
