	 'body': u'<p>My project is a dynamic report app similar to JasperReport and am using JSF 2.2.7 (Mojara) and primefaces 5.0. When a user logs in, he/she sees just the reports assigned to him/her which is dynamically loaded from the database. Everything else is working properly except that when they select a report, the page doesnt load the entire report until a second click.</p>\n\n<p>My problem is the report doesnt load properly until a second click. Here are my code.</p>\n\n<pre><code>@Named(value = "userController")\n@SessionScoped\npublic class ReportUserController implements Serializable {\n\nprivate HtmlPanelGroup panelGroup;  // with getter and setter\n\n@PostConstruct\npublic void init() {\n    values = new ArrayList&lt;&gt;();\n    // Retrieve user\'s details and reports here\n\n    MenuModel model = new DefaultMenuModel();\n    Application application = FacesContext.getCurrentInstance().getApplication();\n    panelGroup = (HtmlPanelGroup) application.createComponent(HtmlPanelGroup.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n    PanelGrid panelGrid = (PanelGrid) application.createComponent(PanelGrid.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n    panelGrid.setColumns(2);\n\n    // Retrieve reports for d group the logged-in user belong\n    List&lt;Report&gt; repts = setupController.getExistingReports();\n\n    DefaultSubMenu reports = new DefaultSubMenu("Reports");\n    for (Report rep : repts) {\n        DefaultMenuItem menuItem = new DefaultMenuItem(rep.getReportName());\n        menuItem.setId(rep.getReportName().replaceAll("\\\\s+", "")); \n        menuItem.setAjax(true);\n        menuItem.setUpdate(":reportForm");\n        menuItem.setProcess("@form");\n        menuItem.setCommand("#{userController.loadReport(" + rep.getId() + ")}");\n        reports.addElement(menuItem);\n        reports.addElement(new DefaultSeparator());\n\n    }\n    model.addElement(reports);\n    Menubar menubar = (Menubar) application.createComponent(Menubar.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n    menubar.setModel(model);\n\n    panelGroup.getChildren().add(menubar);\n\n}\n\npublic void loadReport(Long id) {\n\n    selectedReport = reportFacade.find(id);\n    if (parameters != null) {\n        parameters.clear();\n    }\n\n    if (values != null) {\n        values.clear();\n    }\n\n    queryColumns = selectedReport.getColumns();\n\n    queryParams = selectedReport.getReportParameters();\n    query = selectedReport.getReportQuery();\n\n    // This method is called to build the components of the page to be rendered dynamically.\n    // And it\'s every time a new report is selected\n    buildPage();\n\n}\n\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>And here is the <code>buildPage()</code> method in the same class. (Please bear with me its a stupidly long code)</p>\n\n<pre><code>    public void buildPage() {\n\n    Application application = FacesContext.getCurrentInstance().getApplication();\n    reportPanelGroup = (HtmlPanelGroup)    application.createComponent(HtmlPanelGroup.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n    PanelGrid panelGrid = (PanelGrid) application.createComponent(PanelGrid.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n    panelGrid.setColumns(2);\n\n    for (ReportParameter param : queryParams) {\n\n        String parameterLabel = param.getLabel();\n        String componentType = param.getComponentType();\n        String calendarPattern = param.getCalendarPattern();\n        boolean required = param.isRequired();\n        boolean userProperty = param.isUserProperty();\n        String queryPosition = param.getQueryPosition();\n        String sqlDatePattern = param.getSqlDatePattern();\n        String dataType = param.getDataType();\n        String userPropertyName = param.getUserPropertyName();\n        List&lt;DropDown&gt; dropDowns = param.getDropDowns();\n\n        if ((userProperty)) {\n            // Retrieve some info from the logged-in user              \n        } else {\n\n            OutputLabel label = (OutputLabel) application.createComponent(OutputLabel.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n\n            label.setId(parameterLabel.replaceAll("\\\\s+", "") + "label");\n            label.setValue(parameterLabel + ":");\n\n            if (componentType.equalsIgnoreCase("Calendar")) {\n                Calendar cal = (Calendar) application.createComponent(Calendar.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n\n                cal.setId(parameterLabel.replaceAll("\\\\s+", ""));\n                cal.setShowButtonPanel(true);\n                cal.setPattern(calendarPattern);\n                cal.setRequired(required);\n\n                cal.setValueExpression("value",\n                        getExpressionFactory()\n                        .createValueExpression(getELContext(), "#{userController.parameters[\'"\n                                + queryPosition.trim() + "\']}", Date.class));\n\n                label.setFor(parameterLabel.replaceAll("\\\\s+", ""));\n                panelGrid.getChildren().add(label);\n\n                panelGrid.getChildren().add(cal);\n\n            } else if (componentType.equalsIgnoreCase("TextField")) {\n                InputText input = (InputText) application.createComponent(InputText.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n                input.setRequired(required);\n (componentType.equalsIgnoreCase("DropDown")) {\n\n                SelectOneMenu selectOneMenu = (SelectOneMenu) application.createComponent(SelectOneMenu.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n selectOneMenu.setId(parameterLabel.replaceAll("\\\\s+", ""));\n\n                selectItems.setId(parameterLabel.replaceAll("\\\\s+", "") + "selectItems");\n\n                List&lt;SelectItem&gt; items = new ArrayList&lt;&gt;();\n\n                items.add(new SelectItem("", "Select..."));\n                if (dropDowns != null &amp;&amp; !dropDowns.isEmpty()) {\n                    for (DropDown d : dropDowns) {\n                        items.add(new SelectItem(d.getValue(), d.getLabel()));\n                    }\n                }\n\n                selectItems.setValue(items);\n                selectOneMenu.getChildren().add(selectItems);\n\n                selectOneMenu.setValueExpression("value",\n                        getExpressionFactory()\n                        .createValueExpression(getELContext(), "#{userController.parameters[\'"\n                                + queryPosition.trim() + "\']}", String.class));\n\n                label.setFor(parameterLabel.replaceAll("\\\\s+", ""));\n                panelGrid.getChildren().add(label);\n\n                panelGrid.getChildren().add(selectOneMenu);\n\n            }\n        }\n Class[]{ActionEvent.class});\n    MethodExpressionActionListener meal = new MethodExpressionActionListener(performSearch);\n    searchBtn.addActionListener(meal);\n    searchBtn.setType("submit");\n\n spacer.setHeight("30");\n    reportPanelGroup.getChildren().add(spacer);\n\n    HtmlForm downloadForm = (HtmlForm) application.createComponent(HtmlForm.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n    downloadForm.setId("downloadForm");\n\n    CommandLink downloadBtn = (CommandLink) application.createComponent(CommandLink.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n    downloadBtn.setId("downloadBtnID");\n    downloadBtn.setValue("Test Download");\n    //downloadBtn.setIcon("icon ui-icon-search");\n    downloadBtn.setAjax(false);\n\n    String reportName = new ArrayList&lt;&gt;();\n\n    for (int i = 0; i &lt; queryColumns.size(); i++) {\n        Column col = (Column) application.createComponent(Column.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n        col.setHeaderText(queryColumns.get(i).getPrefferedName());\n        if (queryColumns.get(i).isLink()) {\n            HtmlForm linkForm = (HtmlForm) application.createComponent(HtmlForm.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n            linkForm.setId("linkForm");\n            CommandLink link = (CommandLink)     application.createComponent(CommandLink.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n\n            if (queryColumns.get(i).isDataMasked()) {\n                link.setValueExpression("value", getExpressionFactory().createValueExpression(getELContext(),\n                        "#{userController.maskStringValue(val[" + i + "]," + queryColumns.get(i).getLeftDigit() + "," + queryColumns.get(i).getRightDigit() + ")}", String.class));\n            } else {\n                link.setValueExpression("value", getExpressionFactory().createValueExpression(getELContext(),\n                        "#{val[" + i + "]}", String.class));\n            }\n\n            link.setStyle("text-decoration: underline; color: blue;");\n            MethodExpression action = ef.createMethodExpression(getELContext(),\n                    "customizeColumns?faces-redirect=true", null, new Class[]{String.class});\n            link.setAjax(false);\n            link.setActionExpression(action);\n            linkForm.getChildren().add(link);\n            col.getChildren().add(linkForm);\n        } else {\n            HtmlOutputText out = (HtmlOutputText) application.createComponent(HtmlOutputText.COMPONENT_TYPE);\n            if (queryColumns.get(i).getFormatAs() != null &amp;&amp; queryColumns.get(i).getFormatAs().equals("Amount")) {\n                out.setValueExpression("value", getExpressionFactory().createValueExpression(getELContext(),\n                        "#{userController.formatAsAmount(val[" + i + "])}", String.class));\n            } else if (queryColumns.get(i).getFormatAs() != null &amp;&amp; queryColumns.get(i).getFormatAs().equals("Number")) {\n                out.setValueExpression("value", getExpressionFactory().createValueExpression(getELContext(),\n                        "#{userController.formatAsNumber(val[" + i + "])}", String.class));\n            } else if (queryColumns.get(i).isDataMasked()) {\n                out.setValueExpression("value", getExpressionFactory().createValueExpression(getELContext(),\n                        "#{userController.maskStringValue(val[" + i + "]," + queryColumns.get(i).getLeftDigit() + "," + queryColumns.get(i).getRightDigit() + ")}", String.class));\n            } else {\n                out.setValueExpression("value", getExpressionFactory().createValueExpression(getELContext(),\n                        "#{val[" + i + "]}", String.class));\n            }\n\n            col.getChildren().add(out);\n        }\n        cols.add(col);\n    }\n\n    dynamicTable.setColumns(cols); //renderReport\n    dynamicTable.setValueExpression("rendered", getExpressionFactory()\n            .createValueExpression(getELContext(), "#{userController.values.size() &gt; 0}",     Boolean.class));\n\n    dynamicTable.setPaginator(true);\n    dynamicTable.setRowsPerPageTemplate("20,50,100");\n\n    reportPanelGroup.getChildren().add(dynamicTable);\n\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>And here is my page:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;?xml version=\'1.0\' 	              'body': u'<p>I got same error on my windows machine.</p>\n\n<p>When I compared project file system with other working project I found that</p>\n\n<pre><code>  project.properties \n</code></pre>\n\n<p>was missing, So I Created a txt file and renamed it to "project.properties" then got this message on my console.</p>\n\n<pre><code> "Project has no project.properties file! Edit the project properties to set one"\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Then I went through project menu</p>\n\n<pre><code>project-&gt;properties-&gt;android-&gt;choose &amp; set the "project build target".\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>then build it.now everything was smooth.</p>\n\n<p>We just setup a valid project.properites file for that project. </p>',

2015-01-03 09:42:24+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/813602/ingo-karkat> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=1&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:42:24+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27747227/dealing-with-saxonevaluate-exception>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<pre><code>&lt;xf:var\n    as="xs:string"\n    name="..."\n    value="\n        if(@arg1 =\'null\')\n        then \'asd\'\n        else \'saxon:evaluate(instance(\'\'arg1\'\'))"/&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>To test for a blank string, better use <code>normalize-space()</code>. Also, I guess that <code>instance(\'arg1\')</code> is where the value is stored in both cases:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;xf:var\n    as="xs:string"\n    name="..."\n    value="\n        if (normalize-space(instance(\'arg1\')) = \'\')\n        then \'asd\'\n        else \'saxon:evaluate(instance(\'\'arg1\'\'))\'\n"/&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>But I am a bit unclear on why you need to quote the <code>saxon:evaluate()</code> call. Do you want the variable to hold:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>the result of the evaluation?</li>\n<li>or an XPath expression?</li>\n</ol>',
	              'comments': [u"I've updated my question, sorry to be unprecise in the first place."],

	 'body': u'<p>I have an XBL file where I can pass some arguments from my form, let\'s say : </p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;my-xbl arg1=\'\' arg2=\'\'&gt;\n&lt;/my-xbl&gt;\n\n&lt;xf:input ref=\'@arg1\'/&gt;\n&lt;xf:input ref=\'@arg2\'/&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Then I have something like this : </p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;xf:var as="xs:string" name="control-value" value="saxon:evaluate(instance(\'arg1\'))"/&gt;  \n&lt;xf:var as="xs:string" name="control-name" value="saxon:evaluate(instance(\'arg2\'))"/&gt;\n&lt;xf:setvalue ref="xxf:instance(\'fr-form-instance\')//*[name() = $control-name]"\n                                     value="$control-value"/&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>The problem is when arg1 is empty string (it means that in my form when I press Control settings and skipp arg1 field, just leaving it empty) then my form crashes. 2015-01-03 09:42:25+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27751070/vim-custom-syntax-highlight-how-to-highlight-a-variable-that-stores-a-function>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>You need to find out which syntax group causes the highlighting. <code>:syn list</code> shows all active groups, but it\'s easier when you install the <a href="http://www.vim.org/scripts/script.php?script_id=383" rel="nofollow">SyntaxAttr.vim - Show syntax highlighting attributes of character under cursor</a> plugin.</p>\n\n<p>If the syntax script you\'re using provides a dedicated syntax group (something named <code>coffeeFunction</code>), changing the highlighting is as easy as putting</p>\n\n<pre><code>:highlight link coffeeFunction Function\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>into your <code>~/.vimrc</code>. If there\'s no dedicated group, you\'d have to extend the syntax script (or ask the script\'s author to do). The challenge there is that the new definition has to fit in with the others (especially with regards to <code>contained=...</code> relations. You may also search for different syntax scripts. AFAIK, no CoffeeScript syntax script presently ships with Vim, so there may be several competing versions out there.</p>',
	              'comments': [],

2015-01-03 09:42:26+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/iphone-standalone-web-app/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>An iOS web app whose content is purely web-browser-based and runs outside of Mobile Safari in a chromeless browser using the meta declaration: &lt;meta name="apple-mobile-web-app-capable" content="yes" /&gt;</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>In order to make websites and web apps appear more "app-like" on iOS devices, mobile Webkit supports the <code>apple-mobile-web-app-capable</code> meta tag. When the app is opened in Safari, this tag will have no effect. But when this tag is used, and the application is saved to the home screen as an icon and opened that way, it is said to be running in standalone mode and is referred to as a standalone web app. </p>\n\n<p>Standalone web apps do not have any of the Safari UI visible. For security reasons, because they run in their own process space, they run a <em>different version of Webkit and use a different Javascript engine</em>. Because of these differences, standalone web apps often behave differently than apps running in mobile Safari.</p>\n\n<p>This tag is declared:</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-html prettyprint-override"><code>&lt;meta name="apple-mobile-web-app-capable" content="yes" /&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>To install the application to work in standalone mode, open the website in mobile Safari and then:</p>\n\n<p>Tap <img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/iPCDC.png" alt="share">, <img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/J7DxN.png" alt="add to homescreen">, enter a name, and then <img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/VBPVQ.png" alt="add">.</p>\n\n<p>This installs an icon on the iOS device\'s home screen. When opened from this icon, the app will be running in standalone mode.</p>\n\n<p>When running in standalone mode, Webkit also supports the <code>apple-mobile-web-app-status-bar-style</code> meta tag to control the color of the iOS device\'s status bar.</p>\n\n<p>More information can be found in the Safari Web Content Guide\'s section, <a href="http://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#DOCUMENTATION/AppleApplications/Reference/SafariWebContent/ConfiguringWebApplications/ConfiguringWebApplications.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40002051-CH3-SW3" rel="nofollow">"Configuring Web Applications"</a>.</p>',
	 'name': 'iphone-standalone-web-app',
	 'qcount': 198,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/iphone-standalone-web-app/info'}

2015-01-03 09:42:27+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/confidence-interval/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27557926/calculate-the-percentage-of-observations-that-lie-outside-the-90-confidence-int)
2015-01-03 09:42:27+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/confidence-interval/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>In statistics, a confidence interval is a measure of the precision of an estimate of an underlying parameter. In principle, if the estimate is computed several times on independent samples of data, the parameter should fall within associated confidence intervals a set proportion of the time. This proportion is known as the coverage probability, and is most commonly set to be 95%.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>When estimating a vector of parameters, c(\u03b8), based on observations of some random variables whose distribution depends on those parameters in some way, a confidence interval (for scalar  \u03b8) or confidence region (for vector c(\u03b8)), is some set C=C(<em>X</em>) such that P(c(\u03b8) \u2208 C) = 1\u2212\u03b1. To note:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>The confidence interval is a function of the data, <em>X</em>, so is itself random.  </li>\n<li>The statement regarding the probability that  c(\u03b8) \u2208 C  should be regarded with respect to the randomness in <em>X</em> which controls <em>C</em>. Since confidence intervals are a <em>frequentist</em> notion, one should not think of the probability as applying to the unobserved parameter c(\u03b8), which, to a frequentist, <em>is not random</em>.</li>\n<li>Often one can only compute <em>approximate</em> confidence intervals, which may have the nominal coverage asymptotically in the sample size. </li>\n</ol>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p><strong>Tag usage</strong></p>\n\n<p>Questions on <a href="/questions/tagged/confidence-interval" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'confidence-interval\'" rel="tag">confidence-interval</a> should be about implementation and <strong>programming</strong> problems, not about the statistical or theoretical properties of the technique.\nConsider whether your question might be better suited to <a href="http://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/tagged/confidence-interval">Cross Validated</a>, the StackExchange site for statistics, machine learning and data analysis.</p>',
	 'name': 'confidence-interval',
	 'qcount': 173,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/confidence-interval/info'}

2015-01-03 09:42:27+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/ggplot2/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>ggplot2 is an actively maintained open-source chart-drawing library for R, written by Hadley Wickham, based upon the principles of "Grammar of Graphics".  It partially replaces R\'s basic plot and the lattice package, while providing a clean, powerful, orthogonal and fun API.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://had.co.nz/ggplot2/" rel="nofollow">ggplot2</a> is an <a href="https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2" rel="nofollow">actively maintained open-source</a> chart-drawing library for <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/r/info">R</a>, written by <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/users/16632/hadley">Hadley Wickham</a>, based upon the principles of <a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0387987746" rel="nofollow">"Grammar of Graphics"</a>, by Leland Wilkinson.  It partially replaces R\'s <a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/views/Graphics.html" rel="nofollow">basic plot</a> and the <a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/lattice/index.html" rel="nofollow">lattice package</a>, while providing a clean, powerful, and orthogonal and <strong>fun</strong> API.</p>\n\n<p>Resources:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ggplot2/index.html" rel="nofollow">Download</a> from the package archive or use <code>install.packages("ggplot2")</code></li>\n<li>Hadley\'s online old <a href="http://had.co.nz/ggplot2/" rel="nofollow">documentation</a> (pre-0.9) and new <a href="http://had.co.nz/ggplot2/docs/" rel="nofollow">documentation</a></li>\n<li>View the <a href="http://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/wiki" rel="nofollow">wiki</a> at github for tips, examples and case studies</li>\n<li>Hadley\'s Book <a href="http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/search?index=books&amp;linkCode=qs&amp;keywords=0387981403" rel="nofollow">"ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis"</a> at Amazon - <a href="http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=F_hwtlzPXBcC&amp;printsec=frontcover&amp;dq=ggplot2&amp;source=bl&amp;ots=FsAN6sCXmF&amp;sig=91iNnYNrvhbHAnAMIBinyUDOyYw&amp;hl=en&amp;ei=_FXlTPW5GM-r4Qba7qnwDg&amp;sa=X&amp;oi=book_result&amp;ct=result&amp;resnum=10&amp;ved=0CEoQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">preview</a></li>\n<li>Winston Chang\'s <a href="http://shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920023135.do" rel="nofollow">"R Graphics Cookbook"</a> at O\'Reilly</li>\n<li>Google Groups <a href="http://groups.google.com/group/ggplot2" rel="nofollow">Discussion</a></li>\n<li>View the <a href="https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2" rel="nofollow">source</a> at github</li>\n<li>Detailed usage and comparison to lattice at "<a href="http://learnr.wordpress.com/tag/ggplot2/" rel="nofollow">Learning R</a>"</li>\n<li>Hadley\'s <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/users/16632/hadley">stackoverflow user</a></li>\n<li>On Mar 1st 2012 a major new version was released, 0.9.0. A <a href="http://cloud.github.com/downloads/hadley/ggplot2/guide-col.pdf" rel="nofollow">PDF</a> detailing many of the new features and changes is available.</li>\n<li>On Sept 11th 2012, version 0.9.2 was released. See <a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ggplot2/ggplot2.pdf" rel="nofollow">documentation</a> and <a href="https://github.com/hadley/ggplot2/blob/ggplot2-0.9.2/NEWS" rel="nofollow">a list of changes</a>.</li>\n<li>Winston Chang\'s <a href="http://www.cookbook-r.com/" rel="nofollow">Cookbook for R</a> has <a href="http://www.cookbook-r.com/Graphs/" rel="nofollow">pages</a> that have been updated to reflect changes in the new version of ggplot2 0.9.2.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>There are several related packages on CRAN that are based upon or extend ggplot2\'s functionality:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/GGally/index.html" rel="nofollow">GGally</a> Package contains templates for different plots to be combined into a plot matrix, as well as a parallel coordinate plot function.</li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ggcolpairs/index.html" rel="nofollow">ggcolpairs</a> Combination of GGplot2 plots into a matrix based on data columns</li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ggdendro/index.html" rel="nofollow">ggdendro</a> Tools for extracting dendrogram and tree diagram plot data for use with ggplot</li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/granovaGG/index.html" rel="nofollow">granovaGG</a> Graphical Analysis of Variance Using ggplot2</li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/nvis/index.html" rel="nofollow">nvis</a> Combination of visualization functions for nuclear data using ggplot2 and ggcolpairs</li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ggmap/index.html" rel="nofollow">ggmap</a> allows visualization of spatial data and models on top of Google Maps, OpenStreetMaps, Stamen Maps, or CloudMade Maps using ggplot2</li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ggthemes/index.html" rel="nofollow">ggthemes</a> contains extra geoms, scales, and themes for use with ggplot2</li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ggsubplot/index.html" rel="nofollow">ggsubplot</a> makes it easy to embed customized subplots within larger graphics</li>\n<li>Finally, the package <a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/gridExtra/index.html" rel="nofollow">gridExtra</a> is often useful, as ggplot2 is based upon the grid graphics system.</li>\n</ul>',
	 'name': 'ggplot2',
	 'qcount': 6972,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/ggplot2/info'}

It is a subproject of Glassfish.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Mojarra is the codename of Sun/Oracle\'s JSF reference implementation. It is a subproject of Glassfish.</p>\n\n<h3>Online resources</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://javaserverfaces.java.net" rel="nofollow">Mojarra homepage</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Related tag info pages</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/jsf/info">JSF tag info page</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Frequently asked questions</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7162190/what-is-mojarra">What is Mojarra?</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4530746/mojarra-or-myfaces-jsf2-0-starter">Mojarra vs MyFaces</a></li>\n</ul>',

2015-01-03 09:42:28+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/jsf-2/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27737810/dynamic-jsf-primefaces-poor-loading)
2015-01-03 09:42:28+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/jsf-2/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>JavaServer Faces (JSF) is a model-view-presenter framework typically used to create web applications. Version 2.x is a major step ahead compared to JSF 1.x, significantly expanding the standard set of components and component libraries. If you\'re using JSF 2.x, tag your questions as such so that more suited answers can be given.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>JavaServer Faces 2.x is a major step ahead as compared to JSF 1.x, significantly expanding the standard set of components and component libraries. Facelets (which was designed specifically for JavaServer Faces) was adopted as the official view technology for JSF 2.x. This eliminates the life-cycle conflicts that existed with JSP, forcing workarounds by Java developers. Lot of things which are hardly possible in JSF 1.x can be done more elegantly in JSF 2.x. If you\'re using JSF 2.x, tag your questions as such so that more suited answers can be given.</p>\n\n<p>For the real wiki, please jump over to the <a href="/questions/tagged/jsf" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jsf\'" rel="tag">jsf</a> wiki: <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/jsf/info">http://stackoverflow.com/tags/jsf/info</a>.</p>',
	 'name': 'jsf-2',
	 'qcount': 13466,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/jsf-2/info'}
2015-01-03 09:42:28+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/jsf/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27737810/dynamic-jsf-primefaces-poor-loading)
2015-01-03 09:42:28+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/jsf/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>JavaServer Faces (JSF) is a model-view-presenter framework typically used to create web applications.\r\n\r\nUsing the standard components and render kit, stateful HTML views can be defined using JSP or Facelets tags and wired to model data and application logic.\r\n</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JavaServer_Faces" rel="nofollow">JavaServer Faces (JSF)</a> is a model-view-presenter framework typically used to create web applications. Using the standard components and render kit, stateful HTML views can be defined using JSP or Facelets tags and wired to model data and application logic.</p>\n\n<h2>Information to provide when asking JSF questions:</h2>\n\n<p>If you want accurate answers to your JSF questions, you will get better answers more quickly if you include the following information in the question:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><strong>Which JSF implementation and version are you using?</strong> <a href="http://javaserverfaces.java.net" rel="nofollow">Mojarra</a> or <a href="http://myfaces.apache.org" rel="nofollow">MyFaces</a>? 1.0.x, 1.1.x, 1.2.x, 2.0.x, 2.1.x or 2.2.x? Particularly the difference between 1.x and 2.x is too big to be able give a reliable answer which can cover both versions. Also, each of the JSF implementations may have its own set of version-specific bugs/quirks so that the answerer can, if necessary, take this into account.</p></li>\n<li><p><strong>Which view technology are you using?</strong> JSP or Facelets (XHTML)? If you don\'t mention anything and it\'s obvious enough from the question (by e.g. code, tags, stacktrace, etc) that you\'re using JSF 2.x, then Facelets will usually always be assumed as JSP is deprecated since JSF 2.0. </p>\n\n<p>Note that while Facelets uses by default the XHTML extension, XHTML is from the other side on <em>not</em> necessarily Facelets. So when asking a question specifically about Facelets, please don\'t use the term "XHTML" and for sure do not use the <code>[xhtml]</code> tag. Ones who know about XHTML do not necessarily know something about Facelets. <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/xhtml/info">Click here to learn more about what exactly XHTML is</a>.</p></li>\n<li><p><strong>Any faces messages or warnings/errors/exceptions in server logs?</strong> If the application appears to be failing silently, make sure that you\'ve added a <code>&lt;h:messages /&gt;</code> tag to your view to avoid that you miss any faces messages. Also make sure that you have read the server logs from top to bottom and investigate any line which represents a warning or error or looks otherwise abnormal. Provide this information in the question.</p></li>\n<li><p><strong>Provide a minimal, complete, and verifiable example! (<a href="http://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve">MCVE</a>)</strong> Try to isolate the problem as much as possible into the smallest possible but complete copy\'n\'paste\'n\'runnable example. Import declarations and getters/setters are however not strictly necessary, as a bit sane IDE can just autocomplete/generate them. Also anything outside <code>&lt;h:body&gt;</code> in the view is not strictly necessary as it usually also speaks for itself. You should assume that the answerer will copypaste the provided code into a <code>&lt;h:body&gt;</code> or a templateless test file (and you should also first test it yourself beforehand!).</p>\n\n<p>Easiest would be to copy the problematic code into a new project and remove step by step as much as possible irrelevant resources (CSS/JS/images), tags (templates, layout, text, etc), attributes (style, styleclass, title, etc) and Java code (unrelated properties, EJBs, etc) as long as the problem still exhibits. Any DB data should be just stubbed in bean\'s <code>@PostConstruct</code> or action/listener method. Now, you should end up with the smallest possible backing bean class and a view (JSP/Facelets) file which someone else should be able to just copy\'n\'paste\'n\'run <em>without any changes</em> (expect of auto-organizing imports and autogenerating getters/setters if necessary, of course) to reproduce your exact problem themselves. </p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Minimum requirements:</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><strong>JSF 2.2</strong> requires a minimum of Servlet 3.0, because of the new file upload component which is internally using the standard Servlet 3.0 API without the need for 3rd party libraries. It requires a minimum of Java 1.6.</li>\n<li><strong>JSF 2.1</strong> uses some Servlet 3.0 specific features, but is backwards compatible with Servlet 2.5. Those Servlet 3.0 features are optional.</li>\n<li><strong>JSF 2.0</strong> which uses by default Facelets 2.x requires a minimum of EL 2.1 which goes hand in hand with Servlet 2.5, so it requires after all Servlet 2.5. If you supply your own EL 2.1 API/impl, then you can in theory run JSF 2.0 on Servlet 2.4. It requires a minimum of Java 1.5.</li>\n<li><strong>JSF 1.2</strong> works on Servlet 2.4, but requires a minimum of JSP/EL 2.1 which goes hand in hand with Servlet 2.5, so it after all requires Servlet 2.5. If you replace JSP 2.1 by Facelets 1.x as default view technology, then you can use JSF 1.2 on Servlet 2.4. It requires a minimum of Java 1.5.</li>\n<li><strong>JSF 1.0</strong> and <strong>1.1</strong> requires a minimum of Servlet 2.4 / JSP 2.0 and Java 1.4.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Examples of Servlet 3.1 containers are Tomcat 8.0.x, WildFly 8.x, GlassFish 4.x, and TomEE 2.x.\nExamples of Servlet 3.0 containers are Tomcat 7.0.x, JBoss AS 6.x/7.x, GlassFish 3.x, and TomEE 1.x.<br>\nExamples of Servlet 2.5 containers are Tomcat 6.0.x, JBoss AS 5.x, and GlassFish 2.x.<br>\nExamples of Servlet 2.4 containers are Tomcat 5.5.x, JBoss AS 4.x, and Sun Java Application Server.  </p>\n\n<h2>Hello World Example:</h2>\n\n<p><strong>Preparing:</strong> Depending on the server used, JSF may already be built-in (full fledged Java EE containers such as <a href="http://glassfish.java.net" rel="nofollow">GlassFish</a>, <a href="http://www.jboss.org/jbossas" rel="nofollow">JBoss AS</a>, <a href="http://wildfly.org" rel="nofollow">WildFly</a>, <a href="http://tomee.apache.org" rel="nofollow">TomEE</a>, WebSphere, etc.), or not (barebones JSP/Servlet containers such as <a href="http://tomcat.apache.org" rel="nofollow">Tomcat</a>, <a href="http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/" rel="nofollow">Jetty</a>, etc.). If not, then you\'d need to download a JSF implementation to <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4530746/mojarra-or-myfaces-jsf2-0-starter">your choice</a> and drop the necessary JAR files in <code>/WEB-INF/lib</code> folder. Don\'t forget the <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/jstl/info">JSTL</a> JAR file(s), those barebones containers usually also don\'t even ship with JSTL.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Controller:</strong> First register the <code>FacesServlet</code> in <code>/WEB-INF/web.xml</code> as follows:</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-xml prettyprint-override"><code>&lt;servlet&gt;\n    &lt;servlet-name&gt;facesServlet&lt;/servlet-name&gt;\n    &lt;servlet-class&gt;javax.faces.webapp.FacesServlet&lt;/servlet-class&gt;\n&lt;/servlet&gt;\n&lt;servlet-mapping&gt;\n    &lt;servlet-name&gt;facesServlet&lt;/servlet-name&gt;\n    &lt;url-pattern&gt;*.xhtml&lt;/url-pattern&gt;\n&lt;/servlet-mapping&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><strong>Model:</strong> Then create a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JavaBeans" rel="nofollow">javabean</a> class as follows:</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-java prettyprint-override"><code>package com.example;\n\nimport javax.faces.bean.ManagedBean;\nimport javax.faces.bean.RequestScoped;\n\n@ManagedBean\n@RequestScoped\npublic class Hello {\n\n    private String name;\n    private String message;\n\n    public String createMessage() {\n        message = "Hello, " + name + "!";\n        return null; // No navigation, so goes back to same view. You can also just make the method void.\n    }\n\n    public String getName() {\n        return name;\n    }\n\n    public void setName(String name) {\n        this.name = name;\n    }\n\n    public String getMessage() {\n        return message;\n    }\n\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><strong>View:</strong> Finally create a <a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/6/tutorial/doc/giepx.html" rel="nofollow">Facelets</a> file <code>hello.xhtml</code> as follows:</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-html prettyprint-override"><code>&lt;!DOCTYPE html&gt;\n&lt;html lang="en"\n    xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"\n    xmlns:f="http://xmlns.jcp.org/jsf/core"\n    xmlns:h="http://xmlns.jcp.org/jsf/html"&gt;\n    &lt;h:head&gt;\n        &lt;title&gt;Hello, World!&lt;/title&gt;\n    &lt;/h:head&gt;\n    &lt;h:body&gt;\n        &lt;h:form&gt;\n            &lt;h:outputLabel for="name" value="Enter your name" required="true" /&gt;\n            &lt;h:inputText id="name" value="#{hello.name}" /&gt;\n            &lt;h:message for="name" /&gt;\n            &lt;br /&gt;\n            &lt;h:commandButton value="Say hello" action="#{hello.createMessage}"&gt;\n                &lt;f:ajax execute="@form" render="@form" /&gt;\n            &lt;/h:commandButton&gt;\n            &lt;br /&gt;\n            &lt;h:outputText value="#{hello.message}" /&gt;\n        &lt;/h:form&gt;\n    &lt;/h:body&gt;\n&lt;/html&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Start the server and open it by <code>http://localhost:8080/contextname/hello.xhtml</code>.</p>\n\n<p><em>Note: the <code>xmlns.jcp.org</code> domain in XML namespace is new since JSF 2.2, if you\'re forced to use JSF 2.0/2.1, use <code>java.sun.com</code> domain instead.</em></p>\n\n<h3>Online resources and tutorials:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javaee/download-139288.html" rel="nofollow">JavaServer Faces Technology</a>\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.jcp.org/en/jsr/detail?id=314" rel="nofollow">Specification and API documentation</a></li>\n</ul></li>\n<li>Oracle Java EE tutorials\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/tutorial/jsf-intro.htm" rel="nofollow">Java EE 7 tutorial - JavaServer Faces Technology (JSF 2.2)</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/6/tutorial/doc/bnaph.html" rel="nofollow">Java EE 6 tutorial - JavaServer Faces Technology (JSF 2.0)</a> - <a href="http://java.net/downloads/javaeetutorial/javaeetutorial6.zip" rel="nofollow">Tutorial examples</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/5/tutorial/doc/bnaph.html" rel="nofollow">Java EE 5 tutorial - JavaServer Faces Technology (JSF 1.2)</a> - <a href="http://java.net/downloads/javaeetutorial/javaeetutorial5.zip" rel="nofollow">Tutorial examples</a></li>\n</ul></li>\n<li>ZEEF.com\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://jsf.zeef.com/bauke.scholtz" rel="nofollow">JSF by Bauke Scholtz</a></li>\n</ul></li>\n<li>Mkyong.com\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.mkyong.com/tutorials/jsf-2-0-tutorials/" rel="nofollow">JSF 2.0 tutorial</a></li>\n</ul></li>\n<li>Coreservlets.com\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.coreservlets.com/JSF-Tutorial/jsf2/" rel="nofollow">JSF 2.0 tutorials</a></li>\n</ul></li>\n<li>The BalusC code\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://balusc.blogspot.nl/2014/10/jsf-22-tutorial-with-eclipse-and-wildfly.html" rel="nofollow">JSF 2.2 Tutorial with Eclipse and WildFly</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://balusc.blogspot.com/2011/01/jsf-20-tutorial-with-eclipse-and.html" rel="nofollow">JSF 2.0 Tutorial with Eclipse and Glassfish</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://balusc.blogspot.com/2011/09/communication-in-jsf-20.html" rel="nofollow">Communication in JSF 2.0</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://balusc.blogspot.com/2010/06/benefits-and-pitfalls-of-viewscoped.html" rel="nofollow">JSF 2.0 CRUD examples</a></li>\n</ul></li>\n<li>Video Training\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.programming-simplified.com/jsf_video_training.html" rel="nofollow">JSF 2.0( Java Server Faces) Video Training</a></li>\n</ul></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Offline resources:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/1782176462" rel="nofollow">Mastering JSF 2.2</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/1430250100" rel="nofollow">Pro JSF 2.2 with HTML5</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/143024626X" rel="nofollow">Beginning Java EE 7 with GlassFish</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>JSF implementations:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://javaserverfaces.java.net/" rel="nofollow">Mojarra</a> - Oracle\'s reference implementation (RI), standard part of e.g. <a href="http://wildfly.org" rel="nofollow">WildFly</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://myfaces.apache.org/" rel="nofollow">Apache MyFaces</a> - Apache\'s alternative, standard part of e.g. <a href="http://tomee.apache.org/" rel="nofollow">TomEE</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>JSF component/utility libraries:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://primefaces.org" rel="nofollow">PrimeFaces</a> (<a href="http://www.primefaces.org/showcase/" rel="nofollow">showcase</a>) - component library, based on jQuery + jQuery UI</li>\n<li><a href="http://jboss.org/richfaces" rel="nofollow">RichFaces</a> (<a href="http://showcase.richfaces.org/" rel="nofollow">showcase</a>) - component library, based on jQuery + custom UI</li>\n<li><a href="http://icefaces.org" rel="nofollow">IceFaces</a> (<a href="http://component-showcase.icefaces.org/component-showcase/showcase.iface" rel="nofollow">showcase</a>) - component library, clone of PrimeFaces 2.x + some enhanced components</li>\n<li><a href="http://openfaces.org" rel="nofollow">OpenFaces</a> (<a href="http://openfaces.org/demo/overview/homepage.jsf" rel="nofollow">showcase</a>) - component library, based on custom JS/ajax + custom UI</li>\n<li><a href="http://myfaces.apache.org/tomahawk" rel="nofollow">Tomahawk</a> - component library, basic extensions to standard JSF, e.g. <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1867605/is-it-possible-to-use-jsf-to-build-clean-css-layouts-without-using-tables/1867670#1867670">tableless radio buttons</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://myfaces.apache.org/trinidad/" rel="nofollow">Trinidad</a> - component library, enhanced extensions to standard JSF + custom JS/ajax</li>\n<li><a href="http://omnifaces.org" rel="nofollow">OmniFaces</a> (<a href="http://showcase.omnifaces.org" rel="nofollow">showcase</a>) - utility library, compatible with any JSF component library</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Frequently asked questions:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Check the "frequent" tab of the <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/jsf?sort=frequent">JSF</a> and <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/jsf-2?sort=frequent">JSF2</a> tags.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>More links:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Check <a href="https://jsf.zeef.com/bauke.scholtz" rel="nofollow">JSF at ZEEF</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Related tags:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li>JSF general<br>\n<a href="/questions/tagged/mojarra" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'mojarra\'" rel="tag">mojarra</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/myfaces" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'myfaces\'" rel="tag">myfaces</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/facelets" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'facelets\'" rel="tag">facelets</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/tagfile" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'tagfile\'" rel="tag">tagfile</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/composite-component" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'composite-component\'" rel="tag">composite-component</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/custom-component" classes/tags<br>\n<a href="/questions/tagged/datatable" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'datatable\'" rel="tag">datatable</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/uirepeat" class="post-tag" 2015-01-03 09:42:29+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/r/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>R is a free, open-source programming language and software environment for statistical computing, bioinformatics, and graphics. Please supplement your question with a minimal reproducible example. For statistical questions please use http://stats.stackexchange.com.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<h1>R Programming Language</h1>\n\n<p><a href="http://www.r-project.org" rel="nofollow" title="R project homepage">R</a> is a free, open-source programming language and software environment for statistical computing, bioinformatics, and graphics. R is an implementation of the <a href="http://lib.stat.cmu.edu/S/Spoetry/Tutor/slanguage.html" rel="nofollow">S programming language</a> combined with lexical scoping semantics inspired by <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/scheme/info" title="Scheme on StackOverflow">Scheme</a>.  R was created by <a href="http://www.stat.auckland.ac.nz/~ihaka/" rel="nofollow">Ross Ihaka</a> and <a href="http://www.gene.com/scientists/our-scientists/robert-gentleman" rel="nofollow">Robert Gentleman</a> and is now developed by the <a href="http://www.r-project.org/contributors.html" rel="nofollow">R Development Core Team</a>. The R environment is easily extended through a packaging system on <a href="http://cran.r-project.org" rel="nofollow" title="CRAN The Comprehensive R Archive Network">CRAN</a>, the Comprehensive R Archive Network. </p>\n\n<h2><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/manuals.html" rel="nofollow">Official CRAN Documentation</a></h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-intro.html" rel="nofollow"><em>An Introduction to R</em></a> (<a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-intro.pdf" rel="nofollow">PDF</a>, <a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-intro.epub" rel="nofollow">epub</a>), a basic introduction for beginners.</li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-data.html" rel="nofollow"><em>R Data Import/Export</em></a> (<a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-data.pdf" rel="nofollow">PDF</a>, <a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-data.epub" rel="nofollow">epub</a>), a data import and export guide.</li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-admin.html" rel="nofollow"><em>R Installation and Administration</em></a> (<a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-admin.pdf" rel="nofollow">PDF</a>, <a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-admin.epub" rel="nofollow">epub</a>), an installation guide (from R source code).</li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-exts.html" rel="nofollow"><em>Writing R Extensions</em></a> (<a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-exts.pdf" rel="nofollow">PDF</a>, <a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-exts.epub" rel="nofollow">epub</a>), a development guide for R.</li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-lang.html" rel="nofollow"><em>The R Language Definition</em></a> (<a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-lang.pdf" rel="nofollow">PDF</a>, <a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-lang.epub" rel="nofollow">epub</a>), a more technical discussion of the R language itself.</li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-ints.html" rel="nofollow"><em>R Internals</em></a> (<a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-ints.pdf" rel="nofollow">PDF</a>, <a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-ints.epub" rel="nofollow">epub</a>), internal structures and coding guidelines.</li>\n<li><em>R Reference Index</em> (<a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/fullrefman.pdf" rel="nofollow">PDF</a>), contains all help files of the R standard and recommended packages in printable form.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Other CRAN resources</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://stat.ethz.ch/R-manual/R-patched/doc/html/packages.html" rel="nofollow">Packages in the standard library</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.r-project.org/mail.html" rel="nofollow">R mailing lists</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/views/" rel="nofollow">Task Views</a> - summary of useful packages by subject area. </li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/contrib/" rel="nofollow">Free books</a>, <a href="http://www.r-project.org/doc/bib/R-books.html" rel="nofollow">commercially available books</a> and <a href="http://cran.r-project.org/other-docs.html" rel="nofollow">other documents</a> on R in a variety of languages.</li>\n<li><a href="http://journal.r-project.org/" rel="nofollow">The R Journal</a> lists research articles and summaries of major revisions.</li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/FAQ/R-FAQ.html" rel="nofollow">R FAQ</a> - Official list of R FAQs on CRAN</li>\n<li><a href="https://bugs.r-project.org/bugzilla3/" rel="nofollow">R bug tracking system</a> - report bugs in base-R here.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Free Resources</h2>\n\n<h3>Interactive R learning</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.codeschool.com/courses/try-r" rel="nofollow"><em>Try R</em></a> - An interactive web-based R tutorial</li>\n<li><a from R</li>\n<li><a href="http://swirlstats.com" rel="nofollow"><em>Swirl</em></a> - R-package to learn R interactively</li>\n<li><a href="https://www.coursera.org/course/rprog" rel="nofollow"><em>Coursera</em></a> - Learn how to use R for effective data analysis</li>\n<li><a href="https://www.datacamp.com/courses/introduction-to-r" rel="nofollow"><em>DataCamp</em></a> - Master the basics of R</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Free books on R:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.burns-stat.com/documents/books/the-r-inferno/" rel="nofollow"><em>The R Inferno</em></a> (<a A collaborative textbook</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Programming Chrestomathy (problems written in many languages)</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://rosettacode.org/wiki/Category:R" rel="nofollow">Rosetta Code</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://learnxinyminutes.com/docs/r/" rel="nofollow">Learn X in Y minutes</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://golf.shinh.org/l.rb?r" rel="nofollow">Anarchy golf</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://hyperpolyglot.org/numerical-analysis" rel="nofollow">Hyperpolyglot</a> (R/MATLAB/Python)</li>\n<li><a href="http://pleac.sourceforge.net/pleac_R/index.html" rel="nofollow">PLEAC (Programming Languages Examples Alike Cookbook)</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/List_of_hello_world_programs#S_.28and_R.29" rel="nofollow">Wikibook of Hello World programs</a></li>\n<li>A <a href="http://www.math.umaine.edu/~hiebeler/comp/matlabR.html" rel="nofollow">MATLAB/R</a> (<a href="http://www.math.umaine.edu/~hiebeler/comp/matlabR.pdf" rel="nofollow">PDF</a>) language comparison reference guide by David Hiebeler</li>\n<li>An older <a href="http://mathesaurus.sourceforge.net/" rel="nofollow">MATLAB/Python/R</a> language comparison reference guide by Vidar Bronken Gundersen </li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Other free resource materials</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li>The <a href="http://www.jstatsoft.org/" rel="nofollow"><em>Journal of Statistical Software</em></a> has many papers about R packages</li>\n<li>The <a href="http://yihui.name/knitr" rel="nofollow"><em>knitr</em></a> site by Yihui Xie has resources on reproducible research using that package</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.mayin.org/ajayshah/KB/R/index.html" rel="nofollow"><em>R by example</em></a> by Ajay Shah</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.johndcook.com/blog/r_language_for_programmers/" rel="nofollow"><em>R language for programmers</em></a> by John D. package for <a href="https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/" rel="nofollow">Emacs</a> and <a href="http://xemacs.org/" rel="nofollow">XEmacs</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.rstudio.com/ide/" rel="nofollow">RStudio</a> - R-specific IDE</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.openanalytics.eu/architect" rel="nofollow">Architect</a> - a remix of the <a href="http://www.eclipse.org/eclipse/" rel="nofollow">Eclipse</a> IDE with the <a href="http://www.walware.de/goto/statet" rel="nofollow">StatET</a> plugin</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.revolutionanalytics.com/products/revolution-r.php" rel="nofollow">Revolution-R</a> - commercial IDE with community/enterprise variants</li>\n<li><a href="http://tap.tibco.com/storefront/trialware/tibco-enterprise-runtime-for-r/prod15307.html" rel="nofollow">TERR</a> (TIBCO Enterprise Runtime for R) - commercial IDE with its own R engine</li>\n<li><a href="http://live-analytics.com/" rel="nofollow">Live-R</a> - R IDE in a browser</li>\n<li><a href="http://rforge.net/JGR/" rel="nofollow">JGR</a> - Java-based GUI for R</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.sciviews.org/Tinn-R/" rel="nofollow">Tinn-R</a> - R-specific code editor</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.sciviews.org/SciViews-K" rel="nofollow">Sciviews-K</a> - Extension for the <a href="http://www.activestate.com/komodo-ide" rel="nofollow">Komodo</a> IDE</li>\n<li><a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/npptor/" rel="nofollow">NppToR</a> - plugin for Notepad++</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.vim.org/scripts/script.php?script_id=2628" rel="nofollow">Vim-R</a> - plugin for Vim </li>\n<li><a href="http://rgedit.sourceforge.net/" rel="nofollow">Rgedit</a> - plugin for gedit and pluma</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.deducer.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php?n=Main.DeducerManual" rel="nofollow">Deducer R Editor</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Code style guides</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/R-ints.html#R-coding-standards" rel="nofollow">R internal coding standards</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://master.bioconductor.org/developers/how-to/coding-style/" rel="nofollow">Bioconductor coding standards</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://google-styleguide.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/Rguide.xml" rel="nofollow">Google\'s</a></li>\n<li>Hadley Wickham\u2019s <a href="http://adv-r.had.co.nz/Style.html" rel="nofollow">standard</a> and <a href="http://stat405.had.co.nz/r-style.html" rel="nofollow">Stat 405</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://csgillespie.wordpress.com/2010/11/23/r-style-guide/" rel="nofollow">Colin Gillespie\u2019s</a></li>\n<li>Henrik Bengtsson\u2019s <a href="https://docs.google.com/View?id=dddzqd53_2646dcw759cb" rel="nofollow">basic</a> and <a href="https://docs.google.com/Doc?docid=0ATuHjzgbQ0B8ZGRkenFkNTNfMjY0NTR0azd4enhj" rel="nofollow">Aroma</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/rockchalk/vignettes/Rstyle.pdf" rel="nofollow">Paul E Johnson\u2019s</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://4dpiecharts.com/r-code-style-guide/" rel="nofollow">Richie Cotton\'s</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Other Resources</h2>\n\n<p>Recommended additional R resources include:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.rseek.org/" rel="nofollow">RSeek</a> - a search engine for R (<a href="http://mycroftproject.com/search-engines.html?name=rseek.org" rel="nofollow">Firefox search plugin</a>).</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.cookbook-r.com/" rel="nofollow">Cookbook for R</a> - solutions to common tasks in analyzing data.</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.statmethods.net/" rel="nofollow">Quick-R</a> - accessing the power of R.</li>\n<li>R on <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R_%28programming_language%29" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia</a> and <a href="https://en.wikiversity.org/wiki/R" rel="nofollow">Wikiversity</a>.</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.r-bloggers.com/" rel="nofollow">R-bloggers</a> - R blog aggregator.</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.inside-r.org/r-doc" rel="nofollow">Inside-R</a> and the <a href="http://rgm3.lab.nig.ac.jp/RGM/R_image_list?page=416&amp;init=true" rel="nofollow">R Graphical Manual</a> - enhanced versions of CRAN\'s R Reference Index.</li>\n<li><a href="http://docs.rexamine.com/R-devel/index.html" rel="nofollow">Rexamine</a> - documentation and annotation of R\'s C source code.</li>\n<li><a href="http://planetr.stderr.org/" rel="nofollow">Planet R</a> R package release aggregator (includes many sources outside of CRAN).</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.pluralsight.com/courses/r-programming-fundamentals" rel="nofollow">Pluralsight Course</a> - online video course for beginners.</li>\n<li><a href="http://crantastic.org/" rel="nofollow">crantastic</a> R package review site.</li>\n<li><a href="http://dirk.eddelbuettel.com/cranberries/about/" rel="nofollow">CRANberries</a> - news feed on CRAN package updates.</li>\n<li><a href="http://rattle.togaware.com/" rel="nofollow">Rattle</a> - GUI for data mining using R </li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Alternative R engines</h2>\n\n<p>With the exception of CXXR, designed to improve code clarity and documentation, all alternative R engines have the goal of increasing R\'s performance and memory management.</p>\n\n<h3>Forks of R with near 100% code compatibility</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.revolutionanalytics.com/revolution-r-open" rel="nofollow">Revolution R Open</a> (C-based).</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/database/database-technologies/r/r-distribution/overview/index.html" rel="nofollow">Oracle R distribution</a>, part of <a href="http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/database/database-technologies/r/r-enterprise/overview/index.html" rel="nofollow">Oracle R Enterprise</a> (C-based).</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.pqr-project.org/" rel="nofollow">pqR</a> by Radford Neal (C-based).</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.cs.kent.ac.uk/projects/cxxr/" rel="nofollow">CXXR</a> by Andrew Runnalls (C++-based).</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Rewrites with high code compatibility</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.renjin.org/" rel="nofollow">Renjin</a> by BeDataDriven (Java-based).</li>\n<li><a href="http://tap.tibco.com/storefront/trialware/tibco-enterprise-runtime-for-r/prod15307.html" rel="nofollow">TERR</a> by Tibco (C++-based).</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Experimental and early stage rewrites</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://github.com/jtalbot/riposte" rel="nofollow">Riposte</a> by Justin Talbot (C++-based).</li>\n<li><a href="https://github.com/allr/fastr" rel="nofollow">FastR</a> by Jan Vitek and Tomas Kalibera (Java-based).</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Unrelated tags</h2>\n\n<p>Due to R\'s simple name, questions sometimes get tagged with the <a href="/questions/tagged/r" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'r\'" rel="tag">r</a> tag when a different topic is meant. Here is a list of tags that mis-tagged R questions might be re-tagged to</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/r.java-file" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'r.java-file\'" rel="tag">r.java-file</a> for questions related to the file <code>R.java</code> on <a href="/questions/tagged/android" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'android\'" rel="tag"><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/tKsDb.png" height="16" width="18" alt="" class="sponsor-tag-img">android</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/r.js" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'r.js\'" rel="tag">r.js</a> "A command line tool for running JavaScript scripts that use the Asychronous Module Defintion API (AMD) for declaring and using JavaScript modules and regular JavaScript script files. It is part of the RequireJS project, and works with the RequireJS implementation of AMD." (from the <a href="/questions/tagged/r.js" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'r.js\'" rel="tag">r.js</a> wiki summary)</li>\n</ul>',
	 'name': 'r',
	 'qcount': 76973,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/r/info'}

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Eclipse is an open source IDE with plugins available to support a large variety of languages. This tag should only be used for questions specifically about the Eclipse IDE and not for generalized programming topics.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><strong><a href="https://eclipse.org/" rel="nofollow">Eclipse</a></strong> is an <a href="/questions/tagged/open-source" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'open-source\'" rel="tag">open-source</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/ide" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ide\'" rel="tag">ide</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/platform" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'platform\'" rel="tag">platform</a> written mostly in <a href="/questions/tagged/java" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'java\'" rel="tag">java</a> and primarily used for Java development through the use of the <a href="https://www.eclipse.org/jdt/" rel="nofollow">Java Development Tools</a> (JDT) plugin. It is notable for its rich ecosystem of free and commercial <a href="/questions/tagged/plugins" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'plugins\'" rel="tag">plugins</a>. </p>\n\n<p>Eclipse uses <code>OSGI</code> internally and has built in <code>OSGI</code> implementation called <a href="/questions/tagged/equinox" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'equinox\'" rel="tag">equinox</a>, the same <a href="/questions/tagged/osgi" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'osgi\'" rel="tag">osgi</a>-based framework is used for its plugins. Eclipse has many standard plugins that can be used as an eclipse-like application development platform - this set of plugins is called <a href="/questions/tagged/eclipse-rcp" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'eclipse-rcp\'" rel="tag">eclipse-rcp</a>.</p>\n\n<p>For <a href="/questions/tagged/c" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c\'" rel="tag">c</a>/<a href="/questions/tagged/c%2b%2b" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c++\'" rel="tag">c++</a> development, the <a href="https://www.eclipse.org/cdt/" rel="nofollow">Eclipse CDT Project</a> provides a plugin to create a <code>C/C++</code> development environment within Eclipse.</p>\n\n<p>For <a href="/questions/tagged/php" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'php\'" rel="tag">php</a> and web development, the <a href="https://www.eclipse.org/pdt/" rel="nofollow">Eclipse PDT Project</a> provides a plugin to create a <code>PHP</code> development environment within Eclipse. The popular commercial <a href="/questions/tagged/zend-studio" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'zend-studio\'" rel="tag">zend-studio</a> is also based on Eclipse.</p>\n\n<p>For <a href="/questions/tagged/python" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'python\'" rel="tag">python</a> development, the <a href="http://pydev.org/" rel="nofollow">PyDev project</a> provides a plugin to create a <a href="/questions/tagged/python" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'python\'" rel="tag">python</a> development environment within Eclipse.</p>\n\n<p>For <a href="/questions/tagged/perl" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'perl\'" rel="tag">perl</a> development, the <a href="http://www.epic-ide.org/" rel="nofollow">EPIC</a> project provides a plugin to create a <a href="/questions/tagged/perl" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'perl\'" rel="tag">perl</a> development environment within Eclipse.</p>\n\n<p>For <a href="/questions/tagged/android" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'android\'" rel="tag"><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/tKsDb.png" height="16" width="18" alt="" class="sponsor-tag-img">android</a> development, the <a href="https://developer.android.com/tools/sdk/eclipse-adt.html" rel="nofollow">Android Development Tools</a> provide a plugin to create an <a href="/questions/tagged/android" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'android\'" rel="tag"><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/tKsDb.png" height="16" width="18" alt="" class="sponsor-tag-img">android</a> development environment within Eclipse.</p>\n\n<p>When combined with <a href="/questions/tagged/cygwin" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cygwin\'" rel="tag">cygwin</a> (or <a href="/questions/tagged/mingw" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'mingw\'" rel="tag">mingw</a>), <a href="/questions/tagged/mono" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'mono\'" rel="tag">mono</a>, and its many plugins,  Eclipse provides a crucial part of viable <a href="/questions/tagged/open-source" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'open-source\'" rel="tag">open-source</a> alternatives to using Microsoft <a href="/questions/tagged/visual-studio" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'visual-studio\'" rel="tag">visual-studio</a> as a <a href="/questions/tagged/windows" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'windows\'" rel="tag">windows</a> software development platform in Windows, whilst 2015-01-03 09:42:29+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/css/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752935/width100-stretches-to-the-border-textarea)
2015-01-03 09:42:29+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/css/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a language used to control the visual presentation of HTML and XML documents including (but not limited to) colors, layout, and fonts.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascading_Style_Sheets" rel="nofollow"><strong>CSS</strong></a>, short for <strong>Cascading Style Sheets</strong>, is a language used to control the visual presentation of documents written in a markup language, including <a href="/questions/tagged/html" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'html\'" rel="tag">html</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/xml" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'xml\'" rel="tag">xml</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/xhtml" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'xhtml\'" rel="tag">xhtml</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/svg" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'svg\'" rel="tag">svg</a> and <a href="/questions/tagged/xul" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'xul\'" rel="tag">xul</a>. In early days, the visual presentation was defined by HTML attributes; then CSS was introduced to separate the control of the visual presentation from the content. </p>\n\n<p>A basic CSS document is made of rule sets. Each rule set starts with a <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-selectors/" rel="nofollow"><strong>selector</strong></a> (a pattern that matches elements in an <strong>HTML</strong> or <strong>XML</strong> document) and is followed by a block of one or more property declarations that define the presentation of the matching elements. For example:</p>\n\n<pre><code>/* This is a comment */ \n\na {                             /* Find all &lt;a&gt; elements(HTML links), */\n    color: orange;              /* change their text color to orange, */\n    background-color: pink;     /* their background color to pink, */\n    text-decoration: none;      /* and remove the underline. */\n}\n\na:hover {                       /* But when you hover over an &lt;a&gt; element */\n    color: red;                 /* change the color to red */\n    text-decoration: underline; /* and add an underline again */\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>The simple example above also illustrates why they are called <em>cascading</em> style sheets. When you hover over a link (i.e., an <code>&lt;a&gt;</code> element) in <a href="http://www.htmldog.com/guides/cssbeginner/applyingcss/" rel="nofollow">an HTML page with this style sheet applied to it</a>, <em>both</em> rules apply. So, the link will have a pink background. But, since the <code>a:hover</code> selector is more specific, its <code>color</code> and <strong><code>text-decoration</code></strong> properties override those from the <code>&lt;a&gt;</code> rule set.</p>\n\n<p>The <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/cascade.html#cascade" rel="nofollow">cascading order</a> defines how <a href="http://www.stuffandnonsense.co.uk/archives/css_specificity_wars.html" rel="nofollow">specificity</a> and other factors determine which property value is applied to an element.</p>\n\n<p>Some more CSS, continuing from the example above:</p>\n\n<pre><code>/* Selectors with greater Specificity override less specific ones */\n#article a.tag {\n    color: #F00;\n}\n\n/* Complex selectors can be created from joining multiple simple ones together */\n#sidebar &gt; h3 + p a:first-child {\n    border-bottom: 1px solid #333;\n    font-style: italic;\n}\n\n/* It is also possible to style elements depending on an attribute */\ndiv[id] a[target=_blank] {\n    color: white;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<h2>Selector precedence</h2>\n\n<p>Each component of a CSS selector can be based on one of three possible attributes of an HTML element:</p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>The element\'s ID (from the <code>id</code> attribute)</li>\n<li>The name of one of the element\'s classes (in the <code>class</code> attribute)</li>\n<li>The element\'s tag name</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>Selectors using an ID selector have higher priority than selectors using class names, and selectors using a class name have higher priority than selectors using tag names. This is called selector precedence. <code>!important</code> can be used to override the selector precedence. Whenever possible though, higher specificity should always be used instead of <code>!important</code>, in order to prevent overrides on any other styles that might need to be added.</p>\n\n<p>For example:</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-html prettyprint-override"><code>&lt;!-- Creates an anchor with a class of class1 and an ID of anchor1 --&gt;\n&lt;a class="class1" id="anchor1"&gt;Sample&lt;/a&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n\n\n<pre><code>a {                 /* anchor element */\n    color: orange;\n}\n\n.class1 {           /* any element with class name class1 */\n    color: red;\n}    \n\n#anchor1 {          /* the element with id anchor1 */\n    color: green;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>In the above example, the color of the string "Sample" will be green.</p>\n\n<p>Repeated occurrences of the same selector also increase specificity, as noted in the <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-selectors/#specificity" rel="nofollow">Selectors Level 3 W3C Recomendation</a>.</p>\n\n<pre><code>.class1.class1 {    /* repeated class selector */\n    font-weight: bold;\n}\n\n.class1 {\n    font-weight: normal;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Here the repeated selector has higher specificity than the singular selector and the <code>font-weight</code> of our sample string will be bold.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h3>References</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/" rel="nofollow">W3C CSS2.1 Specification</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-selectors/" rel="nofollow">W3C CSS3 Selectors Specification</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-mediaqueries/" rel="nofollow">W3C CSS3 Media Queries Specification</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3.org/Style/CSS/" rel="nofollow">W3C Cascading Style Sheets home page</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://way2tutorial.com/css/tutorial.php" rel="nofollow">Way2Tutorial CSS Tutorial</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://reference.sitepoint.com/css" rel="nofollow">SitePoint CSS Reference</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://htmldog.com/" rel="nofollow">HTML Dog: HTML and CSS Tutorials</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://dev.opera.com/articles/view/27-css-basics/" rel="nofollow">Cascading Style Sheets on the Web Standards Curriculum</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://net.tutsplus.com/tutorials/html-css-techniques/the-30-css-selectors-you-must-memorize/" rel="nofollow">The 30 CSS Selectors you Must Memorize</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20/" rel="nofollow">W3C Web Content Accessibility Guidelines</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://dochub.io/#css/" rel="nofollow">DocHub Instant Documentation Search</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://devdocs.io/css/" rel="nofollow">DevDocs - Documentation Searching Service</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>CSS Pseudo Selector</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://way2tutorial.com/css/css_pseudo_class_selector.php" rel="nofollow">CSS Pseudo Class Selector</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.w3schools.com/css/css_pseudo_elements.asp" rel="nofollow">Pseudo Element</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Validation</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://jigsaw.w3.org/css-validator/" rel="nofollow">W3C CSS Validation Service</a></li>\n<li><a 	              'body': u"<p>In C++ arrays are stored in contiguous memory.</p>\n\n<p>This means that if you have an element <code>x</code> and you know that it's inside an array and that it's not the first element of the array, then then previous one is</p>\n\n<pre><code>*(&amp;x - 1)\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>i.e. the element pointed by the address of <code>x</code> after we subtract 1 (note that this works because pointer arithmetic in C++ considers element size, so <code>&amp;x - 1</code> is not point to the byte before, but to the element before).</p>",

	              'vote': 2}],

It allows high efficiency in many text editing tasks but has a steep learning curve. To learn the basics, try ":help vimtutor".</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Vim is a free and open source text editor with a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_curve#In_Culture" rel="nofollow">steep learning curve</a> that leads to high efficiency in many tasks related to text editing. If you wish to start with Vim, try to run <code>:help vimtutor</code>, which will teach you basic commands.</p>\n\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vim_%28text_editor%29" rel="nofollow">Vim</a> is a highly configurable text editor built to enable efficient text editing. It is an improved version of the vi editor distributed with most UNIX systems and is available on a large number of other systems including Win32, MS-DOS, OS X, AMIGA, OS/2, Cygwin and <a href="http://www.vim.org/download.php#others" rel="nofollow">many more</a>. Vim is written by Bram Moolenaar. </p>\n\n<p>Vim is often called a "programmer\'s editor," and is so useful for programming that many consider it an entire IDE. It\'s not just for programmers, though. Vim is perfect for all kinds of text editing, from composing email to editing configuration files.</p>\n\n<h3>Before you ask:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Vim has an extensive help system that will often address your questions.
