2015-01-03 09:42:32+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/450027/uninstalling-an-msi-file-from-the-command-line-without-using-msiexec> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=1&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:42:32+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/3677897/rawan> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=1&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:42:32+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/450027/uninstalling-an-msi-file-from-the-command-line-without-using-msiexec>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>Short answer: you can\'t. Use MSIEXEC /x</p>\n\n<p>Long answer: When you run the MSI file directly at the command line, all that\'s happening is that it runs MSIEXEC for you. This association is stored in the registry. You can see a list of associations by (in Windows Explorer) going to Tools / Folder Options / File Types.</p>\n\n<p>For example, you can run a .DOC file from the command line, and WordPad or WinWord will open it for you.</p>\n\n<p>If you look in the registry under <code>HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\\.msi</code>, you\'ll see that .MSI files are associated with the ProgID "Msi.Package". If you look in <code>HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\\Msi.Package\\shell\\Open\\command</code>, you\'ll see the command line that Windows actually uses when you "run" a .MSI file.</p>',
	              'comments': [u"You actually could by replacing the command in the registry to also contain the option /x. But I'm sure no one wants to do that because if you do you can no longer install an msi by double-clicking on it.",
	                           u'Not sure I agree with ',
	                           u'\'s "you can\'t". On my WinXP install, ',
	                           u' contains ',
	                           u'. Seems if one is willing to have to specify ',
	                           u' to install in ',
	                           u', where they could have (by default) just specified the MSI filename; then they could change that registry value to ',
	                           u' to allow the specifying of the ',
	                           u' switch in ',
	                           u', and right click the MSI to access (at least) the install option in the GUI.',
	                           u'I bet you $1000 USD that I can programmatically uninstall an MSI without calling out to msiexec.exe.  You can use API calls instead.  However you can probably guess which EXE will then get called by those API calls. :)'],
	              'extid': 450043,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/450027/uninstalling-an-msi-file-from-the-command-line-without-using-msiexec/450043#450043',
	              'user_id': 8446,
	              'vote': 32},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>There are several ways to uninstall an MSI package. The following is intended as a sort of "reference" please <strong>edit</strong> with <strong>corrections</strong>, <strong>improvements</strong> and <strong>additions</strong>. <em>The Powershell section in particular, could benefit from an updated script</em>.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p>Some MSI files are installed as part of <strong>bundles</strong> via mechanism such as <strong><a href="http://wixtoolset.org/documentation/manual/v3/bundle/" rel="nofollow">Burn</a></strong> (Wix Toolkit) or <strong><a href="http://helpnet.installshield.com/installshield18helplib/SteCreatingSuites.htm" rel="nofollow">Installshield Suite</a></strong> projects. This can make uninstall slightly different from what is seen below. Here is <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/a/25374825/129130">an example for Installshield Suite projects</a>. </p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p><strong>If uninstall is failing entirely (not possible to run), see sections 12 &amp; 13 below</strong> for a potential way to "undo" the installation using <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_Restore" rel="nofollow">system restore</a> and / or cleanup tools.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p>If you got <strong>CCleaner</strong> or similar cleanup tools installed, perhaps jump to <strong>section 11</strong>.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>1. Using the <strong>original MSI</strong></h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>If you have access to the original MSI used for the installation, you can simply <strong>right click</strong> it in <strong>Windows Explorer</strong> and select <strong>Uninstall</strong>.</li>\n<li>As stated above you can do the same by command line: \n<strong><em>msiexec /x filename.msi /q</em></strong></li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>2. Using the <strong>ARP (Add/Remove Programs) Applet</strong></h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Just got to mention the normal approach though it is obvious </li>\n<li>Go <strong>start</strong> <kbd>\u2192</kbd> <strong>run</strong> <kbd>\u2192</kbd> <strong>appwiz.cpl</strong> <kbd>\u2192</kbd> <kbd>ENTER</kbd> in order to open the add/remove programs applet (or click add/ remove programs in the control panel)</li>\n<li>Click "<strong>Remove</strong>" for the product you want to uninstall.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>3. Using <strong>msiexec.exe command line</strong></h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>You can locate the required GUID to pass to <strong>msiexec.exe /x</strong> by opening regedit.exe at <strong>HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Uninstall\\</strong> and search for the application name (or just browse through each sub folder untill you find it).</li>\n<li>When you have found it you can pass it to msiexec as explained above: </li>\n</ul>\n\n<pre class="lang-sh prettyprint-override"><code>    msiexec.exe /x {0077A7C7-3333-2222-1111-111111111000}\n</code></pre>\n\n<ul>\n<li>The above command can be run directly from a command prompt (<strong>cmd.exe</strong>) or run from within a <strong>batch file</strong> or even from within an executable as a shell operation.</li>\n<li>More information on <a href="http://serverfault.com/a/274673/20599">this serverfault.com post</a> and <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/a/21502621/129130">this stackoverflow post</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>NB:</strong> These registry paths are not up to date for 64-bit windows. I will update as soon as I can verify, or someone else update it please.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>4. Using the <strong>cached MSI database</strong> in the super hidden cache folder</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>MSI strips out all cabs (older Windows versions) and caches each MSI installed in a super hidden system folder at <strong>%SystemRoot%\\Installer</strong> (you need to show hidden files to see it). </li>\n<li>All the MSI files here will have a random name assigned, but you can get information about each MSI by showing the Windows Explorer status bar (View -&gt; Status Bar) and then selecting an MSI. The summary stream from the MSI will be visible at the bottom of the Windows Explorer window. Or as Christopher Galpin points out, turn on the "Comments" column in Windows Explorer and select the MSI file  (<a href="http://csi-windows.com/blog/all/27-csi-news-general/334-identifying-cached-msi-packages-in-cwindowsinstaller-without-opening-them" rel="nofollow"><strong>see this article for how to do this</strong></a>).</li>\n<li>Once you find the right MSI, just right click it and go Uninstall.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>NB</strong>: This supper hidden folder is now being treated differently in Windows 7 onwards. <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/a/1189524/129130">MSI files are now cached full-size</a>. Read the linked thread for more details - recommended read for anyone who finds this answer and fiddles with dangerous Windows settings.</p>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>5. Using <strong><a href="http://thoughtsofmarcus.blogspot.no/2012/12/clever-uninstall-of-msi.html" rel="nofollow">PowerShell</a></strong></h2>\n\n<pre><code>    $app = Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_Product -Filter "Name = \'YOUR_APP\'"\n    $app.Uninstall()\n</code></pre>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Entry added by Even Mien</li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/113542/how-can-i-uninstall-an-application-using-powershell"><strong>More Powershell information here</strong></a></li>\n<li>I have not tested this myself, but it appears $app.Uninstall() may run the UninstallString registered in the ARP applet\'s registry settings. This means it may run modify instead of uninstall in some cases.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>6. Using the .NET <strong>DTF Class Library</strong> (part of <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6060281/windows-installer-and-the-creation-of-wix/12101548#12101548">the Wix toolkit</a>)</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><strong>DTF</strong> (Deployment Tools Foundation) is distributed as part of Wix as explained here: <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8637300/is-source-code-for-deployment-tools-foundation-available">Is source-code for Deployment Tools Foundation available?</a>. Wix, in turn, is a library for compiling MSI files from XML source files. <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1544292/what-installation-product-to-use-installshield-wix-wise-advanced-installer/1546941#1546941">Read more about Wix in this article on different MSI tools</a>.</li>\n<li>DTF is essentially a <strong>.NET wrapper for the Win32 Windows Installer API</strong>. It eliminates all need for COM Interop when working with Windows Installer via automation and is nothing short of a <strong>.NET jewel</strong> - <em>perhaps the easiest to use .NET library I have ever seen. Highly recommended - great even for training students in C#</em>.</li>\n<li>The following <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/a/17535555/129130">source</a> from MSI expert <a href="http://blog.deploymentengineering.com/" rel="nofollow"><strong>Christopher Painter</strong></a> using C# and DTF:</li>\n</ul>\n\n<pre class="lang-cs prettyprint-override"><code>    using Microsoft.Deployment.WindowsInstaller;\n\n    public static void Uninstall( string productCode)\n    {\n      Installer.ConfigureProduct(productCode, 0, InstallState.Absent, "REBOOT=\\"R\\" /l*v uninstall.log");\n    }\n</code></pre>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Anther alternative from Tom Blodget: <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17149811/checking-for-successful-uninstall/17175837#17175837">Checking for successful uninstall</a></li>\n<li>More information on <strong>msiexec.exe</strong> versus <strong>automation</strong> on: <a href="http://serverfault.com/questions/577969/is-it-possible-to-disable-msiexec-help-gui/596519#596519"><strong>serverfault.com</strong></a>.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>7. Using the <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa367810(v=vs.85).aspx" rel="nofollow"><strong>Windows Installer Automation API</strong></a></h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Here is a community discussion of this option: <a href="http://community.flexerasoftware.com/archive/index.php?t-153737.html" rel="nofollow">Windows Installer Automation api community sample</a></li>\n<li>The API can be accessed via <a href="http://serverfault.com/a/596519/20599"><strong>script automation and C++ API calls</strong></a> (my post on serverfault.com)</li>\n<li><p>The following source from MSI expert <a href="http://blog.deploymentengineering.com/" rel="nofollow"><strong>Christopher Painter</strong></a> using VBScript:</p>\n\n<pre><code>Const msiUILevelNone = 2\n\nSet objInstaller = CreateObject("WindowsInstaller.Installer")\nobjInstaller.UILevel = msiUILevelNone\nobjInstaller.InstallProduct( "product.msi", "REMOVE=ALL")\nSet objInstaller = Nothing\n</code></pre></li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>8. Using a <strong><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/a/23396011/129130">Windows Installer major upgrade</a></strong></h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>A Windows Installer major upgrade may happen as part of the installation of another MSI file.</li>\n<li>A major upgrade is authored by identifying related products in the MSI\'s "Upgrade table". These related setups are then handled as specified in the table. Generally that means they are uninstalled, but the main setup can also be aborted instead.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>9. Using <strong>an advanced deployment system / Remote Administration System</strong></h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_Center_Configuration_Manager" rel="nofollow">SCCM</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CA_Unicenter" rel="nofollow">CA Unicenter</a>, Altiris Client Management Suite, and several others</li>\n<li>These tools feature advanced client PC management, and this includes the install and uninstall of MSI files</li>\n<li>These tools seem to use a combination of msiexec.exe, automation, WMI, etc... and even their own way of invoking installs and uninstalls.</li>\n<li>In my experience these tools feature a lot of "personality" and you need to adapt to their different ways of doing things.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>10. Using <strong>WMI - Windows Management Instrumentation</strong></h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Adding just for completeness. It is <strong>not recommended</strong> to use this approach since it is very slow\n<ul>\n<li>A <strong>software consistency check</strong> is triggered every time <strong>Win32_Product</strong> is called of each installation</li>\n<li>The consistency check is <strong>incredibly slow</strong>, and it <strong>may also trigger a software repair</strong>. See this article: <strong><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17868285/powershell-uninstall-script-have-a-real-headache/17868466#17868466">Powershell Uninstall Script - Have a real headache</a></strong></li>\n</ul></li>\n<li>The <strong><a href="http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=8572" rel="nofollow">WMICodeCreator.exe</a></strong> code creation tool can be used to experiement\n<ul>\n<li>Install can be invoked via <code>Win32_Product.Install</code></li>\n<li>Uninstall can be invoked via <code>Win32_Product.Uninstall</code></li>\n</ul></li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>11. Using <strong>a third party tool such as <a href="https://www.piriform.com/CCLEANER" rel="nofollow">ccleaner</a> or similar</strong></h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Several Windows applications feature their own interface for uninstalling not just MSI packages but legacy installers too</li>\n<li>I don\'t want to make any specific tool recommendations here, but the well known <a href="https://www.piriform.com/CCLEANER" rel="nofollow">CCleaner</a> features such an uninstall interface</li>\n<li>Uninstalling like this should work OK, I think these tools mess with too many things when you try their "cleanup features" though. Use with caution. If you only use the uninstall feature, you should be ok.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>12. Using <strong>a cleanup tool such as <del>msizap</del> or similar</strong></h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>For completeness <del>msizap.exe</del> should be mentioned though it is <strong>deprecated</strong>, <strong>unsupported</strong> and <strong>outdated</strong>. It should not be used on any newer Windows versions</li>\n<li>This command line tool (<del>msizap.exe</del>) also had a GUI available (<del>MSICUU2.exe</del>), both tools are deprectated</li>\n<li>The intended use of these tools was to clean out failing uninstalls:\n<ul>\n<li>Generally for the rare case when the cached MSI with the random name is erroneously missing and uninstall fails for this reason whilst asking for the original MSI</li>\n<li>Also for other types of failing uninstalls</li>\n<li>It could also be used to zap any MSI installation, though that is obviously not advisable. </li>\n<li>More information: <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/208530/why-does-msi-require-the-original-msi-file-to-proceed-with-an-uninstall/1189524#1189524">Why does MSI require the original .msi file to proceed with an uninstall?</a></li>\n</ul></li>\n<li><a href="http://support2.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;290301" rel="nofollow">This newer support tool</a> can be tried on recent Windows versions if you have defunct MSI packages needing uninstall.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<hr>\n\n<h2>13. Using <strong><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_Restore" rel="nofollow">system restore</a></strong> ("installation undo" - last resort imho)</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>This is strictly speaking not a way to "<strong>uninstall</strong>" but to "<strong>undo</strong>" the last install, or several installs for that matter.</li>\n<li>Restoring via a restore point brings the system back to a <strong>previous installation state</strong> (you can find video demos of this on youtube or a similar site).</li>\n<li>Note that the feature can be disabled entirely or partly - it is possible to disable permanently for the whole machine, or adhoc per install.</li>\n<li><em>I have seen new, unsolvable installation problems resulting from a system restore, but normally it works OK</em>. Obviously don\'t use the feature for fun, it\'s a last resort and is best used for <strong>rollback of new drivers</strong> or setups that have just been installed and are found to cause immediate problems (bluescreen, reboots, instability, etc...).</li>\n<li>The longer you go back the more rework you will create for yourself, and the higher the risk will be. Most systems feature only a few restore points, and most of them stretch back just a month or two I believe.</li>\n<li>Be aware that system restore might affect <strong>Windows Updates</strong> that must then be re-applied - as well as many other system settings. Beyond pure annoyances, this can also cause security issues to resurface and you might want to run a specific security check on the target box(es) using <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Baseline_Security_Analyzer" rel="nofollow"><strong>Microsoft Baseline Security Analyzer</strong></a> or similar tools.</li>\n<li>Since I mentioned system restore I suppose I should mention <a href="http://support.microsoft.com/kb/307852" rel="nofollow"><strong>the Last Known Good Configuration feature</strong></a>. This feature has nothing to do with uninstall or system restore, but is the last boot configuration that worked or resulted in a running system. It can be used to get your system running again if it bluescreens or halts during booting. This often happens after driver installs.</li>\n</ul>',

2015-01-03 09:42:35+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/ckeditor/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>CKEditor is a JavaScript based WYSIWYG editor created for use within web pages. It is open source and plugin based making it both customizable and extensible. </p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://ckeditor.com/" rel="nofollow">CKEditor</a> is a JavaScript based <a href="/questions/tagged/wysiwyg" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'wysiwyg\'" rel="tag">wysiwyg</a> editor created for use within web pages. It is open source and plugin based making it both customizable and extensible. It has a rich JavaScript API, comes Ajax ready, and a jQuery adapter is available. </p>\n\n<p>Releases are available for integration with PHP, ASP.NET, and Java based installations. Drupal, Joomla, Liferay and WordPress all have packages available that allow for easy integration. An additional (paid) version is available for integration with SharePoint.</p>\n\n<p>The editor is compliant with worldwide accessibility standards like the W3C WCAG and the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_508_Amendment_to_the_Rehabilitation_Act_of_1973" rel="nofollow">US Section 508</a> (making websites accessible by those with a disability), and supports HTML5.</p>\n\n<p><a href="/questions/tagged/wysiwyg" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'wysiwyg\'" rel="tag">wysiwyg</a> = What You See Is What You Get</p>\n\n<h2>Asking questions</h2>\n\n<p>When posting a new question, please mention your specific version. Also be mindful of the fact that CKEditor is the successor to <a href="/questions/tagged/fckeditor" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'fckeditor\'" rel="tag">fckeditor</a> and configuration and settings have changed drastically between the releases.</p>\n\n<h3>Resources</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://ckeditor.com/download" rel="nofollow">CKEditor downloads</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://docs.ckeditor.com/" rel="nofollow">Official documentation</a>. </li>\n<li><a href="http://dev.ckeditor.com/" rel="nofollow">CKEditor Developers Community Site</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://docs.ckeditor.com/#!/api" rel="nofollow">JavaScript API Documentation</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor-dev" rel="nofollow">Github development repository of CKEditor</a></li>\n</ul>',
	 'name': 'ckeditor',
	 'qcount': 4123,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/ckeditor/info'}

If you have administrator rights on a Debian/Ubuntu server, and SSH is not already available (see your <a href="http://drupal.org/node/59680" rel="nofollow">phpinfo</a>) it can usually be installed by executing: <code>apt-get install libssh2-php</code>.</li>\n<li><a href="http://php.net/PDO" rel="nofollow">PHP Data Objects (PDO)</a> must be activated for Drupal 7 to install and run correctly. Look in your php.ini. Uncomment (remove the leading semicolon) at line <code>extension=php_pdo.dll</code>, <code>extension=php_pdo_mysql.dll</code>. In Linux, these would be <code>extension=pdo.so</code>, and <code>extension=pdo_mysql.so</code>. Some Linux distributions may have these extensions by default in files found in the conf.d folder. If these lines are not there, you will need to add them. The PECL version of PDO is not compatible with Drupal 7 and cannot be used. More information can be found on <a href="http://drupal.org/node/549702" rel="nofollow">What is PDO?</a>.</li>\n<li>Drupal 7 may require the time parameter to be at least 30 seconds.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>For more information, see <a href="/questions/tagged/drupal" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'drupal\'" rel="tag">drupal</a>.</p>\n\n<h3>Resources</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://drupal.org/list-changes/drupal?keywords_description=&amp;to_branch=7.x&amp;version=&amp;created_op=%3E=&amp;created%5Bvalue%5D=&amp;created%5Bmin%5D=&amp;created%5Bmax%5D=" rel="nofollow">Change records</a></li>\n</ul>',

I\'ve added a null check to protect against this possible scenario. </p>\n\n<p>To help debug your service I tend to use the technique <a href="http://einaregilsson.com/run-windows-service-as-a-console-program/" rel="nofollow">described here</a> to run the app as console application (for easy debugging) or windows service.</p>\n\n<pre><code>using System;\nusing System.Xml;\n\npublic class Program\n{\n\n    static string xmlFile = @"&lt;?xml version=""1.0"" encoding=""UTF-8""?&gt;\n        &lt;job&gt;\n        &lt;type&gt;freelance&lt;/type&gt;\n        &lt;text&gt;blah&lt;/text&gt;\n        &lt;/job&gt;";\n\n    public static void Main()\n    {\n        var doc = new XmlDocument();\n        doc.LoadXml(xmlFile);\n\n        XmlNode xmltype = doc.DocumentElement.SelectSingleNode("/job/type");\n        if(xmltype==null)\n        {\n           Console.WriteLine("/job/type not found");\n        } else {\n           Console.WriteLine(xmltype.InnerText);\n        }\n    }\n}\n</code></pre>',

	              'body': u'<p>I don\'t know if I\'ve understood you correctly. Do you wanna send the information once or do you want to refresh the information as the user set/unset the checkboxes?   </p>\n\n<p>If you need to POST data for your ajax request you can use the code below:</p>\n\n<pre><code> var oTable = $(\'#selector\').dataTable( {\n            "sAjaxSource": "your-url",\n            "fnServerData": function ( sSource, aoData, fnCallback ) {\n                    aoData.push( {"name": "param1", "value": 1} );\n                    aoData.push( {"name": "param2", "value": 2} );\n                    $.ajax( {\n                            "dataType": \'json\',\n                            "type": "POST",\n                            "url": sSource,\n                            "data": aoData,\n                            "success": function(result){\n                                if (result.iTotalRecords == 0) {\n                                        $("#datatable_unit_users").hide();\n                                } else {\n                                        $("#datatable_unit_users").show();\n                                        fnCallback(result)\n                                }\n                            }\n\n                    } );\n            },\n            ...\n    )};\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>If you need to refresh your information you might use the API function fnReloadAjax (<a href="http://datatables.net/plug-ins/api" rel="nofollow">http://datatables.net/plug-ins/api</a>).</p>\n\n<p>Hope it helps</p>',

Also called "inner class".</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>In <a href="/questions/tagged/object-oriented-design" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'object-oriented-design\'" rel="tag">object-oriented-design</a> there are times when a class <code>A</code> is used only as a component of another class <code>B</code> and should not be instanced outside <code>B</code>. In those cases proper encapsulation suggest defining that class as a <em>nested</em> or <em>inner class</em>.</p>\n\n<p>Several languages support this feature (C++, Java, .Net languages, D, python, for example) although with minor differences in where nested classes can be defined, how can they be used; and some languages support more than one variety of nested class.</p>',

2015-01-03 09:42:39+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/command-line/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/450027/uninstalling-an-msi-file-from-the-command-line-without-using-msiexec)
2015-01-03 09:42:39+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/command-line/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>A command line is a string given to a command interpreter that tells it actions to take, such as running programs or copying files. The interpreter processes command lines with escapes and substitutions.  </p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>A command-line interface (<a href="/questions/tagged/cli" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'cli\'" rel="tag">cli</a>) is a mechanism for interacting with a computer operating system or software by typing commands to perform specific tasks. This text-only interface contrasts with the use of a mouse pointer with a graphical user interface (GUI) to click on options, or menus on a text user interface (TUI) to select options.</p>\n\n<p>This method of instructing a computer to perform a given task is referred to as <em>entering</em> a command. The system waits for the user to conclude the submitting of the text command by pressing the Enter key (a descendant of the carriage return key of a typewriter keyboard). A command-line interpreter then receives, parses, and executes the requested user command. The command-line interpreter may be run in a text terminal or in a terminal emulator window as a remote shell client such as <a href="/questions/tagged/putty" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'putty\'" rel="tag">putty</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Upon completion, the command usually returns output to the user in the form of text lines on the CLI. </p>',
	 'name': 'command-line',
	 'qcount': 11078,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/command-line/info'}

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Directory-level configuration file used by Apache web servers. </p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>The <code>.htaccess</code> file is a configuration file for the Apache web server, allowing configuration settings to be made at a directory-specific level, overriding the server-wide or site-level settings in the main Apache server-level configuration. It must be enabled in the server-level configuration to work.</p>\n\n<p>Most directory-specific (though not all) Apache settings can be configured in <code>.htaccess</code>. One of the most common usages for it is URL redirection using mod_rewrite, which is used by many sites for SEO purposes and to provide easier-to-read URLs. The Apache documentation also has <a href="http://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/mod/mod_rewrite.html" rel="nofollow">further information about mod_rewrite</a> as well as <a href="http://wiki.apache.org/httpd/WhenNotToUseRewrite" rel="nofollow">simpler solutions for many common use cases</a>. It is also commonly used to define error pages.</p>\n\n<p><code>.htaccess</code> files can also be used for specifying custom error pages (e.g. for 404 errors); directory-specific security and user authentication; configuring the PHP installation; file handlers and MIME types; output compression, and more.</p>\n\n<p>For more information on <code>.htaccess</code> files and how to use them, see the <a href="http://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/howto/htaccess.html" rel="nofollow">Apache documentation</a>.</p>\n\n<h3>More information</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.htaccess" rel="nofollow">.htaccess Wikipedia Article</a></li>\n</ul>',
	 'name': '.htaccess',
	 'qcount': 36869,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/.htaccess/info'}

It is a highly flexible tool, based upon the foundations of progressive enhancement, which will add advanced interaction controls to any HTML table</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://datatables.net/" rel="nofollow">Data-tables</a> is a <a href="/questions/tagged/plug-in" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'plug-in\'" rel="tag">plug-in</a> for the <a href="/questions/tagged/jquery" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jquery\'" rel="tag">jquery</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/javascript" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'javascript\'" rel="tag">javascript</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/library" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'library\'" rel="tag">library</a>. It is a <em>highly flexible tool</em>, based upon the foundations of progressive enhancement, which will add advanced interaction <a href="/questions/tagged/controls" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'controls\'" rel="tag">controls</a> to any <a href="/questions/tagged/html-table" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'html-table\'" rel="tag">html-table</a>.</p>\n\n<h2>Key features :</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Variable length pagination</li>\n<li>On-the-fly filtering</li>\n<li>Multi-column sorting with data type detection</li>\n<li>Smart handling of column widths</li>\n<li>Display data from almost any data source</li>\n<li>DOM, JavaScript array, Ajax file and server-side processing (PHP, C#, Perl, Ruby, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adobe_Integrated_Runtime" rel="nofollow">AIR</a>, Gears, Python, etc.)</li>\n<li>Scrolling options for table viewport</li>\n<li>Fully internationalisable</li>\n<li>jQuery UI ThemeRoller support</li>\n<li>Rock solid - backed by a suite of 2600+ unit tests</li>\n<li>Wide variety of plug-ins inc. examples</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Coding :</h2>\n\n<h3>Default HTML table :</h3>\n\n<p>The table (and also each row of it) should have and <code>id</code> attribute, a header surrounded with<code>&lt;thead&gt;&lt;/thead&gt;</code> and also the body surrounded with <code>&lt;tbody&gt;&lt;/tbody&gt;</code>.</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-html prettyprint-override"><code>&lt;table id="example"&gt;\n   &lt;thead&gt;\n      &lt;tr&gt;\n         &lt;th&gt;Company name&lt;/th&gt;\n         &lt;th&gt;Address&lt;/th&gt;\n         &lt;th&gt;Town&lt;/th&gt;\n      &lt;/tr&gt;\n &lt;td&gt;Lothian&lt;/td&gt;\n       &lt;/tr&gt;\n       &lt;tr id="2"&gt;\n          &lt;td&gt;The Empire&lt;/td&gt;\n          &lt;td&gt;Milton Keynes Leisure Plaza&lt;/td&gt;\n          &lt;td&gt;Buckinghamshire&lt;/td&gt;\n       &lt;/tr&gt;\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\n&lt;/table&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<h3>Initializing the plugin</h3>\n\n<p>After the proper include of the required <code>JavaScript/JQuery libraries</code> the <a href="/questions/tagged/plug-in" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'plug-in\'" rel="tag">plug-in</a> can be initialized with a few line of code. The text following the <code>#</code> character and the <code>id</code> attribute of the table must be identical.</p>\n\n<pre class="lang-js prettyprint-override"><code>$(document).ready(function() {\n    $(\'#example\').dataTable();\n});\n</code></pre>',

2015-01-03 09:42:43+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/yacc/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>The computer program yacc is a parser generator developed by Stephen C. Johnson at AT&amp;T for the Unix operating system.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>The name is an acronym for "Yet Another Compiler Compiler." It generates a parser (the part of a compiler that tries to make syntactic sense of the source code) based on an analytic grammar written in a notation similar to BNF. Historically, Yacc has generated the code for the parser in the C programming language.</p>\n\n<p>Yacc used to be available as the default parser generator on most Unix systems. It has since been supplanted as the default by more recent, largely compatible, programs such as Berkeley Yacc, GNU bison, MKS yacc and Abraxas pcyacc. An updated version of the original AT&amp;T version is included as part of Sun\'s OpenSolaris project. Each offers slight improvements and additional features over the original yacc, but the concept has remained the same. Yacc has also been rewritten for other languages, including Ratfor, ML, Ada, Pascal, Java, Python and Common Lisp.</p>\n\n<p>The parser generated by yacc requires a lexical analyzer. Lexical analyzer generators, such as Lex or Flex are widely available. The IEEE POSIX P1003.2 standard defines the functionality and requirements for both Lex and Yacc.</p>\n\n<p>Some versions of AT&amp;T Yacc have become open source. For example, source code (for different implementations) is available with the standard distributions of Plan 9 and OpenSolaris.</p>\n\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yacc" rel="nofollow">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yacc</a></p>',
	 'name': 'yacc',
	 'qcount': 893,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/yacc/info'}
2015-01-03 09:42:44+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/parsing/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/tags/bisonc++/info)
2015-01-03 09:42:44+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/parsing/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Parsing refers to breaking an artifact into its constituent elements and capturing the relationship between those elements. This tag isn\'t for questions about the hosted service Parse.com (use [parse.com]) or PHP "parse errors" (use [php]).</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><strong><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsing" rel="nofollow">Parsing</a></strong> refers to the action by software of breaking an artifact into its constituent elements and capturing the relationship between those elements.</p>\n\n<p>When the artifact is a stream of arbitrary text, parsing is often used to mean breaking the stream into constituent atoms (called words, tokens or lexemes).</p>\n\n<p>When the artifact is a stream of natural language text, parsing is used to mean breaking the stream into natural language elements (words and punctuation) and discovering the structure of the text as phrases or sentences.</p>\n\n<p>When the artifact is a stream of text corresponding to a computer language (or other formal language), parsing consists of applying any of a variety of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category%3aParsing_algorithms" rel="nofollow">parsing algorithms</a> (ad hoc, recursive descent, LL, LR, Packrat, Earley or other) to the source text (often broken into lexemes by another lower level parser called a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexical_analysis" rel="nofollow">"lexer"</a>) to verify the validity of the source language, and often to construct a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parse_tree" rel="nofollow">parse tree</a> representing the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Production_%28computer_science%29" rel="nofollow">grammar productions</a> used to tile the text.</p>\n\n<p>The term can be applied more generally to analyzing any complex structure such as a binary data file or a graph.</p>',
	 'name': 'parsing',
	 'qcount': 27126,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/parsing/info'}

At its core is an interpreter for Emacs Lisp, a dialect of the Lisp programming language with extensions to support text editing.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/" rel="nofollow">GNU Emacs</a> is an extensible, customizable text editor.  Begun in the mid-1970s as a set of macros on top of TECO, it was re-written using C and <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/elisp/index.html" rel="nofollow">Emacs Lisp</a> to provide portability and an extendable interface.  It continues to be actively developed today.</p>\n\n<p>Emacs provides context-sensitive editing modes with syntax coloring, is self documenting, has full Unicode support and extensions to do almost anything.  Die-hard Emacs users do most everything from within Emacs: write, compile, run and debug code; read/compose email; browse the web; do project planning etc. Some other editors, like Visual Studio or Eclipse provide Emacs keybindings.</p>\n\n<h2>Useful Links</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li>A <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/emacs-paper.html" rel="nofollow">paper</a> by Richard Stallman describing the design of Emacs</li>\n<li>The <a href="http://www.emacswiki.org/" rel="nofollow">Emacs Wiki</a>, a collaborative wiki for extensions to Emacs</li>\n<li>Wikipedia\'s <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emacs" rel="nofollow">Emacs page</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.h-online.com/open/features/Emacs-the-birth-of-the-GPL-969471.html" rel="nofollow">History of Emacs and GPL</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/" rel="nofollow">GNU Emacs homepage</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h2>Wisdom from the stack</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/48006/is-it-worth-investing-time-in-learning-to-use-emacs">Is it worth investing time in learning to use emacs?</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/269812/how-to-quickly-get-started-at-using-and-learning-emacs">How to quickly get started at using and learning Emacs</a> </li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2582555/emacs-without-lisp">Emacs without lisp</a></li>\n<li>Stack Overflow <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/emacs-lisp/info">emacs-lisp</a> and <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/emacs/info">emacs</a> tags</li>\n</ul>',

2015-01-03 09:42:45+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/stack/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>A stack is a last in, first out (LIFO) abstract data type and data structure.  Perhaps the most common use of stacks is to store subroutine arguments and return addresses.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>A <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack_%28data_structure%29" rel="nofollow">stack</a> is a data structure, often used as an abstract data type (ADT) in many programming languages, to store data in a last in, first out (LIFO) manner. You could imagine it like a stack of cards. If you put a card onto the top of the stack, and then take the top card off the stack, you\'ll get the same card you put onto it.</p>\n\n<p>Putting data onto a stack is called pushing. Taking something from a stack is called popping. Checking what\'s on top of a stack without removing it is called peaking.</p>\n\n<p>Here is an example program:</p>\n\n<pre><code>a = new stack()\na.push(5)\nb = a.peak()\nprint(b)\na.push(6)\nb = a.pop()\nprint(b)\nb = a.pop()\nprint(b)\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>would give the output:</p>\n\n<pre><code>5\n6\n5\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>One of the cases where a stack is used is on the execution of code, see <a href="/questions/tagged/callstack" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'callstack\'" rel="tag">callstack</a>.\nWhen the program starts running, the stack is empty. When a function is called, that function is pushed onto the stack, and the execution environment keeps track of the position inside the code where it was. If it reaches another function inside that function, the new function is again pushed onto the stack. When execution reaches the end of a function, that function is popped off the stack, and control is returned to the function on the top of the stack.</p>',
	 'name': 'stack',
	 'qcount': 4618,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/stack/info'}

Debugging tends to be harder when various subsystems are tightly coupled, as changes in one may cause bugs to emerge in another. Many books have been written about debugging, as it involves numerous aspects, including interactive debugging, control flow, integration testing, log files, monitoring (application, system), memory dumps, profiling, Statistical Process Control, and special design tactics to improve detection while simplifying changes.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Applications for Debugging:</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windbg" rel="nofollow">WinDbg</a> - A debugger for low-level debugging, mostly used for <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ee817659.aspx" rel="nofollow">production debugging</a> and difficult error solving.\n<ul>\n<li>WinDbg also contains extensions for .Net debugging like ".Sos", ".SosEx" and more...</li>\n</ul></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ollydbg" rel="nofollow">OllyDbg</a> - An assembly debugger mostly used for reverse engineering and cracking.\n<ul>\n<li>Note that as for February 2014 <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ollydbg" rel="nofollow">OllyDbg</a> only support 32 Bit application debugging.</li>\n</ul></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>Learning Sources:</strong></p>\n\n<p><em>Books:</em></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0321374460" rel="nofollow">Advanced Windows Debugging</a></p></li>\n<li><p><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0814474578" rel="nofollow">Debugging: The 9 Indispensable Rules for Finding Even the Most Elusive Software and Hardware Problems</a></p></li>\n</ul>',

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>jGRASP is a lightweight development environment, created specifically to provide automatic generation of software visualizations to improve the comprehensibility of software.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://www.jgrasp.org/" rel="nofollow">jGRASP</a> is a lightweight development environment, created specifically to provide automatic generation of software visualizations to improve the comprehensibility of software.</p>\n\n<p>jGRASP is implemented in Java, and runs on all platforms with a Java Virtual Machine (Java version 1.5 or higher). jGRASP produces Control Structure Diagrams (CSDs) for Java, C, C++, Objective-C, Ada, and VHDL; Complexity Profile Graphs (CPGs) for Java and Ada; UML class diagrams for Java; and has dynamic object viewers that work in conjunction with an integrated debugger and workbench for Java. The viewers include a data structure identifier mechanism which recognizes objects that represent traditional data structures such as stacks, queues, linked lists, binary trees, and hash tables, and then displays them in an intuitive textbook-like presentation view.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Related Tags</strong></p>\n\n<p><a href="/questions/tagged/java" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'java\'" rel="tag">java</a><a href="/questions/tagged/uml" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'uml\'" rel="tag">uml</a><a href="/questions/tagged/ada" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ada\'" rel="tag">ada</a><a href="/questions/tagged/c" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c\'" rel="tag">c</a><a href="/questions/tagged/c%2b%2b" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'c++\'" rel="tag">c++</a><a href="/questions/tagged/objective-c" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'objective-c\'" rel="tag">objective-c</a></p>',

2015-01-03 09:42:46+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/compiler-construction/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>The tag [compiler-construction] should be applied to questions concerning the programming of compilers or for questions about the detailed inner workings of compilers.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>A compiler is a program which translates one language into another. Compiler construction is the process of creating a compiler.</p>\n\n<p>The tag <a href="/questions/tagged/compiler-construction" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'compiler-construction\'" rel="tag">compiler-construction</a> should be applied to questions concerning the programming of compilers or for questions about the detailed inner workings of compilers.</p>\n\n<h2>One language to another? I thought they made executables!</h2>\n\n<p>The notional, garden variety compiler does exactly that: it translates a human readable computer programming language (like fortran or c++ or java) into a machine executable format. Or not.</p>\n\n<p>In fact many real world compilers translate a high level language into assembly code which is subsequently assembled by a separate program. The standard java compiler translate java code into JVM bytecode, which must be run by a dedicated program (the Java execution environment) which may include a Just In Time (JIT) compiler that translates the bytecode into chip native machine instructions on the fly. The earliest versions of the language that became c++ were called cfront and were compiled to c. And so on.</p>\n\n<h2>Big List of Resources:</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.cs.indiana.edu/~dyb/pubs/nano-jfp.pdf" rel="nofollow">A Nanopass Framework for Compiler Education</a> <sup><sup>PDF</sup></sup></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/1558603204" rel="nofollow">Advanced Compiler Design and Implementation</a> <sup><sup>Book</sup></sup></li>\n<li><a href="http://scheme2006.cs.uchicago.edu/11-ghuloum.pdf" rel="nofollow">An Incremental Approach to Compiler Construction</a> <sup><sup>PDF</sup></sup></li>\n<li><a href="http://javadude.com/articles/antlr3xtut" rel="nofollow">ANTLR 3.x Video Tutorial</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/onlamp/2004/04/15/parrot_compiler_construction.html" rel="nofollow">Building a Parrot Compiler</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.cs.man.ac.uk/~pjj/farrell/compmain.html" rel="nofollow">Compiler Basics</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0201403536" rel="nofollow">Compiler Construction</a> <sup><sup>Book</sup></sup></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0442275366" rel="nofollow">Compiler Design and Construction</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.cs.princeton.edu/~appel/modern/ml/" rel="nofollow">Modern Compiler Consturction</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0805321667" rel="nofollow">Crafting a Compiler with C</a> <sup><sup>Book</sup></sup></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compilers:_Principles%2C_Techniques%2C_and_Tools" rel="nofollow">Dragon Book</a> <sup><sup>Book</sup></sup> - Widely considered "the book" for compiler writing.</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.cs.indiana.edu/eopl/" rel="nofollow">Essentials of Programming Languages</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://flipcode.com/archives/articles.shtml" rel="nofollow">Flipcode Article Archive</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/1931841578" rel="nofollow">Game Scripting Mastery</a> <sup><sup>Book</sup></sup></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.icemanind.com/VMCS.pdf" rel="nofollow">How to build a virtual machine from scratch in C#</a> <sup><sup>PDF</sup></sup></li>\n<li><a href="http://research.microsoft.com/~simonpj/papers/pj-lester-book/" rel="nofollow">Implementing Functional Languages</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.codeproject.com/KB/recipes/programminglanguagetoools.aspx" rel="nofollow">Implementing Programming Languages using C# 4.0</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interpreter_pattern" rel="nofollow">Interpreter pattern</a> - specifies a way to evaluate sentences in a language\n<ul>\n<li>Described in <a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0201633612" rel="nofollow">Design Patterns</a> <sup><sup>Book</sup></sup></li>\n</ul></li>\n<li><a href="http://pragprog.com/titles/tpdsl/language-implementation-patterns" rel="nofollow">Language Implementation Patterns: Create Your Own Domain-Specific and General Programming Languages</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://compilers.iecc.com/crenshaw/" rel="nofollow">Lets Build a Compiler</a> \n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.stack.nl/~marcov/compiler.pdf" rel="nofollow">The PDF version</a> <sup><sup>PDF</sup></sup> </li>\n</ul></li>\n<li><a href="http://tinyurl.com/5txtuk" rel="nofollow">Linkers and Loaders</a> <sup><sup>Google Books</sup></sup></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0521562473" rel="nofollow">Lisp in Small Pieces (LiSP)</a> <sup><sup>Book</sup></sup></li>\n<li><a href="http://llvm.org/docs/tutorial/" rel="nofollow">LLVM Tutorial</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0521607647" rel="nofollow">Modern Compiler Implementation in ML</a> <sup><sup>Book</sup></sup> - It is frequently used with the free Bison parser generator. Unlike Bison, flex is <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/flex/" rel="nofollow">not part of the GNU Project</a>.</p>\n\n<p>See also: <a href="/questions/tagged/bison" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'bison\'" rel="tag">bison</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/lex" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'lex\'" rel="tag">lex</a> <a href="/questions/tagged/yacc" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'yacc\'" rel="tag">yacc</a></p>',

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Bison is the GNU parser generator. It generates LALR parsers, but can also generate GLR parsers for grammars that are not LALR. It has a mode of compatibility with its old predecessor Yacc (yet another compiler compiler).</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Bison is the GNU parser generator. It generates LALR parsers, but can also generate GLR parsers for grammars that are not LALR. In POSIX mode, Bison is compatible with Yacc (yet another compiler compiler). flex, an automatic lexical analyser, is often used with Bison, to tokenise input data and provide Bison with tokens.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Websites:</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/bison/manual/" rel="nofollow">GNU bison manual</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>See also:</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/antlr" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'antlr\'" rel="tag">antlr</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/flex-lexer" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'flex-lexer\'" rel="tag">flex-lexer</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/lex" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'lex\'" rel="tag">lex</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/yacc" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'yacc\'" rel="tag">yacc</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/jison" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'jison\'" rel="tag">jison</a></li>\n</ul>',

It is known for its large collection of simple command-line utilities which allow powerful file handling and text processing capabilities to be implemented via shell scripts.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><strong>Wiki:</strong></p>\n\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix" rel="nofollow">Unix</a> was developed as an in-house operating system for <strong>AT&amp;T</strong>, but in the 1980s became both a prime academic operating system (with U.C. Berkeley\'s version, called <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/bsd/info">BSD</a>, being the reference platform for development of what would become the Internet) and a commercial success in the form of AT&amp;T\'s System V, Microsoft/SCO\'s XENIX (PCs) and various workstation versions from Sun, Silicon Graphics, and others.</p>\n\n<p>In the 1990s, Sun\'s Solaris and the free Unix clone <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/linux/info">Linux</a> would rise in popularity. Linux is largely Unix-compatible but lacks the trademark. Currently, Unix is commonly found on server platforms; the primary desktop variant is <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/osx/info">Mac OS X</a>, based on BSD.</p>\n\n<p>Apart from its command-line interface, most "Unices" support the standardized <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/xwindow/info">X Window System</a> for GUIs. (So does Mac OS X, but its primary GUI is Apple\'s proprietary Quartz.)</p>\n\n<p>The various Unix implementation (and to a lesser extent, clones such as Linux) are unified in a standard called <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/posix/info">POSIX</a>. <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/c/info">C</a> has been its primary programming language since the 1970s, but many other languages are available.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Tag usage:</strong></p>\n\n<p>The tag <a href="/questions/tagged/unix" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'unix\'" rel="tag">unix</a> can be used for Unix system programming related problems. The tag can also contain programming question using Unix platform. For non-programming Unix usage questions, visit the <a href="http://unix.stackexchange.com/">Unix &amp; Linux</a> Stack Exchange site.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Read more:</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix" rel="nofollow">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix</a> </li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/A_Quick_Introduction_to_Unix" rel="nofollow">http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/A_Quick_Introduction_to_Unix</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.ee.surrey.ac.uk/Teaching/Unix/" rel="nofollow">http://www.ee.surrey.ac.uk/Teaching/Unix/</a></li>\n</ul>',

2015-01-03 09:42:51+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732658/obj-c-and-spritekit-changing-a-sprite-value-that-is-created-randomly> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=1&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:42:51+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/1420407/rahul> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=1&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:42:51+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732658/obj-c-and-spritekit-changing-a-sprite-value-that-is-created-randomly>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>You can simply associate a property with the ANBDropsNode class which can be set when the drop is instantiated.</p>\n\n<p>In the ANBDropsNode.h file,</p>\n\n<pre><code>@interface ANBDropsNode\n\n@property (strong, nonatomic) NSString *dropColor; //This property will hold the value associated with the color.\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Then in the dropOfType class method:</p>\n\n<pre><code>+(instancetype)dropOfType:(ANBDropType)type {\n\n    NSString *strDropColor;\n\n    if (type == ANBDropTypeBlue) {\n        strDropColor = @"bluedrop";\n    } else if (type == ANBDropTypeGreen) {\n        strDropColor = @"greendrop";\n    } else if (type == ANBDropTypeOrange) {\n        strDropColor = @"orangedrop";\n    } else if (type == ANBDropTypeRed){\n        strDropColor = @"reddrop";\n    }\n\n    ANBDropsNode *drop = [self spriteNodeWithImageNamed:strDropColor];\n    drop.dropColor = strDropColor;\n\n    [drop setupPhysicsBody];\n    return drop;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Now, in your collision detection delegate method, you can find out the color of the node by simply referring the <code>dropColor</code> property.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753436,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732658/obj-c-and-spritekit-changing-a-sprite-value-that-is-created-randomly/27753436#27753436',
	              'user_id': 2043580,
	              'vote': 0},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Sorry in advance for any english mistakes, as I\'m not an native english speaker.  </p>\n\n<p>From your question I understand that the reason you are keeping a reference to the drop (<code>self.drop</code>) is to check what is its colour when it hits the ground.<br>\nSo you could just delete that, and create a new <code>SKSpriteNode</code> object each time, instead of just changing the reference of the current property.<br>\nIf you have any other reason for keeping a reference to that drop, just still keep a reference.<br>\nNote that doing any of the above, will not affect the code below.  </p>\n\n<p>I think that you were in the right direction (when asking about <code>didBeginContact</code>) but took the wrong approach/mindset, since there is no need to keep a reference when using <code>didBeginContact</code>, because you can get the nodes in contact from this method.  </p>\n\n<p>Anyway, here is the code + explanations  </p>\n\n<pre><code>// MyScene.m  \n\n// First, conform to SKPhysicsContactDelegate, so you can get didBeginContact \'calls\'\n@interface MyScene () &lt;SKPhysicsContactDelegate&gt;  \n@end  \n\n@implementation MyScene  \n\n// Now add the following constant, that you\'ll use as the physics body category bit masks  \nstatic const uint32_t groundCategory = 0x01 &lt;&lt; 0;  \nstatic const uint32_t dropsCategory  = 0x01 &lt;&lt; 1;  \n\n// Somewhere in your initialisation, set yourself to be the physicsWorld  \n// contact delegate, so you\'ll receive the didBeginContact \'calls\',  \n// And also call setupGround method, that we will create in here as well\n-(id)initSceneWithSize:(CGSize)size {  \n    ...\n    ...\n    self.physicsWorld.contactDelegate = self;  \n    [self setupGround];  \n    ...  \n}  \n\n// Here we will create the ground node, so we can detect when a drop  \n// Hits the ground.  \n// The reason that, in the below code, I am setting just the ground,  \n// and not the whole borders of the screen, is because the drops  \n// are added above the screen \'borders\', and if we would make  \n// a \'frame\' node, and not a \'ground\' node, we will also receive  \n// contact delegate calls, when the nodes first enter the scene  \n// and hits the top \'border\' of the frame\n-(void)setupGround {  \n    SKNode *groundNode     = [SKNode node];  \n    groundNode.strokeColor = [SKColor clearColor];  \n    groundNode.fillColor   = [SKColor clearColor];  \n    // Not sure if the above two are mandatory, but better be safe than sorry...  \n\n    // Here we set the physics body to start at the bottom left edge of the screen  \n    // and be the width of the screen, and the size of 1 points  \n    // Then, we also set its category bit mask\n    CGRect groundRect = CGRectMake(0, 0, self.size.width, 1);\n    groundNode.physicsBody = [SKPhysicsBody bodyWithEdgeLoopFromRect:groundRect];  \n    groundNode.physicsBody.categoryBitMask = groundCategory;  \n\n    [self addChild:groundNode];  \n}  \n\n// Next we will modify your current method of creating drops, to also have  \n// their name property to holds the corresponding colour name  \n+(instancetype)dropOfType:(ANBDropType)type {\n\n    ANBDropsNode *drop;\n\n    if (type == ANBDropTypeBlue) {\n        drop = [self spriteNodeWithImageNamed:@"bluedrop"];\n        drop.name = @"Blue";\n    } else if (type == ANBDropTypeGreen) {\n        drop = [self spriteNodeWithImageNamed:@"greendrop"];\n        drop.name = @"Green";\n    } else if (type == ANBDropTypeOrange) {\n        drop = [self spriteNodeWithImageNamed:@"orangedrop"];\n        drop.name = @"Orange";\n    } else if (type == ANBDropTypeRed){\n        drop = [self spriteNodeWithImageNamed:@"reddrop"];\n        drop.name = @"Red";\n    }\n\n    [drop setupPhysicsBody];\n    return drop;\n}  \n\n// In your setupPhysicsBody method of the drop, add the following to define  \n// the drop\'s bit mask, contact test, and collision.  \n// Make sure you are adding them AFTER setting the physics body, and not before.  \n// Since you revealed no code regarding this method, I will assume \'self\' is  \n// referring to the drop, since you call this method on the drop.\n-(void) setupPhysicsBody {  \n    ...  \n    ...  \n    ...  \n    self.physicsBody.categoryBitMask    = dropsCategory;  \n    self.physicsBody.contactTestBitMask = groundCategory;  \n    self.physicsBody.collisionBitMask   = 0;  \n    // The above code sets the drop category bit mask, sets its contactTestBitMask  \n    // to be of the groundCategory, so whenever an object with drop category, will  \n    // \'touch\' and object with groundCategory, our didBeginContact delegate will  \n    // get called.  \n    // Also, we\'ve set the collision bit mask to be 0, since we only want to  \n    // be notified when a contact begins, but we don\'t actually want them both to  \n    // \'collide\', and therefore, have the drops \'lying\' on the ground.  \n    ...  \n    ...  \n    ...  \n}  \n\n// Now we can set the didBeginContact: delegate method.  \n// Note that, as the name of the method suggests, this method gets called when a  \n// Contact is began, meaning, the drop is still visible on screen.  \n// If you would like to do whatever you want to do, when the drop leaves the screen,  \n// just call the didEndContact: delegate method  \n-(void)didBeginContact:(SKPhysicsContact *)contact {  \n    // SKPhysicsContact have two properties, bodyA and bodyB, which represents  \n    // the two nodes that contacted each other.  \n    // Since there is no certain way to know which body will always be our drop,  \n    // We will check the bodies category bit masks, to determine which is which  \n    ANBDropsNode *drop = (contact.bodyA.categoryBitMask &lt; contact.bodyB.categoryBitMask) ? (ANBDropsNode *)contact.bodyB.node : (ANBDropsNode *)contact.bodyA.node;  \n    // In the above we are checking the category bit masks,  \n    // Note that we set groundCategory to be 1, and dropsCategory to be 2,  \n    // So we are checking which is higher.  \n    // If bodyA bit mask is lower than bodyB bit mask, that means the bodyA is  \n    // the ground, and bodyB is the drop, so we set the drop to be bodyB\'s node  \n    // Else, we set it to be bodyA\'s node.  \n\n    // Now you can easily get the drop colour from the name property we\'ve set in  \n    // the beginning. you can do some sort of if-else statement, that check  \n    // \'if isEqualToString\'. Here I just NSLog the colour  \n    NSLog(@"%@", drop.name);\n\n}  \n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Good luck mate.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753473,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732658/obj-c-and-spritekit-changing-a-sprite-value-that-is-created-randomly/27753473#27753473',
	              'user_id': 3999715,
	              'vote': 0}],
	 'body': u'<p>I\'m making a game using SpriteKit and Objective-C.</p>\n\n<p>I have four different texture drops (Blue, Green, Orange and Red) that falls down on screen randomly.</p>\n\n<p>In my ANBDropNode class I have this method:</p>\n\n<pre><code>+(instancetype)dropOfType:(ANBDropType)type {\n\n    ANBDropsNode *drop;\n\n    if (type == ANBDropTypeBlue) {\n        drop = [self spriteNodeWithImageNamed:@"bluedrop"];\n    } else if (type == ANBDropTypeGreen) {\n        drop = [self spriteNodeWithImageNamed:@"greendrop"];\n    } else if (type == ANBDropTypeOrange) {\n        drop = [self spriteNodeWithImageNamed:@"orangedrop"];\n    } else if (type == ANBDropTypeRed){\n        drop = [self spriteNodeWithImageNamed:@"reddrop"];\n    }\n\n    [drop setupPhysicsBody];\n    return drop;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>And in my GamePlayScene these two:</p>\n\n<pre><code>    -(void)addDrops {\n\n        NSUInteger randomDrop = [ANBUtil randomWithMin:0 max:4];\n\n        self.drop = [ANBDropsNode dropOfType:randomDrop];\n\n        float y = self.frame.size.height + self.drop.size.height;\n        float x = [ANBUtil randomWithMin:10 + self.drop.size.width\n                                     max:self.frame.size.width - self.drop.size.width - 10];\n        self.drop.position = CGPointMake(x, y);\n\n        [self addChild:self.drop];\n    }\n\n    -(void)update:(NSTimeInterval)currentTime {\n\n        if (self.lastUpdateTimeInterval) {\n            self.timeSinceDropAdded += currentTime - self.lastUpdateTimeInterval;\n        }\n\n        if (self.timeSinceDropAdded &gt; 1) {\n            [self addDrops];\n            self.timeSinceDropAdded = 0;\n        }\n\n        self.lastUpdateTimeInterval = currentTime;\n\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>The question is (and it may sound a little dumber, I know): before the drop hits the ground it has already changed it value. 	 'body': u'<p>I am trying to follow along the tutorial on cloud haskell <a href="http://haskell-distributed.github.io/tutorials/1ch.html#sending-messages" rel="nofollow">here</a>. For my purpose, I wanted to evaluate quickcheck properties in different slaves. So I added a Hint evaluator that takes a module name to load, and an expression to evaluate within the context of that module. </p>\n\n<p>Now, my problem is that when I try to run it after compiling it, I get all the messages just before evaluation, and the process seems to exit.</p>\n\n<pre><code>./dist/build/d-mucheck/d-mucheck\nSat Jan  3 09:16:34 UTC 2015 pid://127.0.0.1:10501:0:10: send mymodule\nSat Jan  3 09:16:34 UTC 2015 pid://127.0.0.1:10501:0:11: Got mymodule and test:quickCheckResult revProp\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>However, if I run <code>main</code> from <code>cabal repl</code> I get the expected output. So my question is, am I doing any thing wrong? How do I get it to produce the expected output in the command line?</p>\n\n<p>My code</p>\n\n<pre><code>{-# LANGUAGE StandaloneDeriving, DeriveDataTypeable, TypeSynonymInstances #-}\n\nmodule Main where\nimport Control.Concurrent (threadDelay)\nimport Control.Monad (forever)\nimport Control.Distributed.Process\nimport Control.Distributed.Process.Node (forkProcess, newLocalNode, initRemoteTable)\nimport Network.Transport.TCP (createTransport, defaultTCPParameters)\nimport qualified Language.Haskell.Interpreter as I\nimport qualified Test.QuickCheck.Test as Qc\n\nimport Data.Typeable\nderiving instance Typeable Qc.Result\n\ntype InterpreterOutput = Either I.InterpreterError Qc.Result\n\nlocalHost, localPort :: String\nlocalHost = "127.0.0.1"\nlocalPort = "10501"\n\nevaluator :: String -&gt; String -&gt; IO InterpreterOutput\nevaluator mymodule myexpr = I.runInterpreter evM\n  where evM = do I.loadModules [mymodule]\n                 ms &lt;- I.getLoadedModules\n                 I.setTopLevelModules ms\n                 result &lt;- I.interpret myexpr (I.as :: (Typeable a =&gt; IO a)) &gt;&gt;= liftIO\n                 return result\n\nmuServer :: (ProcessId, String, String) -&gt; Process ()\nmuServer (sender, mymodule, myexpr) = do\n  say $ "Got mymodule and test:" ++ myexpr\n  iResult &lt;- liftIO (evaluator mymodule myexpr)\n  val &lt;- case iResult of\n        Left err -&gt; do say $ "error " ++ (show err)\n                       return (show err)\n        Right out -&gt; do say $ "success " ++ (show out)\n                        return (show out)\n  say $ "Got mymodule and test:" ++ myexpr\n  send sender (show val)\n\nmain :: IO ()\nmain = do\n  Right t &lt;- createTransport localHost localPort defaultTCPParameters\n  node &lt;- newLocalNode t initRemoteTable\n  _ &lt;- forkProcess node $ do\n    myPid &lt;- spawnLocal $ forever $ do\n      receiveWait [match muServer]\n\n    self &lt;- getSelfPid\n    say $ "send mymodule"\n    send myPid (self, "Examples/QuickCheckTest.hs", "quickCheckResult revProp")\n\n    m &lt;- expectTimeout 1000000\n    case m of\n      Nothing  -&gt; die "at worker: nothing came back!"\n      (Just s) -&gt; do say $ "at worker: got " ++ s ++ " back!"\n    return ()\n\n  liftIO $ threadDelay (1*1000000)\n  return ()\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>The sample module with quickcheck properties</p>\n\n<pre><code>module Examples.QuickCheckTest where\nimport Test.QuickCheck\nimport Data.List\n\nqsort :: [Int] -&gt; [Int]\nqsort [] = []\nqsort (x:xs) = qsort l ++ [x] ++ qsort r\n    where l = filter (&lt; x) xs\n          r = filter (&gt;= x) xs\n\nidEmpProp xs = qsort xs == qsort (qsort xs)\nrevProp xs = qsort xs == qsort (reverse xs)\nmodelProp xs = qsort xs == sort xs\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>If I use just a simple module,</p>\n\n<pre><code>module Test where\nmytest :: IO String\nmytest = return "Hello from module Test"\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>and then use <code>mytest</code> as the evaluation string (replacing Qc.Result with string), I get the expected output from the slave.</p>',

2015-01-03 09:42:52+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753394/validate-regex-in-javascript> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=1&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:42:52+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/1773155/shajeel-afzal> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=1&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:42:52+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753394/validate-regex-in-javascript>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Try this instead:</p>\n\n<pre><code>\\/ ?(\\w+ ?)+\\/Search\n</code></pre>\n\n<ul>\n<li><code>\\/</code> \u2013 no real need for a character class (i.e. opened by <code>[</code> and closed by <code>]</code>) to match a slash...when you can just match the slash</li>\n<li><code>?</code> \u2013 allowing for a single space or none following the opening slash, being that I am not sure how firmly you expect a space to follow</li>\n<li><code>(\\w+ ?)+</code> \u2013 one or more word characters followed optionally by a space, this subpattern itself occurring once or more</li>\n<li><code>\\/</code> \u2013 the closing slash</li>\n<li><code>Search</code> \u2013 the fixed word <code>Search</code> that you expect following the closing slash</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>You can try the updated pattern out with the textbox value you provided in a <a href="http://fiddle.re/6n0pd6" rel="nofollow">regex fiddle</a>.</p>',
	              'comments': [u'Thanks it worked'],
	              'extid': 27753435,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753394/validate-regex-in-javascript/27753435#27753435',
	              'user_id': 1810429,
	              'vote': 2},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>I think this is the expresion you are looking for: </p>\n\n<pre><code>\\\\[\\w]*\\\\Search\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [u'I want something like this /adminPanel/Search.',
	                           u"Where is '/'  . Your are taking \\"],
	              'extid': 27753433,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753394/validate-regex-in-javascript/27753433#27753433',
	              'user_id': 395890,
	              'vote': 0},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u"<p>Since everyone seems to ignore your actual question, what's wrong with your regex is this: </p>\n\n<ol>\n<li>character classes <code>[...]</code>. This makes <code>[\\Search]</code> match <em>a single character</em> out of <code>\\Search</code>, <em>not</em> the literal word <code>Search</code>.</li>\n<li>for some reason you wrote <code>/\\/</code> when you actually just want to match a single forward slash <code>/</code>.</li>\n<li>You want to match multiple characters, so you have to change <code>\\w</code> to <code>\\w+</code>.</li>\n</ol>\n\n<p>Result:</p>\n\n<pre><code>/\\w+/Search\n</code></pre>",
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753493,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753394/validate-regex-in-javascript/27753493#27753493',
	              'user_id': 1222951,
	              'vote': 0}],
	 'body': u'<p>I want to validate my textbox with regex expression . Texbox value should be like this \n " / any word /Search " . Forward slash then any word can occur than again forward slash then a fixed word "Search" . I tried this but its not working</p>\n\n<pre><code>[/\\/][\\w][/\\/][\\Search]\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>What is wrong in this?</p>',
	 'comments': [],

= SKSpriteNode(imageNamed: "bar6")\n\n    let bar6e = SKSpriteNode(imageNamed: "bar6")\n    let bar6f = SKSpriteNode(imageNamed: "bar6")\n\n    let bar6g = SKSpriteNode(imageNamed: "bar6")\n    let (){\n            bar6e.position = CGPointMake(600 ,CGRectGetMaxY(self.frame))\n            bar6f.position = CGPointMake(1400,CGRectGetMaxY(self.frame))\n            addChild(bar6e)\n            addChild(bar6f)\n\n\n        }\n        func spawn4 (){\n            bar6g.position = CGPointMake(700 ,CGRectGetMaxY(self.frame))\n            bar6h.position = CGPointMake(1500,CGRectGetMaxY(self.frame))\n            addChild(bar6g)\n            addChild(bar6h)\n\n\n        }\n\n        func spawn5 (){\n            bar6i.position = CGPointMake(700 SKAction.runBlock({ self.spawn1() })\n        var b = SKAction.runBlock(spawn2)\n        var c = SKAction.runBlock(spawn3)\n        var d = SKAction.runBlock(spawn4)\n        var e = SKAction.sequence([delayE,e,actionmove,delchild])\n\n        var repeat1 = SKAction.repeatActionForever(sequence1)\n        var repeat2 = SKAction.repeatActionForever(sequence2)\n        var repeat3 = CGRectGetMidY(self.frame))\n       background.yScale = 10.0\n        background.xScale = 10.0\n\n        addChild(background)\n\n        //running the actions\n        bar6a.runAction(repeat1)\n        bar6b.runAction(repeat1)\n        bar6c.runAction(repeat2)\n        bar6d.runAction(repeat2)\n        bar6e.runAction(repeat3)\n        bar6f.runAction(repeat3)\n        bar6g.runAction(repeat4)\n 	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Ubuntu is a free desktop and server operating system based on Debian GNU/Linux. Note that this is for programming questions specific to Ubuntu and http://askubuntu.com is dedicated to answering general Ubuntu questions.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<blockquote>\n  <p>Questions concerning Using and administering Ubuntu, running\n  third-party applications on Ubuntu, development on Ubuntu, or services\n  provided by Ubuntu may be better suited for <a href="http://askubuntu.com/">Ask\n  Ubuntu</a> rather than Stack Overflow.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<h3>Philosophy</h3>\n\n<p>The goal of the <a href="http://www.ubuntu.com/project" rel="nofollow">Ubuntu project</a> is to provide a free computer environment, centered on a Linux distribution and complemented by online services.</p>\n\n<h3>Releases</h3>\n\n<p>The core of the Ubuntu distribution contains a Gnome-based desktop environment which is tightly integrated to the system, in particular providing a GUI for hardware management and system administration. The supported core also includes other desktop environments such as KDE, although their integration is managed by side projects such as <a href="http://www.kubuntu.org/" rel="nofollow">Kubuntu</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Ubuntu includes a small amount of non-free software such as drivers. Ubuntu offers a large amount of packages directly taken from <a href="http://unix.stackexchange.com/tags/debian/info">Debian</a>\'s unstable distribution, in the form of the <a href="https://help.ubuntu.com/8.04/serverguide/C/extra-repositories.html" rel="nofollow">universe repository</a>.</p>\n\n<p>There is a release of Ubuntu every six months. One in four is a long-term support (LTS) release.</p>\n\n<h3>Derivatives</h3>\n\n<p>Side projects of Ubuntu include:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.edubuntu.org/" rel="nofollow">Edubuntu</a>: for use in teaching.</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.kubuntu.org/" rel="nofollow">Kubuntu</a>: managing the integration of KDE into Ubuntu.</li>\n<li><a href="http://mythbuntu.org/" rel="nofollow">Mythbuntu</a>: for media centers.</li>\n<li><a href="http://ubuntustudio.org/" rel="nofollow">Ubuntu Studio</a>: for multimedia production.</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.xubuntu.org/" rel="nofollow">Xubuntu</a>: managing the integration of Xfce into Ubuntu.</li>\n<li><a href="http://lubuntu.net/" rel="nofollow">Lubuntu</a>: managing the integration of LXDE into Ubuntu, focusing on speed and energy efficiency.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Documentation</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://help.ubuntu.com/" rel="nofollow">Official documentation</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://help.ubuntu.com/community" rel="nofollow">Community documentation</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+bugs" rel="nofollow">Bug reports</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://packages.ubuntu.com/" rel="nofollow">Available packages</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+ppas" rel="nofollow">Third-party package repositories</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://manpages.ubuntu.com/" rel="nofollow">Manual pages</a> (e.g. <a href="http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/lucid/man1/man.1.html" rel="nofollow">man(1) in 10.04</a>)</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.ubuntu.com/support/community" rel="nofollow">Support sources</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Common tasks</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Install a package: <code>apt-get install <em>package-name</em></code></li>\n<li>Apply updates: <code>apt-get update; apt-get upgrade</code></li>\n</ul>',
