	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Use angularJS built in date filter. Here is a working example that will make things easy:</p>\n\n<p><a href="http://plnkr.co/edit/X1k3nQdYi9K1zfP2yfR6?p=preview" rel="nofollow">http://plnkr.co/edit/X1k3nQdYi9K1zfP2yfR6?p=preview</a></p>\n\n<p>Code:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;html&gt;\n\n&lt;head&gt;\n  &lt;meta charset="UTF-8" /&gt;\n  &lt;title&gt;require moment&lt;/title&gt;\n&lt;/head&gt;\n\n&lt;body ng-app="app"&gt;\n  &lt;div ng-controller="TimeCtrl"&gt;\n    &lt;p&gt;\n      {{dayNumber}}\n      &lt;br /&gt;{{quotes[dayNumber]}}\n    &lt;/p&gt;\n  &lt;/div&gt;\n  &lt;script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/angular.js/1.3.7/angular.js"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n  &lt;script&gt;\n    angular.module("app", [])\n      .controller("TimeCtrl", function($scope, $filter) {\n        $scope.quotes = {\n          1: \'Its the first of the month\',\n          2: \'Its the second of the month\',\n          3: \'Its the third of the month\',\n          4: \'Its the fourth of the month\',\n          5: \'Its the fifth of the month\',\n          6: \'Its the sixth of the month\'\n        }\n        $scope.dayNumber = $filter(\'date\')(new Date(), \'d\');\n      });\n  &lt;/script&gt;\n&lt;/body&gt;\n\n&lt;/html&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Output is:</p>\n\n<pre><code>4 \nIts the fourth of the month\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>===========</p>\n\n<p>After adding PHP code and AngularJS:</p>\n\n<p>You should go back to using json_encode, don\'t try to do it yourself. Just remember to decode it in the javascript:</p>\n\n<pre><code>/*\nforeach($arr as $key =&gt; $value ){\n    if(++$i === $numItems) {\n        echo "$key: \'$value[quote]\' ";\n      }else{\n    echo "$key: \'$value[quote]\', ";\n    }\n}\n\necho "&lt;pre&gt;";\nvar_dump($arr);\n*/\n//var_dump($arr);\n\n# JSON-encode the response\n$json_response = json_encode($arr);\n\n// # Return the response\necho $json_response;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>And don\'t forget to decode the JSON from a string into a javascript object after it gets retrieved:</p>\n\n<pre><code>var app = angular.module(\'app\',[]);\napp.controller(\'TimeCtrl\', function($scope, $filter, $http, $timeout) {\n  $http.post(\'ajax/getQuotes.php\').success(function(data){\n      // This triggers a \'digest\', to tell the views to update.\n      $timeout(function() {\n          // Parse the JSON\n          $scope.quotes = JSON.parse(data);\n      })\n  });\n  $scope.dayNumber = $filter(\'date\')(new Date(), \'d\');\n\n   // Also, this won\'t do anything sensible\n   console.log($http);\n});\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Finally, if the result is bound to a view and you need to see it update, you should wrap your changes in a $timeout or call $rootScope.$apply, see above.</p>',

So what i get is: 3 '",
	                           u"Can you show exactly what the php file output is? Is it JSON? Is it an array on an object? You may need to decode it. Finally, you may also need to call $rootScope.$apply if it's asnychronous (run in an AJAX call)",

So for instance today we are the 3rd, so my script would call post ID 3.</p>\n\n<p>This is my app.js:</p>\n\n<pre><code>var app = angular.module(\'myApp\',[]);\napp.controller(\'quotesCtrl\', function($scope, $http) {\n  $http.post(\'ajax/getQuotes.php\').success(function(data){\n    $scope.quotes = data;\n  });\n\n});\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>UPDATE!</p>\n\n<p>Thank you Peter, I\'m almost sooo close to get this working! 2015-01-03 09:43:52+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/go/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753395/how-to-run-golang-code-directly-from-terminal-command-line)
2015-01-03 09:43:52+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/go/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Go, also called golang, is an open source programming language initially developed at Google. It is a statically-typed language with syntax loosely derived from that of C, adding automatic memory management, type safety, some dynamic-typing capabilities, additional built-in types such as variable-length arrays and key-value maps, and a large standard library.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://golang.org/" rel="nofollow">Go</a> is a general-purpose language designed with systems programming in mind. While created by Google employees, including Ken Thompson, Rob Pike and Robert Griesemer, Go is an open source project with a large contributor base outside of Google. It is aimed to be efficient both for development and execution with a focus on fast compilation and increasing the maintainability of large projects. Go was originally targeted at systems programming tasks such as building server/web applications, high throughput middle-ware and databases. Go has a growing ecosystem of libraries allowing it to be used for a wide variety of tasks such as developing end-user daemons, CLIs and desktop applications. </p>\n\n<p>Go is expressive, concise, clean, and efficient. Its first class concurrency mechanisms make it easy to write programs that get the most out of multi-core and networked machines, while its <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_type_system" rel="nofollow">structural type system</a> enables flexible and modular program construction. Go compiles quickly to <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_safe" rel="nofollow">memory safe</a> machine code yet has the convenience of garbage collection and the power of run-time reflection. It\'s a fast, statically typed, compiled language that develops like a dynamically typed, interpreted language, but performs like native code.</p>\n\n<p>There are now several Go programs deployed in production inside and outside Google, as well as being supported directly by <a href="https://developers.google.com/appengine/" rel="nofollow">Google App Engine</a>.</p>\n\n<p>On March 28, 2012, The Go team released version 1.0, along with binary distributions.</p>\n\n<p>The latest version is <a href="https://golang.org/doc/devel/release.html#go1.4" rel="nofollow">1.4</a> released on December 10, 2014.</p>\n\n<h3>Go Tutorials</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://tour.golang.org" rel="nofollow">A Tour of Go</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://golangtutorials.blogspot.com/2011/05/table-of-contents.html" rel="nofollow">Golang Tutorials</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html" rel="nofollow">Effective Go</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://play.golang.org/" rel="nofollow">Go Playground</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.golang-book.com/" rel="nofollow">An Introduction to programming in Go</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://jan.newmarch.name/go/" rel="nofollow">Network programming with Go</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://gobyexample.com/" rel="nofollow">Go by Example</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://www.learnxinyminutes.com/docs/go/" rel="nofollow">Learn X in Y minutes - Go</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://code.google.com/p/go-wiki/wiki/Style" rel="nofollow">Go Style Guide</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://gophervids.appspot.com/" rel="nofollow">GopherVids</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://golang.org/doc/asm" rel="nofollow">A Quick Guide to Go\'s Assembler</a> </li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Go Books</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0321774639" rel="nofollow">Programming in Go: Creating Applications for the 21st Century</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0321817141" rel="nofollow">The Go Programming Language Phrasebook</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/1469769166" rel="nofollow">The Way To Go: A Thorough Introduction To The Go Programming Language</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/1453636676" rel="nofollow">Go Programming</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Free Go Books</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.golang-book.com/" rel="nofollow">An Introduction to Programming in Go (online)</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://gobyexample.com/" rel="nofollow">Go by Example (online)</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://github.com/astaxie/build-web-application-with-golang/blob/master/ebook/preface.md" rel="nofollow">build web application with golang (Chinese, online)</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://github.com/astaxie/build-web-application-with-golang/blob/master/ja/ebook/preface.md" rel="nofollow">build web application with golang (Japanese, online)</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://miek.nl/posts/2014/Jun/01/learning-go/" rel="nofollow">Learning Go</a> <a href="http://www.miek.nl/downloads/Go/" rel="nofollow">Compiled PDF</a> / <a href="https://github.com/miekg/gobook" rel="nofollow">Source</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Go projects</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://code.google.com/p/go-wiki/wiki/Projects" rel="nofollow">List of projects / Libraries / Tools / Examples</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://godoc.org/" rel="nofollow">GoDoc - In any event, your incoming load balancer IP wouldn't be used for outgoing connections.</p>\n\n<p>You could assign elastic IPs to the actual instances behind the load balancer, which would then be used for outgoing requests. You get 5 free elastic ips, and I believe you can apply for more if you need them.</p>\n\n<p>Additionally if using a VPC and if your instances are in a private subnet then they will only be able to access the internet via the NAT instance(s) you setup, and you can of course assign an elastic IP to the NAT instances</p>",

2015-01-03 09:43:54+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27672570/vectorize-nested-for-loop-python> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:43:54+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27672570/vectorize-nested-for-loop-python>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Very simply, <code>numpy</code> allows for element-wise operation on its arrays without having to loop over each of its dimensions. </p>\n\n<p>So say you want to apply a simple operator on each element, e.g. <code>scalar multiplication</code> by a number <code>2</code>, then you can do either of the following:</p>\n\n<pre><code>array*2\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>or </p>\n\n<pre><code>np.multiply( array,2)\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Depending on the nature of <code>stuff</code> you are doing within your loop, you may adapt other techniques to do an elementwise operation using <code>vectorization</code>.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27672942,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27672570/vectorize-nested-for-loop-python/27672942#27672942',
	              'user_id': 3954575,
	              'vote': 1},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<ul>\n<li>Your first concern should be to see if you can carry out your calculations using numpy\'s element-wise operators.</li>\n<li>If that doesn\'t work, look at the <em>universal functions</em> (ufuncs) built into numpy.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Both of these are coded in compiled C (or Fortran) and are <em>much</em> faster than looping in Python. Additionally, your code will be shorter and easier to understand.</p>\n\n<p>Additional parameters that might improve performance are which compiler was used to compile numpy and which lineair algebra library is used (assuming your code uses linear algebra). E.g. the <a href="http://math-atlas.sourceforge.net/" rel="nofollow">ATLAS</a> are automatically tuned for the machine they are built on. Intel sells a Fortran compiler and math libraries that are supposed to be very fast on an Intel processor. IIRC, they also parallelize over all available cores.</p>\n\n<p>If your math libraries don\'t use multiple cores automatically, using the <code>multiprocessing</code> module might be an option. Assuming the problem can be parallelized, this can reduce the runtime (almost) by a factor of 1/N where N is the number of cores. Minus of course the overhead necessary to distribute the problem and gather the results.</p>\n\n<p>Alternatively, for problems that can be parallelized, you could use <a href="http://documen.tician.de/pycuda/" rel="nofollow">pyCUDA</a> with numpy if you have a NVidia video card.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27673082,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27672570/vectorize-nested-for-loop-python/27673082#27673082',
	              'user_id': 1219295,
	              'vote': 1},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>For your question to make sense to me, I think you need the code to look like this.  Otherwise you\'ll never get to even <code>i=0</code>, <code>j=1</code> until <code>list</code> is full.  I\'m moving where <code>list</code> is defined.  I can\'t imagine that it is slow as currently implemented --- list will be full very quickly, and then the for loops should be very fast.  Here is what I believe you intended.  Please clarify if this is not correct.</p>\n\n<pre><code>for i in range (0,array.shape[0]):\n    for j in range (0,array.shape[1]):\n         list = []\n         while len(list) &lt; 100:\n                print "identity", i, j\n\n                #find neighboring entry with greatest value (e.g., assume it is [i-1, j] with value 10)\n                list.append((i-1,j))\n                i = i-1\n                j = j\n         #perform operations on list\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Let\'s do some modifications.  I\'ll assume there is a function <code>get_max_nbr((i,j))</code> which returns the coordinates of the maximum neighbor.  One of the places your code is slow is that it will call get_max_nbr for the same coordinate many times.  The code below uses <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1988804/what-is-memoization-and-how-can-i-use-it-in-python">memoization</a> to get around this.</p>\n\n<pre><code>maxnbr = {}\nfor i in range(0,array.shape[0]):\n    for j in range (0,array.shape[1]):\n        list = []\n        current_loc = (i,j)\n        while len(list) &lt; 100:\n            if current_loc not in maxnbr:  #if this is our first time seeing current_loc\n                maxnbr[current_loc] = get_max_nbr(current_loc)\n            current_loc = maxnbr[current_loc]\n            list.append(current_loc)\n        #process list here                 \n</code></pre>\n\n<p>This doesn\'t successfully vectorize, but it does create the list you want, and it should be a significant improvement.  It may be that if we knew more about the list processing we might be able to find a better approach, but it\'s not clear.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27752506,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27672570/vectorize-nested-for-loop-python/27752506#27752506',
	              'user_id': 2966723,
	              'vote': 0},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>If your goal is to find the local maxima in the array, you can use <a href="http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy-0.14.0/reference/generated/scipy.ndimage.filters.maximum_filter.html" rel="nofollow"><code>scipy.ndimage.filters.maximum_filter</code></a> with a 3\xd73 window and then check for equality:</p>\n\n<pre><code>import numpy\nimport scipy\nimport scipy.ndimage\n\narr = numpy.array([[1, 1, 2, 8],\n                   [5, 5, 4, 1],\n                   [9, 5, 8, 8],\n                   [7, 3, 6, 6]])\nmaxima = zip(*(scipy.ndimage.filters.maximum_filter(arr, 3) == arr).nonzero())\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>The speed of this will depend greatly on whether you really need to use only the first 100 and how many maxima there are. If so, breaking out early will probably be faster. Refining your question with the real meat of what you are doing will help us to get a better solution, though.</p>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753427,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27672570/vectorize-nested-for-loop-python/27753427#27753427',
	              'user_id': 1648033,
	              'vote': 0}],
	 'body': u'<p>I have a numpy array that I\'m iterating through with:</p>\n\n<pre><code>    list = []\n\n    for i in range (0,array.shape[0]):\n        for j in range (0,array.shape[1]):\n             while len(list) &lt; 100:\n                    print "identity", i, j\n                    #find neighboring entry with greatest value (e.g., assume it is [i-1, j] with value 10)\n                    list.append((i-1,j))\n                    i = i-1\n                    j = j\n             #perform operations on list\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>I want to accelerate this process. It\'s very slow. </p>',
	 'comments': [u"Your code doesn't make sense, since ",
	              u' will be a number, not something you can iterate over.  Also, how to vectorize it (or whether it is possible) will depend on the "stuff" you are doing inside the loop.',
	              u'1). to use ',
	              u' loop properly, you need to form an ',
	              u' first, i.e. a ',
	              u' from the scalar ',
	              u', in order to loop over it e.g. ',
	              u'. 2). Please explain whether you are applying an operator on all the ',

2015-01-03 09:43:55+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27686302/circular-uiview-and-buttons> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:43:55+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/4399172/peter-ashwell> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:43:55+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27686302/circular-uiview-and-buttons>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>To make a round view you can alter the view\'s layer\'s <code>cornerRadius</code> property.\nFor instance, you can create a square (width == height) button somewhere, create an outlet for it in your viewController (e.g. <code>@property (weak, nonatomic) IBOutlet UIButton *bMyButton;</code>) and then set it\'s corner radius like so:</p>\n\n<pre><code>- (void)viewDidLoad {\n    [super viewDidLoad];\n    self.bMyButton.layer.cornerRadius = self.bMyButton.frame.size.height / 2;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>To make the button "float" above the tableView, I believe, you should add it as a subview of the top view (on the same level of hierarchy as the tableView).\nAnd, finally, you can "attach" a view to the bottom right corner via constraints (auto layout). You can read more about auto layout here: <a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/AutolayoutPG/Introduction/Introduction.html" rel="nofollow">Auto Layout Guide</a></p>\n\n<p>As for the shadow, I\'ve never done that, but I guess, you should take a look at other <code>layer</code> properties: <code>shadowRadius</code>, <code>shadowOffset</code>, <code>shadowOpacity</code>, etc.</p>\n\n<p>For instance:</p>\n\n<pre><code>self.bMyButton.layer.shadowRadius = self.bMyButton.frame.size.width / 2 + 5;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Note, that a UIView might not be clipped to it\'s bounds. This is the case of UIImageView, for example. If you want a round UIImageView, you\'ll also have to set <code>masksToBounds</code> to <code>YES</code>:</p>\n\n<pre><code>self.imgMyImageView.layer.masksToBounds = YES;\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27686485,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27686302/circular-uiview-and-buttons/27686485#27686485',
	              'user_id': 1856325,
	              'vote': 2},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>If you want to add <code>UIButton</code> programmatically. </p>\n\n<pre><code>//margin\nCGFloat margin = 10.f;\n//your image\nUIImage *image = [UIImage imageNamed:@"side_menu.png"];\n//create a button of custom type\nUIButton *circularBtn = [UIButton buttonWithType:UIButtonTypeCustom];\n//set background colour (if your image includes background colour then you may don\'t need this)\ncircularBtn.backgroundColor = [UIColor colorWithRed:245.f/255.f green:71.f/255.f blue:64.f/255.f alpha:1.f];\n//set your image\n[circularBtn setImage:image forState:UIControlStateNormal];\n//dynamic frame\ncircularBtn.frame = CGRectMake(self.view.frame.size.width - (image.size.width * 2.f + margin ), \nself.view.frame.size.height - (image.size.height * 2.f + margin), \n(image.size.width * 2.f), (image.size.height * 2.f));\n//add to self or any other view you want\n[self.view addSubview:circularBtn];\n//round the button\ncircularBtn.layer.cornerRadius = circularBtn.frame.size.width/2.f;\n//add the shadow\ncircularBtn.layer.shadowColor = [UIColor blackColor].CGColor;\ncircularBtn.layer.shadowOpacity = 0.7f;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>It should look like,</p>\n\n<p><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/wC3ma.png" alt="enter image description here"></p>\n\n<p>In my example, I\'d the transparent image of size 40x40 (WxH) and @2x.</p>',

Many administrative commands and system calls are reserved to root.</p>\n\n<p>Use <a href="/questions/tagged/rooted-device" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'rooted-device\'" rel="tag">rooted-device</a> if your question is not about the user, but simply about a device that has been rooted.</p>\n\n<p>Root is a system user. It is rare to log in directly as root, but rather, users who are privileged enough gain root access for one command with <code>sudo</code> <a href="/questions/tagged/sudo" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'sudo\'" rel="tag">sudo</a>, or log into a temporary root shell with <code>su</code> <a href="/questions/tagged/su" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'su\'" rel="tag">su</a>.</p>\n\n<p>In the world of <a href="/questions/tagged/android" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'android\'" rel="tag"><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/tKsDb.png" height="16" width="18" alt="" class="sponsor-tag-img">android</a> (which runs on an Linux kernel), a rooted device is one where OS protections have been disabled, allowing processes to run as root, and thus do things they would normally be prevented from doing, such as reading all files on the device.</p>\n\n<p>Not to be confused with CERN\'s ROOT framework for statistical analysis in C++, see <a href="/questions/tagged/root-framework" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'root-framework\'" rel="tag">root-framework</a>.</p>',

2015-01-03 09:43:58+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/geolocation/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753428/is-there-a-database-api-with-information-about-cities-geographical-extension)
2015-01-03 09:43:58+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/geolocation/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Geolocation is the identification of the real-world geographic location of an object, such as a cell phone or an Internet-connected computer terminal. Geolocation may refer to the practice of assessing the location, or to the actual assessed location.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Geolocation is closely related to positioning but can be distinguished from it by a greater emphasis on determining a meaningful location (e.g. a street address) rather than just a set of geographic coordinates. Specifically this involves the use of advanced RF location systems utilising, for example, Time Difference Of Arrival (TDOA) where greater specificity of location is possible. TDOA systems often utilise mapping displays or other graphical information system. This is in contrast to more traditional radio location technologies, for example Direction Finding where a line of bearing to a transmitter is achieved and not the specific location.</p>\n\n<p>In terms of the internet and computer geolocation can be performed by associating a geographic location with the Internet Protocol (IP) address, MAC address, RFID, hardware embedded article/production number, embedded software number (such as UUID, Exif/IPTC/XMP or modern steganography), invoice, Wi-Fi connection location, or device GPS coordinates, or other, perhaps self-disclosed information. Geolocation usually works by automatically looking up an IP address on a WHOIS service and retrieving the registrant\'s physical address.</p>\n\n<p>IP address geolocation data can include information such as country, region, city, postal/zip code, latitude, longitude and timezone. Deeper data sets can determine other parameters such as domain name, connection speed, ISP, language, proxies, company name, US DMA/MSA, NAICS codes, and home/business.</p>\n\n<p>The word geolocation is also used in other contexts to refer to the process of inferring the location of a tracked animal based, for instance, on the time history of sunlight brightness or the water temperature and depth measured by an instrument attached to the animal. Such instruments are commonly called archival tags or dataloggers.</p>',
	 'name': 'geolocation',
	 'qcount': 6013,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/geolocation/info'}
2015-01-03 09:43:58+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/shell/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753363/how-to-access-root-packages-through-php)
2015-01-03 09:43:58+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/shell/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>The term \'shell\' refers to a general class of text-based command interpreters most often associated with the Unix &amp; Linux operating systems.  </p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>The term \'shell\' refers to a general class of text-based command interpreters most often associated with the Unix &amp; Linux operating systems.  </p>\n\n<h3>Popular <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_shells" rel="nofollow">shells</a> to date</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bourne_shell" rel="nofollow">Bourne shell</a> and POSIX shell (sh)</li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Almquist_shell" rel="nofollow">Almquist shell</a> and Debian Almquist shell (dash)</li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korn_shell" rel="nofollow">Korn shell</a> (ksh)\n<ul>\n<li>Public Domain Korn Shell (pdksh), not developed since 1999</li>\n<li>MirBSD Korn Shell (mksh)</li>\n</ul></li>\n<li>GNU <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bash_%28Unix_shell%29" rel="nofollow">Bourne again shell</a> (bash)</li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z_shell" rel="nofollow">Z Shell</a> (zsh)</li>\n<li><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rc" rel="nofollow">rc</a> (rc)</li>\n<li>C shell family\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C_shell" rel="nofollow">csh</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tcsh" rel="nofollow">tcsh</a></li>\n</ul></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>While some of these resemble each other closely, there are often subtle differences. All of ksh93, mksh and bash are supersets of the POSIX shell, which in turn is a superset of the original Bourne Shell.  By default all of ksh93, mksh and bash support mutually incompatible extensions in syntax and behavior, but they also share some extensions (beyond what POSIX offers).  The Z Shell and rc are, by default, <strong>not</strong> compatible to the POSIX shell family.  Questions about the shell and code samples should be clear about the environment and the version of the shell. Tcsh comes originally as a design improvement to the original C shell. The tcsh shell has been widely used before bash became established shell. One major popular system implementation was the Solaris family. The shell concepts: ~, history, path expansion (globbing), directory stack and aliases all originally came from the csh.</p>\n\n<p>Some view the DOS \'cmd\' prompt as a minimal shell of sorts.  It is also possible to install Cygwin on Windows and emulate a full Unix environment with complete shell capabilities.</p>\n\n<p>In graphical user mode, terminal emulators are used to access shell. Some of the examples are  <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xterm" rel="nofollow">xterm</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GNOME_Terminal" rel="nofollow">GNOME Terminal</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_%28OS_X%29" rel="nofollow">OS X Terminal</a>.</p>\n\n<h3>Related tags</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/sh" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'sh\'" rel="tag">sh</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/ksh" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ksh\'" rel="tag">ksh</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/mksh" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'mksh\'" rel="tag">mksh</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/zsh" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'zsh\'" rel="tag">zsh</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/unix" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'unix\'" rel="tag">unix</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/bash" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'bash\'" rel="tag">bash</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/csh" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'csh\'" rel="tag">csh</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/tcsh" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'tcsh\'" rel="tag">tcsh</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/rc-shell" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'rc-shell\'" rel="tag">rc-shell</a> and <a href="/questions/tagged/rc" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'rc\'" rel="tag">rc</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/fish" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'fish\'" rel="tag">fish</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Reference</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/bashref.html" rel="nofollow">Bash Reference Manual</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_shell" rel="nofollow">Unix shell Wikipedia</a></li>\n</ul>',

A lot of software solutions are offered on the Internet that can automate these processes. In particular, some integrated development environments provide interactive access to documentation, code metadata, etc.</p>\n\n<p>See more information about language support for generation programs at <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_documentation_generators#Language_support" rel="nofollow">Comparison of documentation generators</a>.</p>',

This affords benefits in terms of function calls, memory access, parallelization and code expressiveness. Some programming languages, such as MATLAB, are optimised to give the best performance when vectorized.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Vectorization refers to a programming paradigm where the process of loop-based, scalar-oriented code is instead written using matrix and vector operations. Vectorization has the following benefits:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><p>Performance: Vectorized code has better performance regarding function calls and memory access, and as a result, often runs much faster than the corresponding code containing loops.</p></li>\n<li><p>Appearance: Vectorized code appears more like the textbook mathematical expressions, making the code more comprehensible.</p></li>\n<li><p>Less Error Prone: vectorized code is shorter than loop based code, hence there are fewer opportunities to introduce programming bugs.</p></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Some programming languages, in particular <a href="http://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/matlab_prog/vectorization.html" rel="nofollow">MATLAB</a>, are optimised to give the best performance when vectorized.  </p>',

	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>A for loop is a control structure used by many programming languages to iterate over a range. It is a way of repeating statements a number of times until the loop ends. Depending on the language this may be over a range of integers, iterators, etc.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>A for loop is an <em>entry control</em> loop. <em>Entry control</em> means that before the execution <em>enters</em> the loop, the loop\'s condition is verified. If the condition is <code>false</code> the loop body will not execute.</p>\n\n<p>The basic syntax is as follows:</p>\n\n<pre><code>for ( initialization of iteration variable ; condition ; increment/decrement )\n{\n     ...\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/For_loop" rel="nofollow">For loop on Wikipedia</a></p>\n\n<p>See also: <a href="/questions/tagged/loops" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'loops\'" rel="tag">loops</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/while-loop" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'while-loop\'" rel="tag">while-loop</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/foreach" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'foreach\'" rel="tag">foreach</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/do-while" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'do-while\'" rel="tag">do-while</a>, and <a href="/questions/tagged/do" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'do\'" rel="tag">do</a>.</p>',
	 'name': 'for-loop',
	 'qcount': 16344,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/for-loop/info'}

Successful load balancing optimizes resource use, maximizes throughput, minimizes response time, and avoids overload. Using multiple components with load balancing instead of a single component may increase reliability through redundancy. Load balancing is usually provided by dedicated software or hardware, such as a multilayer switch or a Domain Name System server Process.</p>',

2015-01-03 09:44:03+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/database/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>A database is an organized collection of data typically used to model certain situations. Use this tag if you have questions about designing a database. If it is about a particular database management system, (e.g., MySQL), please use that tag instead.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>From <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database" rel="nofollow">Wikipedia</a>:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>A database is an organized collection of data. The data is typically\n  organized to model relevant aspects of reality (for example, the\n  availability of rooms in hotels), in a way that supports processes\n  requiring this information (for example, finding a hotel with\n  vacancies).</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>A large proportion of websites and applications rely on databases. They are a crucial component of telecommunications systems, banking systems, video games, and just about any other software system or electronic device that maintains some amount of persistent information. In addition to persistence, database systems provide a number of other properties that make them exceptionally useful and convenient: reliability, efficiency, scalability, concurrency control, data abstraction, and high-level query languages. Databases are so ubiquitous and important that computer science graduates frequently cite their database class as the one most useful to them in their industry or graduate-school careers.<sup><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_manipulation_language" rel="nofollow">2</a></sup></p>\n\n<p>A <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_manipulation_language" rel="nofollow">Data Manipulation Language</a> (<a href="/questions/tagged/dml" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'dml\'" rel="tag">dml</a>) is used to affect the contents of the database. The most widely used <a href="/questions/tagged/dml" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'dml\'" rel="tag">dml</a> is <a href="/questions/tagged/sql" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'sql\'" rel="tag">sql</a>.</p>\n\n<p>The term <em>database</em> should not be confused with <em><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_management_system" rel="nofollow">Database Management System</a></em> (DBMS). A <a href="/questions/tagged/dbms" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'dbms\'" rel="tag">dbms</a> is the system software used to create and manage databases and provide users and applications with access to the database(s). A database is to a DBMS as a document is to a word processor.</p>\n\n<h3>A few notable DBMSs:</h3>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/mysql" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'mysql\'" rel="tag">mysql</a> - <a href="http://www.sqlite.org/" rel="nofollow">SQLite Website</a></li>\n<li><a href="/questions/tagged/sqlserver" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'sqlserver\'" rel="tag">sqlserver</a> - A sprite is frequently used for elements that "<em>move</em>" in a scene, like a character in a game.</p>\n\n<p>As <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sprite_%28computer_graphics%29" rel="nofollow">mentioned in Wikipedia</a>, in video games there were hardware methods for the integration of sprites and these days many 3D graphic cards offer some support for them.</p>\n\n<h2>CSS Sprites</h2>\n\n<p>In CSS a sprite means not a very small image here but a big image having a collection of small images. The proper term should be <strong>sprite sheet</strong>.</p>\n\n<p>CSS sprites are a very good way to reduce the number of HTTP requests made for image resources. Images are combined into one larger image at defined X and Y coordinates. Having assigned this generated image to relevant page elements the background-position CSS property can then be used to shift the visible area to the required component image as per requirement.</p>\n\n<p>(Previous version of this section in <a href="http://ashwaniksharma.wordpress.com/2011/11/07/css-image-sprites-a-boon-for-htmlcss-developers/" rel="nofollow">the blog of Ashwani Sharma</a>)</p>',
	 'name': 'sprites',
	 'qcount': 527,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/sprites/info'}

2015-01-03 09:44:04+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/haskell/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Haskell is an advanced functional programming language, featuring strong static typing, lazy evaluation, extensive parallelism and concurrency support, and unique abstraction capabilities.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://www.haskell.org/haskellwiki/Haskell" rel="nofollow"><strong>Haskell</strong></a> is a purely functional programming language. An open-source product of more than twenty years of cutting-edge research, it allows rapid development of robust, concise, correct software. With strong support for integration with other languages, built-in concurrency and parallelism, debuggers, profilers, rich libraries, and an active community, Haskell makes it easier to produce flexible, maintainable, high-quality software.</p>\n\n<h2>Checklist</h2>\n\n<p>To avoid answering the same questions over and over again, please check the list of interesting questions and this checklist:</p>\n\n<h3>Type-checking problems at compilation</h3>\n\n<p>While Haskell\'s type system is very powerful, its behaviour can sometimes be confusing. The more <em>explicit type signatures</em> you add, the less possibilities there are for the compiler to deduce absurd relations. Type signatures also make questions more understandable, because it\'s obvious what you want a function to do.</p>\n\n<h3>Performance issues</h3>\n\n<p>In case of performance issues, please make sure that you <em>compile</em> your code with <em>optimizations enabled</em>. Passing <code>-O2</code> to the compiler makes many performance issues go away.</p>\n\n<p>It is also important to know which version of the compiler and libraries you use. Providing those pieces of information may significantly decrease the time it takes the community to answer your question.</p>\n\n<h3>"What is function <code>foo</code> / operator <code>#$*</code>?"</h3>\n\n<p>Haskell\'s syntax is very simple, in the sense that <em>everything</em> (apart from the few <a href="http://www.haskell.org/haskellwiki/Keywords" rel="nofollow">keywords</a>) is just a library function<sup>1</sup>, including all infix operators. Those functions can easily be searched for,</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://holumbus.fh-wedel.de/hayoo/hayoo.html" rel="nofollow">Hayoo</a> searches identifiers and signatures throughout the entire Hackage database.</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.haskell.org/hoogle/?hoogle=hoogle" rel="nofollow">Hoogle</a> also searches for identifiers and signatures, but only works when the function comes from a known package.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Please try these engines first before asking a question like <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24019887/what-is-haskell-diamond-symbol#24019887">this</a> or <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2346872/what-does-the-symbol-mean-in-haskell">this</a> or <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8604801/syntax-what-does-mean-in-haskell">this</a>.</p>\n\n<h2>Getting started</h2>\n\n<ol>\n<li>Download the <a href="http://hackage.haskell.org/platform/" rel="nofollow">Haskell Platform</a> for your platform. This includes the state-of-the-art Glasgow Haskell Compiler (GHC) and common developer tools and libraries.</li>\n<li>Check out these Stack Overflow questions with links to popular websites and tutorials:\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1012573/how-to-learn-haskell">How to learn Haskell</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16918/beginners-guide-to-haskell">Beginners Guide to Haskell?</a></li>\n</ul></li>\n<li>Have fun, and ask questions!</li>\n</ol>\n\n<h2>Interesting 2015-01-03 09:44:04+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/sprite-kit/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>Sprite Kit is Apple\'s framework for creating 2D games for iOS 7+ and Mac OS X 10.9+. It\'s a 2D rendering engine combined with a physics engine.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Sprite Kit provides a graphics rendering and animation infrastructure that you can use to animate arbitrary textured images, or sprites. Sprite Kit uses a traditional rendering loop where the contents of each frame are processed before the frame is rendered.</p>\n\n<p>Sprite Kit is available on iOS (<a href="/questions/tagged/ios" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios\'" rel="tag">ios</a>) and OS X (<a href="/questions/tagged/osx" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'osx\'" rel="tag">osx</a>). It uses the graphics hardware available on the hosting device to composite 2D images at high frame rates. Sprite Kit supports many different kinds of content, including:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Untextured or textured rectangles (sprites)</li>\n<li>Text</li>\n<li>Arbitrary CGPath-based shapes</li>\n<li>Video\nSprite Kit also provides support for cropping and other special effects; you can apply these effects to all or a portion of your content. You can animate or change these elements in each frame. You can also attach physics bodies to these elements so that they properly support forces and collisions.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>Because Sprite Kit supports a rich rendering infrastructure and handles all of the low-level work to submit drawing commands to OpenGL (<a href="/questions/tagged/opengl" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'opengl\'" rel="tag">opengl</a>), you can focus your efforts on solving higher-level design problems and creating great gameplay.</p>\n\n<h2>Resources:</h2>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/documentation/GraphicsAnimation/Conceptual/SpriteKit_PG/Introduction/Introduction.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40013043" rel="nofollow">Sprite Kit Programming Guide</a></li>\n</ul>',

	 'qcount': 4038,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/sprite-kit/info'}
2015-01-03 09:44:05+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752800/can-send-function-return-0-using-bsd-socket-in-blocking-mode> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:44:05+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/4414640/gvornew43534> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:44:05+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752800/can-send-function-return-0-using-bsd-socket-in-blocking-mode>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u"<blockquote>\n  <p>When calling send function, if there is no space in socket buffer for entire message, there will be stored as much bytes as there is space and that amount will be returned. If there is no space at all, function will block until there is at least 1 byte of space available, store it and return stored amount.</p>\n  \n  <p>Are above sentences true?</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>No. There was a discussion about this some years ago on news:comp.protocols.tcp-ip where all the implementors gather, and there was a consensus that Posix requires not only that it can't return zero, it can't return less than the value of the <code>length</code> parameter, in blocking mode.</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>Is there situation when send will return 0 bytes?(Except when SNDTIMEO is set and time expires)</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>Yes, <em>if and only if</em> the <code>length</code> parameter supplied is zero.</p>\n\n<p>NB if <code>SO_SNDTIMEO</code> is set to a non-zero value and the timeout expires, <code>send()</code> won't return zero: it will return -1 with <code>errno</code> equal to <code>EAGAIN/EWOULBLOCK,</code> if no bytes were transferred.</p>",
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753068,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752800/can-send-function-return-0-using-bsd-socket-in-blocking-mode/27753068#27753068',

	              'vote': 0},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>@EJP: Thank you for this answer, I cant mark it as accepted as I dont have access to that account anymore, nor upvote on new account.</p>',

	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752800/can-send-function-return-0-using-bsd-socket-in-blocking-mode/27753424#27753424',

	              'vote': -1}],

2015-01-03 09:44:05+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748650/getting-object-reference-error-when-using-setter-injection-for-actionfilter>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u"<p>Defining <code>StructureMapFilterProvider</code> to setup property injection:</p>\n\n<pre><code>using StructureMap;\nusing System.Collections.Generic;\nusing System.Web.Mvc;\n\nnamespace DI06.CustomFilters\n{\n    public class StructureMapFilterProvider : FilterAttributeFilterProvider\n    {\n        private readonly IContainer _container;\n        public StructureMapFilterProvider(IContainer container)\n        {\n            _container = container;\n        }\n\n        public override IEnumerable&lt;Filter&gt; GetFilters(ControllerContext controllerContext, ActionDescriptor actionDescriptor)\n        {\n            var filters = base.GetFilters(controllerContext, actionDescriptor);\n            foreach (var filter in filters)\n            {\n                _container.BuildUp(filter.Instance);\n                yield return filter;\n            }\n        }\n    }\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Creating our custom StructureMap <code>Container</code>:</p>\n\n<pre><code>using System;\nusing System.Threading;\nusing DI06.Services;\nusing DI06.Services.Contracts;\nusing StructureMap;\n\nnamespace DI06.IocConfig\n{\n    public static class SmObjectFactory\n    {\n        private static readonly Lazy&lt;Container&gt; _containerBuilder =\n            new Lazy&lt;Container&gt;(defaultContainer, LazyThreadSafetyMode.ExecutionAndPublication);\n\n        public static IContainer Container\n        {\n            get { return _containerBuilder.Value; }\n        }\n\n        private static Container defaultContainer()\n        {\n            return new Container(x =&gt;\n            {\n                x.For&lt;ILogActionService&gt;().Use&lt;LogActionService&gt;();\n\n                x.Policies.SetAllProperties(y =&gt;\n                {\n                    y.OfType&lt;ILogActionService&gt;();\n                });\n            });\n        }\n    }\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>And then it's necessary to remove the old FilterAttributeFilterProvider and replace it with the new <code>StructureMapFilterProvider</code> (in <code>Application_Start</code> method):</p>\n\n<pre><code>var filterProvider = FilterProviders.Providers.Single(provider =&gt; provider is FilterAttributeFilterProvider);\nFilterProviders.Providers.Remove(filterProvider);\nFilterProviders.Providers.Add(SmObjectFactory.Container.GetInstance&lt;StructureMapFilterProvider&gt;());\n</code></pre>",
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753376,

	              'user_id': 298573,
	              'vote': 0}],

set; }\n            public IUnitOfWork Uow { get; set; }\n            public ILogActionService LogActionService { get; set; }\n\n            public IApplicationUserManager ApplicationUserManager { get; set; }\n            public LogAttribute(string desciption)\n            {\n                Description = desciption;\n            }\n\n            public override void OnActionExecuted(ActionExecutedContext filterContext)\n            {\n                //var userId = filterContext.HttpContext.User.Identity.GetUserId();\n                //var user = await ApplicationUserManager.FindByIdAsync(2);\n                var model = new LogAction(filterContext.ActionDescriptor.ActionName,\n                    filterContext.ActionDescriptor.ControllerDescriptor.ControllerName, Description);\n                LogActionService.AddLog(model);\n                Uow.SaveAllChanges();\n                base.OnActionExecuted(filterContext);\n            }\n        } \n</code></pre>\n\n<p>So, I also created custom filter provider for injecting my dependency using StructureMap:</p>\n\n<pre><code>public class StructureMapFilterProvider : FilterAttributeFilterProvider\n    {\n        private Func&lt;IContainer&gt; _container;\n\n        public StructureMapFilterProvider(Func&lt;IContainer&gt; container)\n        {\n            _container = container;\n        }\n\n        public override IEnumerable&lt;Filter&gt; GetFilters(ControllerContext controllerContext, ActionDescriptor actionDescriptor)\n        {\n            var filters = base.GetFilters(controllerContext, actionDescriptor);\n            var container = _container();\n            foreach (var filter in filters)\n            {\n                container.BuildUp(filter.Instance);\n                yield return filter;\n            }\n        }\n    }\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Then I\'ve registered that in Global.asax:</p>\n\n<pre><code>cfg.For&lt;IFilterProvider&gt;().Use(new StructureMapFilterProvider(() =&gt;  SmObjectFactory.Container));\n                cfg.Policies.SetAllProperties(x =&gt; x.Matching(p =&gt; p.DeclaringType.CanBeCastTo(typeof(ActionFilterAttribute)) &amp;&amp;\n                    p.DeclaringType.Namespace.StartsWith("MyNamespace") &amp;&amp; \n                    !p.PropertyType.IsPrimitive &amp;&amp;\n                    p.PropertyType != typeof(string)));\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Everything should be ok, But when I decorate my action method with Log attribute, I get <strong>Object reference not set to an instance of an object.</strong> I set break point in OnActionExecuted it tells that LogActionService is null:</p>\n\n<pre><code>public override void OnActionExecuted(ActionExecutedContext filterContext)\n{\n            //var userId = filterContext.HttpContext.User.Identity.GetUserId();\n            //var user = await ApplicationUserManager.FindByIdAsync(2);\n            var model = new LogAction(filterContext.ActionDescriptor.ActionName,\n                filterContext.ActionDescriptor.ControllerDescriptor.ControllerName, Description);\n            LogActionService.AddLog(model);\n            Uow.SaveAllChanges();\n            base.OnActionExecuted(filterContext);\n} \n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Any idea? Thanks in advanced.</p>',

2015-01-03 09:44:06+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753241/form-doesnt-resize-properly-in-bootstrap-when-fully-stacked> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:44:06+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/users/3317291/knitevision> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:44:06+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753241/form-doesnt-resize-properly-in-bootstrap-when-fully-stacked>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>The problem is in your <code>float: right</code> property. The column has 50% width and floats to right, leading to it "doesn\'t resize properly". It is fine above 768px, but below 768px the bootstrap\'s "mobile first" principle takes action and all the columns become <code>auto-width</code>. Above 768px width it had 50% width (your <code>col-sm-6</code>) but below it all collapses leading to ugly display.</p>\n\n<p>You want a media query to make it look fine below 768px:</p>\n\n<p><a href="http://jsfiddle.net/52VtD/9806/" rel="nofollow"><strong>JSFiddle demo</strong></a></p>\n\n<p>I added:</p>\n\n<p><strong>HTML</strong></p>\n\n<p><code>col-sm-6 email-form</code> instead of <code>col-sm-6 pull-right</code>.</p>\n\n<p><strong>CSS</strong> </p>\n\n<pre><code>.email-form {\n    float: right; /* Floats right when width &gt; 768px */\n}\n\n@media screen and (max-width: 768px) {\n    .email-form {\n        float: none; /* Doesn\'t float when width &lt; 768px */\n    }\n}\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [u'Thanks, but the form does still not fill the width as with the text divs when they are stacked and narrow. Can you amend?',
	                           u'@Svea ',
	                           u'Thank you knitevision.'],
	              'extid': 27753330,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753241/form-doesnt-resize-properly-in-bootstrap-when-fully-stacked/27753330#27753330',
	              'user_id': 3317291,
	              'vote': 1},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>try this,</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;div class="col-sm-6 pull-right"&gt;/*remove class pull-right*/\n             &lt;h3&gt;2&lt;/h3&gt;\n\n            &lt;form id="contactform" method="post" class="form-horizontal" action=""&gt;\n                &lt;div class="form-group"&gt;\n                    &lt;label class="control-label"&gt;Email&lt;/label&gt;\n                    &lt;input type="text" class="form-control" name="name" id="name" placeholder="Type in your email"&gt;\n                &lt;/div&gt;\n            &lt;/form&gt;\n        &lt;/div&gt;\n</code></pre>',

	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>Try to use <code>parseFloat()</code> instead of <code>parseInt()</code></p>\n\n<p>Also use <code>&lt;script type="text/javascript"&gt;</code> instead of <code>&lt;script language="javascript"&gt;</code> that will be more standard and correct</p>',

	              'vote': 3},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u"<p>parseInt will convert any decimal to an integer so <code>parseInt(1.5)</code> becomes <code>1</code>. That is why parseInt(1.5) + parseInt(1.5) + parseInt(1.5) = 3. If you want it to equal 4.5 then just replace parseInt with parseFloat:</p>\n\n<pre><code>function AddInputs()\n{\n  var total = 0;\n  var coll = document.getElementsByClassName('add')\n  for ( var i = 0; i&lt;coll.length; i++)\n  {\n    var ele = coll[i];\n    total += parseFloat(ele.value);\n  }\n  var Display = document.getElementById('Display');\n  Display.innerHTML = total;\n}\n</code></pre>",
	              'comments': [],
	              'extid': 27753421,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27753382/calculate-parseint-with-decimal/27753421#27753421',
	              'user_id': 2326610,
	              'vote': 1},
	             {'accept': False,
	              'body': u"<p>When you call <code>parseInt</code> on 1.50 you're getting the integer part of that value (1 in this case). Just replace <code>parseInt</code> with <code>parseFloat</code> and you'll get the value you expect.</p>",

What is the purpose of it? Can\'t the same be done with const vectors? What is the difference of the two programs below?</p>\n\n<p>Using initializer list:</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include &lt;iostream&gt;\n\nusing namespace std;\n\nint sumL(initializer_list&lt;int&gt; l){\n    int sum = 0;\n    for (const auto i: l){\n        sum += i;\n    }\n    return sum;\n}\n\nint main(){\n\n    cout &lt;&lt; sumL({1, 2, 3}) &lt;&lt; "\\n";\n\n    return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Using const vector:</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include &lt;iostream&gt;\n#include &lt;vector&gt;\n\nusing namespace std;\n\nint sumV(const vector&lt;int&gt; l){\n    int sum = 0;\n    for (const auto i: l){\n        sum += i;\n    }\n    return sum;\n}\n\nint main(){\n\n    cout &lt;&lt; sumV({1, 2, 3}) &lt;&lt; "\\n";\n\n    return 0;\n}\n</code></pre>',

2015-01-03 09:44:09+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752771/combine-different-angular-programs> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions?page=2&sort=active)
2015-01-03 09:44:09+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752771/combine-different-angular-programs>
	{'answers': [{'accept': False,
	              'body': u'<p>First, let\'s assume you have included the files</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;script src="//ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/angularjs/1.2.14/angular.min.js"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n&lt;script src="//oblador.github.io/angular-scroll/0.6.2/angular-scroll.min.js"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n&lt;script src="//oblador.github.io/angular-parallax/angular-parallax.min.js"&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Next, you must include it in your module, with:</p>\n\n<pre><code>angular.module(\'myApp\', [\'duParallax\'])\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Next, inject <code>parallaxHelper</code> in your controller (see <a href="https://docs.angularjs.org/guide/di" rel="nofollow">Angular Dependency Injection</a>), and use <code>parallaxHelper.createAnimator(transition)</code>:</p>\n\n<pre><code>.controller(\'MyCtrl\', function($scope, parallaxHelper){\n    $scope.background = parallaxHelper.createAnimator(-0.3);\n  }\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Finally, insert in your html the points you want to apply parallax, using the respective scope vars that you have used in the controller. In the previous case:</p>\n\n<pre><code>&lt;section ng-controller="MyCtrl"&gt;\n  &lt;img src="img.png" du-parallax y="background" alt="" /&gt;\n&lt;/section&gt;\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>That should be all! Source: <a href="https://github.com/oblador/angular-parallax" rel="nofollow">Quick start guide</a> </p>',

2015-01-03 09:44:09+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/winsock/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27752800/can-send-function-return-0-using-bsd-socket-in-blocking-mode)
2015-01-03 09:44:09+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/winsock/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>In computing, the Windows Sockets API (WSA), which was later shortened to Winsock, is a technical specification that defines how Windows network software should access network services, especially TCP/IP.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>It defines a standard interface between a Windows TCP/IP client application (such as an FTP client or a web browser) and the underlying TCP/IP protocol stack. The nomenclature is based on the Berkeley sockets API model used in BSD for communications between programs. Initially, all the participating developers resisted the shortening of the name to Winsock for a long time, since there was much confusion among users between the API and the DLL library file (winsock.dll) which only exposed the common WSA interfaces to applications above it. Users would commonly believe that only making sure the DLL file was present on a system would provide full TCP/IP protocol support.</p>\n\n<p>The Windows Sockets API specification defines two interfaces: the API used by application developers, and the SPI, which provides a means for network software developers to add new protocol modules to the system. Each interface represents a contract. The API guarantees that a conforming application will function correctly with a conformant protocol implementation from any network software vendor. The SPI contract guarantees that a conforming protocol module may be added to Windows and will thereby be usable by an API-conformant application. Although these contracts were important when Windows Sockets was first released, as network environments required multi-protocol support (see above) they are now of only academic interest. Included in the Windows Sockets API version 2.0 are functions to use IPX/SPX, but no commercial application is known to exist which utilises this transport, since the protocol was all but obsolete already at the time WSA 2.0 shipped. Microsoft has shipped the TCP/IP protocol stack with all recent versions of Windows, and there are no significant independent alternatives. Nor has there been significant interest in implementing protocols other than the TCP/IP family (includes UDP and RTSP), IrDA, and Bluetooth.</p>\n\n<p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winsock" rel="nofollow">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winsock</a></p>',
	 'name': 'winsock',
	 'qcount': 1427,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/winsock/info'}

This tag is designated for software related interfacing with networking protocols. Typically, the term is not associated with interfacing with the hardware, but basic knowledge of how the hardware processes network packets can be crucial in debugging connectivity problems.</p>',

2015-01-03 09:44:11+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Crawled (200) <GET http://stackoverflow.com/tags/asp.net-mvc/info> (referer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27748650/getting-object-reference-error-when-using-setter-injection-for-actionfilter)
2015-01-03 09:44:11+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/asp.net-mvc/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>The ASP.NET MVC Framework is an open source web application framework and tooling that implements a version of the model-view-controller (MVC) pattern tailored towards web applications and built upon an ASP.NET technology foundation.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>The Microsoft <a href="http://www.asp.net/mvc" rel="nofollow">ASP.NET MVC Framework</a> is an <a href="http://aspnetwebstack.codeplex.com/" rel="nofollow">open source</a> web application framework and tooling that implements a version of the model-view-controller (MVC) pattern tailored towards web applications.</p>\n\n<p>The ASP.NET MVC framework provides an alternative to the ASP.NET WebForms Framework for creating Web applications, and is a more lightweight and testable framework than its WebForms cousin, even though they are both built upon the same base ASP.NET foundation.  It uses existing ASP.NET features, and in more recent versions has become more unified with WebForms via Microsoft\'s <code>One ASP.NET</code> initiative.  The MVC framework is defined in the System.Web.Mvc assembly.</p>\n\n<p>ASP.NET MVC releases also tend to package additional technologies, such as the Razor View Engine, Web Optimization Framework, ASP.NET WebAPI, along with tooling such as Scaffolding, and integration into Visual Studio.</p>\n\n<p>The Model-View-Controller architectural pattern, upon which ASP.NET MVC is based separates an application into three main components: the model, the view, and the controller. The reason for this separation is to provide a cleaner overall architecture, while improving maintainability.  This concept is often referred to as a <code>Seperation of Concerns</code>.  </p>\n\n<p>A model represents the state of a particular aspect of the application. Frequently, a model maps to a database table with the entries in the table representing the state of the application. A controller handles interactions and updates the model to reflect a change in state of the application, and then passes information to the view. A view accepts necessary information from the controller and renders a user interface to display that.</p>\n\n<p>Since the ASP.NET MVC 4 release, Microsoft has shipped the framework both with a specific release of Visual Studio, as well as via the <a href="http://nuget.codeplex.com/" rel="nofollow">Nuget</a> package management system.  This package management method allows for easier "out of band" releases (versions not tied to a specific version of Visual Studio), along with a more module release so that sub-components can be chosen to be included or not (ASP.NET WebApi for example).</p>\n\n<p>The latest announcements from Microsoft regarding ASP.NET MVC usually come from the <a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/b/webdev/" rel="nofollow">.NET Web Development and Tools Blog</a>, <a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/b/visualstudio/" rel="nofollow">Visual Studio Blog</a> or <a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/b/dotnet/" rel="nofollow">.NET Framework Blog</a>. Other notable blogs relating to MVC are <a href="http://weblogs.asp.net/scottgu/" rel="nofollow">Scott Guthrie\'s Blog</a>, <a href="http://hanselman.com" rel="nofollow">ASP.NET by Scott Hanselman</a>, and <a href="http://weblogs.asp.net/imranbaloch" rel="nofollow">Imran Baloch\'s Blog</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Unless you have a good reason not to, try to keep your MVC version current.  There are bug fixes in newer versions, as well as new features.  It makes little sense to create new projects using older versions of MVC today.  The first thing you should do after creating a new project is open up the NuGet package manager and apply all updates (with the possible exception of jQuery 2.x.  If you need compatibility with older browsers stay with the latest version jQuery 1.x, which is feature compatible with the 2.x line)</p>\n\n<p><strong>Versions shipped with Visual Studio</strong></p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Visual Studio 2008 - None (MVC was released after 2008 was)</li>\n<li>Visual Studio 2010 - ASP.NET MVC 2 (no point releases)</li>\n<li>Visual Studio 2012 - ASP.NET MVC 5.0.0</li>\n<li>Visual Studio 2013 - ASP.NET MVC 5.1.0</li>\n<li>Visual Studio 2015 (aka "14") - ASP.NET MVC 6.x (Preview Release)</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>** Requirements by version</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>MVC 1 - Visual Studio 2008 - CLR 2.0</li>\n<li>MVC 2 - Visual Studio 2008 - CLR 2.0</li>\n<li>MVC 3 - Visual Studio 2010 - CLR 4.0 - Framework 4.0</li>\n<li>MVC 4 - Visual Studio 2010 - CLR 4.0 - Framework 4.0</li>\n<li>MVC 5.x - Visual Studio 2012 - CLR 4.0 - Framework 4.5</li>\n<li>MVC 6.x - Visual Studio 2015 (aka "14") - (Preview release) </li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>Current Releases:</strong> (Available through NuGet)</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.AspNet.Mvc/5.2.2" rel="nofollow">Stable release 5.2.2</a> (August 28, 2014)</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.asp.net/vnext/overview/aspnet-vnext/overview" rel="nofollow">Beta Release 6.0.0-beta1</a> (November 11, 2014)</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>References</strong>:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://www.asp.net/mvc/tutorials/mvc-5/introduction/getting-started" rel="nofollow">Getting Started with ASP.NET MVC 5</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://weblogs.asp.net/scottgu/archive/2009/03/10/free-asp-net-mvc-ebook-tutorial.aspx" rel="nofollow">NerdDinner Walkthrough</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASP.NET_MVC_Framework" rel="nofollow">ASP.NET MVC Framework</a> Wikipedia Article</li>\n<li><a href="https://aspnetwebstack.codeplex.com/" rel="nofollow">ASP.NET Source Code Stack</a>  (including MVC)</li>\n<li><a href="http://www.dotnetfoundation.org/prjaspnetvnext.aspx" rel="nofollow">ASP.NET vNext Source Code</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<h3>Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)</h3>\n\n<p>Please note that most questions that may refer to a specific version of MVC, will likely apply to newer versions as well. Use "twitter-bootstrap" and NOT "bootstrap" to ask a question about this framework.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><a href="http://getbootstrap.com/" rel="nofollow">Bootstrap</a> is a front-end framework from Twitter designed to kickstart the front-end development of webapps and sites. Among other things, it includes base CSS and HTML for typography, icons, forms, buttons, tables, layout grids, and navigation, along with custom-built jQuery plugins and support for responsive layouts.</p>\n\n<p>There are two major versions of the framework:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li><a href="http://getbootstrap.com/2.3.2/" rel="nofollow">Bootstrap 2.3.2</a> - <a href="/questions/tagged/twitter-bootstrap-2" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'twitter-bootstrap-2\'" rel="tag">twitter-bootstrap-2</a></li>\n<li><a href="http://getbootstrap.com/getting-started/" rel="nofollow">Bootstrap 3</a> - <a href="/questions/tagged/twitter-bootstrap-3" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'twitter-bootstrap-3\'" rel="tag">twitter-bootstrap-3</a></li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>It is tested and supported in the major modern browsers, such as <a href="http://getbootstrap.com/getting-started/#support" rel="nofollow">the latest versions of Safari, Google Chrome, Firefox, and Internet Explorer 8+</a>.</p>\n\n<p>Starting with version 2.0, the default download package contains cumulative JavaScript and CSS files. This often refers to a process flow over a network connection, but by no means is limited to such.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>In computer networking, a socket is an endpoint of a bidirectional inter-process communication flow across an Internet Protocol-based computer network, such as the Internet.</p>\n\n<p>An internet socket address is the combination of an IP address (the location of the computer) and a port (which is mapped to the application program process) into a single identity, much like one end of a telephone connection is the combination of a phone number and a particular extension.</p>\n\n<p>An example IPv4 socket appears as: <code>10.1.1.1:80</code></p>\n\n<p>An example IPv6 socket appears as: <code>[fe80::1]:80</code> (Note the brackets)</p>\n\n<p>The term is believed to have originated with the Berkeley Sockets API for Unix ca. 1983.</p>\n\n<p>Related tags are <a href="/questions/tagged/network-programming" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'network-programming\'" rel="tag">network-programming</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/network-protocols" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'network-protocols\'" rel="tag">network-protocols</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/udp" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'udp\'" rel="tag">udp</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/tcp" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'tcp\'" rel="tag">tcp</a> and <a href="/questions/tagged/client-server" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'client-server\'" rel="tag">client-server</a>.</p>',

2015-01-03 09:44:13+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/parseint/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>parseInt is a function that returns the integer representation of a given string.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p><code>parseInt</code> is a function that returns the integer representation of a given string. It requires one parameter, but usually it can accept two parameters:</p>\n\n<pre><code>parseInt(toParse)\nparseInt(toParse, radix)\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Where <code>toParse</code> is a string, and <code>radix</code> is an integer. When the one-parameter function is called, a radix of <code>10</code> is used for the conversion.</p>\n\n<p>In <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/javascript/info">Javascript</a> the syntax is <code>parseInt(toParse, radix)</code>\nExamples of use with :</p>\n\n<pre><code>document.write(parseInt("10") + "&lt;br&gt;");\ndocument.write(parseInt("82", 16) + "&lt;br&gt;");\ndocument.write(parseInt("11.25") + "&lt;br&gt;");\ndocument.write(parseInt("23 11 55 32") + "&lt;br&gt;");\ndocument.write(parseInt(" 7 ") + "&lt;br&gt;");\ndocument.write(parseInt("45 programmers") + "&lt;br&gt;");\ndocument.write(parseInt("I am 23") + "&lt;br&gt;");\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Output:</p>\n\n<pre><code>10\n130\n11\n23\n7\n45\nNaN\n</code></pre>\n\n<hr>\n\n<p>In <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/tags/java/info">Java</a> the syntax is <code>Integer.parseInt(toParse, radix)</code>. Unlike javascript, with java you have to be sure that you try to parse an integer. Parsing <code>11.25</code>, <code>23 11 55 32</code> or <code>45 programmers</code> will fire a <code>NumberFormatException</code>.</p>\n\n<p>Examples:</p>\n\n<pre><code>System.out.println(Integer.parseInt("10"));\nSystem.out.println(Integer.parseInt("82", 16));\nSystem.out.println(Integer.parseInt("11.25"));\nSystem.out.println(Integer.parseInt("23 11 55 32"));\nSystem.out.println(Integer.parseInt(" 7 "));\nSystem.out.println(Integer.parseInt("45 programmers"));\nSystem.out.println(Integer.parseInt("I am 23"));\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Output:</p>\n\n<pre><code>10\n130\nException in thread "main" java.lang.NumberFormatException: For input string: "11.25"\n</code></pre>',
	 'name': 'parseint',
	 'qcount': 316,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/parseint/info'}

It\'s a common practice in statically-typed languages.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>Initialization deals with the task of initializing the contents of data structures.\nInitialization can help improve performance. For example,  for and while loops that incrementally increase the size of a data structure each time through the loop can adversely affect performance and memory use. Repeatedly resizing arrays often spend extra time looking for larger contiguous blocks of memory, and then moving the array into those blocks. Using initialization can improve code execution time by preallocating the maximum amount of space required for the array.</p>',

Permission are employed in several systems, such as file systems, DBMS, apps (iOS, Android, Windows Store, ...) and claims-based identity.</p>\n\n<p>From a programming perspective, we are not interested in how to assign permissions in a particular context (i.e. in a company) but in how these are implemented (which permissions are implemented, in which way we combine them, how they impact performance, ...).</p>\n\n<p>This tag should be used:</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>for questions about how permissions work in a particular systems;</li>\n<li>for scenarios/problems that involves permissions in a substantial way.</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p>This tag should not be used for asking about the specific permissions that should be assigned in a particular scenario.</p>\n\n<p>Related tags: <a href="/questions/tagged/filesystem" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'filesystem\'" rel="tag">filesystem</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/database" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'database\'" rel="tag">database</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/android" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'android\'" rel="tag"><img src="http://i.stack.imgur.com/tKsDb.png" height="16" width="18" alt="" class="sponsor-tag-img">android</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/ios" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'ios\'" rel="tag">ios</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/windows-store-apps" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'windows-store-apps\'" rel="tag">windows-store-apps</a>, <a href="/questions/tagged/claims-based-identity" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged \'claims-based-identity\'" rel="tag">claims-based-identity</a> </p>',

2015-01-03 09:44:17+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/tags/constructor/info>
	{'descr': u'<div class="welovestackoverflow" id="wiki-excerpt" style="display:none">\r\n                <p>A special type of subroutine called at the creation of an object.</p>\r\n            </div>\r\n<p>In object-oriented programming, a constructor (sometimes shortened to ctor) in a class is a special type of subroutine called at the creation of an object. It prepares the new object for use, often accepting parameters which the constructor uses to set any member variables required when the object is first created.</p>\n\n<p>Most languages allow overloading the constructor in that there can be more than one constructor for a class, with differing parameters. Some languages take consideration of some special types of constructors. These include;</p>\n\n<ul>\n<li>Default constructors</li>\n<li>Copy constructors</li>\n<li>Conversion constructors</li>\n<li>Move constructors</li>\n</ul>\n\n<p><strong>Default constructors</strong></p>\n\n<p>If the programmer does not supply a constructor for an instantiable class, most languages will provide a default constructor. The behaviour of the default constructor is language dependent. It may initialize data members to zero or other sane values, or it may do nothing at all. In C++ a default constructor is required if an array of class objects is to be created. Other languages (Java, C#, VB .NET) have no such restriction.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Copy constructors</strong></p>\n\n<p>Copy constructors define the actions performed by the compiler when copying class objects. A copy constructor generally has one formal parameter (others may be defaulted) that is the type of the class (the parameter may be a reference to an object). It is used to create a copy of an existing object of the same class. Even though both classes are the same, it counts as a conversion constructor.</p>\n\n<p><strong>Conversion constructors</strong></p>\n\n<p>Conversion constructors provide a means for a compiler to create an object belonging to one class based on an object of a different type. These constructors are usually invoked implicitly to convert arguments or operands to an appropriate type, but they may also be called explicitly (usually via an explicit cast operation).</p>\n\n<p><strong>Move constructors</strong></p>\n\n<p>In C++, move constructors take an rvalue reference to an object of the class, and are used to implement ownership transfer of the object\'s resources (moving the resources from the current object to the one being constructed).</p>',
	 'name': 'constructor',
	 'qcount': 8934,
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/tags/constructor/info'}

As such, it can be used as a constant in places where otherwise it couldn\'t be.</p>\r\n            </div>',
