2015-01-03 09:44:22+0000 [stackoverflow] DEBUG: Scraped from <200 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13461027/why-does-the-standard-differentiate-between-direct-list-initialization-and-copy>
	{'answers': [{'accept': True,
	              'body': u'<p>Because they <em>don\'t</em> do the exact same thing. As stated in 13.3.1.7 [over.match.list]:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>In copy-list-initialization, if an explicit constructor is chosen, the initialization is ill-formed.</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>In short, you can only use implicit conversion in copy-list-initialization contexts.</p>\n\n<p>This was explicitly added to make uniform initialization not, um, uniform. Yeah, I know how stupid that sounds, but bear with me.</p>\n\n<p>In 2008, <a href="http://www.open-std.org/JTC1/SC22/WG21/docs/papers/2008/n2640.pdf">N2640 was published (PDF)</a>, taking a look at the current state of uniform initialization. It looked specifically at the difference between direct initialization (<code>T{...}</code>) and copy-initialization (<code>T = {...}</code>).</p>\n\n<p>To summarize, the concern was that <code>explicit</code> constructors would effectively become pointless. If I have some type <code>T</code> that I want to be able to be constructed from an integer, but I don\'t want implicit conversion, I label the constructor explicit.</p>\n\n<p>Then somebody does this:</p>\n\n<pre><code>T func()\n{\n  return {1};\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Without the current wording, this will call my <code>explicit</code> constructor. So what good is it to make the constructor <code>explicit</code> if it doesn\'t change much?</p>\n\n<p>With the current wording, you need to at least use the name directly:</p>\n\n<pre><code>T func()\n{\n  return T{1};\n}\n</code></pre>',
	              'comments': [u"I should've known this, since I constantly complain about ",
	                           u' and ',
	                           u's constructor being ',
	                           u" so I can't do ",
	                           u'. :)',
	                           u'Well, since uniform initialization doesn\'t work uniformly on all types, I think the phrase "make uniform initialization not, um, uniform" is actually void. Eg. in snippet ',
	                           u', ',
	                           u' is a copy of ',
	                           u' for all copyable types ',
	                           u" those that have at least one list-constructor from any type (for those types, it usually doesn't compile). So in templates, you have to resort back to old C++03 initialization if you want to copy or convert.",
	                           u"@jpalecek: That's not true. The ",
	                           u' constructor will ',
	                           u' be used if the given braced-init-list is of the same type as the constructor. Therefore, it would only be called if ',
	                           u' had a ',
	                           u" constructor, which is rather unlikely. And even if it did, wouldn't it just... copy the member(s)? I'm not sure what it is you're concerned about here. The concern is usually for things like ",
	                           u', where the constructor that takes a size_t conflicts with the initailizer_list constructor.',
	                           u'@jpalecek I believe that is a gcc4.5.1 bug, as ',
	                           u' compiles on 4.7.0. ',
	                           u' is being initialized via the (compiler generated) copy constructor, and the constructor taking ',
	                           u' is not selected, even though it is preferred, because the member(s) of the braced-init-list are not convertible to ',
	                           u'. As Nicol says in the earlier comment, if there existed a ',
	                           u' constructor, that would be selected over the copy constructor.',
	                           u'@jpalecek: From section 13.3.1.7, p1: ',
	                           u" So you must be looking at an old version of the standard (I couldn't find that statement anywhere)."],
	              'extid': 13461382,
	              'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13461027/why-does-the-standard-differentiate-between-direct-list-initialization-and-copy/13461382#13461382',
	              'user_id': 734069,
	              'vote': 17}],
	 'body': u"<p>We know that <code>T v(x);</code> is called <em>direct-initialization</em>, while <code>T v = x;</code> is called <em>copy-initialization</em>, meaning that it will construct a temporary <code>T</code> from <code>x</code> that will get copied / moved into <code>v</code> (which is most likely elided).</p>\n\n<p>For list-initialization, the standard differentiates between two forms, depending on the context. <code>T v{x};</code> is called <em>direct-list-initialization</em> while <code>T v = {x};</code> is called <em>copy-list-initialization</em>:</p>\n\n<p><code>\xa78.5.4 [dcl.init.list] p1</code></p>\n\n<blockquote>\n  <p>[...] List-initialization can occur in direct-initialization or copy-initialization\n  contexts; list-initialization in a direct-initialization context is called <em>direct-list-initialization</em> and list-initialization in a copy-initialization context is called <em>copy-list-initialization</em>. [...]</p>\n</blockquote>\n\n<p>However, there are only two more references each in the whole standard. For direct-list-initialization, it's mentioned when creating temporaries like <code>T{x}</code> (<code>\xa75.2.3/3</code>). For copy-list-initialization, it's for the expression in return statements like <code>return {x};</code> (<code>\xa76.6.3/2</code>).</p>\n\n<p>Now, what about the following snippet?</p>\n\n<pre><code>#include &lt;initializer_list&gt;\n\nstruct X{\n  X(X const&amp;) = delete; // no copy\n  X(X&amp;&amp;) = delete // no move\n  X(std::initializer_list&lt;int&gt;){} // only list-init from 'int's\n};\n\nint main(){\n  X x = {42};\n}\n</code></pre>\n\n<p>Normally, from the <code>X x = expr;</code> pattern, we expect the code to fail to compile, because the move constructor of <code>X</code> is defined as <code>delete</code>d. However, the latest versions of Clang and GCC compile the above code just fine, and after digging a bit (and finding the above quote), that seems to be correct behaviour. The standard only ever defines the behaviour for the whole of list-initialization, and doesn't differentiate between the two forms at all except for the above mentioned points. Well, atleast as far as I can see, anyways.</p>\n\n<p>So, to summarize my question again:</p>\n\n<p><strong>What is the use of splitting list-initialization into its two forms if they (apparently) do the exact same thing?</strong></p>",
	 'comments': [u'If you made that third constructor ',
	              u', would it stop working?',
	              u'The difference between direct-initialization and copy-initialization is defined 8.5 #16. The direct-initialization considers only constructors, whereas copy-initialization considers user-defined conversion sequences. Thus making the ctor explicit will result in a compiler error.'],
	 'extid': 13461027,
	 'tags': [u'c++', u'c++11', u'language-lawyer', u'list-initialization'],
	 'title': u'Why does the standard differentiate between direct-list-initialization and copy-list-initialization?',
	 'url': 'http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13461027/why-does-the-standard-differentiate-between-direct-list-initialization-and-copy',
	 'user_id': 500104,
	 'vote': 20}
